column7: Restoration since the 2015 earthquake is phenomenal.
column8: Severely damaged in the April 2015 earthquake, the restoration since has been phenomenal; much of the original doors, windows, wood carvings and brick work have been put back into place, only replaced by very high quality new work when necessary. This was the palace of the Malla kings of Patan, originally built in 1734 AD by displacing Ha Bāhā, though it has been rebuilt several times since (it was leveled in the massive 1934 AD earthquake, for example). The collection continues to expand, too, as (sadly) other historic structures of Patan are rebuilt without preserving their centuries-old carvings but at least letting the museum display them. There are occasional dances and musical events in the courtyard, and the impressively re-established annual Tantric-inspired Kartik Naach is performed in the fall outside the museum. Guide not necessary but many people apparently miss the second, separate entrance and even fewer visit the pond behind the palace.
Ancient city museums has old king traditions and weapons, uniforms. Very informative and good things to know

I like this museum a lot... It is an new, tastefully done addition tho the Old Patan Palace. Lots of old artworks and a very nice layout. Has a garden restaurant out back and is nice part of visiting Patan Durbar Square.
...so make sure to search the whole area else you may miss something. The gardens aren’t really that impressive but the buildings really are: ornate carvings, secluded courtyards and secret views.
Excellent collection of brass and panchloha metal exhibited. Nicely arranged with lot of information. There are people around give some background history.

The entrance fee of NPR1,000 to Patan Durbar Square is inclusive of the Patan Museum. The museum is not huge, but there are good collections such as Hindu and Buddhist Lords, with narration of the religious history in the country, particularly in Patan. Toilet facility available and there is a cafe within the compound of the museum. Good to visit the museum first before going around visiting the architecture at the Durbar Square. There are tour guides around who provides good explanations about the history, culture and architecture at a cost of NPR1,000.

This beautiful building houses a nice collection of budha imagery and very informative descriptions, a good collection of musical instruments and an exhibition of antique photographs and pictures of the durbar

column7: Good place to visit - if you like History & Hindu Sculptures
column8: This was once Royal Palace, now a museum, maintained by Nepal Tourism. They are doing a pretty good job of maintaining the site. This has lots of Hindu Sculptures - look for a guide who would explain you some of the sculptures. You would even be able to see the Hindu epic Mahabharath carved in sculptures, not easy to spot without a guide. Also, visit the ancient bath tub surrounded by sculptures etc. Overall, it might take above 2 hours to visit all the places. Entrance ticket is very reasonably priced for visitors. It is certainly worth a visit.
One of the few museums were you can really learn about local history and culture. Not too long, maybe 30-40 minutes.

column7: An insight into Nepali history and culture
column8: Very interesting museum and complex. Very old and lots of stairs. Lots of temples and palaces and intricate models of Ganesh, Shiva, Buddha etc.  Well worth a visit.

Guided tour from Urban Adventures to see all the ancient sites and temples of those two great cities close to Kathmandu. Guide Satya Kumal was a great host, knowledgeable, patient and good company. A great way to see these sites as it was well organised.

column7: Mini tour of the history and culture of Nepal
column8: The small ancient town of Pathan with its various temples and palaces provides an excellent opportunity to learn about the history and culture of Nepal. There are several temples undergoing renovation. There are lso many shops selling Nepali souvenirs. Several local restaurants are also available. Plan to spend at least 4 the 5 hours in the entire Durham complex.

We entered Patan Museum , through its Sun Dhoka , a finely engraved and gilded gateway constructed in 1734 , facing one of the most beautiful squares in the world and renovated by His Majesty's Government of Nepal and the Austrian Government , at 1015 on 5th November , 2018 . The Sun Dhoka was topped by a beautiful , golden pediment . At the apex of the pediment was a huge Kirtimukha holding his two long fangs with his two hands coming out through his majestic mane . Below the Kirtimukh was the family of Lord Panchmukhi Shiv with his console Parvati and sons Ganesh and Skand . This family was flanked by Makar torana , ( floral-reptile motifs )with two celestial makars depicted as one third terrestrial animal ( trunk of elephant ) in the frontal part , one third aquatic animal ( crocodile ) in the middle part , one third bird ( tail of peacock ) in the hind portion with extended floral tail .  There was a golden window above the Dhoka ( gate ) , once used by the king to make public appearances .The window enshrined Avlokiteshwara aka Karunamaya ( now known all over the world as Machchhendranath , a famous Hindu yogi ) surrounded by the pantheon of Hindu gods .  The old museum building was reinforced with concealed RCC beams & slabs and retrofitted with moisture resistant membranes to protect the walls and roof from dampness .  We first witnessed Shilapatras inscripted from 659 Ad to 1896 AD . Then we climbed new stair case in the eastern wing .  There we saw a ritual oil lamp with bronze donor figure made at Bhaktapur in 1870 AD and placed under terracotta nitche and torana .  Then we saw five Buddhist beautiful figurines showcased together :  The left hand side bottom most figure was of Chamunda / Kali / Mahalaxmi . It was made of Brass in 18th - 19th century in Nepal . Depicted as a skeletal crone as no other Goddess was , the fierce Mahalaxmi - also called Chamunda / Kali - could not be mistaken for any other female deity .  The left hand side top most figure was of Indra . It was made of Gilt copper in 17th - 18th century in Nepal . Indra , an ancient Hindu God reverred by all Nepalese was recognised by his horizontal third eye , in contrast to the vertical third eye of other deities . The right hand side bottom most figure was of Vajradaka . It was made of Bronze in 17th - 18th century in Nepal . The upturned face with gaping mouth identified Vajradaka , an earth spirit who devours ill influences . Tibetans sometime took medicine through his mouth .  The right hand side top most figure was of Yam . It was made of Bronze in 17th - 18th century in Nepal . Yam , a fierce Buddhist protector , " King of Religious Law " , and the personification of death was unmistakable because of his bull head and mount , the water buffalo , a combination shared with no other deity .  At the centre was White Tara of the Seven Eyes . This idol was made of Cold gold , Copper alloy , Gilt , Paint and Semi precius stones in 18th - 19th century in Tibet . This form of the Buddhist Goddess Tara was reognised by her five extra eyes , one on the forehead andtwo each on the palms and soles .  The tantric images of Buddhism , the deities are in sexual embrace . We appreciated two such images :  One such image of Yam and His Consort .This idol is made of Cold gold , Copper alloy , Gilt , Paint and Semi precious stones in 15th century in Tibet . Yam , " Lord of Death " and " King of the Law " united with his consort in the vigorous pose of the fierce deities . Both wear skull studded crowns , his was a garland of severed human heads ; hers was a girdle of humane bone . They were supported by Yam's mount the water buffalo . Originally a Hindu deity , Yam was eventually incorporated into the Buddhist pantheon as a protector .  Another image was of Chakrasamvara and Vajravarahi . This idol was made of Bronze and Gilt in 18th - 19th century in Nepal . When the esoteric Bodhisattva Chakrasamvara united with his consort Vajravarahi , the " Dimand Sow " , they represented the union of wisdom and compassion that is the actuality of enlightenment . This extreme multiheaded and multiaremed representation was characteristic of Tantric imagery .  We also learnt the Lost Wax casting process depicted detail by various photographs having commentary .  The visit to the museum is a MUST to know the cultural richness of Nepalese civilization .  Entry Fee : Included in Patan Darbar Square Entry Fee Timings : 10:30 to 16:30 Closed : Tuesdays

column7: Old is passionate museum in patan
column8: It was a amazing experience we are had here we has see here old thin it's was incredible things has here Archaeological objects we have to see in this museum
The museum is the perfect place to load up on some Nepali history. There are plenty of ancient artifacts to review.

column7: Truly a Unesco World Heritage Site
column8: If you are interested in art and architecture this is a must visit venue. It has been fairly restored post the 2015 earthquake. You can walk up the 3 stories of the Patan Museum which was once the palace of the royal family.

One of the ancient cities in Khatmandu that boasts Nepal's artistic heritage, touching both Buddhism and Hinduism coexistence- - - temples, Newari houses and buildings that were built since 13th century. Museum galleries that exhibits 1,500 artifacts. The place also house 'The Living Goddess Kumari'. The Kumari is believed to be an incarnation of the goddess Taleju - based on 32 criterias such as "eyelashes like a cow" and "thighs like a deer". A new Kumari is typically chosen once the previous one has started her menstruation cycle. The Kumari may only leave her palace on ceremonial occasions, her feet never touching the ground as she is carried around by family members and seeing the Kumari is considered to be 'good luck'.  Entrance fee for foreigner: NRS1000

Patan is one of the largest city of Lalitpur, located in the south of Kathmandu. The place carries many historical places such as Patan Durbar Square, Patan museum or Patan Kumari. You also can see the host of stone and metal workings. The place is filled with old temples and marvellous statues. However, during recent earth quake in Nepal many historical temples were damaged and destroyed!! overall you will love the place, however the crowd and congestion with unorganized roads and ways could be found some what troublesome! No matter which place you go, to carry self safety is always advisable.
It is a small museum but it is worth visiting. Many interesting facts about their culture and history.

column7: A small museum still worth visiting
column8: A fine collection of Nepalese bronze pieces both of Buddhist and Tantric origins. The palace is at the heart of the Durbar Square and certainly worth a visit. The rich heritage of Nepal that is a mixture of Hindu and Buddhist aspects are clearly visible in these exquisite artefacts. A small museum but a lovely collection. The museum has a restaurant and is a lovely peaceful place to unwind.
Beautiful historic place. Got to learn too many things about culture and history of Nepal. Wonderful place

What I like best about this place even though the sun was very hot , there was something about it the building is very cool inside, it felt like if there was a a/c inside, there was none though, very relaxing...rich history.
Make sure to visit the 2 entrances of main museum with golden doors, and the unmarked entry through a tall arch. See arch in photo. You’ll want half day to explore.
A most interesting museum, with lots of features that interest. Cafe which is convenient. I particularly liked the old photographs.
Not a big place but very beautiful with so many antique pieces and history. Worth a visit. Children may not be so excited here though

column7: Nearing the end of our visit to Nepal - perfect
column8: The ancient city of Patan is known in modern terminology as the 'City of Fine Arts'. Well, my husband and I thought this might be a bit lite. The main square is filled with Hindu temples and Buddhist monuments. The Royal Palace pretty much dominates the area in its granduer; the 16th C stone Krishna Mandira with 21 pinnacles dedicated the Lord Krishna does hold its own. But there's more: the Golden Temple and the terra cotta temple of Mahabouddha. By this time we were pretty much exhausted after three weeks of none stop travel. We gazed at all the above maybe more in a stupor than wonder. Now, by reviewing this extraordinary city, we fully appreciate what was to be our last great adventure in Nepal. Nameste.

I along with my friends decided to visit some of the old and UNESCO listed heritage site of Nepal. First off we drove to Patan, an old city located a few kilometers from central Kathmandu. The Patan durbar square was fascinating. Some of the old temples and palace buildings were badly damaged by the earthquake but restoration work was in progress. Patan Museum showcased some interesting artifacts. I fully recommend a visit to this museum for people interested in oriental culture and Buddhism. There’s so much for you to discover here! Thank you!

displays were outstanding, in museum in the Royal Palace complex, with many monuments in the main square and smaller ones in the surrounding. A bustling local and traditional spices, fruits and household goods market is adjoining to the square. 'Gardens' contained tent/shelters where men were reassembling and when necessary remaking parts/trim damaged by earthquake which was very interesting. They were very skilled artisans.

This museum has well displayed artifacts that are relevant to the scope of the Malia kingdom with good explanations in English on the history, evolution, and interactions between the Hindu and Buddhist religions as it applies to Nepalese art. It is not big but all artifacts displayed are both beautiful and informative.

column7: Be sure to find the second entrance, and access to the other courtyards.
column8: Restoration of the complex is going well (I last visited in 2016, and at various times in the past decades as well). The two courtyards and rear of the palace always seem much less visited than the main exhibition halls, be sure not to overlook that area, which is exceptionally beautiful.

column7: Interesting museum to learn the history of the area
column8: The Patan Museum is very informative with a lot of history to be learned here. The surrounding buildings, although damaged in the earthquake and still in various stages of repair, are extremely valuable in learning about the many carvings in both stone and wood that are found on them.  Inside the museum are many sculptures and art from past centuries. We did have a guide which made it easier for us to know what everything was. Enjoyed this area very much.
covers many centuries of Nepalese history intricate sculptures ornate stone carvings gorgeous stone tigers and wonderful wood carvings

column7: Very Informative Museum, Worth the Entrance Fee
column8: Of all the Durbar Squares in Nepal, they say that Patan is the best of them. And though I haven't gone inside the Kathmandu and Bhaktapur Durbar Squares, I would have to say that I'm impressed by this place and especially its museum.  You pay Rs 1000, which is quite a big amount, but the proceeds go to the rehabilitation of the place. I appreciated that when I went to the Patan Museum and learned about the history of the Durbar Square, the rehabilitation efforts that they have put into it, and the future plans for the place.  There were also a few galleries to check out that was very informative about the Hindu and Buddhist history, symbolisms, gods, goddesses, and beliefs.  You can get lost within the area for more than 2 hours, just reading through the descriptions in the museum and learning more about the Nepalese culture.  I recommend it! The museum really is a big plus.

column7: Loaded With History And A Good Collection Of Asian Art
column8: This was once the residence of the Malla kings and now houses a fine collection of religious art displayed in a series of brick and timber rooms. For the casual viewer it was a good museum and for those into Asian art it would be something special and for those not that tuned into the art scene it was interesting architecturally and historically.

Though it has not fully recovered from the earthquake it gives good insights into history and significance of area.  Some good images of pre earthquake days. The building is stunning. Wood carving beautiful, intricate. I particularly loved the fabric mural. Royal bath was amazing. Lots to see. Cafe is worth visiting for a lovely green space, excellent service and plenty of options for dining.
seeing how the kingdom of history progressed through Patan is fascinating and this is a great visit- make sure to stop at the shop

Great museum which will be definitely worth your time. Staff are kind and our guide explained us a lot of what we saw. We came out knowing more and wanting to know even more about Nepal's history and traditions

Patan museum and inside Patan Durbar Square which is a world heritage site and a nice place to understand the history of the local culture in Kathmandu. It’s a vibrant place with lots of people around and open spaces to sit around. The museum is not too big but it has good information on wooden carvings and the amalgamation of Hindu and Buddhist culture in Kathmandu.

column7: Excellent displays in an outstanding example of traditional architecture
column8: Really an outstanding experience for those who want to explore the culture of the Kathmandu Valley. The restoration of the building itself rivals the excellent collection. All in all, a must!

The museum consists of several galleries within the ancient palace. It shows you some basic relics from the history of the area and lets you understand a little better the culture and History . Wirth the visit and the time spent
It is a terrible shame for the city that it has had this horrible disaster, but you can still get a good feel for the history and religion of this lovely country.

Comp[aritively a small museum but full of idols, artefacts of Hindu & Buddhist religions. Exquisitely made in wood & stone. Some stunning pieces. Well-maintained, some damaged by the earthquake & being restored. Informative & historic goes back many hundreds of years.
Patan museum is full of Nepali history, all the historic artifacts here provides information on how the country was 200 years ago.

Patan Museum: A museum situated in Patan, Nepal. It is an UNESCO’s World Heritage Sites displaying traditional sacred arts of Nepal. Patan Museum was inaugurated in 1997 by Late King Birendra Bir Bikram Shah.

column7: all the heritage and religious factor
column8: these is the place where you can learn and get some proper information about the newari culture all the things over here you find it will be antique and very precious. patan durbar square is a perfect place to be to see the diversified culture now as you can see some holy temples as well
This museum highlights the royal treasures of the Patan Kingdom, who ruled Nepal once upon a time. Apart from that, it also showcases the culture and history of Nepal.

This is one of the finest museums I have seen . Most of the artefacts and statues date back to the tenth century . The history and philosophy around each artefact is very well explained in English . The various poses of Buddha , the philosophy behind multiple arms of Hindu Gods , sects of Buddhism etc are interesting to read and learn ! Need good physical stamina to climb the stairs .

Really impressive place to visit. It is a must for all visitors of the region. Patan is one of the oldest bases of Nepali Empire, with incredible history to share. Sites are being restored by international effort. Worth the visit

column7: A Fascinating Journey into the Past
column8: I have visited Patan Durbar Square Museum on many occasions over the past four decades, and it is always an inspiring and learning experience! It is a great example of Seventeenth Century palace architecture! The building is an integrated, wholistic example of design born out of a “culture of construction,” reflecting a society’s social structure, management system, craftsmen and their skills and available materials!
very interesting and very nice to get to look at the ancient oraments! Nice and relax way to look at the history of Nepal. also really nice to wander around the area and relax with friends

Patan Museum was filled with marvelous examples of wooden and metal treasures. It also offered much information on the history of Nepal. Again, there was much obvious damage from the earthquake in 2015. The absolute conviction to repair and restore was apparent around the museum and throughout Patan Durbar Square

There is so much to see around the Kathmandu Valley but if you want to see a place with a long history of arts and culture then Patan is the place to go. It is about 40 minutes from central Kathmandu and there is an entrance fee to the main area. Patan is in Lalitpur district which is said to have been founded in the third century BC by the Kirat dynasty and later expanded by Licchavis in the 6th century. It was expanded further by the Mallas during the medieval period. Patan Durbar Square is listed by UNESCO as one of seven Monument Zones that make up the Kathmandu Valley World Heritage Site. Some Patan monuments were badly damaged in the 2015 earthquakes and work is continuing on rebuilding. But the Museum is outstanding and well worth a visit with excellent displays giving the history of Nepal. There are magnificent displays and the signage is in both English and Nepali. Lalitpur has the highest number of renowned artists and finest craftsmen ever recorded in the history of Nepali art. You can only marvel at the intricate wood and metal work as you move through the museum and admire the workmanship of the craftspeople. After visiting the Museum make sure you walk down the road to the Golden Temple - it was spared by the quakes. You can easily spend half a day at Patan and there are many cafes for lunch or tea. Well worth a visit and the entrance fee.

column7: Amazing Hindu, Buddhist and Tantric artefacts
column8: The museum is a national treasure, located near Durbar Square in Patan. Amazing architecture, enriched with wonderful works of art. The museum is part of the old palace built by the Malla dynasty. Patan Museum is abundant with priceless collection of Hindu, Buddhist and Tantric artefacts. Most of the objects are cast work made of bronze, traditional crafts for which Patan is famous. In the quiet and pleasant ambience of the museum we spent wonderful moments. The rich history of Nepal is preserved and well presented, I recommend a visit to this museum.

Simply beautiful! The palace had been renovated by the famous Austrian architect Hagenmueller. It resisted to the 2015 earthquake. The collection is amazing and there beautiful representation of budhas. There is a nice courtyard with food and beverages catering. The compound includes several royal courtyards and buildings. The famous fountain which has been recently renovated is absolutely gorgeous!

From the lions flanking the entrance, to the gilded arch at the entrance, to the marble and stone shrine in the museum courtyard, the structure of this museum is itself a great history lesson of different historic periods in Nepal history. However, the museum also offers exhibits, which provide a great deal of information regarding this history. This is well worth a visit during any visit to Patan.

Patan Museum is located at Durbar Square, which is the very center of old town Patan. The building of the museum itself is a main attraction of Patan, but inside is also interesting. Although the entrance is a little bit expensive, it is worth seeing.

I wasn’t really expecting to find this great little museum when we were visiting Patan Durbar Square. Although it’s not big place, you should spend adequate time to explore the museum. I would say 1 hour will be enough. The museum focus mostly on Buddhism and Hinduism in general. Even if you are not either, the stories behind the religions which include the history of religions, symbols and arts are fascinating. The museum building itself is a part of the attraction. So I would recommend a stop at this museum. The fee is included in the Durbar Square fee anyway.

column7: Collection of Cultural Heritaze in Patan
column8: Patan Museum, is situated in Lalitpur Mangal Bazar, which was a famous and as a central market of Lalitpur. Now it has all collection of New and old. It is a centre of cultural heritage, many temples are situated around this place. It maintained ancient culture. This Museum itself was a palace of king Sidhi Narsingh Malla. A Malla king of Patan, now with renovation it transform as a Museum. In this Museum there are lot of things the history of King in addition a lot of sculptures images and many more, we enjoyed our trip there. I recommend other tourist to visit and enjoy.
The museum exhibits in a very informative way history and features of Patanˋs very rich Culture. The Visite of the museum is a must while in Patan.

This a a must see museum the building are great and the prices inside are very nice You but your ticket outside and you can find a tour guide there as well lots of nice buildings and rooms the cafe is very good and the staff spoke English Seeing the building being repaired is good as they are around 350 years old I wii be going back

This historic place is in the middle of the city, with many monuments in the main square and smaller ones in the surrounding. A bustling local and traditional spices, fruits and household goods market is adjoining to the square. There are some local spicy food stalls and restaurants in the vicinity, if you want to try local newari taste. A must place to visit when you are in Katmandu

column7: Patan Darbar and Museum...the Place to Be
column8: If you want to have a glimpse of the rich cultural heritage of Nepal, this is the place to be. More than the museum, the entire area is a living museum despite the on-going restoration of the palace and temples.  The design of the Hindu temples and the palace is unique. Not that I'm an archeologist or anthropologist but it makes you marvel at the artistry that went into it. The main materials used are red bricks and hard wood such as teakwood. The designs on the wooden columns and window frames are really intricate if not painstakingly done.  The place is really a cultural complex worthy of our time and attention.

This place is very rich in finding and studying about history. The museum is full of traditional artifacts used or was available during the past. this place is packed with the information for all kind of people like history researcher, study savvy, traveler, archeologist and much more.

This site is approx 20 mins drive from Kathmandu, architecture & crafts are bit different thank kathmandu & Bhaktapur. Though recent massive earthquake has destroyed a lot but restoration work is on, museum is worth visiting, good collection of history, pretty happening gathering for locals too.

Excellent temples and old buildings. There is some earthquake damage but it is still worth going to see. The admission fee is slightly high but worth paying. There seems to be a lot of activity and ceremonies most days.

Marvellous collection of old Buddhist and Hindu statues in a beautiful building. Comfortable seating area with a view onto Patan Durbar Square on top floor. After admiring the intricate workmanship of the Nepali master craftsmen you can enjoy a coffee or meal at the Museum Café in the museum courtyard.
Interesting place to visit. Not very big but it's part of the Durbar Square. It reminds me of some scenes from Dr. Strange... Entrance fees also apply...

column7: Gorgeous - an oasis of deep history
column8: We loved our visit to the Patan museum. Didn't really know what to expect and found surprising delights at every turn. In the main palace, the upstairs galleries gave us much more insight into the spiritual and artistic heritage of Himalayan culture than looking at temples from the outside. The written descriptions of each item are as thoughtful and informative as any we've ever seen.  At first we thought the main building was the entire museum, but then stumbled into the equally wonderful separate courtyard with its own upstairs architectural gallery exhibiting woodwork etc. Magnificent.
Unesco Heritage site. Very good place. But severely damaged in earthquake. Somehow the ticket complex did not accept indian currency.

column7: Great museum... And an oasis if quiet
column8: This was included in the ticket for Durbar Square so I popped in. Personally I don't look at each thing or read about them but I loved this building and especially the garden to sit in. V quiet and peaceful. I think history buffs would love this place.

The 1000 rupees are a little steep. They are fixing a lot of earthquake damage and it is progressing well. I really enjoyed this. It was well laid out and explained the history of the area and the intersection of Buddhism and Hinduism.

column7: History of Patan in one place
column8: I live nearby and I've been to the museum a few times. It is always refreshing to know your local history. Highly recommended.
Museum is within the complex of Patan Durbar Square. It has a great collection of antique artifacts. Can take upto 2 hours to see the entire museum.

Patan is a large series of temples and palaces. Visitors walk between the main buildings which might enclose several city blocks. There are some shops and eateries but we mostly viewed the historic sights. An example of classic architecture, this area was largely spared by the 2014 earthquake. If time is limited, and you have the choice to see Patan or Bhaktapur, I would choose the latter as more interesting (although more damaged) with more activity and museums.

column7: I love this Museum. Must see
column8: Patan Museum in Kathmandu Nepal is excellent collection of antique artifacts. All Murtis are very well carved in wood and metal. I love this Museum. Must see

column7: Specialized in bronze statues and religious objects
column8: My friend and I visited the museum as part of our visit to Patan Dubar Square on April 4, 2017. It is a UNESCO’s World Heritage Sites. The Patan Museum was inaugurated in 1997 by Late King Birendra Bir Bikram Shah. The Patan Museum displays the traditional sacred art of Nepal in an illustrious architectural setting. Its home is an old residential court of Patan Darbar, one of the royal palaces of the former Malla kings of the Kathmandu Valley. Its gilded door and window face one of the most beautiful squares in the world. The residential palace compound of Keshav Narayan Chowk which houses the museum dates from 1734, displacing a Buddhist monastery that is still remembered in an annual public rite on the palace doorstep. But both monastery and palace rest on far older foundations that may go back to the Licchavi Period (ca. 3rd to 9th century). The garden to the rear of the museum has been adapted to incorporate a pleasant resting place and The Patan Museum Cafe run by the Summit Hotel, Kathmandu.

column7: A look into the splendor of the past
column8: There were different buildings open during our visit due to damage to some of the usual buildings from the earthquake. Therefore we got to visit more of the old palace than had previously been open. As with much of Durbar Square, the wood work was amazing but here the metal work was also impressive as was the royal bath. It was nice that it wasn't so crowded so that you could take time to sit and really look.

I really loves this place because it is one of the best preserved ancient place of Nepal. The History of Brave Nepalese and culture of Patan is very well resembled i this location. Highly recommended for 1 day visit. Relaxation and refreshment guaranteed.

In crowded Kathmandu, it's difficult to find a quiet and fresh place like Patan Museum. Tourists can read the ancient culture with calm atmosphere and the classical architecture itself speaks elegant language. Really enjoyable and worthy to visit.

This museum has a collections old ruins, and worth a trip for the art and history enthusiasts as well as all other curious minds. The peacefull surrounding and a garden inside made my brief stay here a lot enjoyable and worthwhile!

The exhibition is very interesting. Many ancient object is displayed. The entrance fee is included in 1000 rps. If you love in history, must see! There have restaurant in the garden behind the museum.

column7: Great history of Buddhism and Hindu
column8: Great layout and best museum in NEPAL. Beautiful old artifacts tracing the history of buddhism and its connection with the Indian Hinduism.

Patan Durbar Square is one of oldest heritage side of Nepal. The structure of temples are so impressive. I love the way of locals from Patan. We visited the beautiful temple - Bangala Mukhi as well.  Highly recommend to travellers 🙏🏻
As i went there in museum .I found excellent collection and maintaining the order as open book of history of Nepal.

Got a guide with us for the museum who expounded on the religion and culture in Nepal as he brought us around the museum. It was part of an ancient palace. Learn a lot from the guide. You can also do the museum tour on your own. Lots of relics, exhibits and intricate architecture. Entrance fee is required.

The building itself is a work of art, it is a lovely walk thru traditional architecture. The Galleries are lovely and well lighted and your ticket gives you access to other buildings too. The only thing is Durbar square is quite expensive for foreigners and sometimes they don't allow access to just the museum without buying both tickets.
Patan Museum is a main museum of the city. Is very interesting! Has a history of Buda, Hindu and much more. Go!

The museum is housed in a 3 tiered heritage building, which also gives one the feeling of being inside such a structure. Low ceiling height and long and narrow halls dominate the interiors. There are a large number of artefacts especially woodwork items. There is also a cafe in the adjacent courtyard. A must see attraction in Patan.
Great museum. Well displayed, infomative, and in such an amazing building (the old palace). Well worth the time.

column7: Pricey but worth it for Art and Architectural Treasures
column8: I think the foreign entry price is a bit steep at NRP 1000 per person but it is actually a gorgeous museum. The descriptions of art iconography are illuminating and in depth, brought to life by true examples in sculpture or architecture. I found the step by step lost wax casting display wonderful. Currently (Jan 2017) Habitat for Humanity and a Nepali aid organization have children affected by earthquake trauma organized in the inner courtyard creating structures. Interesting! Go to the cafe after your visit, it's charming too.

column7: Mountain weath in Stone n Sculpture
column8: A very well designed and executed Museum. A walk not just through the past but a glimpse into the present. The Cafe in the backyard is a treasure too.

column7: Important part of your Patan visit, don't miss it!
column8: The museum is situated right at Patan Durbar square, in a former royal palace complex. The building was largely spared by the 2015 earthquake, and its beautiful facade gives you an idea of "what was", and perhaps of "what will be" once all the renovations around are completed.  To enter the museum, you will walk through a maze of finely decorated courtyards. The museum itself is compact and well planned, with Hindu and Buddhist artefacts displayed in separate galleries. If you don't feel like an expert in local traditions and beliefs, then this is the right place to start. Most objects are fine metalwork depictions of deities, and insights into the metalwork craft - for which Patan was once famous. Photos can be taken inside.  If you decide to finish your tour at the museum, there is a nice cafe at the back courtyard where you can have a drink and relax. Entry to the museum is now covered by the Patan Tourist Entrance Pass, which you can purchase at Patan Durbar square.

column7: Must visit place to see the ancient art and culture of Patan, Nepal.
column8: I am from Nepal and I must recommended to visit Patan Museum not because I am a Nepali but because this place is all about art and culture. Mangalbazar and Patan Museum is one of the must visit place if you are traveling to Nepal.

column7: Really worth spending some time here!
column8: This is a really neat museum. the museum is on one of the old buildings that encloses the Mani Keshab Narayan Chowk. There are lots of exhibits set out over a couple of floors and lots of great explanations beside them. You can get up real close and they allow you to take photos. I though it was well laid laid out and a rally great attraction/ Loved some of the ancient Buddah statues. Entrance is included on your ticket, so don't lose it.

column7: A beacon of hope for the future......................
column8: Amidst the current devastation and rebuilding following the 2015 earthquake, the Patan Museum stands as something of a beacon for the future because it shows what will be achieved when the renovations outside are complete. This is an excellently laid out museum on several floors using the structure of the original traditional building. The artefacts are sympathetically displayed with very good labelling, as are the temporary exhibitions too. The main galleries in this once royal palace, once monastery, follow and explain the the origins, development and symbolism of Hinduism and Buddhism. Other galleries show exhibits which explain the metal technology involved in creating many Buddhist and Hindu effigies. In addition, at the moment (November 2016) and temporarily there are two excellent photographic exhibitions. One contains pictures of an annual traditional Hindu ceremony covering the last thirty years. The other, more powerful, exhibition shows in visual form the struggles of the Dalit people (the so-called 'Untouchables') to gain respect and civil rights. This is a lovely museum but if museums don't have much appeal per se, it is still worth visiting just to see the building itself which is exceptionally fine for its architecture and intricate wooden carvings, or to sit in the tranquil garden and have something to eat or drink at the cafe there.

column7: Uncover the symbolic meanings of hands, eyes, and feet.
column8: “The eyes, hands, and feet all have symbolic meanings.” This multi-story museum is a focal point to start learning about the meanings behind the statues positions and gestures. You could literally spend hours reading the detailed (in English) information. Near the entrance was a special exhibit of paintings sponsored by “End Sexual Violence.” The students will explain the artwork and you are invited to purchase some hand-made cards.

Most of the museum was spared from the earthquake. It is housed in a wonderful palace. Just seeing the palace, this architectural wonder with its many rooms and balconies make this worthwhile. The exhibitions are fascinating, they give you a good overview of the history of Buddhism. The exhibitions are well lit and signed in English. In the last courtyard there is a small coffee shop where you can get something to eat or drink
A must if you visit Kathmandu as it will give you various insights about Culture and the history of the people.

I was visit Patan in 2008. Everything was nice and beautiful. However, after the earthquake, many high ancient building which are landmarks were destroyed from earthquake. Staff didn't notice us and charge for full price $US 10. At least, they should notice the tourist about change from earthquake. I was disappoint for service that they gave.

Patan Museum is one of the best kept museums in the country. Amongst the hustle and bustle of Patan Durbar Square lies this quaint museum that offers a glimpse into the past of the magnificent city of Patan.

column7: Best presented display of religious treasures in Nepal
column8: Situated within the buildings of Patan's Durbah Square, the Patan Museum is noteworthy for both its great, and superbly documented, displays of historic Nepali religious art, and it's location allowing access to the corridors and balconies of the central Durbah palace. And it's included within the ticket price to enter the Durbah area! Not to be missed!

column7: The earthquake doesn't affect the beauty of this place
column8: Definitely a must see in Kathmandu. The king's throne and the many statues are a great intro to the areas history. There was also a nice photo exhibit on the dalits that was very informative.
One of the most important place to visit during your patan durbar square. Old architecture wooden art with many Hindu holy tample.

column7: A perfectly curated traditional sacred art display explaining Hinduism and Buddhism
column8: Located in the astonishing old residential court of Patan Darbar this museum is the perfect place to spend 2-3 hours for those willing to improve their knowledge and understanding of the Hinduism and Buddhism. There's is a nice outdoor cafeteria in the last courtyard, it's a bit pricey but peaceful.

We visited the museum while perusing Durbar Square. We had entered Durbar Square from the "back side" and did not realize we had to pay admission until we were ready to exit near the actual entrance side of the square. A security guard escorted me to the entrance and made me pay the admission fee. I don't think it was handled well. We paid a separate admission fee for the museum and palace which was fine and enjoyed learning more about the local culture. There is a lot of shopping and good food in the square as well.

This museum is a fascinating learning opportunity about Nepali culture and spiritual history. It's an experience not to be missed as the Royal Palace is a joy to explore, but older visitors beware - unfortunately access is by a series of steep ladders between floors only which excludes anyone with frailties or disabilities. The series of courtyards at ground level are wonderful to experience as long as the visitor is capable of stepping over high stone entrances. the Museum Cafe is a delight - a cool, shady oasis from the heat with top food and beverages. The Lonely Planet guidebook recommends taking time out here between tackling different floors of the museum and I agree. A fabulous dip into Nepal's past.
The Patan day dour was awesome. Inside the museum there was many things resembling the glorious history of Nepal and its culture

column7: Worth including this if you have time
column8: This museum was really interesting if you are interested in religion, history or architecture. I admit it may not be high on the list to-do in Kathmandu, but it's interesting if you are a history or architectural buff.

Rich collection of history in this museum. take some time and visit this museum. you can also buy collectibles inside here too. Do not forget to dine at the restaurant which is located inside the compound.
The museum situated in a beautiful well renovated building is a rare gem. The museum showcase arts, craft and artifacts from Patan and Newar culture
This museum got damaged badly during earth quake, repair work is under way, inside entry is not allowed, you can just have an out side view

Devastated by earthquake, the building is quite damaged you cant go inside. Some repair work is going on but it appears Govt is not interested in renovating it but just keeping all these building damaged so they can get more aid.

Beautiful display of Hindu and Buddhist religious objects within a well-preserved building of classic Newari architecture. The building itself seems to be part of the museum’s displays. I found especially informative and interesting the Buddhist section, with displays about the spread of Buddhism outside India’s (and Nepal’s) birthplace, as well as meaning and significance of Buddhism monuments and postures. I found this place a quiet venue to understand and view together at a glance both religions’ features and contributions to the history of this Country (and not only); a contribution to mutual understanding as well, especially in the view of the fact that Buddhism has basically left India (and in Nepal too it is far behind Hinduism in terms of followers, and it is mostly alive thank to Tibetan influence).

The best museum in Nepal. Well worth the money. The entrance fee is 400 NPR, it is well maintained, with good description. The museum gives you the insight of Buddhism, Hinduism, local culture and the craftsmanship.  One may need 2-3 hours for this museum it also covers some parts of the royal palace. It is recommended for the history and musum lovers. I will suggest to visit this museum last after visiting most of the attractions. The missing links and pieces will slowly be connected.

Excellent museum with well curated exhibits, with many historic displayes dating to 16-17th century. The quality of exhibits was exceptional with many delicately crafted pieces very well displaued. The museum is set in a historic mansion which is itself very beautiful. A small museum which takes about 1 hour to go though, but take your time as its a real treat for an art lover.

After the dust and bustle of Durbar square I was very surprised to find this excellent museum in the historic centre of the town. The exhibits were clearly marked, well lit and interesting arranged. There was enough information but not too much. A tranquil and cool environment to learn more about Patan, religion and the people of Nepal. Well worth a visit

This museum is a world class museum that describes and shows the Newar culture of Nepal better than the Metropolitan Museum in New York of Cleveland Museum of art. This is the place to go if you want to begin to understand the history and life of the people of the Kathmandu Valley. You will also see the best description of the lost wax method of casting. Make this an early stop on your tour of Patan and enjoy lunch at the Museum Cafe

column7: One of the better museums in Nepal, if not the best
column8: I enjoyed wandering through the many rooms in the ancient and traditional building and looking at the exhibits, some of which are really interesting though more information would aid understanding of what I was looking at. It was not crowded even for a visit in the middle of the day in the spring tourist season.

Beautiful setting in an old palace, wonderfully clear explanations in English. Even though I had read and seen a lot of Hindu/Buddhist art before, I learned a tremendous amount about the symbolism surrounding the gods and goddesses. If you are interested in Hindu/Buddhist sculpture (and Patan and Kathmandu are rich in this area), this museum is a must. Unless you are already a scholar in this area, you will learn a lot. Great museum!

column7: Interesting for art and history lovers
column8: A little history of the old palace of Patan, which is now the museum, and a wonderful collection of representations of Hindu deities with detailed explanations. Very interesting for art and culture lovers, or those interested in learning more about Hinduism and its many gods and goddesses. The complex also holds a hotel with a café and a beautiful garden, hidden behind the walls of the museum.
Beautifully presented museum with traditional art with exhibition that covers of Nepal 's cultural history.

The way they preserve their culture in Nepal is extraordinary. A day is not enough especially if you enjoy looking at the artistry, interacting with the locals, or really just being amazed by this square of ancient relics.
this is a ancient place which was is beautiful place and i had visited this place by @Rosha Trek & Expedition P. Ltd.

column7: Loved the place. Captured some good pictures which I have attached!
column8: The museum falls under the UNESCO’s World Heritage Sites. We reached the museum around 2pm. The ticket cost is very nominal. The museum displays the traditional sacred art of Nepal in an illustrious architectural setting. Its home is an old residential court of Patan Darbar, one of the royal palaces of the former Malla kings of the Kathmandu Valley. Its gilded door and window face one of the most beautiful squares in the world.  The post-earthquake effects can be seen on the pillars and the rest of the establishment though. Took a few shots to capture the same. A great place for photography.

column7: Patan Museum, a must in Kathmandu valley
column8: Patan Museum, situated in an old Palace, extremely nicely arranged by Austrian architect Götz Hagmüller, Hosts a spectacular collection of Buddhist and Hindu artifacts from the olden times of Nepal. Presentation and location are splendid. A coffee shop (run by Summit Hotel) was added in the garden of the Museum.

column7: A bargain and an amazing place
column8: I love museums and I've been in a lot abroad where the exhibits are fascinating but hard to interpret as info isn't in English. At Patan Museum all of the information is in English and is very detailed. The museum focuses on the history of Hinduism and Buddhism in Patan and has lots of interesting statues. There is two parts to the museum both included in the ticket price of 400 rupees. While the main museum through the golden door is intact the second half through a neighbouring door off the main square has had some damage from the earthquake but this doesn't seem to have had much in it anyway. Definitely make a visit here.  Tip: I paid 1000 rupees for a guide as I wandered into patan square, and apart from showing me where the golden temple is he wasn't worth the price (though he was a nice person). Definitely don't get a guide for the museum as I saw one person being shown round quickly by the guide and he didn't see much of the exhibits. Do it at your own speed.
Major sightseeing attraction. Be prepared for the men who want to guide you. It does help to have one who will then lead you to some shop. History is interesting.
Beautiful place to be, a garden cafe at its back. preserving thousands of years old heritage to Historic City Patan.

just when i thought that there's nothing more to see in Nepal after the earthquake, my friend sunil brought me to this place and i was amazed and enchanted by it. I been wondering how it was made especially those perfectly carved art pieces. So, if your into history and arts this is a must visit place for you.

We visited this during our Nepal trip in December 2010.We had a nice experience visiting this museum with great collection of Hindu and Buddhist artifacts. The museum is located in old residential court of Patan Darbar, one of the royal palaces of the former Malla kings of the Kathmandu Valley. Its gilded door and window face one of the most beautiful squares in the world.There is a entrance fee for this museum.

The details in the front facade is wondrous, the carvings in the dark woods (pillars) is totally impressive. You may enter the square for free and there's a eating area at the back but to enter the actual museum has a fee. (500 or 400nr...) the display of bronzed Gods in different postures from different times is splendid. I especially like the cushioned-window-sitting nooks where you can get closer to the wood carvings and gaze at the people below.

This really is a gem of a museum.  The museum building itself is breathtaking, but you can see that this has all been planned and implemented to a very high standard. All the exhibits are well presented and the level of detail they have gone to in order to explain each exhibit and the religious significance of them is done so in an easy to understand manner. Particularly when you consider that the subject matter of Hindu and Buddhist gods is not the easiest of subjects for the uninitiated to understand.  The entrance fee is very good value and there is an excellent cafe within the main courtyard of the museum. Incidentally you can access the cafe for free from the main entrance off Durbar Square.

This museum was spared from the earthquake damage, and contains an impressive overview of historic artifacts. The rest of the square has been cleared of the earthquake rubble and is still a fascinating attraction.

column7: A wonderful museum in a lovely, authentic old neighborhood
column8: Amazing museum which is working hard on repairs to some roof areas! Go! The historical breadth and documentation, as well as the treasures are very, very good! Great rooftop cafes and Patan shopping (metalwork, art, handicrafts, fabrics) are all a short walk down the old 1-lane streets. Fun to explore the entire area. Much better than the noise and stuff in Thamel.
Is a unique place to see the art and architecture of the Malla kings of Patan. Some of the oldest photographs and paintings as well as metal arts will show the sketch of old Patan and Nepal.

Liked the Museum. Gives an insight in the Period of the Mala Kingdom and other periods in Newari community. Enjoy some thee in the garden. Take time too look all the wonderful iconography of the statues in the Museum.

We visited the Patan Museum in mid-April, shortly before the quake. We don’t know the current status of the museum, but it’s such an underrated attraction we want to give it a shout-out on Trip Advisor, regardless.  The museum is housed in a wing of an old palace that that has been beautifully restored to create a thoroughly modern museum. The collection, mostly sculpture from the Kathmandu Valley, exceeds anything you can see in the western world.  The glory of the Patan Museum is its display. Not only is each individual object attractively displayed, the entire museum is intelligently organized around the goal of clarifying the numerous deities and religious inspirations that gave rise to Nepalese art. The helpful wall texts and labels are in fluent English.  We saw the Patan Museum in the course of a crowded schedule and didn’t have time to explore properly. A couple of hours would have been better.

column7: An understanding of Hinduism and Buddhism
column8: It was a very comprehensive exposure to Hinduism and Buddhism. So tourists need not go farther in terms of researching. They just need to spend under an hour to go through the whole exhibits. The fact that the displays are housed in one of the courtyards (used to be part of the King's palace), with the architecture intact, is quite a plus. One can also feast on different media used to interpret, say, the Buddha sculpture.

column7: This is a must visit if you are a historian / history amazes you.
column8: a place with a great historical significance. Also known as Lalitpur, these were the courts / the royal complex in Nepal. The area has a lot of anciant temples, court rooms, monestries, etc. The most prominant is the Living Goddess Patan Kumari's temple. A seven year old girl living as a goddess in the temple & the stories aroung this religious belief is amazing. it was worthwhile understanding the culture, beliefs, etc of the local residents to familarise yourself with the culture. I was amazed by what I saw & herd.... cannot describe as I believe words are too less..... I'd rather say that you need to have a first hand experiance & you'd agree to what I say - "It is a once in a lifetime experiance".

Among others, a visit to the relatively newly opened Architect Museum was quite a delight and had me pleasantly amazed. The exhibits adequately showcases the unique architecture details of the Newar community that you will see across Kathmandu Valley and help you gain an understanding of all the lovely temples you will see in your visit.

This has to be one of the best you will ever see.  The Museum building, is in itself a World Heritage Treasure... and then you have the rest of the treasures that are housed within it. This is an unparalleled experience.  The gardens are tranquil, the Museum Restaurant is brilliant.  I spent an entire day here. I learned so much from my visit. The window seat settings are one of the highlights.  I will never forget it.

column7: The Museum Behind the Golden Door
column8: The Museum is housed in an old royal palace of the former Malla kings of the Kathmandu Valley; which has undergone a thorough restoration through the joint efforts of the Government of Nepal and the Austrian Government.  The exhibits are kept in excellent display cases with professional lighting. In my opinion this is definitely one of the best museums in Nepal.  There are panels showing how the metal is worked to make the exquisite metal idols that Patan is famous for.  There is a stiff entry fee (NPR 250 for SAARC nationals). BUT the museum is definitely worth it!!!!  Tip: Please spare a minute to climb up to the Bell Tower. You will get a Panoramic view of the Patan Durbar Square.

This is a great place to know about Hinduism, Buddhism and the Nepalese history. Fabulous displays and collections. The museum itself is part of an old palace, a very beautiful medieval court. Our visit to the museum was very enjoyable. Everything comes in one package -- a crash course on religion and history, nice walk inside an old palace, and people watching from the windows.  It is a relatively small museum. We spent about 2 hours inside because of our schedule. This allows us to walk through all areas and get a general idea. If you are a big fan of reading all information in museums, you can easily spend a half day inside.  The museum gift shop has a good collection of books (much cheaper than in Europe), if you are interested.

This museum was absolutely fantastic! Great displays. All of the information was in English, only some of it was in Nepalese (no, I didn't inadvertently transpose that). There are informative displays on how to differentiate the deities. The vast majority of the items are bronze or copper. There is display on the metalworking techniques creating items thru either the lost wax or repousse methods. 4th floor has old pictures of the Patan area. You can also climb up to the bell tower and have a slightly better view fo the Square and get a very good view of the one column directly in front of you with the cobra head at the back. Museum is a definite must-do but didn't think much of the Museum Cafe.

It might be all too easy to drift past this location and not realize the treasure it is.  Spread across two of the historic buildings of Patan's Durbar Square, the museum is a definite must-see. The first building houses the exhibition areas and some of the artefacts and figurines in bronze, gilt and gold are stunning. The museum's incorporation into the old building, an ex-palace and monastery, during renovation has been handled with great care and there is little externally to suggest what you will find along the maze of corridors and floors.  The second building has no exhibits as such but is, itself, the exhibit with incredible carvings and features in its stone and woodwork. To the rear, there is a sunken pool within a garden that is being renovated.  The museum café is very smart and reasonably-priced. There are two museum shops. The items on sale are good quality and their prices reflect that. Don't expect bargain hunting here.  Signs in English, located near the items on exhibition, provide good explanations about the history, etc. of each.

column7: Well organised, A view into Nepal's history
column8: A visit to the Patan museum gives a peek into Nepal's rich history. The various sculpture are neatly organised. Make sure you dont give this a miss.  In case you hire a guide, you can visit this museum at the end of his guided tour.

column7: High Quality and Interesting Alternative to Kathmandu Durbar
column8: We almost walked past this on our visit to Patan. The entry ticket (450 rupees) gets you into both the museum and the newly restored Palace. Both are fascinating and quite newly updated. The museum has a great introduction to Nepalese Hinduism and Buddhism that will appeal to complete newbies as well as those who know something about either.  We took a taxi out in the morning and walked back into town. The taxi fare is negotiable but generally 100 rupees per kilometer ($1/km) should be the upper limit. Our driver was very interested in doing a deal for the entire day which we declined.

column7: Heritage site and precious royal city
column8: one of the heritage site and previous royal city is a real crowd puller. Dont forget to shop bronze statues if you plan to have one, the price could be half of the kathmandu city or only 20% cost of your home country's selling price!

Without doubt Nepal's best museum. A lot of hard work has gone to this gem to gather all the exhibits and make them tell Nepal's cultural and historical story. The stunning collection of artworks is simply amazing. And the way the exhibits are presented makes it very easy for the visitor to get a sense of the achievements people of Patan were capable of attaining. A new wing has also opened. It's prized exhibit is the gold fountain head, stolen some years ago and now recovered. The original piece is part of the museum collection; the one you see in the sunken royal bathing fountain pool is an exact replica. A large piece of land at the back is also being converted into a garden, which should add to its attraction. A fee is charged to enter the museum.

column7: Interesting with lovely cafe/ restaurant out the back , try the orange lime bombs ! Mmm!
column8: Interesting museum that you can wander for an hour or two through, nice to step out of the busyness of the square, out the back is a restaurant /cafe in a garden that is run by the same people as the Summit hotel . Pleasant surroundings and good food . If it's warm it's a nice place to recuperate . Try their orange lime bombs, a lime flavoured very light icrcream/ mousse served in an orange that has been emptied of it's original contents, smooth cool and tangy! The museum has a fee but the restaurant you can just wander right to the back to get to for no charge.

This is a very nice museum where you can learn about Hindu and Buddhist religion and how the Nepalese people have lived with them for centuries. The structure of the building is worthwhile the visit. I was there with my nine years old daughter and she enjoyed the museum also.

This museum is awesome. It is packed with information about Nepal, including the details about history and religious symbols that will give you insights about the things you'll see when you visit the temples and stupas in Nepal. I visited the museum for 2 hours and after I went to several stupas and temples. I think it would be better to visit this museum first, so you could really appreciate and acknowledge the beautiful details lay at every stupa/temple.

This museum is a gem! Walking around Durbar Square in Patan is a fun activity in itself, but paying the extra $ to go to the museum is well worth it! It is clean and organized with so many interesting archeological and historical items that are well-placed with clear and informative wall-texts. It really gives you more background about history and religion in Nepal that will enhance your explorations of other sites around town and throughout the country.

Those who are visiting the Darbar Square can take about an hour and hop in to the this place. The museum is rich in cultural history and background of the evolutio of the Patan people in Nepal. The museum also portrays the significant contributions of ancient Patan people in the History of modern Nepal. Those who are interested in History and Anthropoly will find this museum nice. To me, it was just another local history museum. There are good food stalls outside of the museum. Do not miss the meaty offerings. They are mouth watering.
nice museum with very ancient ornaments and history. love to see lots of architecture things. Highly recommend...............................

Patan city is located about 5 km south of Kathmandu, Patan is one of 3 royal cities in the valley. A destination for connoisseurs of fine arts, Patan is filled with wood and stone carvings, metal statues, ornate architecture, including dozens of Buddhist and Hindu temples, and over 1200 monuments. Patan is believed to have been built in the third century B.C. by the Kirat dynasty later expanded and enriched by the Licchavi and the Malla rulers in the medieval period. Patan Durbar Square, like its counterpart in Kathmandu, is an enchanting mélange of palace buildings, artistic courtyards and graceful pagoda temples. The former Royal palace complex is the centre of Patan’s religious and social life, and houses a beautiful museum. One remarkable monument here is 16th century temples dedicated to the Hindu go Krishna, built entirely of stone.

This has to be one of the best museums in Asia simply for the fact as to how well it has been laid out and how much care has been taken for attention to details. Its truly a tourists delight and a place that everyone must see. The museum used to be the old royal palace so don't forget to spend sometime looking at the building itself apart from the artifacts. Take time also to sit down and watch the world go by from some of the windows where there are comfortable cushions for people to sit down. There are no elevators, so if you have a knee problem, please do take care. The stairs are quite steep, but there are railings.

Patan museum is in former royal palace dating back to 1734. It occupies one side of world heritage listed Durbar Square and there are great views from its upper floors. It costs 250rs and is open 10.30am - 5.30pm, no extra fee for cameras. The exhibits, mostly bronze Hindu and Buddhist sculptures, are laid out immaculately over 3 floors in this lovely old building. Everything is labelled in English and there are some brilliantly simple explanations about the basics of Buddhism and Hinduism, such as why the statues have lots of arms. There was a market in the central courtyard, and a shop and café attached.

I fell in love with this place! The museum building has its own history but the most important are the exhibits ! Most of them are statues , drawings, cast images of Shiva, Vishnu, Parvati and Ganesha . Through these objects an introduction is provided to the history of Hinduism, Tantrism and Buddhism.

The PatAn Durbar square which was just a short distance from the Shaligram Hotel where I was staying is ideal for a couple hours of soaking in the atmosphere of a centuries old city. The museum is located bang in the middle of Patan Durbar square and the whole experience is a must for visitors to Kathmandu.
Such ancient history and such a part of the people of Nepal's culture these wonderful old buildings, was great to visit.

We went and the museum and the entire area of Patan is a must see on a visit to Kathmandu. Patan is an artist community that has been frozen in time in many respects so you can actually see great artisans at work. We saw silver, copper and brass smiths and bought a hand made singing bowl that is literally a piece of art work.
A wealth of history and culture displayed elegantly. Have lunch or a snack in the museum's cafe. Gift shop is expensive but has high quality handicrafts. Bathrooms at the museum cafe are clean.

I was born and raised in Patan. I live in US now. But, I still have a house nearby. This place has a lot of history and it is always buzzing with locals and tourists. My grandfather used to be the head of the museum long time back. I have great memories in this Durbar Square. A must visit for anyone visiting Kathmandu Valley.

column7: I experienced history which I never knew before
column8: Be careful in staircase. There was sudden power cut and everything was dark. I hated it. Beside, I loved everything about this museum.

column7: one of the best in the wold
column8: Patan museum is one of the best in the world we can see how was nepal before 200 years ago and old things...really awesome and its not enough word to write about patan museum. thank you josh
It was a lovely museum and a real treat to be allowed to take photos of their exquisite pieces as so many museums do not allow this.

Brilliant museum and a great secluded cafe in an outdoor garden. The detail and explanations of the Nepali gods was a real help in understanding many of the statues we saw in surrounding temples. Can easily be done in 2 hrs, but give yourself time to relax in the central courtyard garden.
A wonderful collection of art with very interesting informational panels that illuminate what you are seeing. A real bargain too!

column7: Probably the best Museum in all Nepal
column8: Located in an old royal palace, in Patan Durbar Square houses a very unique collection of nepali art, mainly religious bronzes. The building -in a traditional nepali architecture- is a most during your visit to Patan. Also it has a very nice Cafe in the garden and a very special souvenir shop. Visit it!

column7: If you visit one thing in Nepal - go to Patan Museum
column8: The Museum that was conceptualized and curated by a team of international experts is definitely the best place to learn something about the art history of the Kathmandu valley. One of the most extraordinary collections of bronze figures is on display with very well done descriptions of the techniques used to create them. If you visit anything in Nepal - visit the Patan Museum!  There is a nice garden behind the museum where you can relax from the noise of the city, probably the most peaceful place anywhere in Patan. The coffee shop is beautiful but overpriced and the food is boring. Bring your own packed lunch and sit in the small garden or have a - also expensive but very good - lunch at Cafe Swotha only a few meters below Durbar Square!

Best museum I visited in Nepal, diverse collection of artifacts and cultural items with in-depth english descriptions, good refreasher on the religions and traditions of nepalese culture. The buidling itself is a stored historic part of the square and was my favourite part, beautiful architectural details. Its a bit of a taxi ride from Thamel district but well worth it. After the museum we spent some time in the square soaking up the atmosphere and some local children showed us their breakdancing skills. There is a rooftop restaurant practically across the street with great views of the area.

This museum is the best we found in Nepal. It's in a restored palace complex. One enters by stepping through an enormous and grandly appointed golden gate. Once inside, the museum rooms are spread around two or three floors of the old palace complex. They overlook a central coutyard that had a small stupa in it. All the exhibitions were beautifully set-up and well illuminated. There were very informative placards for each exhibit, so one can learn a lot here. We spent at least two hours viewing the exhibitions. I'd also recommend the museum guidebook, which was beautifully photographed. The museum shops were also attractive, as was the very pleasant museum cafe. If you're in Patan, the museum is a must. If you're near Patan, a visit to this museum is almost a reason in itself for visiting Patan.

The Hindu imagery that assails you wherever you travel in Nepal is eye-opening but rather confusing for the uninformed. Thankfully the Patan Museum can help. The museum is set in an evocative old building with views down into the Durbar Square, and the exhibits are presented in a modern and informative style. It tells you a lot about the main gods and their various attributes and iconography.  All in all, it was a very relaxing and useful break from the hustle and bustle of the streets of Kathmandu.

Very popular for traditional architectural buildings that reassembles the history of country. There is a historical center in the Royal Palace. There are many beautiful palaces, temples and squares. its very important place to understand culture history arts and architecture.

Ancient beautiful architecture, have so many Hindo and Buddhist temples and structures in and around Patan Durbar Square built by the Newa People. Also has many "bahals" (courtyards).. Patan is one of the oldest Buddhist cities. It is a center of both Hinduism and Buddhism.. There is Statue of Lion. There is a Palace , The three main courtyards in the palace are Mul Chowk, Sundari Chowk and Keshav Narayan Chowk. Besides these courtyards, the complex boasts impressive temples, religious shrines, and historical places, all noted for their exquisite carvings and beautiful display of ancient Newari architecture.. I strongly recommend especially for people who likes the ancient architectures....

The Newar people, also known as the Nepami constructed the ancient temples, shrines and other structures in the area. The royal square is believed to have been built Malla Kings of Lalitpur. The complex is massive, It is home to 55 large temples, 136 courtyards, residential structures, and more.
You have to visit this place asap, you will be enchanted!! I couldn’t close my mouth because i was shocked, i dont know what kind of talent that they have about handicrafts!! Superb

After getting help with directions from our hotel staff, we traveled by public transportation out to Patan Durbar Square. The bus ride itself was an interesting experience in itself and many locals were able to assist us during the trip. Patan is another World Heritage site that is a must see if visiting Kathmandu. You can see by the architecture and building layout that the city was very wealthy during it's day. Even now the buildings have been restored to their original elegance. Of particular note is the Ancient Royal Palace that includes meticulous carvings and reflects the architecture of the ancient Newar peoples. There are a variety of temples to visit and explore throughout Patan while wandering along the side streets.

column7: Excellent Showcase of Newar Architecture and Culture
column8: Patan Durbar Square, despite being the smallest of the three in the Kathmandu Valley, leaves one of the best impressions and is definitely one of the better-managed historical sites in the area.  Damages from the earthquake have been almost completely restored, and the square offers a great museum with access to most of the palace. While it still has its share of merchants a guides who will solicit you, they're not too intrusive and theres much less of it than a lot of other sites. Garbage and graffiti are controlled better here, its less crowded, and the site offers many things to see. You can easily spend hours here. The entry fee is 1000 rupees but what you get for it makes it feel dignified.  If that weren't enough, the surrounding neighborhood of Lalitpur is very charming and offers a lot of old architecture mixed in with newer restaurants and bars, its a lovely area. I can strongly recommend spending a day in and around the Patan Durbar Square.

Patan's Durbar Sq did not suffer as much damage as Kathmandu in 2015 earthquake and as a result, despite smaller, has more intact buildings. 1000R ticket includes admission to museum. A taxi from Thamel will run between 500 - 700Rs. Not as many tour guides as KTM but not as necessary due to information handout and interesting museum, which is worth it alone. Although small, the museum breaks down identifying diety poses and meanings & contains beautiful artifacts.

A must visit when visiting Kathmandu. It is easy to come from Kathmandu which we did a day trip combined with Bhaktapur Durbar Square for a morning half day trip for about 6 hours (including 1 hour lunch) with a negotiated price arranged with taxi driver through our hotel - Bodhi Boutique Hotel at Thamel district. The taxi fare for the entire trip was NPR 2,500 for the entire 6 hours. After double checked with hotel staff for the rough guide of taxi fare, single trip from Thamel to Baktapur cost NPR 1,000 (45 mins journey) and single trip from Baktapur to Patan is NPR500-600 (35 mins journey) plus single trip from Patan to Kathmandu is NPR500 (20 mins journey). Hence, the additional NPR400-500 is for the waiting time, depending on negotiation with driver. Unlike Baktapur Durbar Square, there are many entry points to Patan Durbar Square since the square is not fully fenced. There will be many security personnels with uniforms walking around to identify foreign tourists and bring them to ticketing office to pay for the tickets that cost NPR 1,000 per person per entry. We thought it was a scam initially, but soon we discovered that it is how it works when visiting to Patan Durbar Square. Locals are allowed to enter the square free of charge. The entrance fee is inclusive of the museum right in front of the square with good introduction and information about Hinduism history and culture in Patan (Latlipur). There are some interesting collections of the Hindu and Buddhist Gods statues, such as Shiva, Krishna, etc. The Square was a typical Newar Achitecture with beautiful wooden carvings, Hindu idols, etc. One of the highlights is the ancient royal palace where Malla Kings of Latlipur resided. We also saw the local devotees carried out the prayer rituals which was an interesting cultural sights. It is one of the three Durbar Squares (including Kathmandu & Baktapur) in the Kathmandu Valleys which is the UNESCO World Heritage Site that is under the threat of earthquake especially the most destructive volcanic eruption in 2015. Restoration effort is ongoing to preserve these valuable historical and cultural site.

column7: Must to be visited during your stay in Kathmandu
column8: Patan Durbar Square is a UNESCO Listed World Heritage Site in Nepal. It is a very popular & beautiful place for sightseeing tour. The beauty, architecture, surroundings, restaurants around & the local typical foods available there attracts every visitors once who visit here. It is a touristic place. You can find many shops here where you can do shopping of typical local items of Nepal. I highly recommend each & every people who are in a visit to Nepal to visit Patan Durbar Square once.

Went here with my guide and she explained everything about old and new. The square has many stories, not just the earthquake in 2015! Highly recommend a visit. I read people complaining about the 1000N$ (€3.50, U$3) and wonder why such complaints are written, considering you'll pay more for a rubbish coffee at Starbucks! Pay the same amount, go in and make sure you visit the Patan palace museum, beautiful and calm cafe inside for a relaxing drink. Enjoy!

we went to the Nepal last April 2019 for Everest base camp trek and I had a 2 day extra so we went to see the historical patan durbar square which is located in the center of Lalitpur district. A traditional Newari city patan has a unique traditions as well as identity. As we were with my tour guide we were lucky to know most of the things that patan durbar square has. The Main durbar square is so unique with its wooden architecture as you see there so much wood work everywhere. The main house used to be the living place of the Malla Kings family in the past and there are many courtyard and Chowk inside. All of this Chowk has it’s own significance. Siddhi Narsingh Malla was the king who built many temples and part of durbar in 17th Century B.C. Krishna Temple was the another attraction over that squre which is built by the stone only in sikhara style which took 25 years to build by King Siddhi Narsingh Malla.
