The place also popular for buddhisim as there are a lot of sakya family and it has a lot of Boudha Bihar. Hiranya Barna Mahavihar is one of the popular. Overall our experience to patan was great with my guide Sabin as I learned many things. I tried the Newari food which was awesome but quite spicy. You must visit patan if you are coming to Nepal. Highly Recommended.

The 600 year old royal palace is open 24 hours. The pagoda like beautiful structures with intricate wood carving are lighted up at night.  People of all ages flock the square, and for the natives, drinking tea there is a trend.  One can spot tea vendors, balloon sellers and souvenir stalls in the courtyards. It also has excellent roof top restaurants.  The complex has beautiful museums. The worn out bricks tell the story of how long they lay there, while the complex as a whole depict the grandeur of royal lifestyle in ancient times.

I visited here when in Kathmandu. It’s pretty much in Kathmandu, just of the “other” side of the river. It’s a UNESCO spot and totally deserving! Much of it has been rebuilt exactly as it was before the earthquake in 2015, using the same materials as they used originally!  I had a guide and was grateful. He showed me little details, explained the religions and philosophy of the people there. A great area with “museums” in the buildings. If you get a guide, get a licensed one, one whose studied and is local!  Lots of nice restaurants and shops around it.

column7: One of the 3 Durbar Squares in the Kathmandu valley
column8: Had visited this historic square in Patan a long back ago. This square is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and is popular tourist attraction.  This historic square is visited by locals as well as foreign tourists. It is full of Hindu temples and Buddhist monuments. One of the main attractions is an ancient royal palace where the Malla Kings of Lalitpur resided. However, it was destroyed by an earthquake in 2015. Currently, it is rebuilt and under restoration. There is an entry fee for visiting this square. It is also one of the 3 Durbar Squares in the Kathmandu valley. Photography is allowed.  This historic square is an ideal place for history lovers. It is a must visit place and should not be missed while in Patan.

column7: The most charming Durbar Square of Kathmandu valley!
column8: Patan(Lalitpur) is right across the holy river of Bagmati from Kathmandu city. In the heart of old town we have a magnificent palace and 9 different temples.Collectively it is known as Patan Durbar Square.It reflects the skill and craftsmanship of the Malla period(1200 to 1768 A.D.). The natives,known as Newars have carved exquisite wooden windows and amazing stone temples and statues all around. The Keshav Narayan chowk(courtyard) has a museum that was set up by Smithsonian Institute.It is now partially damaged by 2015 earthquake but renovation is going on at full speed and everything should be ready in about a year. The inner garden has a delightful cafe as well. This part of the palace was renivated by the Austrian government(1983-1997). The Mul chowk(Central courtyard) and the private bath/ritual courtyard were done by US,UK,Nepalese and Japanese help. The Mul chowk has statues of the Ganges and Yamuna river with some fine wooden struts (with original colors) dating back to 17th century. The private bath complex is the oldest part of the palace dating back to 1610 A.D.It now has a gallery open with some frescoes.The inner garden area is a currently a workshop for woodcarvers (for renovation purpose) and it also has a lily pool with some stone figures. The main golden door leading to Keshav narayan chowk is flanked by two wooden benches where seniors sit and talk about nostalgia. Next to it is a water spout dating back to 570 A.D. and has two small resthouses. Bang infront of the golden gate is the stone temple of Krishna,the 1st Shikara style temple of the valley. The shiva temple next to it has some extraordinary wooden struts. The surrounding area has some restos and a small flea market and some souvenir shops. Just a minute away from Bhimsen temple in a back alley is Om handicraft which is fixed price and has some quality products. Overall the Patan Durbar Square is a wonderful area to visit.
It's one of the must visit place in Kathmandu. There are many beautiful palaces, temples and squares. its very important place to understand culture history arts and architecture .

June 6 2019 was the second time I visited Patan Durbar Square after 5.5 years ago before the 2015 massive earthquake; fortunately most of the structures are intact & not destroyed by the catastrophe ~  The entrance fees is 1,000 Nepali Rupees for foreigners & children under 10 is free. We hired a guide this trip and it’s worth it, we managed to see some places which we didn’t get to see the last time & the guide Jay did a good job in explaining the history & background of the square.  I must compliment the architectures especially the bathing pool of the Queen, it’s so beautifully crafted!  All in all, this is a place not to be missed if you visit Kathmandu :)

In my opinion a must see during a trip to Nepal! Even better than Kathmandu's Durbar Square and even if the earthquake damaged some of the shrines and buildings the magic of this place is still intact. Very interesting also the visit to the inner courtyards and small museums (included in the entrance fee) hosted in the buildings on the right side of the square. Good info and detailed leaflet about other attractions located in Patan, not far from Durbar.

I was on a solo trip to Nepal earlier this year in January. Basically I wanted to explore and run some rivers on my Kayak. But during my visit there, I was told to visit this place by a friend. Just how wonderful Patan Durbar square is for a traveller to experience some of the tradition & heritage structures of Nepal. the oldest of the three cities in the Kathmandu valley. The square is made up of 136 courtyards and 55 temples. It was destroyed by earthquake few years back and some places are still under maintenance & rebuilding stage. However all the structures are amazing, heritage Hindu kingdom. There are a number of historic temples & they include some extraordinary erotic carvings on one of the temples in a traditional South Asian style. The Patan Museum is also simply amazing. Also the Mahabuddha temple is an easy walk from here. You might get lucky to witness some religious processions and performances in the square as well. Supposedly these are fairly regular. So if you want to time your visit accordingly may be you can contact the tourist office before visiting. As I was alone and also less crowd during the morning visit, I got absorbed and felt so spiritual. There is so much ancient culture in this thriving and beautiful place.  This is a must visit place for all travellers to Nepal. I ticked off another beautiful destination on my unknown places bucket list :)  I bow down to this land and the people of this land who have built & preserved this gem of a place for the world to experience.

Patan is very famous for traditional architectural buildings that reassembles the history of country. It is one of the three durbar squares in Kathmandu valley. And a must visit place in patan and don't forget to try newari cusines when you are around this place.

column7: excellent walking adventure around Lalitpur and Patan Durbar Square
column8: As most Durbar squares in Nepal, we paid 1000 rupees. Most of the buildings are still under reconstruction but you can still admire the beauty of the Newari architecture.  We practically spent the whole day from mid morning until around six pm walking around the square and the side alleys of Lalitpur.  Try to avoid the evening as it is chaotic with all the cars, motorbikes and people walking around unless that is what you’re looking for.  The ticket gives you access to the museum which is a great way to learn about Buddhism and Hinduism through the sculptures, there is also a cafe inside. This was once part of the royal palace.  Avoid the museum shop which is extremely expensive and costs more than three times the prices of the shops around the town.  The square itself is very impressive with beautiful ancient buildings, a lot of buildings are still inaccessible due to the post earthquake reconstruction but the photo opportunities are constant.  The Newari architecture is phenomenal and the intricacy and detail of the arts and crafts is definitely something that is lacking within first world countries. The buildings in the adjacent streets and squares are stunning.  With incredible Stupas and shrines popping up in every corner and back street between houses and shops that have been there for centuries with most intact.  We encountered numerous Newari women working incessantly in the rebuilding of the area, carrying very heavy brick bags over their heads.  The streets are perfect for a shopping day with very impressive wood, metal and clay works available along with Mandala and Thaka art. Costing upwards of 1500 rupees for a student painting.  Barter for prices and compare one shop to another as some are double the price of others.  The roads are a bit crazy with motorcycles and cars passing all the time in tiny streets. But we felt very safe walking around and no one bothered us at all.  All in all an excellent walking adventure around Lalitpur and Patan Durbar Square.

It was a pity that Patan Durbar Square was mostly under repairs. It was small but one can only imagine the beauty and grandeur before the earthquake. We spent some time in the museum appreciating the centuries old religious statues. An unexpected plus point was buying a beautiful Thangka painted by a master from the Tibeyan Thangka Buddhist Painting School and managed bargained it down to the price we had in mind. Spent an hour there learning how to differentiate between a student, professional and master painted Thanka, which was really educational and makes you appreciate the time and detailed work that goes into one. Now we have a beautiful momento to remind us of Nepal.

column7: UNESCO World Heritage Site in central Kathmandu
column8: Patan Durbar Square is an amazing treasure trove of Buddhist and Hindu temples, statues, and museums. It was substantially damaged in the 2015 earthquake, but repairs are underway. Absolutely beautiful, unique sights everywhere. The area can be toured in about 30 minutes, but if you have more time, there are several museums to check out. Lots of places to sit and have a coffee, shop, and enjoy the ambiance as well. It was an easy walk from my hotel, a wonderful quick sightseeing trip on last day of my business trip to Kathmandu.

column7: A rich of culture place need to be seen once being in Nepal
column8: I am not lucky but lucky to be able to visit this place after the terrified earthquake in 2015. A lot of renovation, construction works are going on. Though, I still found the squares being so charming. If time allow, I wish I could spend a whole day there just to look at the sparkling architectures, or listening to the whistling of the pigeons mixing with the noises from crows and the ring from the bells and the murmur of prayers arounds the temples. It is so unique and peaceful.

Okay, so the gaye isn't great but if you have walked out here then at least you've got away from most of the tourists and seen a bit of Patan. Carry on down the road (past the bus station) for 5 minutes. Via left and you come to a lovely little cafe (Cafe Cheeno) and just past it a big shopping mall.
Patan is my born place. Patan is one of most cultural and ancient city in Kathmandu valley. You will be great visiting the temples, stupas and durbar square in Patan.

column7: A Tacky Old Gate Without Much Class
column8: This is not the best part of Patan or a very classy exit or entrance but it is there and allows you in and out. At some stage it make have looked spectacular but not so much now.

column7: Historic Entry to Rich Cultural Monuments
column8: This place shows the historic importance of monuments. It consists of multiple arts representation cultural and traditional background of that particular area with its own historic identity and significance. Gate also shows the primitive design concept and art of thinking.

This was one of the most iconic place in Patan but now its nothing more than a big gate which looks old and dirty. I think Nepal Government needs to wake up and do something about it. And there are too many street vendors around.

If you want to have an idea of what real Patan looks like i recommand you to spend some time around Patan Dhoka. If you take the road from the post office you'll find a lot of tiny local restaurant here you can eat the daal bath for a very very small price (and trust me it's delicious !) In addition, here you can find the bus terminal to go to Kathmandu.
The historic gate marks the starting point of Patan. An arched gate that is of historic significance. However, there is a bus stop nearby which makes this place easily accessible from Kathmandu.

Beautiful gate between the old Patan and Kathmandu, also, a good place to visit on a "shopping day": next to a big bookstore (as I was told by local, but it was closed on that day) not too far from 3 fairtrade souvenir shops (on the main road going down into Kathmandu).
It's just something that you might pass on your way. There is certainly no reason to make any effort to see it. It's not ancient or anything.

The whole Durbar quarter is an absolute must, and although some of the area has been damaged by the earthquake of a few years ago, it's still somewhere well worth visiting. The buildings, carvings, and treasures are superb.

the royal palace in Batan is a big building, which is really beautiful inside and is really worth a visit. We were almost the lonely people inside so we could take some nice pictures of this old palace.

Its a strange experience to visit the palace. it seems like abandoned places, but still with some staff. Its dirty, dusty and the area where the shooting took place, strangely kept. As a backyard with no history.

column7: Just like they left it. Gives you a 1980's feel
column8: If you remember visiting your grandparents home when you were a kids. This will remind you of it. A very large private home/palace that still has the rotary phones and manual TV's. I was surprise that the ground and property are not being well maintained and the area of the killing of the royal family is still closed. Worth seeing for the historic aspect. Worth seeing .
This palace is located in the Patan darbar area. This is an Ancient palace with terracotta artifacts.

What a treat to have a yoga session with Kanchan! He his passionate, brilliant and a fantastic yoga teacher. Being Canadian, this was the first time that I was exposed to « real » yoga. Strongly recommended!

Namaste 🙏🏻  We had the great pleasure to meet with Kanchan in Kathmandou and to experience his talent for Yoga & Meditation 🧘‍♂️. On top of being an amazing human filled with kindness and happiness, Kanchan is very knowledgeable on the ancient techniques and is very good in transmitting the message. His track record, hard work and connection to the universe make him a wonderful encounter. We went back home with some good messages that we will put into practice. We HIGHLY recommend him.  Thanks a lot Kanchan, we hope to see you soon!  Driss & Henri.

column7: Good place to be humble and learn
column8: Classes are great with the perfect blend of different yoga styles, even for the beginners. Our teacher Kanchan sir is exceptionally encouraging and comforting. He brings out the strength in everyone. The best thing is everyone feels at peace by the end of class and that is what a yoga class should do. It really is true spiritual practice.

column7: Perfect for beginners class, Taught by true yogi kanchan jee 😊
column8: It was my first time for yoga in kathmandu. I was quite nervous as I was the beginner here. Our guru kanchan jee made me feel comfortable and told me how to work with my body's flexibility as I was very new to yoga. He taught me the basic concept of yoga and how it helps to control mind, body and spirit. Moreover, he is very friendly guru and he treats every student's like his friend and understand their flaws in every postures. If you are in ktm ( Patan ) and are looking for a worthy beginner class, KANCHAN YOGA is the right place. Highly recommended!

column7: A unique yogi from the Himalaya!!!
column8: Growing up in a yogic family in a small village in the Himalaya, Kanchan really internalized yoga in his blood. He provides authentic teachings of hatha and Ashtanga yoga and know all secret corners and treks in the Nepali Himalaya. Apart from this, he is a brilliant and exhilarating character! Very visionary and creative! We did a lot of yoga practice together. I would say he is a unique yoga teacher!

Kanchan is an inspiring yoga teacher and yogi. Many people can teach a great yoga class, and he is definitely one of them - but what makes Kanchan unique is his personal connections to and understanding of each of his students as individuals. As a “real” yogi, I think that’s something that’s very important to him as opposed to simply teaching yoga – and that’s what makes him special. He made my time in Kathmandu fulfilling in a way it wouldn’t have otherwise been, and I wish I could join one of his retreats and practice with him regularly! Anyone who is lucky enough to be in Kathmandu or Patan should definitely take his classes!

column7: Private yoga lessons for my unstretchy self.
column8: I spent about 3 weeks in Nepal where I had the absolute pleasure of having one to one classes with Kanchan. I’ve never really done any yoga before and learnt a great deal from him. He was such a darling to talk to and felt so comfortable with him. It was my first big trip on my own so was grateful for his friendship and teachings. I hope to come back some day! Just a few tips on the studio. The traffic is shocking and can seem dangerous! So give the teachers some time as it’s very easy to get caught up in it and they can possibly be late. But they’re SO worth it. Thank you so much Kanchan ☯️

In Durbar Square. Aside from staying in a beautiful and ancient architectural building, the staff are the warmest and most accommodating. The Inn is very clean and the rooms are so unique. Despite the Winter cold, the owner insured that the room remained warm by placing an electric heater in it along with an electric blanket. I love the Inn Patan and will hopefully return again some day.

column7: Wonderfull stay at the Inn Patan
column8: Old authentic newar house few minutes from Dubar square Patan. Quiet courtyard inside with restaurant indoor and outdoor. High level of services . Electric warm bed so confortable . Warm and helpness welcome from the staff.

I stayed at the Inn Patan with my 18 year old daughter. The staff and Inn are both wonderful. They greeted us weary from 24 hours of travel with hot tea and a visit to get to know one another. Each day the staff took care of us. For a mom traveling with a teenage daughter to a new country, they were more than helpful. They communicated well in advance of the trip and answered any questions I had. We were just a block away from the Patan Durbar Square and Patan Museum. I would highly recommend the Inn Patan to anyone who wants to stay in Kathmandu.

I have been attending the studio classes for almost 5 years now and have generally been very pleased with the quality and variety of classes offered.  However, this past weekend I went on my first weekend yoga retreat with Pranamaya and was very impressed. The teachers (Anna and Christin) were excellent. The location, Hattiban, was perfect - surrounded by forest and nature but a bit luxurious too. I thought the retreat was great value for the price, as it included all food, coffee/tea/snacks, accommodation, 6-7 hours of yoga (and a bit of meditation) with a fantastic, experienced teacher, transportation and sauna. On top of it all, it felt really good to focus on mind, body and spirit, and I came back refreshed, happy and with a few new friends. Sign me up for another!

I have been living in Patan for the past year and attending yoga classes at Pranamaya has become part of my daily ritual. My yoga practice has grown and developed tremendously over this time due to the quality of the studio and the caliber of the instructors. I also love the variety of classes the studio offers. There is something for everyone!

column7: Perfect way to end a Nepal visit...
column8: Searching 'yoga in Kathmandu', I found this Yoga Studio and signed up for one of the 3 day yoga retreats. Thought it would be a perfect way to get ready for long plane fights back to Montana.  I was so impressed and happy with the whole event! They provide transport into the walls of the Neydo Monastery compound in Pharping, The wonderful room provided in a very, very nice accodation is right next to the temple and one can hear the music and prayers from your room balcony. The classes were amazing, full of information and sharing of knowledge from our very special instructor, Nicky...it gave me the one thing I had been looking for all over Nepal to take home with me...a real and lasting gift to myself...inspiration for one's yoga practice that money cannot buy!  I will recommend this to anyone looking for a wonderful experience. When I return to Nepal for the 3rd time, this will be at the top of my list.

only another atempt to use foreigners to attract innocent people , they believe they have achieve some kind of qualification after paying for the "Yoga Teacher certicated " Made In India, there is Only two Real things in Yoga.....Guru and Disciple, and neither of them is used here, is just a business, they pay their Yoga Lessons with some pseudo Guru that was using them in Rishikesh and now they believe the can Teach Yoga, Yoga is not a Business, is not assana is not pranayama, is a way of life and it shall be followed with Devotion first of all , Om nama Shivaja

I’ve been visiting this place almost every year over the last decade. Similar to old wine, the place only gets better with age. Wonderful staff and delicious food. Value for money. If you’ve had enough of the restaurants and cafes in Thamel and Jhamsikhel, this...More

column7: Decent place for a quick bite
column8: The place is bang in the middle of the hustle bustle of patan, and parking can be tough to find. However, should you get past all that, the salads at the place is nice, and so is the coffee. Equally enticing is the book store attached to the restaurant where you can spend some time checking out the books. They have a decent collection of books on nepal

I've been several times in the past few weeks and each time I have been more than satisfied. Wide menu, but not so wide that it becomes impossible to provide. Dishes are well prepared and of ample size - I've had the wraps, pork cutlet, chicken salad and some desserts so far and each was at least up to expectation, but generally beyond. Prices are extremely reasonable and service is generally good, though can become a bit backed up during a busy lunch hour. Well worth the visit.

column7: Good experience but not a very special one
column8: this is a typical nepali Café for tourists. The atmosphere is quite nice, very relaxing and calm. The personnal is nice and gentle and will serve you with efficiency and professionalism. Prices are honest for such a place. Personaly i prefer less classy places where i can meet some nepali people and not only tourists.
There's history and there is food. Very good food. Plus beautiful architecture. This is one place that ticks quite a few boxes for the discerning traveller

column7: Tiramisu for the win against the grumpy staff
column8: I have been to Dhokaima a couple of times for lunch and several times for pastry-takeaway.  I find the setting of the cafe to be delightful but the actual thing that keeps me coming back here is the pastry. Tiramisu and chocolate cakes here are the best one could find at a relatively cheaper price.  I was,however,shocked to see preferential treatment of the foreigners versus locals . I wish I could avoid one of the ladies, who did not even manage to return our smiles. The pizza here was also a huge let-down.  If you can manage to overlook these flaws, you will enjoy your visit to this beautiful eatery. 4 stars for the garden and Tiramisu.

I wanted to have some continental meal after daily spicy but good local cuisine. I was surprised of the quality of my Wiener Schnitzel and sauteed vegetables, accompanied by cabbage and apple salad and french fries. I lived in Austria and must admit it was real good! Conclude with a nice Dessert (chocolate cake was delicious) ans a nice Espresso in the yard terrace. Comfortable, good, excellent service. Prices are definitely higher than average (I paid in total about 8 usd) but it's worth it!

Dhokaima Café is located at the gate of Patan, 5 mins towards core Patan..and you come across a great heritage site, many 15th century monuments, Hindu and Buddhist temples, city squares, bahals and the famous Patan Durbar Square.. and the restaurant gives you an insight to all of these..the food is great too! and you have a great bookshop just within the restaurant!! What more can you think of!

column7: Please review your staff hiring process, for at least teach them how to behave with customers!!!
column8: So, i and a friend of mine went to this place to have coffee and a smoke. The waiter told us that, there was no electricity hence no coffee. Hearing this my friend ordered two cups of tea. While we sat, just out of courtesy we ordered a plate of momo so that coming to the place might seem reasonable to them. Up on waiting on for more than 25 mins for a plate of momo, my friend, he asked the manager( he was or not) to cancel the order if it were to take any longer. 10 mins later he turns up with a plate of momo, literally dropped it on our table with a thud and this is what that (floor manager or so) had to say with a condescending tone" We dont have our momos frozen, we make it fresh". Upon seeing the hole patched momo that took freakin 35 mins to cook with that attitude with no more than 10-15 customers in the whole restro, I stood up to pucnh that guy in the face, but maintained by cool and told him that he was insolent , an illiterate to behave like that with the customers.  How can this place hire someone with such behavioral traits. Shame on you 'Dhokai ma Cafe' to not have even care to say sorry to us on his behalf, but stayed quiet. Shame On YOU!!!!

Wow really hard to put into words our experience here. As a chef and a person with a knowledge of the food industry I can honestly say that this was one of the worst dining experiences of my life.  I'll try be brief as I know how essay reviews are to read but seriously what I endured deserve one.  Yer well lovely looking place, nice sounding menu on the mid price range with some really tasty sounding options. Great. Lovely courtyard, perfect.  So my partner ordered the lasagna and I the Chinese inspired mushroom and pak choy. We had a great feeling as a place with great reviews and such a well presented location deserves high expectations. The lasagna came out only slightly warm and the middle still cold and as you can see from the photo not a lot of love to gratinate the cheese on top, a basic for any lasagna. We asked for it to me warmed and knowing a microwave would be the answer and sure enough after 2mins we received it warm of course but as expected the microwaved cheese leaking oil!!! Tasty!  My dish was actually very tasty exept for the 3rd bite including a rock. Okay, this for me is seriously unexectable, it is in no way a mistake, it tell me that the kitchen doesn't wash their pak choy!! This can pass for a street food dish but not a restaurant of this standard.  I called the waiter over, he took the dish away and then brought me the menu.... I of course asked for the manager. To be honest she handled the situation fairly well, after I suggested her to offer me a new complementary dish. The BLT that I ordered was tasty but really nothing special. Besides the fact that after the first bite she came running over to ask if "I loved the new dish." Seeing the waiters and the manager in the reflection standing around the cash register and looking over in my direction and laughing didn't help the already broken trust.  Wouldn't return and if I were you don't bother. Stick to a street side samosa.

column7: Popular with locals and tourists but average food
column8: One of the busier restaurants I ate at and popular to both the tourist and Nepali crowd. I came for lunch and opted to sit on the terrace outside where most of the patrons were seated.  The service here was unfortunately substandard. The staff were slow and unable to keep track of whether or not a table had already had been helped. I waited for a bit before a staff member came to my table to see if I ordered food; I had not, I hadn't even seen a menu yet. Fast forward to getting my menu and deciding which dish I wanted and it was the same process again. After a while someone asked if I had ordered which I was finally able to do.  I ordered a lamb curry/dhal bat specialty of theirs which unfortunately was average at best. The rice was dry and had the texture and taste of being old. The lamb was hard in spots and generally not tender. The lentils and chili were both forgettable.  While it isn't an expensive restaurant, I think you can do better at the same price point somewhere else.

column7: Cafe Plus: historically renovated cafe plus bookstore, research center and small conference venue
column8: The cafe itself is lovely, as many reviewers have already noted, but it's the whole package that makes this place special. As the name of the cafe says, located right at Patan Dhoka--an arched 'Gate' in the historical wall around the old city kingdom of Patan--and under the watchful and creative eyes of an equally historic family of priests and scholars, Dhokaima is the most public meeting point in this beautifully restored compound, which includes not only the cafe, but, as well, three influential scholarly organizations. The oldest of these--Madan Puraskar Pustakalaya--has been preserving and promoting resources in the Nepali language for some sixty years (http://madanpuraskar.org/) and hosts related public events and exhibitions to showcase the collections. The Himal Association, begun as the original Himal magazine in 1987, expanded so much that it outgrew its Patan Dhoka quarters and moved to Lazimpat but it remains still very much a presence, especially in the excellent bookstore adjacent to the cafe. Last, but far from least, is the Social Science Baha, which, with its library, lectures, fellowships, and conferences (including those coordinated with the U.S.-based Association for Nepal and Himalayan Studies), makes the Dokhaima compound a pivotal place for both local and foreign Nepali-centric scholars.

column7: Great oasis at the edge of Patan
column8: Good food, nice cosy bar (try the hot rum punch with Khukri Rum), good coffee, and reasonable prices. The Momos are fab. Just a 5 minute walk from the labyrinthine gullies of historic Patan.

When I was first recommended to this restaurant by the guest house where I was staying I was anxious to see what all the hubbub was about. When I arrived to the address I wasn't sure if I was going to go in because the outside was very non descriptor. Once you get past the front door a beautifully decorated lobby entrance led to a wonderfully landscaped garden area where there were about 15 tables. I had to wait 15 minutes for a table because this was obviously a popular place especially for tourists. I ordered the special Nepalese meal that had a perfect amount of spices and texture. I ordered a coffee latte that was served hot. The wi-fi was available but didn't seem to work. But, that was the only glitch.

column7: One of the best restaurant in Nepal
column8: the restaurant located at Patan (Lalitpur), which personally felt that it's the least touristy/authentic/beautiful heritage town compared with Bakhtapur and Thamel. The restaurant is located just beside Patan gate, and serve very decent Newari and western cuisine in very reasonable price. My favorite, the brownies...More

column7: A really nice place to eat a traditional Newari Thali
column8: Though a multi cuisine restaurant, Dhokaima has a really nice Newari Thali that is worth trying out. Dhokaima (and the adjoining Yala Maya centre) has really great ambience, and its a perfect place to sit out in the open and grab some Kathmandu sun

located in the old town of patandhoka...this place has such a certain warm kind of ambiance to it with such good food and even better deserts and pastries, a haven for people who'r looking a quite place to sit down grab a book or magazine.

Easy to find at the north gate. Had a lunch and a dinner there while on a short stay in Patan. Lunch was very nice- warm, sunny day sitting outside in the courtyard garden. Lots of sun or shade options. Wifi and newspapers available. Pleasant staff, pretty quick service. Extensive menu. Opted for a sandwich and cappuccino after 5 weeks of trekking type food- very good! Almost the best coffee to date for this trip- I'd go back for that alone. Chocolate cake was watery- ? Frozen/defrosted but still hit the spot. Free filtered water. Dinner was fine- different atmosphere. It had been raining and was quite cool so we sat inside- not as nice as the day time experience. Can recommend the spaghetti with pesto. Apparently outside toilets very clean, can't say the same for the inside one- dirty, with Mosquitos buzzing around. I had difficulty rating this cafe for my review- for day time cake and coffee i'd say very good, but for a dinner experience - Average.

I love this restaurant. It's one of my favorite in Patan. You can eat inside, but the real fun is being outside in the garden. Just on the other side of the brick wall Patan bustles away. But inside the walls, the bamboo and umbrellas are so soothing...  The absolute best thing here are the Mojitos. Made with fresh mint grown on the grounds and often picked AFTER you order! What could be fresher than that! I love the Mojitos so much that after an absence of 11 months, the bartender immediately recognized me upon my return.  The momos (veg and chicken) are also quite good with some nice spicy, flavorful dipping sauces. And I love the spring rolls. The chicken tandoori sandwich with mango chutney is a bargain. The spinach pasta is bland, but fine.  And the banana and apple/mango spring roll dessert with ice cream is quite good as well.  The prices are a little higher than some other places, but the food is much better than the typical tourist restaurant in Patan Durbar Square. I would highly recommend anyone visiting the area stop by here before or after for lunch or dinner.  Any taxi driver can find it, just ask to be taken to Patan Dhoka (Gate). The cafe is right next to the old Patan city gate. And there are always taxis outside in the square if you need a ride afterwards (even at night).  Enjoy!

column7: Gorgeous Elephant statues , beautiful ancient temple
column8: Two elephant statues on the stairs of an old beautiful temple, are located in Patan (Lalitpur) Darbar marg.
Amazing architecture, the damage from the earthquake is still being dealt with, but in order to preserve the historical integrity, i guess taking your time is important

column7: Cone pizza is the must try
column8: I went to this cafe month ago. Cone pizza is the must try in this cafe wheareas bakery iteams is not so good. My friend and I ordered some cakes along with my absolute favorite food (chicken mo:mo) and they were average. The place overall...More

We stopped for a quick lunch before visiting Patan's Durbar Square; this traditional (but very touristic) restaurant is very near to the beautiful square and has a similarly beautiful location. The food was nice - we had Dhal Bhat - and the service kind and...More
Found unknown object in coffee. None of the staff knows what it is. My experience says small cockroach. Manager can only say sorry

column7: Food was fine, but tried to steal our money when paying on card
column8: Simple meal was fine and reasonably-priced but ruined by appalling dishonest service by one member of staff.  However, upon leaving, we tried to pay our bill of R555, and were told we couldn’t pay on card because the machine didn’t accept MasterCard. (This was a lie as we had been there 2 days previous to this incident and paid on Mastercard.) The woman on reception basically ignored us, answering the phone on two separate occasions when she was apparently serving us. When she eventually did let us try our card, she swiped it and typed in R5,555.55 instead of R555 and pressed enter to put it through. I pressed cancel to no avail, so pulled the cord out of the wall to make sure we weren’t charged and we left without paying.  We did return later and paid for our meal, directly to the manager and made our situation known. It was a real shame as the service from the two young men who had served us at our table was attentive and friendly.

We noticed they served the Mo Mo per 8 pieces instead or the traditional per 10 pieces. The food was ok. The wait staff were friendly. Nice little quaint cafe thats very clean and cozy to eat at. Love the location next to Patan Durbar Square. Since we came during Dashain Festival. It was convenient that the place was open. The price of the place is for tourists. Spent about 1600 rupees for me and my wife. Service charge was 10 percent

went with my two year old daughter and she had a blast looking at the decor. we had a nice time here for a late morning snack. the chocolate cake was moist and served warm so you could see the steam as you cut into it - perfect for a crisp morning. the egg sandwich was nice and hot (albeit a tiny bit salty). the enclosed outdoor courtyard is very clean and quite pretty. I was happy enough with the e pertinence to bring some croissants back to my husband!

One who like traditional food of Kathmandu Valley may try to visit this restaurant. They have floor sitting arrangements n cosy arrangements for family members. Food quality , test, price n service is good. Beside traditional cuisine they serve continental n Chinese food as well. Restaurant is located quite near to patan durbar square.

column7: Average food, ok atmosphere, ok staff
column8: In spite of references in a few travelbooks we did not experience anything special at Cafe de Patan. The tastes of our Newari traditional vegetarian dish (a set menu composed of several snacks in the menu) did not blend, the food did not seem to be prepared with care and presentation does not look in anyway like the photo's presented by management on their site.Not worth visiting again.

column7: Romantic place in the romantic Patan!
column8: Cafè de Patan is located a few step from Durbar square,is the perfect place to relax,eat some genuine nepali and newari food but also western cousine in a really nice atmosfere;the menu is a little more expensive in front of the rest of patan but you can do it( a momo is 130 rps in front of 50-60 that you pay on street).It's one of the few place that serve food after 8pm but not too much after... At the end of the meal i suggest a shot of Ayla the traditional newari drink!
really well decorated &good foods in traditional nepaly way.

column7: Great Cafe in Patan and awesome Staff!
column8: Lovely place to have lunch on a sunny afternoon with a clear view towards some of the old buildings from the outdoor seats. I had chosen a secluded spot to dine in order to have some privacy from the crowd dining at the cafe. I was served by Pawan and he went all out to make sure I was dutifully served by checking in regularly to see if I need anything else to be served (the seat location was well concealed by some landscape features so he needed to make effort to get to me). Awesome service it was! The food was nicely prepared and delicious too. Definitely one of the place to enjoy a good meal and quiet break from the bustling city.

column7: Good food, not very original but good enough !
column8: We had lunch after visiting the museum, food was good, missing a bit of originality but we enjoyed it...

Well, tried their kwati soup, its very bland. For main course we tried red curry vegetables and veg grilled sandwich, their vegetables are frozen, no taste at all. However their only good point is the area, they are very lucky to have it and they need to do some justice to it.. please..not going again, definitely not for food. Price is pricy, service is good though..

column7: A True Breakout Space in a Garden
column8: This wonderful open air garden cafe, sits within trees, bushes and flowers. There are pergolas and pavilions allowing dining under shade. The food is simple, tasty and healthy! I enjoyed the traditional Nepali thali with rice, dal, vegetables and mutton! When you visit the Patan Darbaar Square, end your visit the Museum Cafe. The photo image on the back page of my book LETTERS TO A YOUNG ARCHITECT was taken in this garden restaurant! See amazon -

column7: Excellent stopover for lunch/tea/dinner after exploring Durbar Square!
column8: We visited this cafe as we were wandering through the museum bldg. at Patan Durbar Square in late December 2015. The cafe has a wonderful ambience, set in a garden-style outdoor environment. The damaged Krishna temple can be clearly seen from the cafe. The food choices were good. We had traditional Nepali tea, coffee and toast here. All were tasty. But we regretted not having had lunch there; there were plenty of choices to choose from: Nepali veg and non-veg thalis (set menus), momos (dumplings), sandwiches, fries, etc. Prices were also reasonable.  Overall, a great spot for a meal!
A traditional setting like no other at the back of the historic museum. Very pleasant garden. Very quiet and relaxing. Food OK

The location inside the old palace complex gardens is perfect for a restaurant. It is vey easy to sit and enjoy the view while munching on momos. The food is done by Summit Hotel and the quality is very good.

This is a nice restaurant located right at the back of Patan Museum. Ambience is lovely, set in a garden, with a view of the old palace. We had some mains and were not impressed, I think better stick with some light sandwiches and rest sipping a drink.

We came across this cafe by chance while my husband and I were taking a walk in the Durbar Sqaure. Their service is simply brilliant and the food was awesome. As I prefer spicy food, I made a request to them to make my dish extra spicy and that is exactly what I got. The food was so enjoyable!  This is situated in Durbar Square. However, it is quite quiet and you can get the meal and the rest that you so need by that time of the day after walking through the ancient cities. This is undoubtedly one of the best cafes that I visited in Nepal!

We were really looking forward to returning to Cafe Swotha after our stay in Traditional Homes Swotha back in 2013 when we pretty much had most of our meals here. We were delighted to see that the dining room is still intimate and modern, with...More

column7: Impeccably decent and clean eatery just off of the mayhem
column8: Our expedition around the UNESCO region of Patan was chaotic and total bombarded our senses ... we were exhausted from batting off beggars and Con-artists seeing us walking through and seeing dollar signs. We turned a corner and found this little place twinkling in white fairy lights. The familiarity of the fairy lights enticed me in. I was on guard Incase it was another lure under false pretences, but I was pleasantly surprised. Kind hospitable waiters attentively serving each table and making every one of the guests feel welcomed and appreciated. Their level of English was impeccable and their class of service. The restaurant had traditional music piping through at optimum level. Table spacing was decent too with the bustle of the restaurant thriving the atmosphere yet, impossible to over hear conversations as they haven’t greedily packed out the venue. Fresh carnations upon every table, with clean table cloths laid neatly and considerately. The place is a dream and totally transformed our day! The food was beautifully presented and well portioned. Prices are more than fair and printed on the menu (so no need for the tiresome bartering!) come here when you come to Patan. It will make your entire trip feel more calm and beautiful. It will also make you realise that not all Nepalese are out to make money off of you without giving back! Really. The most memorable dining experience of Patan.

I ordered some gnocchi that were not very good, but with it we were given some water. I asked if it was filtered water and they said it was...I just spend a night with fever and was not able to do my sightseeing.  Also the prices posted outside are lower than the actual menu. The just say “those are the old prices”

I was attracted by the signage of this cafe so chose to follow the sign down a narrow lane that led to this cafe. It forms part of a restored traditional Newari residence that is now a bed and breakfast. We had a light snack of hummous and baba ganoush served with small triangles of warmed pitta for 500 rupees. I had a masala tea and a refreshing minty lemon soda whilst relaxing in the secluded courtyard. I was most interested in viewing one of the rooms but sadly they were all occupied, however, the brochure shows fabulously spacious suites and several of the rooms were priced at $80. Pity I didn't get to see one! I probably wouldnt have come back to my house that evening.

Sat at a tiny table in the tiny courtyard in the dappled sunlight listening to birds and very distant traffic of patan. A glass of Chardonnay and and outstanding sundried tomato and olive gnocchi! An awesome change from the amazing Nepali and Hindi curries ive devoured for past 5 days. Excellent service, reasonable prices. Cheaper wine by the glass than in thamel or bhouda.

column7: Nice cafe/lunch place near Patan Durbar Square
column8: Very nice food from a limited menu perfect for a quick lunch break when visiting Patan or a coffee break to rest your legs. Friendly staff and efficient service in a nicely renovated old traditional newari home. Don’t miss it!

column7: My favorite place for food in Old Patan
column8: I spent a few months living in Old Patan and Swotha was my to-go venue for breakfast meeting or just to enjoy a good coffee. My favorite spot! Great garden with a cozy feeling, delicious bread, good quality coffee.

column7: Cool little oasis tucked away from the chaos of Durbar Square in Patan
column8: Easy to see why this is an expat favorite. Tucked into a narrow side street, away from the chaos of the Square, with simple, chic inside seating, as well as a little walled garden area. Menu is very limited, but the food was great in terms of quality and taste. Not a traditional Nepali restaurant, in fact, it was only foreigners eating there when we went, but the ambience is really nice if you need a sanctuary from the bustle of Kathmandu for a few hours. Very efficient service too.

Tucked away on one of the streets leading away from the bustling Durbar Square in Patan, this cafe is part of the larger traditional guest house set-up and offers a sense of calm and peace with a little garden all to itself. Food was delicious and we got to sample the local Nepali thali which was served in a lovely bronze/brass set of cutlery. Their pasta was amazing too. Sankar, the lone waiter, is polite, helpful and brisk with his ability run the place well. The pricing is definitely upscale compared to the smaller cafes in Patan but worth a visit for some peace and flavors.

column7: Romantic Café in the heart of Patan Durbar Square
column8: We loved the tea and pastries we ordered from this café. We just chanced upon this spot as we took this quiet side street in the heart of this UNESCO world heritage site. Will definitely come back and even try the guest house connected to the café as well.

column7: Great place, middle of Old Patan, very good food
column8: I am coming again and again in cafe Swotha, and it remains a great place to relax, eat simple food, enjoy the area, feeling mindful and zen....
Had a pleasant dinner with my wife. The food is really nice. Highly recommended. The cafe itself is a renovated old style Newari house, which gives you an authentic Experience

Located very near to the historic Patan Durbar Square, inside a small alley, Cafe Swotha is a good place to dine out with your family and loved ones.  It's little bit cozy so don't plan your big gatherings here but a great place to enjoy your evenings as the big hanging lamps catches your eyesight from a distance. Good food, good service, a tourist accomodation too. Has a traditional touch to the interiors, serves European food and Nepali food. You can plan your stay if you are visiting Patan.

Just one block of the northern end of Durbar Square near Swotha Square you will find this gem of a cafe / restaurant. Great food, pleasant staff and nice modern atmosphere. A nice alternative to what is on offer around this upcoming area of Patan. Not that well signposted but is at the end of a short lane on your right as you pass the souvenir shops. The "Melting Pot' craft shop is on the corner of the lane. Definitely worth a visit!

column7: Glad we found this small restaurant.
column8: Friends suggested we find this little place just one block off the square, and we were glad we did. Very helpful and child friendly staff, and a traditional menu with something for everyone - also good cold beer. The trip to the loo was slightly hazardous without a torch. Would recommend this cafe that also offers accommodation, though I have no first hand knowledge about this.

column7: Love the good n beverage with silent environment
column8: Definately worth it...Great ambience...quite...friendly staff(well disciplined)...Nepali Thali..worth the taste of Nepali cuisine...exotic point for expats and tourist...
Wonderful, creative refitting of old Newari house. Nepal needs more of these projects. Menu nice mix of options. I have had their Nepali thali and their gnocchi. Both delicious.

This is a very special boutique hotel and cafe/restaurant hidden just out of sight of the bustle of Patan Darbar Square. Extremely well managed, reasonably priced and pleasant. The decor takes full advantage of traditional architecture but with all amenities.

My wife and I ate here for a few nights while staying at Traditional Homes, above the restaurant. This place is more than a cafe. It has great dinner, excellent service and drinks, and reasonable prices. Staff are willing to accommodate special requests. We especially enjoyed having fresh, green organic salads, with more than just iceburg lettuce! Deserts are fantastic too (apple crumble and cheesecake recommended).

I spent two weeks in Patan and this restaurant and its sister, Cibo Bistro, became my two favorite places to eat. I was lulled back over and over by the soups: potato and carrot, zucchini and carrot, cream of tomato…all served with a slice of brown bread that was some of the best brown bread I had in the entire country. Plus it was the first café I came to trust with fresh salad, i.e. organic greens, sundried tomatoes, black and green olives, and a light dressing. Nearly every day if not every other day, I came in and sat at what I deemed “the Chef’s table”, i.e. one of the barstools in the front entry way. The guys that work there are so sweet and if you’re traveling alone, strike up a conversation. These guys (3 of which are in their early 20s) are pretty outstanding in making your wishes come true. One day I wanted a mulled wine (hot wine) and boom – they served one up though it wasn’t on the menu. Another day I really was craving avocado and shazam…an avocado salad with olive oil, lemon juice, salt and pepper. It’s a shame that their online presence isn’t more prevalent for the foreigners who search the internet for recommendations because I’d go here any day of the week, (probably every day of the week) if this was a restaurant near my home. And I can guarantee you that if they ever come out with a cook book for soups, I’m the first one to buy in. They put places like Panera, Pret, Eat, etc to shame. Oh and by the way, I had the ham and cheese sandwich twice (yum – real cheese!), the spaghetti Bolognese (fantastic meat sauce), the pepper steak (ok this was alright – not my favorite piece of beef in Nepal – that was in Pokhara, but still good), and they make the best crispy French fries I had locally. And if it helps two big tips: 1. They are open every day 7am-10pm and 2. It’s a bit harder to find as it seems no one ever knows places that are even within a block of them…it’s very close to Café Pagoda in Durbar Sq, Coffee, Tea and Me, and Newa Chen B&B. Sometimes people know Swotha kiosk, but I found that every time I asked about Swotha Sq, not a single local knew what I was talking about. Guys – thanks for making me feel at home, always having a seat available for me, and keeping me company.

This restaurant lives up to the expectations after staying in the B&B Traditional Homes Swotha, to which the restaurant belongs. Dishes cooked to perfection, well balanced tastes and served by knowledgeable and friendly staff. They make you feel welcome and at home. Best on the menu: Nepali Thali, their lassies, cheesecake and rich and creamy chocolate mousse.

This cafe is a great find in the Swotha Traditional Homes Hotel, tucked away only 1min walk from Patan's Durbar Square and on the same street as Hira Guest House. I was wanting good food after trekking for weeks. It did not disappoint. Ordered the Nepalese Thali approx 500Rp and it was fantastic, but a lot more expensive than other places. Came back to try to some of their other dishes that i saw other patrons having. Everything was great. Staff are lovely. I spent some time there using their free Wifi, writing in my journal, eating their wonderful food and felt very at ease. Definitely recommend.

column7: Most delicious meal in amazing setting
column8: This place has it all: 1) most delicious organic food, 2) lovely boutique design, 3) located in the middle (yet very quiet) of the wonderfully atmospheric old Patan neighborhood.

column7: Sweet little place with food you want to eat
column8: We stayed here at the hotel when they were renovating the café and they had a limited menu- so we ended up trying everything. :) Everything we ate was fresh and delicious and original- great when faced with the standard tourist menus again and again. Breakfasts were filling and fresh. Salads were the same. Seems people not staying here come here to eat too- quite a find.
Wonderfully, freshly made food in a mix of fresh local vegetables, fruit and others combined with some European influence. a real oasis within Lalitpur and Kathmandu.

Attached to the gorgeous Swotha Traditional Homes guesthouse the restaurant had the same understated elegance and laid back vibe. It is not cheap but it is lovely simple fresh food and the desserts and cakes were amazing!
A beautifully restored/updated traditional building, with some of the best food in the area. The Gnocchi are really nice.

The Swotha Cafe downstairs from the Traditional homes is where (wait for it), where I had the best food I ate in 3 weeks in Nepal - and I ate some lovely food in Luxury mountain lodges and other hotels. This cafe is the closest you'll get to a french pavement cafe in Nepal, I should think, and when you just want a change from the generally wonderful spicy food, with a simple but delicious pancake or omlette or the amazing chicken skewers then you've found your place. This is THE place to eat in Patan as far as I'm concerned,and I tried a few, as I'm a bit of a foody. I'd enjoyed it so much, I intend to drive from Thamel for a leisurely lunch and to see the Durbar Square (which is in my opinion the best of the 'big 3' Squares) next time I'm in Nepal. Highly Recommended!

column7: Ate some of the best food of our trip here
column8: World class spaghettis. The famous cheesecake is amazing, as is the service. This place was a real treat and highlight. It's tucked down a street off the northern end of Patan Square.
The temple is well maintained and the keepers are friendly. It was late afternoon and was not very busy; I had a pleasant visit.
Workmanship is one of a kind. Everything is Nepal is to be honest. So exotic and different to other places and cultures...

column7: one of the ancient temple in nepal
column8: if you want to learn ancient scripture and sculpture probably this temple is the best one. this temple is 1000 year ago
Really worth to throw an eye into this Golden Temple. A lot of big and small things can be observed, fringed with gold.

column7: Beautiful , Clean , Fascinating and Impressive Golden Temple
column8: We entered Hiranya Varna Mahavihar /.Kwa Bahal / Golden Temple , just at a 5 minutes walkable distance from Traditional Homes SWOTHA where we stayed and from Patan Darbar Square after paying Rs 100 as an entrance fee at 0515 on 15th Nov 2018 . There was a sign board guiding the tourists to enter Hiranya Varna Mahavihar aka Golden Temple guarded by two huge , life size stone lions ( one male another female ) . The temple got this name because of the gold plated pagoda type roof , beautiful golden facade and other golden edifices that adorn the mahavihar . We went there so early to listen to the listened to the sounds of chanting of prayers , revolving prayer wheels , ringing bells , etc .We sat there experiencing divine vibrations for an hour . We took a break of 3 hours and returned at 0945 .  A guide accompanied us around the temple explaining the history and significance of the temple and many figurines , statues and paintings adorning the walls of the temple ,  This three-storey golden pagoda of Shakyamuni Buddha was built in the twelfth century by King Bhaskar Varman .At the entrance , we were confronted by two large brass elephants with riders , as the guardians .The brass and silver doorway was topped by a gorgeous repousse bass relief of the Buddha sitting in the Bhumisparsha mudra flanked by his two disciples , Sariputra and Mudgalayana . Afterwards there was a shrine adorned with a silver and golden chaitya .Behind it , there was a main shrine of Buddha .  Inside the shrine there was the bejewelled Buddha having an elaborate crown on his head . A huge Prabhamandal was intricately carved in gold on his entire body . Outside the shrine a beautifully carved panel showed various life scenes of the Buddha .  The design of the complex represents all the three main vehicles or Yanas of Buddhism . The main shrine represents the basic exoteric Shravakayana , the large Tibetan style image of Amoghapasha Lokeshwara on the first floor is the main Mahayanic deity . On the first floor , the principle Vajrayanic deity of the Kwa Bahah - Yogambara with three faces , black , white and red , and three eyes (each) was locked in a passionate embrace with his consort , Jnana Dakini . His first two hands held a vajra and bell . The remaining right hands caressed the breast of the consort and held an arrow. The left hands held a skullcup and a bowl . A jewel , crescent moon and vishvavajra adorn the black hair as an ornament , with a garland of five skulls and the five Buddhas as a crown , having the six mudras , wearing a tiger skin . Seated in the sattvasana , in the lap was the mother Jnana Dakini , white , with one face and two hands . The right hand held a katvanga staff and the left a skullcup - embracing the father adorned with the five mudras .  The Kwa Bahah is the repository of yet another famous text , the gold lettered Ashtasahasrika Prajnaparampita - a key Mahayan text written in India in first century AD .  Though one can not take photographs inside the shrine , she can spend hours together doccumating the various fascinating figurines and paintings along the walls .
Golden Temple is a very old temple of Nepal. It is very famous in Nepal. One should visit this temple.

This 'hidden' temple is small but the artworks are largely intact and magnificent. The monks practice just to the right of the main chamber. Loads of great Nepali syncretism here, and a super hidden stupa just up the street on your left.

This is a temple where monks came to live for a month for training, but you won’t hear about it if you don’t hire a guide. Try to find a guide or someone that can explain the history behind this temple.
We visited the Golden Temple in late afternoon sunshine! Unique atmosphere! Don't miss when you are in Patan.
This temple entry is cofusing actually about all of them but after you get in you'll know how i felt.thise styles and art are crazy .how the skillful people were here in ancient time
The entrance foretells nothing of the splendor of the inside. Truly a charming and very ornate temple that demands your attention. Linger a while and take in the exquisite workmanship all around you.

column7: Take a walk through Old Patan to find this delight
column8: Golden, yes, and fascinating too.  Don't step down into the courtyard if you're wearing leather, but sit on one of the benches and drink it in. Silent (though there's the odd ring of a bell), calm and a feast for the eyes - such decoration, shapes, buildings. Patan Durbar Square nearby is also a wonder, but the Golden Temple gets so much more into such a small space. Do both!

The Buddhist Golden Temple is 12th Century temple that contains a 2000-year-old religious Buddhist book written in gold, the Pragya Paramita. Prayer wheels are around all of the walls of the temple. Nearby are the Singing bowl shops; they are worth a visit, too,

column7: More to see than I thought
column8: This is a small Buddhist temple, but I was surprised that there was actually quite a bit to see. We had a guide who gave us the history and made the visit more interesting. There were many gold items that were very beautiful. We stood in one place for awhile to absorb it all. Watch your head as you go through doorways. Doorways are for very short people!  We went in the afternoon, and it wasn’t very crowded. Don’t know if the mornings are busier. If in Patan, this is worth a visit.

when you learn about the history of the Kathmandu valley and the kingdoms that existed within it - it makes all the visits that more interesting. the Golden temple is very impressive and a great visit

It is basically just one courtyard with some objects in it; it kinda looks like someone made their home into a tourist trap. I would not go out of my way to see it, but it if you are in Patan why not? It is only 100 rupees to enter. The place itself is not as old as it would appear as there was a sign saying it was established in 1986 if I remember correctly.
One of the temple not to be missed in old Patan. Better to visit with a guide. The temple as well as it surrounding streets, yards and temples will give you a reply taste of this amazing neighborhood

I didn’t know about this place beforehand and only ran into it unexpectedly while exploring the Patan Durbar area. What a great surprise it was. A well maintained (almost pristine) Hindu temple without crowds and hawkers. Very ornate carvings and statutes pepper the whole temple. A local visitor talked with me about something that was going on at the time. Evidently, a young boy is like an important priest or something to that effect here, and it was time for him to come out for his lunchtime prayers or something like that. Not that this was any spectacular ritual to watch but I was glad to catch a glimpse of a local tradition at the temple. Be sure to go out back behind the temple as there are a few historical Buddhist sitters there.

column7: Beautiful combined Hindu and Budhist Temple! Wow
column8: What an incredibly beautiful place! It holds hundreds of years of history. At the entrance you have Hindu temple and if you go up you have a beautiful Buddhist praying room. It is worth it for sure. At the entrance we met this great guide Manoj Shahi, who then took us to a lot of other places we could never have found on our own! Like hidden stupas, nice restaurante, and to the Darbar square, explaining the history behind it all. What a great time!
This is an amazing temple made of gold! Different then any I saw while on my visit even the architectural style was not typical of Nepal. It’s a must see if you are in the area.
This temple was a definitely highlight with beautiful temple architecture with many ornate features, carvings, shrines, statues, animals, images of Buddha meditating, prayer wheels, and such.

A visit to this place really worth. Full of ancient architecture and statues makes you feel like you are in different era. Very carefully crafted statues looks like they are living. I really enjoyed visiting this place and Patan town itself.
This beautiful temple survived the earthquake, when so much damage is around about this relatively intact temple lifts the spirit, all is not lost

I have visited the Golden Temple many times. Words can't really express the feeling you have sitting inside looking just looking at the statues and hearing the sounds of the bells and chanting. The Temple goes back to 11th Century. There is a child Priest who is always at the Temple all tyear round as part if the Buddhist tradition. There are people to advise you of the history, but there is no pestering you sometimes find in other places. 10/10 every time I have visited. I was there yesterday meditating 🙏

Small but mighty little jem. We stumbled upon this place by accident. What a joy! If you get there this month, the head priest is only 9 yr.s old! He ran into us playing tag with his friends in the temple! He also has a little pet turtle that walks around the interior of the temple. I can't make this up. It's true. Go go go!

Hiranyabarna mahabihar is the best visiting destination in Patan city. the temple offers the very ancient creation in the historical architechtorsand monuments. as went there i found trinquilities of culture. I experienced the best visit.

Architecture is amazing. Once you have entered the gate its totally different ambiance inside.like the other buildings you will be drawn into how the Curvings was done, the craftsmanship is really one of a kind.  Lucky to have witness one heritage site showcasing how artistic our ancestors are.
We hard really good time visiting here. The finest metal craft which inspire me lots and will definitely back again when i come to Nepal.

As part of our tour in Patan my friend and I visited the Dubar Square on April 4, 2017.Situated to the north of the Durbar Square is a Buddhist monastery, popularly known as the Golden Temple (Hiranya Varna Mahavihar). It got this name because of the beautiful golden facade and other golden edifices that adorn the monastery. This significant site is believed to have been built in the 12th century by King Bhaskar Verma; however, some say that it was created in its present form in 1409. At the entrance, you will be greeted by two large brass elephants and riders, standing as the guardians. Straight ahead from here is a shrine adorned with a silver and golden chaitya and behind it is the main shrine where a statue of Buddha is placed. The entire courtyard is also decorated with various effigies. You should take a closer look at these statues as the detailing is very fine.  A separate fee has to be paid for entering this temple. Cost of entering the Durbar Square is exclusive of this because technically, the premises actually falls out of the square area. The Golden Temple is actually a monastery, so like in every other Buddhist shrine, you are expected to remain silent or talk in very low tones. Secondly, photography is not allowed inside the shrine and you can take pictures only in the courtyard area.
Golden Temple is worth visiting. Carving and statue art and Architecture is Unparalleled .every Murti is great .OLD is GOLD. say WOW

We stayed in the hotel nearby Golden Temple. In the morning, we went to this temple to see how Nepali pray. It is a very nice place and a must-visit to see about traditional people and their belief.  You can also light up candles, make wishes and follow each steps how to pray in the temple.  It is not allowed to wear leather shoes inside, so please respect the place.  Foreigners should pay small entrance fee, but in early morning there was no staff to collect the fee. However, we can put some money in donation box.  I highly recommend this place if you book a hotel near Patan Durbar Square.
Amazing place. Go out the back entrance into a very historic courtyard. Sit and absorb the atmosphere of this incredible temple. A must see

column7: Excellent Temple rich in art and history
column8: I normally go to this temple for prayers. This temple is a must visit one as it is rich in art and craft. This place also got a long history with newari culture. Lots of tourist visit this place everyday. This temple is near Patan Durbar Square.
Good ol' heritage site with a long history. It is not a very big site but it is a nice good place to visit.

Located at a junction in north Patan a short distance from Patan Durbar Square. It is a Newari Buddhist monastery built in 14th cent. with an ornate 3 tiered roof. Most of the temple is actually brass polished to resemble gold. Leather items are not permitted inside. At the entrance are two large brass guardian elephants and riders. In front is a shrine with a silver and gold chaitya. Photography inside the shrine is prohibited but pictures may be taken in the interior of the courtyard. Going around the central shrine are large bronze Bodhisattvas. There are brass monkeys holding out jackfruit as offerings. Behind them is Padmapani Lokeshwar and the fourth is Manjushree. The main shrine directly behind the smaller one contains a statue of Sakyamuni and a Buddha image. Many of the artifacts inside the courtyard are highly detailed. Inside the Golden temple monastery facing the two golden elephants on the left is a small door which leads to the stairs to visit the monastery.
This place is both historic and current. Very well kept, clean temple. Must visit or the only visit in Patan.

column7: This is one of the main attractions!
column8: The Golden Temple (Hiranyavarna Mahavihara) is located up a side street close to and north of Durbar Square. The entrance is really imposing as you enter a narrow corridor and catch a glimpse of the temples 3 tiered roof. It had been describes as the "most opulent temple" in Nepal as it is really quite ornate. The actual temple which sits in the middle of an inner courtyard is highly guilded. There are lots of nice statues here. The main deity, the Sakyamuni Buddah lies in a "silver" shrine, to the back of the complex and is highly decorated. There is a small entry fee "Rp 100? ". If you do go to Patan - do not miss this!
This place is very peaceful place and the people of this place are really nice and friendly.I wish to go again next year.

The Golden Temple is an absolute must visit if you have the opportunity to go to Patan Durbar Square. The energy of this temple fits in with the name. A truly "Golden" experience. The beauty of this temple is simply stunning. Most of my pics from here are on my camera ao unfortunately only have one to share at this time as I am still in Nepal.

column7: The beauty that hidden in the middle of the old town
column8: Beautiful architecture and details. You need to pay to enter the golden temple. I cant really remember the entrance fee (prob about 100 Nepali rupee). But its worth of money. Once you enter the centra of the temple, you can catch the feeling how people live in their olden day. You can go to the 2nd level where the monastry located. There is a hall for people to pray and offer the candle offering. Its dark but calm and quiet.... this place can be one of the must see in Kathmandu.
a lot of history. peace and calm, excellent paintings and idols. would have been better if people can clean this holy place a bit.

This temple is hidden in one of the back streets of Patan old city and while you need to look for it, it is absolutely worth the visit. Incredible sculptures, Hindu and Buddhist symbols and full of colourful locals. Absolutely worth the visit
I visited golden temple with my mom and daughter. It's a nice place and also my daughter learn some culture.

Unfortunately, like many of Kathmandu's buildings, the Golden Temple had been damaged in the earthquake of 2015. Still, the beauty of this great temple is visible through the remaining intact structure. Hopefully it's able to be rebuilt and returned to its former glory.

column7: A favorite for sculpture Bas Relief and cast bronze
column8: Down a side road away from the Durbar square you find the Golden Temple - what an amazing place! I like it best in the early morning before tourists are there and people are worshipping. A local Newari group (old men) sometimes plays music quietly in the courtyard, while people conduct their pujas. A special place to see in the Patan area.
this place is stunning.. so much cuture and rich in history. a great place for art and photo friendlies
Located in a narrow street surrounded by many metal crafts shops this temple offers an untouched architecture by the 2015 earthquake. Many pilgrims here and very impressive temple.

This temple is a don't-miss when you are in Patan. It is an example of a Bahal or Newari Buddhist temple and has probably the best collection of Newari metal sculptures in one place. On the way to the temple from Durbar square you can see many of the buildings were damaged during the earthquake and have wooden beams supporting the walls. Luckily this temple remained intact.

This temple offers a very sacred feel for me. Every little details of the architecture brings me to the past time when the temple was builded. I enjoy this temple for an hour after I went sight seeing around the Patan Durbar Square and feeding the pigeons. Nepal offers us a very sacred Hindu touch and feeling. The entrance of the Golden Temple is very "captureable" and it is a very nice place to come.

column7: Hiranya Varna Mahavihar is a great, golden roofed temple and a monastery in the heart of Patan
column8: Little off the main square at Patan/Lalitpur, Hiranya Varna Mahavihar offers a complete retreat, as it is a closed court with the Golden Temple on one and an old Newar Buddhist monastery on the other. A small additional entry fee is asked for by the very helpful caretaker there. Best is to sit down for a while on the right hand side on one of the benches below the monastery and to watch the ongoing ceremonies, the coming and going of devotees.
This is a real gem in the middle of Patan. The temple is fascinating with some amazing architecture and temple ornaments

Patan with narrow streets; crowded and traditional palaces has many temples. But the best of them is Golden temple. You can not push leathers shoes because in Buddhist temple uses of leathers proinhibited. There are two lions for protection of the temples around of it.and there is palace for denotion. .

We stayed in this square,viewing the temple daily from our guesthouse window. Most worshippers came in morning. Although appears old&ancient, the stellar construction & intricate carving on the walls looks stunning

When you don't expect it you find the thing you are looking for. This is exactly what happened to us! The temple has an old sacred feel to it. It is in a court yard of it's own so nice and quiet from the street noise.
It was amazing to see all these historic shrines. As a buddhist I fellt very well in there. I hope it is not damaged after the quake. That would be a big loss.

This is one of the most impressive and beautiful temples in Kathmandu. The large and details stone carvings especially at the entrance are breathtaking. A wonderful place to visit and walk around in the square.  We were there just a day before the earthquake so not sure how much damage to this area or if it is still standing- I surely hope it is and that no one was hurt in the area as there where many buildings close by.  Sad to think something so wonderful and old might not have survived the quake of 2015  If it is there it is well worth the visit when possible

This place is magnificent. It's on par with Asia's greatest temples, despite somewhat humble appearance. The wooden carvings are entrancing, and atmosphere is magical. Don't forget to visit the praying hall on the second floor - it's the real deal.

column7: Gorgeous little temple - tucked away but well worth the effort to find it.....
column8: Following our walk around the Durbar Sq in Patan we set off, guidebook in hand, to see what else patan had to offer. We actually walked past the entrance to this little temple and had to go back as we really didn't believe we had found the entrance.  There is a small entry fee to the temple but it's well worth it.  The temple consists of a small courtyard with a centeral pagoda and siderooms off the courtyard. The whole place is festooned with Gold Leaf - loads of religious idols and prayer wheels. It is very much a living working temple and it's an honour to watch the local populance attend to their devotions.  Well well worth the effort in getting here and finding the temple - a real highlight.

This is only a short walk away from Durbar Square. Therefore it carries a separate entrance fee. However, it was well worth the visit. The temple from the outside looks small and dense which it is. However, the temple is filled with gold carvings which was beautiful and intricate. Unfortunately according to our guide, some of it has been recently restored so its actually a mix of bronze and gold. We spent about 15 minutes inside.

This is a gorgeous temple. Well even that is an understatement. Might be one of my favourites in Nepal. It is easy to miss and is about a 10 min walk. Look around carefully whilst walking we almost walked past! The carvings and statues are beyond magical. When we visited there was chanting and people sitting together in a corner accompanied by the bells. Beautiful experience

column7: Exquisite work of art and craft
column8: I wonder, why this is not considered a wonder of the world. This is however one of the must visit, unesco world heritage sites set in kathmandu valley. This has a main temple, an inner temple and a continuous boundary like double storied temple and monastery. The overall area covered is relatively small but the level of details on each sq. inch of the temple beats imagination. There re miniature fire serpents, dragons, elephants on mythological turtles and a whole world of Vedic Hinduism crafted on metal, stone and wood here. A must visit if in nepal.
Is a 3 storey golden pagoda of Shakyamuni buddha and is built in the 12th century. Beautiful carvings on its walls and paintings depicting a complete life history of buddha.

column7: Walk A Few Minutes North of Durbar Square
column8: Also known as Kwa Bahal, the Golden Temple is part of a small monastery complex. Once inside, you'll discover a courtyard filled with shrines and statues of deities.
