The temple itself is three roofs high and made of gilded copper with carved lions guarding the entrance. the metal work on this ancient building and in its artifacts is particularly interesting. See my photos for details.  There was a tremendous amount of activity at this temple with the faithful turning prayer wheels and leaving offerings. This was one of the more exciting visits we made in Patan.

Our guide indicated the temple has a priest who is a young boy around 12 years old. This boy is chosen from the priest/holy caste of Nepali. The boy serves for 30 days. During this time the boy may not use soap to wash himself or his clothing. After 30 days another boy is chosen to become the temple priest. This temple also has plenty of holy rats eating the offerings.

Well, I have to say there's not much to see in Patan aside from Durbar Square and this temple. It's a Tibetan Buddhist temple covered in gold color. The best thing about this temple I have to say, is the craftsmanship (someone also said this somewhere in among the comments). Whenever I see wood-carving works here in Nepal, I do very much appreciate the effort and time that the craft man put in to create such details. This is a fine example for such excellent work. Obviously, when you're already in Patan, you shouldn't skip this temple.

Did not see much in evidence to connect directly with the original rat apart from, of course, the profusion of intricate, gold-colored architecture. It is the ornate craftsmanship that merits the visit.

column7: the perfect place to calm your mind
column8: huge golden temple within the traditional city. its really amazing place from the entrance with the great artwork in ceiling followed by huge door and series of sculpture . the perfect place to calm your mind

Golden Temple is hidden away from the crowded streets and crossroads of the ancient city of Lalitpur (Patan/Yala) is one of the most intriguing, most elegant, and most ornate Buddhist monuments of Nepal: the monastery called Hiranya Varna Mahavihar. To tourists it is more often known as The Golden Temple.  This Buddhist temple complex is believed to have been constructed in the twelth century by a ruler called Bhaskara Dev Varma. He was born a Hindu but became a great devotee of Lord Shakyamuni Buddha. Over the entrance doorway there are two wooden struts carved with the two most important Hindu gods, Shiva and Vishnu, who guard this Buddhist temple. It is one of the distinctive features of Hiranya Varna Mahavihar that many strict and elaborate rituals are maintained here which have been abandoned or were never performed in other such monastery temples.  The principal priest of this monastery is a young boy who must on no account be over twelve years old. With the assistance of an older boy or young man, he carries out the regular liturgical service in the shrine of the main Buddha. Both priests must be members of the monastery and they serve for a period of one month, during which time they must stay inside the courtyard. The only exception to this is that twice a day the younger priest circulates the area where most of the monastery members live ringing a bell, at the end of the morning service and before the evening service.  The main temple in the courtyard is a three-tiered rectangular pagoda structure dominating the entire complex. Its roofs and screened windows, including cornices and struts, are all gilded with gold. The temple banners that hang down from the roof to the level of the doorway are remarkable. A legend links them with the Buddha, who used them as a ladder to come down from heaven to earth.

You will pass this temple if you head north from Patan's Durbar Square towards the Kumbheshwor 5 storey temple. It has a small entrance which is easily missed. 50rs to get in. Once inside it opens out into a compact courtyard with a very tall central pagoda. You can walk around the upper levels where some 12th C Buddhist artwork has been protected behind glass. There are also some large prayer wheels. Very little information is given in English so the meaning of the art remains a mystery, unless you can find a guide.
This temple is magnificent - it's covered in real gold and is quite a spectacle - not large so it won't take you a long time to see, but stunning all the same.

This living/breathing temple is a real gem in Patan and maybe on e of the most interesting in Kathmandu Valley. Also you have opportunity to stay in Hira Guest House which is located on the Temple Property. You won't be disappointed.

I had heard a lot about this temple. I was excited as I was told the statue in the temple resembled to real Gautam Buddha. A holy manuscript is read everyday which had special power. And many other things which made my expectations sky high for the place. As I visited the area, the road construction was a night mare. There were no guided alternate roads so we had to literally walk muddy narrow passage. The temple area was small and clean. Well maintained. But I couldn't find depth in anything. So much I wanted to learn but not by reading or listening but by experiencing. I felt, everything I read and told were just passed as tales and nothing more. It was early morning and I could see devotees - male and females flocking the temple. Is it a good idea to throw rice grains and metal coins on century old monuments? For me, the place is overrated. It was wise of old kings to build such mater piece but could not see enough effort to at least showcase it properly today.

column7: exquisite and be sure to go upstairs
column8: I am told that if you go around 4 a.m., there is daily chanting in the upstairs (Buddhist) section. I never did get out of bed early enough to see if it is true. Patan is a hotbed of Buddhism so it wouldn't surprise me.  be sure to go upstairs to the right to see the meditation hall.

This place is situated in the heart of ancient Lalitpur(Yala)city.it is full of art and architectural of Nepali pattern.The most ancient structure is the Swoyambhu Stupa in the courtyard.The holy text of Pragya Parmita,written in letters of gold is also faith of people is preserved here since accient times for recitation.
Chicken chilly here is my absolute favorite and the open momos . The consistency of food they have maintained is nice to see . Nice place over all .

column7: Great mo mos and a varied atmosphere
column8: We enjoy this restaurant. They have their own style of mo mo - they are open on the top. The sauce with them is delicious and unique. We have had egg rolls, chicken cordon blue, fried rice, spring rolls, mutton, fish and chips. Other than the fish we have enjoyed the flavor of everything.  Seating can be outside at tables and chairs. Inside upstairs sitting on cushions at a low table, downstairs at regular tables or a semi open area with couches and tables.  Service is good and each persons dishes come out quite close together.
Fantastic, authentic Spanish cuisine and more! Great service and ambiente. Bibhushan is a fantastic chef and also very happy to give cooking classes and share his knowledge. Would recommend 10/10 (:

We had a very fun candle light dinner. The ambiance looks antique and apt for a Spanish place. Very few tables, however we were the only ones so it did not matter. They have a few vegetarian options, so we didn't have any trouble choosing our dishes. Their portion size is Small, so order accordingly
One of the best meals we have out had in Kathmandu. Nice wait staff, good food, real attempt to make this a more "Spanish" experience.

column7: Hands down the best food we've eaten in Nepal
column8: We stumbled into this fine establishment one Friday evening to be met by the warm welcome of Bibhushan Raj Joshi, and my goodness the food was incredible. Such good value for money, and some of the best tapas we've ever eaten. And the desserts! Oh the desserts! They were so delicious! I think we're going to need new belts. We even finished off with some traditional Nepali alcohol called Roxy that he threw in for free, whilst inviting us back to learn how to cook with him later in the week. We left with full bellies and warm hearts (helped by the Roxy)

As told by my collegues I made a visit to find and experince amazing range of spanish cuisine with cozy and elegant ambience, staffs were very well trained and not to forget the highlight of the visit the collection of best desserts...memorable royal exclusive dining experience I should say....

I have known this restaurant for quite a time and this time according to staff's recommendation we tried newly introduced exclusive tapas set which was beyond our expectation. Hats off to el mediterraneo team.

My son and I ate at El Mediterraneo at the end of our five weeks in Sri Lanka and Nepal. We felt a strong need for food other than curries, and tapas sounded good. And they were GREAT. The albondigas (tiny meatballs) and potatas bravas (roasted potatos with an excellent piquant sauce) were exceptional. As were the Serrano ham with tomato and the smoky eggplant. We ended up ordering doubles of several things. Oh - the chicken pincho was really good, too. At the end of this delightful and stress free meal (all things catered to the traveler's need for fresh fruits and veggies washed in iodine), I found to my horror and embarrassment that I had left all my money back at the hotel. I arranged a plan to leave my son as "hostage" (don't worry - he's 20) while I taxied back to hotel, then back to restaurant to pay, then back to hotel. The manager stepped in and acted with such kindness and grace, assuring me that he could work this out with my hotel and I was not to worry. Sure enough, a plan was hatched and carried out without us having to do all that running around! So, not only delicious food, but true hospitality was available. It was a wonderful way to end our trip abroad.
The food was unique with creative plating. I tried the dessert(Natillas).The custard was very light and rich in flavour. Great service. Great hospitality. Truly excellente..!

Very attentive, friendly service and a pleasant Mediterranean atmosphere (apart from the weather!). Wonderful, authentic Spanish food - a real gem in the chaos of Kathmandu and a welcome change from curry. Highly recommended.

Yes, I am Spanish and this restaurant had transported me to the lovely flavors my hometown... But this place is it also a great place for Nepalese people who want to taste real Spanish food and who are willing to escape a bit from the rice and spicy food!!  Perfect service, very friendly waiters and a very cozy and comfortable atmosphere.  I really recommend this!!
The restaurant is situated in jhumsikhel .You can find variety of tapas. My favorite happens to be stuffed calamari and fish stew because I am a seafood lover. The taste is at it's best level.
The restaurant is situated in jhumsikhel .You can find variety of tapas. My favorite happens to be stuffed calamari and fish stew because I am a seafood lover. The taste is at it's best level.

Staying at this guesthouse was such an incredible experience. I LOVED the decor, the service, and the location. They do a really incredible job of keeping the space clean, while giving you a good taste of what the traditional Newari style is like. My room had a double bed, an eating area, a private bathroom, and a closet to. hand stuff up. I was nervous about the temperature (I live in Hawaii & the temperature was in the 40's EEK!), but the warm blankets they provided were more than enough. The breakfast they served gave a good variety of foods and had as much tea as you could drink! I sat in one of the window frames looking out on the courtyard. It had. posts on either side that show the beautiful characteristics of the traditional wood carvings. The staff. was

This is an absolutely wonderful, comfortable stay if you are looking for traditional Newari lodging. The people who own and run the house are very welcoming, accommodating and warm. There is also a very nice cafe on the floor level with comfortable seating. The entire house is very open and the courtyard and garden are great because you can keep your windows open without facing the noisy street. The ceilings are quite low though so if you are taller than 5'8" it might be an issue. I'm 6'1'' and got used to it. It makes it feel really cozy. The overall experience of staying here was very relaxing. The breakfast is also top notch!

column7: A vivid reminder of the culture and architecture that is disappearing in Nepal
column8: Drop in for a visit even if you don't stay here, to appreciate what Newari culture has been for the past centuries. The house is impeccably restored (with UNESCO support) and can only make one nostalgic for what has been lost in only a single lifetime. Unbeatable location between Mangal Bazaar and Kumbheswar/Baglamukhi temples, with a great staff, serves a good breakfast, too. Only 8 rooms (all different) so book early. Not particularly inexpensive but worth the price, and be warned, the outside street noise is loud.

column7: Great Place to Experience Living Traditionally
column8: Located right within Patan, Traditional Homes Swotha is an excellent place to stay. As mentioned by others, it is located within walking distance to Patan Durbar Square. The staff was extremely helpful in helping us to arrange for a driver to bring us around Kathmandu, and extending our checkout time until we were ready to leave for the airport in the late evening. The room was spacious and clean, with hot water for shower (very important during winter). It would be nice if the room had a heater as well. Nevertheless, the bed had an electric blanket, which was extremely helpful for us who hail from sunny Singapore.

column7: A two week trip to Nepal, staying in Patan.
column8: We were very happy staying in Traditional Homes. I had communicated with Punam on several occasions prior to our arrival and she was very efficient and quick to respond. All the staff were delightful and very friendly, as well as Punam the waiters in the Swotha Café were great and made a point of taking our order for breakfast the evening before we had to make an early departure. Our room was simple but delightful and comfortable, the shower room was small but there was masses of hot water. I think our rooms might have been the smallest and were several floors up, the staircase was quite steep and narrow which didn’t worry us but it might be good to check where your room will be if the stairs concern you. There was no headboard as there was a low shelf that ran along the

Rooms in a very old, refurbished house - clean, simple and wonderful staff who made our stay so special. Don’t expect upmarket and you will not be disappointed. We had the attic suite room which was quite a climb up narrow stairs but well worth it. Clean, purified water guaranteed by the staff. Good WiFi. Charming, tiny restaurant downstairs with excellent Thali. Also a restaurant next door, worth trying as more atmospheric. Best of all were the friendly staff. Sights of Patan a few minutes walk away.

column7: The perfect place for a home-like, comfortable stay!
column8: I was in Kathmandu for about five weeks, interning at an office 5-minutes away. Mr. Shrestha is an incredible host who made breakfast and laundry arrangements easy, as well as arranging for taxis, walking tours and anything you might need. For example, I was here in December and I changed heaters not once, but twice with ease! The location is stunning - it overlooks a temple on water and is a short walk away from the UNESCO World Heritage Site Patan Durbar Square! Patan/Lalitpur is an ideal place if you want to experience the old city and you can easily get a taxi to Kathmandu and Bhaktapur to visit other heritage landmarks and sites. The guesthouse is also a short walk away from Labim Mall. The guesthouse has great wifi; is a short distance from convenience stores, food

column7: A great long-term or short-term stay in Patan or Kathmandu!
column8: I was in Nepal for a work trip, and I stayed at Tajaa Pha for approximately four months. It was an excellent place to stay! Shilandra and his family were extremely hospitable. As a solo traveler, I felt like part of the family and very comfortable at the Tajaa Pha. My laundry was promptly returned every week, and a great breakfast was always available if I did not feel like cooking that day. The home is centrally located to Patan - close to Patan Durbar Square, many other Newari heritage sites, and only a short taxi ride away from central Kathmandu. This is a must stay location if you are in Patan or want to escape hectic Thamel. The view from the top floor is great; it provides the best view of Patan and the mountains on a clear day.

This was the best hotel we stayed at in Nepal. A traditional house, so tastefully decorated. Centrally located, nice garden. The room was very pleasant, spacious and comfortable. Friendly and professional staff. Wish we could have stayed longer than one night!

I would definitely go back there if I return to Kathmandu. A very old nepalese home, renovated and very tastefully decorated with all the conveniences. I loved the feel of it. Very nice and helpful staff. Breakfast is made to order. Close to attractions in Patan. I traveled by myself and felt quite safe.

Boutique heritage home is a home away from home.i spent 4 nights there and could not be any happier.First,the hotel is very conveniently located, walking distance to the center of patan, patan durbar square and with very easy transportation to Kathmandu, and the airport and is close to all major attractions. The hotel is a newly decorated,very well kept old hotel that has been running for years.It is phenomenal and offers you a taste of an authentic Nepali hotel,with a great history with all the bonuses of a hip and modern hotel. The place is sparkling clean,modern,cozy ,safe and accommodating. It offers great nights of sleep!! There is hot water at any time , as well as electricity and super fast WiFi ( all of which could be a problem in Nepal). What makes this place even more

column7: Great Hotel with an excellent service
column8: I had an unforgettable experience of staying at this beautiful place which is located in the heart of a city.I was in Nepal for my business trip but while staying at timila i felt as if i was in my holiday because the surrounding was so peaceful with artistic & historic manifests.Overall i loved the hotel and would recommend to all 🙂

Visited 'The village cafe' with old Nepalese friends after a long break. Great Newari food. Rustic feel. Had all the Newari specialties. Bhatmas, choila, ghundruk, bara, aalo sandheko, chatamari, yomari. The bara was crispy and made just right. I had a masala soda. Great drink....More

We hosted an event at Village cafe in June 2018 with above 90 attendees for a traditional newari feast dinner. The helpful staff, great food, and the setting they put up, helped in making it a success. They are very open to customization as per...More

The Village Cafe is a restaurant offering traditional authentic Newari kitchen in a beautiful, clean and quite building near Pulchowk Road. We literally almost ordered everything on the menu :) :) and were happy we everything! Easy too find, extremely affordable.

Excellent local food with some fusion items which are delicious. Nice place to stay and take a break. It supports women, In villages. There is an excellent craft shop which wood supports local village women and we should apply the organisation

column7: Authentic Nepali cuisine protecting traditional culture
column8: Had a lovely meal here - got to try a range of authentic Nepali dishes and learned about the heritage of the cuisine - even got a mini kitchen tour! Very friendly staff, good food for a good cause.

column7: Gorgeous place to eat and enjoy an afternoon
column8: My partner and I thoroughly enjoy visiting The Village Cafe. Delicious food, roomy seating and true Nepalese food we really enjoyed trying. Thank you for great service and ambiance.
Great traditional food, easy to find from Durbar square. Clean quiet location. Quick service - we were only people there for lunch though!

If you would like to experience traditional Newari snacks and meals cooked by women who have mastered their art at home, this is the place. BYOB makes this a good place to visit for after work drinks with colleagues or friends.

column7: The best food experience you would have in KTM.
column8: More than the fact that the food is delicious, eating at a restaurant that combines values as an integral part of their business model made the experience even better. The staff are SO nice and welcoming and the traditional food is the best I've had in KTM. Highly recommended!!  Eliran, ISRAEL

column7: Good food, nice environment, great organization
column8: This little restaurant is the perfect place for a simple dinner or a party whether with foreigners or locals. The food is traditional Newari, which is its own very distinct cuisine--neither Indian-framed "Nepali" nor Chinese-framed "Tibetan." It's a cuisine that lends itself especially well to...More

column7: Good variety of local dishes, Slow service, Nice atmosphere, Mosquitoes-many
column8: This is nicely tucked away in an alley so relatively quiet and has a nice upper floor patio seating area, very comfortable and nice atmosphere. Felt very relaxed here and the staff are lovely, just very unorganised and very slow. It took about 15 minutes for someone to acknowledge us, but this was ok. The menu is really impressive and looks more like a picture book for a coffee table. I really think it is the nicest menu I have ever seen and it explains the dishes. This is unique and so is the food.  We chose the platters which you can try a variety of the dishes (I do recommend this). Although one of the soups (?) was really terrible but only because it didn't suit our taste buds…it reminded me of sewage unfortunately and was a concoction of several types of beans. Otherwise, the other dishes I thought were impressing and many flavours I have never tried before.  The service didn't get any better and unfortunately I didn't bring mosquito spray and scored many bites, so we had to go inside to ask for the bill which took about 15 minutes more to produce the small piece of paper. Organisation is not there strong point, however if you overlook this, the food & atmosphere are at least worth coming for at least once.
Mouth-watering Newari platter and the variety of Yomaries.Nice environment, friendly staffs and quick service.Totally recommended.

I was looking for traditional Newari food to try during our stay in Patan. People there are really friendly, food is really tasty and great value. At the same time you also support the local women to work. Totally recommended.

column7: Is this the same restaurant as in the reviews?
column8: It's been a year since the last time I swore I'd never return again. But it was a bunch of friends, and I was swept away in the tides of peer pressure.  Surely, I thought, now they've taken the last year to tighten up their service so food comes out at the same time -- or that food comes out, period! Surely, their waiters will be more present. Surely, their bar service will be more on point.  Oh well.  It was a Saturday night, moderately busy, but plenty of waitstaff in front of house. Got seated promptly with menus, but that was the last I saw of anything resembling decent service.  I got excited about wine list. No one came to take an order, so after 15 minutes or so, I walked around the dining room until I could coax a waiter over to the table. I ordered some wine and food.  Twenty minutes later, no drinks yet. Used the bathroom. A stark contrast to the elegant open air dining room, the WC had all the ambience of a truck stop.  Another 10 minutes pass. A waiter comes to tell me (a different waiter, every time) about how they don't have that wine. Or that other wine I wanted. Or the other one. I ask him to tell me about the wines they *do* have. A few high end imports, well beyond what I originally intended to spend. Order their lackluster house wine instead (the one my corner bodega sells for 1/4 of the price). At least they had that. No one else at this point had received drinks either, not even water.  At last, my food arrived. All of it at once, app and main. One full hour later (seriously) my friend's food arrives. Some late joiners received their food much later still.  As for the quality of the food, I just don't get it, people! I mean, yes, we live in Kathmandu, not NYC or Paris or Singapore. I do get that. Managed expectations and all that. But the wings were non-offensive at best, and the pizza? Meh. The thin crust was soggy and bland, the ingredients tasted previously frozen. There is better pizza to be had in this town, three minutes walking to Roadhouse, to be specific. Not sure why so many reviewers are backflipping about Vesper food.  The final spectacle: separate checks. Holy cow. You'd think we'd asked for their firstborn child. So much resentment. But c'mon, people come to your restaurant precisely because you can support medium to large parties. Why you hating?  That's fine. I won't return anywhere I'm not wanted. At least not for another year.

column7: Don't miss out the best Italian food in Kathmandu
column8: Vesper Cafe is a rare gem in Patan area only a short drive from downtown Kathmandu! This is a top of the line restaurant where the food and wines are top notch together with a warm & friendly atmosphere it will give you a memory that last's! Their pizzas are real stone owen made, exquisitely thin and crispy with a vast number extra toppings you can choose from. Everything on their menu is carefully prepared and their wine list is an absolute dream for all Italian wine lovers! Don't miss out their 2007 Brunello de Montalcino, slightly pricy but absolutely delightful! If you are in Kathmandu this is a must visit address is Jamsikhel, Patan, don't miss it!

I was transported back to Napa Valley one evening when invited to dine here! Refreshing drinks in an al fresco setting which was essentially indoors! We both opted for pork roast! Came with creamy mashed potatoes and medley of spring vegetables! Mmmm delicious!  And yes, California standard washrooms- spacious, clean and bright, dry and modern! Most memorable meal so far!

column7: A good excuse for another glass of wine!
column8: Lovely place to catch up with old friends! Good food and wine, relaxed ambience, and nice staff. Unfortunately the kitchen was having issues the night we went, so it took quite a while for all of the orders to reach the table. A good excuse for another glass of wine!

column7: Expensive and Pathetic Food and Service!!!
column8: I remember going to this restaurant with one of my mates last May. As soon as we walked in we were seated in the courtyard and given a menu to order food and beverages. Coming from Australia things don't seem very as expensive here but when I dined in this restaurant my thoughts were changed. My mate and myself orders beers, chicken chilli and a pasta. To my surprise when our order was served I found no cheese topped on the pasta which was quite unusual and the chicken chilli served had more cheap veggies than chicken and was served cold. I asked the waiter if he could bring me some cheese to sprinkle on the pasta I had ordered. So he did (which I assumed would be a complimentary). But to my absolute surprise while going though the bill I discovered that I was charged NPR160+23%TAX for the parmesan cheese which was just a pinch in a small bowl, which I initially thought was complimentary. Pasta was NPR370+23%TAX & beer was NPR450+23%TAX. I wish I had retained the receipt with me so that I could upload on TripAdvisor. Also food here is very very very expensive and is not affordable by everyone. It is just meant for the people coming from overseas, people who make big bucks. I would highly suggest anyone thinking of going to this restaurant in the near future to reconsider your decision and plan elsewhere. One of the worst restaurant I have dined in Kathmandu.

I went to Vesper for an early dinner with friends and our small children: two toddlers and one infant. All the Italian food and the seafood appetizer we ordered was very tasty and reasonably priced, although the fish and chips was just average.  The Vesper House is now serving the full restaurant menu after the old Cafe building was destroyed, and they have expanded the space to accommodate more people. It is a nice, modern, clean space with plenty of room, although i hope they add a "play" room for little ones like the old building had to make it more family friendly.  The service was very friendly and the staff accommodated us and the children. However, a staff member should return to the table after the food has been served to check, and also ask if we want our bill or dessert after the meal. Each time I've eaten at Vesper (both old and new) it's taken forever to ask for and get the bill.  Overall the food is very good in comparison with many other restaurants in the area, and the facilities are great.

Yes! Individual flat bread pizzas were really yummy. The outdoor dining was charming, right off a main street but in another world. And it had a great bathroom with real toilet paper...a big plus when visiting Kathmandu.

column7: It's ok, but is that enough?
column8: In the past 10 days of staying in Patan I feel like I've been around the block a few - in terms of restaurants. Tonight I decided to try Vesper's and was thrilled to see Mulled Wine available as it was a cool evening. So I ordered a mulled wine, plain soda and a pepperoni pizza with mushrooms and a side of pesto. I was simply shocked to see "pepperoni" so I had to try it. I sat by a heater inside and read my book peacefully, sipping the mulled wine, which was overly fragrant (I tried to take a deep breath before I took a drink). I actually loved the flavor of the wine, but wasn't too keen on the spices floating in the wine, i.e. couldn't that be strained off prior to serving? The pizza arrived and I was famished so I inhaled 2 slices without even really taking a moment to make a decision on whether I actually liked it. And ultimately my conclusion was - meh. Something about it just didn't taste right. Maybe it's the cheese, maybe the sauce...crust was alright. But hey I've been living near NYC for nearly 13 years and before that Italy, so what was I expecting. If I went back - though I doubt I will in the next 10 days I'll be here - I'd probably give pasta or risotto a shot.

column7: A western gem in the heat of Kathmandu
column8: A true oasis of food and ambiance in the middle of Kathmandu. Ideal for when you need a break from the cultural and sensory overload of Nepal and simply want a peaceful, elegant space with great food and ambiance. Fast wifi, good service, great wine selection and attentive staff.

column7: Bad service, decent but overpriced food
column8: I went here after reading the reviews, thinking I was in for a real treat. All I can say is it was average, and I won't go back. Service was initially attentive, but gradually declined..of course until it was time for me to pay/tip, and my waiter magically reappeared and was quite attentive. Blue cheese salad ordered was missing two key ingredients entirely, and the cheese was barely noticeable. The good thing is that they took it off my bill when I pointed it out and they confirmed that indeed, they were out of the ingredients. Pizza was fine, nice thin crust and good toppings. Neither the salad nor the pizza were worth the cost. But it really was the poor service that turned me off to this place. Won't be back.

column7: after six months, a new visit to The Vesper Café
column8: After six months, I came back to Nepal and I visited the Vesper café and restaurant for lunch. It is a wonderful place to forget the noisy and polluted life of Kathmandu. An interior garden will welcome you with flower and music (the owner is a lover of jazz music) in a ambiance that fusioned eupean and nepali style. A wonderful pizza (the best of Nepal!) and other italian dishes are waiting for you. Alongsiude the Vesper café and restaurant, you can find the Vesper wine house, a real "cave à vin" in Nepal, with italian and french wines of the top quality! If you visit Nepal, you cannot miss a visit to this restaurant and wine house!

column7: Real Italian touch good food good wine
column8: Arrive in Katmandu our friends suggest to try Vesper Cafe, me and my boyfriend we go for a dinner and immediately i get the real Italian touch in the menu. We start our dinner with a nice white wine and calamari and for the main course we order a good beef steek with a great bottle of Brunello di Montalcino excellent experience !!! I suggest to visit vesper cafe if you want a real Italian touch with a nice service and good hospitality

column7: Great Wine and Food excellent atmosphere
column8: I find vesper cafe for coincidence during my trip in Katmandu and immediately i get a nice hospitality, and warm welcome. We have a dinner with our friends start with a nice glass of Vesper house wines from Italy Orvieto, we sharing a nice pasta e pizza make in the real traditional oven great experience we really surprise for a quality of food and wines and reasonable price. We back again in the last 3 days we stay Katmandu excellent place.

Every time we come to the Vesper, we are treated like family. We love coming here because of the atmosphere, the food, the drinks and the staff. Every person working is nice, and everything about the Vesper says that they genuinely want to give people a good experience. Also, the road in front of the restaurant has been finished, so it is much nicer to get in and out of than in months past. My wife and I love it here, and have met many good friends!

I visit Vesper Cafe' few times during my trip in Katmandu and always i surprise for the quality of excellent wines selection and food menu. The atmosphere in Vesper is unique creative touch from Gagan & Alex inspired from the Italy and France tradition. I suggest to visit Vesper for taste a glass of wine with good Italian food.

The Vesper Café is a wonderful wine bar where you can taste real french and italian wine. A big garden can help you to gustate these wine and you can eat an excellent international and nepalese cooking. "Un restaurant que l'on doit absolumment visiter!!!"  Fabio Armand (Vallée d'Aoste)

column7: My favorite place in the patan durbar square.
column8: Whenever i come to the Patan Durbar Square this is one of my favorite place to be, with a great view from the terrace and above average food this is one of the hubs for tourist to take a panoramic look into the far end hills covering the valley or just to enjoy the majestic mountains at the farthest of sight.Along with that it provides a peculiar view or the durbar square along with the hustle bustle of the market right below, proves to be the best view spot along with a variety of flavors from the menu.(thou not recommended for budget people, as it is slightly expensive than other cafes,restaurants with the same menu, but right on the money with its location)

We had lunch at this restaurant located in the top of a building (I bet it was in the third and fourth floors), just in front of Patan Durbar Square. From its rooftop the view is amazing!!! We had a panoramic view of the square, surrounding buildings and the Himalayas!!! It's a great place to take pictures! We ordered veggies momos (kind of steamed pasta filled with a mix of vegetables) and a traditional chicken sandwich with french fries. Food was very good, as well as the relation quality price. Recommendable!

We have enjoyed a good meal with a view of Patan Durbar Square at good price and traditional Nepali restaurant setting. We sat on the non-smoking area and the kids had great time looking at the temples from afar.  The staff however, was not accommodating as we were used to in Nepal. But he did give us fast service.

To be honest we were led up the garden path (5 flights of narrow stairs) by the tour guide we hired to show us around Patan. To be honest the place is not as appealing as some others in the vicinity. The USP has to be the view the place offers you from the roof top. For a change I had the momos and my wife had the Nepali thali - we both enjoyed the meal - hungry as we were at 2.30pm and it being our first meal for the day. (Why? That's another story). The momos were definitely the best we had on the trip. If you discount the quality of the peanut sauce that we had elsewhere, by themselves the chicken momos at the Taleju were the best we had in Nepal. They were spiced up to the optimum level and well marinated and consequently I quite enjoyed them as a meal in itself. The meal was passable - rice, dhal, green leafy vegetable, paneer (cottage-cheese) based gravy, chicken gravy - nothing to write home about but tasty all the same. My verdict - give it a shot if you are out of options.

Krishna Ashtami!!  The birthday of Lord Krishna is celebrated as Krishn Ashtami. Krishna, the dark- skinned god revered as a manifestation of Lord Vishnu, who taught warrior Arjuna the value of Karma in the Bhagwad Gita, was born at midnight on the eighth day of the dark moon of August which is known as ashtami.. To celebrate the birthday of this popular Hindu god, devotees flock to Krishna temples all over Nepal; Kathmandu Valley's Krishna Mandir in Patan Durbar Square is the centere of celebrations and is thronged by a large number of devotees who gather at night to pay homage beyond mid-night. Even during the day, hordes of devotees visit the temple to pray and make offerings. t night, men and women from far and wide gather in and around the 17th century stone temple singing praises of Lord Krishna waiting for the midnight hour. Euphoric prayers and incantations fill the air, and small oil lamps are lit as a mark of felicitation and devotion to the god. Images of Lord Krishna are also carried around the city in processions accompanied by joyous crowds of followers and musical troupes. Along the lanes of old Kathmandu people display framed pictures of Krishna showing various episodes of his amazing life.

Built in the 17 century the temple has survived numerous earthquakes and hold a commanding position in the Durbar square of Patan. Most of the important scenes from the ancient epics of Ramayana and Mahabharata are engraved on it.

My husband and I have spent two weeks in India and two in Nepal. We are not yet overcome with ennui after visiting yet another unimaginable feat of architecture. Upon seeing this remarkable building we were unsure if it was completed from an original concept, OR, after many visual and structural visions, evolved into its finished form. The interplay of levels and balconys and intricate detailing is remarkable. But it does seem very fragile and not earthquake proof. May it survive and awe many more visitors. Nameste.

Patan Durbar Square need no introduction. It is delightful to observe that this city has managed in so short time to restore or already having restored so many of it's heritage devastated in the 2015 earthquake. Its beautiful to again see the glory of this superb temple in the heart of Patan ! Kudos to the Newari community !

column7: King Siddhinarsingh's Memorial Known As Krishna Mandir
column8: This was built inn 1637 by King Siddhinarsingh and is one of the earliest stone temples, or Indian origin in Nepal. It is an impressive structure and appeared intact. It has architectural similarities to the stone temple behind the ticket office known as the Krishna Temple and reviewers may get confused
when visiting Patan it is hard to miss this temple. Make sure to catch it while there- take in all the history and the significance- this will be sure to catch your ey
its very good place to visit if u r into hindu rituals. the temple is made from one stone and you can see the handicraft of the old heritage of the nepalese people over here

Amazing architecture, enriched with wonderful works of art. The Krishna Mandir Temple is located on Durbar Square. It is surrounded by magnificent buildings, temples, shops and always a lot of people. The three storey stone temple is the finest stone monument in Nepal. Like everything in Nepal and this temple has a rich history. The temple was established in 1637 AD, as a copy of another Hindu temple of Lord Krishna present in Mathura, India. There are stone carvings of various gods and goddesses on the passage of the temple.
It is for those that want to sightsee! It's quite historic and also see the effect after earthquake.... it's quite interesting and beautiful! :) slightly overcrowded but it is still worth it!

column7: The most important temple in Patan Durbar Square and UNESCO World Heritage Sites
column8: My friend and I visited this Temple on April 4,2017. Shikara-style Krisnhna Mandir Temple (Chayasim Deval) stands out with its ornate stonework. Built in 1637 by King Siddhinarsingh Malla to house Hindu deities. Under the twenty-one golden pinnacles, three floors enshrine Hindu deities: the first floor is dedicated to Krishna, the second to Shiva and the third to Lokeshwor. See beautiful paintings from the Ramayana in the interior. Admire the stunning columns with their intricate stone carvings and embellishments. See the statue of man-bird Garuda kneeling with folded arms on the top of the column facing the temple. Entrance to the inside of the temple is forbidden for non-Hindus. It worth the visit.
It lies in southeast Kathmandu valley the Krishna mandir is made by the Malla king in Thirteen sanctuary also the UNESCO heritage site.

The entire structure is being restored and has scaffolding around it. Known as Bishwanath or Visvesvara, it has 2 plinth levels and 2 roofs. The two elephants with riders can be seen. It is closed to visitors and one can only imagine its original glory.

The temple is completely covered in scaffolding and there is a fence around it. It looks pretty intact from the outside and on the day I was there there were a lot of Hiindu's inside it. The temple is built of stone blocks, ighly carved and is on 3 teirs. It is built in the Moghul style and is really different from the rest of the temples here. It is, so I am told, very popular and can get quite crowded. I walked around it but did not go in - was not sure how safe it was!!

This temple is inside the Patan Durbar square. Very impressive with its stone structure, and 21 golden pinnacles. The temple walls have engravings of Ramayana and Mahabharata. Cannot miss this ancient structure.

Located in the heart of Patan Darbar Square Krishna temple gives unique itoduction. It has great historic value. This temple was built of stone and carving Mahabharat Story in each stone., there are 21 golden gajurs in rhe rptemple.bthis temple shows its unique architecture design and historic importance. I belive it gives everyone specific experience, so i recommend to visit atleast once.
Different than original Nepalese style temple, this Krishna temple has 21 pinnacle. It is 3 storied temple with mahadev, radha & Krishna, and budhha in three different floors.

This tree storied temple looks like a hand carved jewel. The metal shines with glints and glares on a summer afternoon. The temple itself is centre point of visit in Patan. It stands in the middle of Durbar square and is usually easy to find. a visit and sit at the premises to claim the respite of the shadows.

in this mandir the original shape od the indian classical shikara has been modified . in this elegant three floors building the slim pillars give an air of lightness to the gray stone. the decoration is sober and enhances the game of shade and ligh of the porticos . during Krishna Astami,about the end of august ,the temple is surrounded by an immense ,colored crowd of devotees,offering flowers,fruits and religious chanting,a magic experience ,especially by night.

column7: Steep climb for a great view
column8: The Krishna temple is built very similarly to some of the temples in India. There are steep and narrow stairs that lead you to the sanctum. The sanctum itself is not on the ground level which itself is a unique piece of architecture in Hindu temples. Great views of the square await you when you get on the top.
This is a fine example of the traditional Krishna Temples you see in Nepal. It is well worth spending a few minutes to explore all the details.

Patan Krishna Temple is also known as hindu lord Krishna Temple, So this place attracts all the hindu during the hindu festival .,It has also been listed in World Heritage Site of UNESCO .There are more than 1,200 Buddhist monuments of various shapes and sizes scattered in and around patan the city which has attracted thousands of tourist every year.
Every body who is in Kathmandu should not to be missed to visit old palce and musium and old type of source of water tape.

A visit to Patan Durbar Square and the great museum inside the old palace is a msut for anyone visiting Kathmandu. Within the square, the Krishna Mandir is unique and special with superb stonework and detail.

Beautiful and opportunity to know ancient Nepal. There are so many good things to see in and around this destination. It would be further beneficial if there is a local guide who knows more on the ancient culture, history and tradition of Nepal. Should you have any query or detailed requirement on how to make your trip most rewarding please do not hesitate to contact myself. I shall be more than pleased to assist you.

First of all the guy who runs Taza is an amazing person and the food will be served with a smile. The food is delicious and make sure you are wearing a lose pair of clothes as you gonna feel tight after a belly full of middle eastern surprises, The aesthetics are splendid, murals-paintings are fabulous speaking about the famous places of Syria.

This very unassuming restaurant is on the Main Street of Pulchowk near UN House. The decor is simple but clean. The Taza special platter was huge and easily shared between 2-3 people. It all tasted really fresh and the flat bread was very soft. So nice to have real middle eastern food in town.
Very good original middle eastern food with hummus, mtabal, falafel. Quite unexpensive but small portions, so you need to order several dishes if you are hungry. Very friendly Syrian staff.

Light, soft delicious pita bread served with humus, baba ghanoush, felafel, or shawarma if you are a carnivore - all fantastic. They have a neat simple menu that does not offer anything but the traditional foods they know best. The only thing missing is the deeply fragrant cardamom coffee that is found in Syria. There are tables and the place is very basic no decor to speak and an effort made here could help business.
I love zatar and falafel. It's good taste for everyone who want to have different. I highly recommend to visit
Great amazing Syrian / Mediterranean food , friendly staff , you can taste the real shawarma , falafel , hummus and Mutabbal in KTM.
This is totally a unique restaurant which serves middle eastern food. We loved the foods that were served specially the toshka. Simply loving it.

Tasneem is a wonderful and friendly lady who immediately makes you feel welcome at the restaurant. The menu is plentiful and it often comes with new suggestions to try from Tasneem. The food is absolutely delicious and we have become regular customers over the past...More

There were alot of problems, I don’t know where to start from! Service was extremely bad, appetizer and half of the main course came together, waited 30 mins for the other half ! Taste was 3/10 ! This is an honest review take it or...More

Here is a genuine review. So the thing is....it's been 2 months since I have quit meat and I don't plan on getting back either. I remember telling my mom who is a vegetarian that there is no scope for vegies and the idea of...More

I've been to lot of premium chain of biryani restaurants but TKK's biryani standout well and offers unique flavour. The hospitality is great and the owner leaves no stone unturned for you to have a great experience over here.

column7: Ordered too much, ate it all, and ordered more -- extraordinary
column8: Tasneem's was a surprise find recommended by a friend of ours on a quick trip to Kathmandu, and it was incredible -- highly, highly recommend.  After cocktails (try the spicy whiskey one), we ordered the chicken mix and mutton mix platters to begin, and each was delicious... my favorites were the chicken tikka, the mutton kebab bites, and the melt-in-your-mouth cutlets. We then moved on to the chicken inquilab and the butter chicken, and both were great, though the butter chicken is an absolute must-order -- it's among the best dishes I've eaten, and is every bit the blend of spiced, spicy, rich, and tangy that you want it to be. It's flawless.  We were already stuffed but just... couldn't stop? We ordered another round of beers and naan, wiped the chicken dishes clean, and moved on to the gajjar ka halwa, which was a slow-cooked dessert made of carrots, milk, butter, raisins... it was an amazing end to a phenomenal meal.  I'd like to offer a balanced review, but frankly can't think of any critiques of this meal -- the food was stellar, the ambience and service were top-notch, and I'd seriously consider swinging through Kathmandu again soon just to revisit this menu. Five stars, and would give a sixth if I could.

Some of the best chicken tikka and mutton sheekh kebab I have ever had cooked live in a warm, homely courtyard environment. The appetizers followed with some traditional Bohra biryani that is very different from what I have had before. Loved the personal hospitality of Chef Tasneem who is never far away to recommend the house specials. Will be back soon for some more barbecue items.

column7: A real gourmet experience at Tasneem's
column8: I live in Bangkok and visited Kathmandu for four days at the end of August. I went to TKK on the recommendation of a friend. I am an Indian but I had to non-Indian friends with me. The experience was amazing, This is no ordinary run of mill Indian Tandoori restaurant. This place showcases Bohra cuisine with recipes passed down through generations. The complexity of flavors and the richness of the dishes showed the TLC put into the cooking. We focused on the kebabs accompanied by Gorkha beer. I have rarely tasted such tender meat. The mutton sigri and chicken cutlet melt in the mouth. The butter chicken is amazing as the gravy is the best that I have tasted. I had the Nihari which was also excellent but the biryani was already finished ( to my deep regret). The restaurant is in an old Nepali house and is spread over three levels. The place was full of groups of friends and family with a really fun vibe. Please go there with a big appetite but I bet you cannot help overeating. The service is amazing and try and get the real cool owners to talk about their food. It makes the food taste even better.

Can’t believe found an amazing Indian restaurant in Kathmandu, the food here are just fantastic. Mutton and chicken biryani are my favorites. Also panner masala, soo good. The foods seem very well prepared with their unique authentic originally from Bhora Muslim, knowned to be originally migrated from Yemen to Gujarat. Ms. Tasneem, the owener, manages this restaurant from the kitchen to ensure all are in high quality. Attached photo of dessert, gajar ka halwa, made from carrot.

column7: What a treat !! Will visit you again soon
column8: Just visited Kathmandu with three accompanying professors from the US. A friend of mine recommended this place for authentic and tasteful cuisine. I am glad that in ten days we visited this place three times. My favorite Chicken Angara, goat Kabsa (takes 16 hours of slow cooking) and the Mutton biryani. All preparations are halal. The best part was Tasneem and Harsh being there and providing personal attention and narrating the history behind preparations. That was priceless. We earned good friends as well. Service is prompt and the staff very courteous. Enjoy the decor on the walls where original bollywood film posters are framed. It was great for a movie buff like me. So the place has a unique ambience. And do pack chocolate bags for your family.

My husband and I were visiting Kathmandu for his business colleague's wedding. Since we are from Mumbai, a local friend recommended us Tasneem's as it is a restaurant run by a couple from Mumbai specialising in Bohra food from Mumbai. It is quaint old house with a small sign outside, which you could miss if you are not paying attention. But what we did not miss was the taste of Mumbai. We ordered a chicken and a mutton platter. It arrived full of variety of kebabs, tikkas with authentic chutneys straight out of by lanes of Muhammad Ali Road in Mumbai... It was just as authentic as any kebab tikka eatery there! Definitely recommend to all travellers. Pleasantly surprised !!!
The food was superb, we strongly recommend the kebab & biryani! The waiter is always incredibly chatty and friendly. This cafe is real gem.
Excellent curries and biryanis -unique flavors - complex flavors beyond traditional Indian food. Servings are small so you may need to order more. Limited vegetarian options.

I love Tasneem's Kitchen, and the variety and quality she promises and delivers! I have found a new favourite in the Paneer Makhani, and this, amidst all her other delectable selections of food from her part of India, is pure bliss on the tastebuds. Besides the amazing food, you'll find the warmth of hospitality that only comes from the the heart of a woman proud of her heritage and dedicated to bringing it to us in Nepal. I cannot say enough to express my deep gratitude for Tasneem and her team, who again and again deliver amazing dining experiences!

We’ve been here on several occasions and are very happy with the quality of the food.  I have gluten allergies and ms. Tasneem took time to explain in detail what foods I could eat and her recommendations. They also used to have gluten free beer, but it’s been off the menu lately. She explained me that they are putting a lot of effort into training their staff to handle different allergies which is rare to find in Nepal.  An absolute gem!

This is my 3rd visit to TKK and I just love her mouth watering chicken masala and other non veg starters.This is the best and authentic place to have the real Bora Muslim thali that i so miss whenever i travel outside Mumbai. Her restaurant...More

This place is the real deal. Admittedly, every single time I come, I can't stop ordering butter chicken. It is so delicious and the serving size is hefty. The food here is incredible (I can't describe how delicious enough), the service is great, and the atmosphere is lovely. If you are in Kathmandu, find a chance to eat at Tasneems!! I actually met Tasneem the other day when dining there; very kind and nice woman!  I noticed that it is on the expensive side for food in Nepal, but I would say well worth it!

column7: A feast for the eyes and mouth - BECAUSE ITS DELICIOUS !!!
column8: Had gone there with my son (fussy eater) and we both loved the Bohra Thaal - a 12 course meal which traditionally starts from the desserts ( good news to sweet lovers)... A perfect balance of food between sweet and savory and reasonably priced. The huge plate or thaal in nepali, containing 12 delicious variants not only looks tempting but also soul pleasing. This combination not only define the richness of Bohra culture but also the unique way of eating which contains so much of discipline and understanding of your pallet.

column7: The Best Indian Restaurant in Kathmandu.
column8: The best Indian Restaurant with a blend of great food, amazing ppl who make them & an ambiance that take u to old school bollywood. Tasneems place is where we find the best of indian food in town. All my friends & colleagues from India & Nepal have our regular joint n thats TKK. Bless Tasneem Shahani who has devoted to share her culinary craft for Ktm dwellers who just cant get enough of her Biryanis & special treat including Kabsa. The only place in Ktm that can live upto the Paavbhaaji of mumbai; thank god they have delivery, lunch packets & catering services for corporates & group orders. If you love indian food & if you havent been to Tasneems; there s sth serious you re missing out on. Cheers

column7: Staffs at the restaurant really show they care
column8: We went for lunch and we had mini lunch boxes that were so well presented and tastiest Indian food I have had in Nepal. The chef really knows what he was doing with flavours and subtle changes to traditional dishes that I really appreciated. I don't want my butter chicken same everywhere so I thought that should be mentioned in the review. Definitely going there again.

I was recommended this place by a friend who had recently eaten here and it didn’t disappoint.  The food tasted amazing, so much flavour and just the right amount of spice - really very good. We had a mixture of meat and veggie dishes; the butter chicken is one of the nicest curries I’ve ever tasted (the chicken is shredded rather than being in “lumps” so the meat is really soft) and the dahl was great too. The mutton dish wasn’t to my taste, but the meat was very soft with a thick rich sauce.  The actual restaurant is very nice too, the beautiful entrance, the terrace and the low tables on the second floor where you sit on chairs resting on the floor. It’s also interesting to read about the culture of the owner and some of the their traditions around food and eating together as a family.  A great evening, will definitely go back if I’m in Kathmandu again!

I would like to say that Tasneem’s King’s Kitchen in Pulchowk, next to the old Patan fire station, does a great job of self-promotion and advertising its unique brand of Bohra food experience. I emphasize the last two words because although this is food with...More

This is one place that you must go...for really everything. Food of course is finger licking, decor and ambience very bollywood, hostess is charming and service is great. We ordered mutton mini lunch thali (which was quite big and filling though), Aam panna and simply loved it. Do walk around the place...it has 3 levels and many side seatings. What you will love about the place is old Hindi films posters all over the walls...very nostalgic. I sat under the Sholay poster and and enjoyed lunch and conversation with my amazing Nepalese girl guide.

Conveniently located in Jhamiskhel, TKK is a restaurant that will provide food fanatics an interesting dining experience. Furnished with simple decor with seating available indoors and outdoors in an internal courtyard, TKK is a restaurant with no-frills and only authentic finger licking good food.  What makes the entire dining experience at TKK different is how the leading lady Tasneem eloquently explains the whole meal and the significance behind it's origin. Not many restaurants provide you with such a homely service, where you are acknowledged about how the each dish in your meal is prepared.  We pre-ordered the famous Bohra Thaali to celebrate New Year's Eve at TKK. A Bohra meal is a big platter of authentic Bohra Cuisine. The whole meal begins by passing the salt and it is only after each member is seated around and has tasted it that the first course is served. All members from the family dines out of one platter called the thaal. The meal was accommodated for ten people.  Interestingly, the first course is dessert, which was a complete new way of dining for us.The Bohras consider it auspicious to begin their meal with a sweet dish. In the Bohra language, all desserts are called mithaas and the savoury dishes kharaas.  The main course featured lip-smacking Curries for vegetarians and unforgettable Chicken and Mutton dishes for the carnivores teamed with Flavored Rice and Naan Roti. But that’s not all, the meal ended with Gajar Ka Halwa and Paan which is a must for the eaters to cleanse their tongue.  Apart from this, past visits made our family a regular at TKK. The Biryani is legendary here: The meats, herbs and spices are placed in a pot that is then sealed and slow-cooked over a very low flame for hours. The meat cooks in its own juices, taking on the flavors of the seasoning, and resulting in a hearty and aromatic dish that is the specialty of TKK.  All in all, the food is excellent and the servings are very generous. Definitely, worth the value. If you haven't dined at TKK yet then tsk tsk tsk ;)

column7: Excellent Experience with Food, Ambiance and the Best of All the Personalized Service
column8: I am Consultant and a Trainer for Retail Outlet and QSR and Specialize in Customer Service living in Kathmandu. I should say the Dinner I had in Tasneem's on the 26th Dec 2017 was an amazing experience. Every Sunday they are closed for the Public, but this Sunday due to Christmas Eve and the Demand of their Clients they were open. Since they had opened on the Sunday they had declared that Tuesday would be closed. One of our friends not releasing that it was closed called the owner Tasneem to order their Famous Kabssa for the dinner that day. But was little disappointed that it was closed. Has my friend hung up the phone she got a call within 5 mins from Tasneem and confirming the order for the same night though they were closed.  We were altogether 10 of us. We reached the restaurant and were greeted by both Tasneem and Harsh her Husband and to our shock we released that they were the only one in the restaurant with one or two assistance. I was amazed with the Hospitality they had rendered and they had opened the restaurant just for us so that we would not be disappointed. Has we are seated to seats both of them come to us and apologies if there would be any goof up in the service since Tasneem and Harsh both were serving us. The drinks and Soft drinks come and then it was followed by the Famous Kabssa and Seriously my Jaw dropped down seeing this in Actual...OMG......This was is another 5 Star ..... This is a meat lovers paradise ...The whole Experience I should say is an Excellence of Service....My Five Star to you Tasneem & Harsh for a memorable Dinner we had…..Cheers to you Both!!!!  I should say to all the people Travelling to Kathmandu do drop by this Wonderful Restaurant and do meet the Tasneem and Harsh for sure. They would really make your day.

column7: Food or service, you'll not be disappointed
column8: The flavors, the taste, the ambience, the service and the old Bollywood movie vibes – this fusion is sure to make anyone become a regular customer at Tasneem’s Kings Kitchen. The food at TKK is absolutely spot on authenticity and healthy. It gives you feeling of food-orgasm: totally satisfying and worth paying for. I crave for chicken biryani, just like a baby craves for candies; I tried many restaurant for biryani and butter chicken and I end up here almost every time. I strongly recommend for everyone to pay visit at least one to enjoy the yummylicious food and great service.

When in Kathmandu recently, one of the highlights of my visit was the meal at Tasneem’s Kings Kitchen (TKK). It was also a reunion of sorts as when living in Kathmandu ten years ago, we were regulars of Tasneem’s home catering, food perfect for house parties – wholesome deliciousness with homey flavours. Tasneem had since then gone on to open her restaurant and my husband and I were keen to see the place and, of course, to meet Tasneem and her family – it had been exactly ten years since we saw them last. Twelve of us were booked for lunch at TKK and to be honest, we were wondering how the restaurant would manage, expecting a Mom and Pop operation. However, on reaching TKK, we were charmed by the lovely and well run restaurant created by Tasneem and her husband, Harshawardhan.  We were also delighted to find that the food served was as wholesome as we remembered from years ago but the flavours had been upped to pack a restaurant dining experience punch. Right from the aam panna and the jal jeera drinks that we ordered to the starters and the main meal to dessert – every thing was fabulous! As we were 12 of us with different preferences, we made our choices there and then, ordering off the menu, so it can be safely said that everyone else in the restaurant, too, was having the same quality of food that we were served.  Of special mention are the scrumptious Bohra Chicken Cutlets (nothing comes close to the ones served at TKK – even in Bombay which is known for this cutlet) with the mince succulent and a light coating of egg cooked just right; the innovative vegetarian seekh kabab delivering an intense burst of flavour; the fragrant mutton biryani and the equally aromatic vegetable biryani with the delectable pineapple raita; the delicious kababs and tandoor items – vegetarian and non vegetarian – perfectly grilled, lightly crusted on the outside, juicy on the inside.  Saving the best for last is Tasneem’s signature Butter Chicken prepared in a unique way. Instead of the usual chunky tikkas of chicken, you are served pulled chicken (marinated and cooked slowly till tender enough to be pulled into strips) in a rich, creamy gravy. The resultant dish is a luscious blend with the gravy going deep into every bit of chicken unlike the usual dish made with chunks of meat with the gravy only coating the tikka. The Butter Chicken made in Tasneem’s style is also easy to have with the pulled chicken lending itself to being wrapped and eaten in any roti of your choice unlike the tikka style as larger chunks do not hold well in rotis like the thicker tandoori and paratha. While on rotis, there is an assortment of Indian breads, the garlic butter naan being a personal favourite, as is the velvety phirni we ordered for dessert.  It is easy to see that Tasneem has not compromised in any way on the high standards she set for herself when starting out and catering to smaller groups of people with her wholesome and appetizing home catering. For instance, her mutton kababs still have no tallow added, something many commercial establishments resort to, to increase volume and quantity. The change: from catering from her home, her setting is now TKK – a warm and inviting place – where she and her husband make you feel at home, providing exceptional Indian food with the young and enthusiastic wait staff providing excellent service. Tasneem’s home catering set a benchmark in Kathmandu. Her restaurant sets it once again. Will be back for the Nihari and Kabsa. Good luck and best wishes.

Tasneems Kings Kitchen is a rare find in Kathmandu. I've been coming back to Tasneems for almost two years now and I've never had a bad meal here, ever. Tasneem, the ever present host, is always there greeting at the door, stepping through the dishes to suit your mood and always ready to give recommendations.  Indian food in Kathmandu has oddly never been a strength for this city despite its proximity. Tasneem's Kings Kitchen is one of those locations where the food is an absolute labour of love, hard to find spices are imported by Tasneem and she puts them to excellent use.  Last night I was invited to a traditional Bora meal (8 people required), I didn't know much going into it. What awaited was multiple courses ranging from custard to carrot pudding to amazing mutton slow cooked over 14 hours. It was an absolute delight, our entire group savored each and every mouthful. (Let her know in advance that you want the Thaal Bohra feast)  There has been some recent additions to the restaurant providing covering over their bar and reception area, beautiful lighting and a wonderful courtyard. My special recommendations, go for biryani, butter chicken, naan and some chicken Multani Wings. Actually, try everything on the menu at least once, beautiful tasty food awaits. Tasneem puts everything into every dish, so, if you're looking for authentic family style dishes then look no further.

Tasneem puts her entire heart and soul into providing you the most authentic Muslim dishes served in true family style. We had a lovely meal with some dear friends which made us all feel like we were feasting together as a family. We've also ordered Tasneem's biryani for catering special occasions at home and it's always a hit!
It's amazing. I would love to visit it again and again n will recommend others too if they wish to enjoy real Asian cuisine🙂 and Kabsa.

column7: The night i rediscovered Indian food in Kathmandu
column8: A perfect blend of taste and ambiance. From unique menu in drinks, appetizers and the main course it just won me over a meal.. Planning to visit soon

column7: Delightful wholesome food for the body and soul in a calming ambiace
column8: If you are somebody who likes good home-style food served with pure flavours then this is the restaurant that you would like to visit. Lets start with the ambiance, we were a large group of friends of 18 and were seated in the portico surrounded by plants that contributed to a natural water conservation system that self sustains the restaurants water requirements. Well appointed solar panels that do not jar the sights also contribute towards the power requirements of the restaurant. All of this is discretely set in a very natural environment. A place where you would like to relax and enjoy your food.  Then to the food itself. Had 6 starters cannot decide which one should get a special mention. All had it's unique flavours and authenticity, a welcome change from restaurants that have a common base for all foods. Most of the starters had the "Bohra" touch. For those not in the know the "Bohra's" are a small community in India that is know for it's unique dishes that tickle every palate and want in you. The serving that night certainly stirred my want to come back to the restaurant again and I was still on my starters. The of course was the main course, difficult to beat the starters was my initial thought and kept my expectations not that high. The lamb stole my heart, the best I have had in the valley in terms of texture and taste served with freshly made Indian breads. Lets just say if you like Indian food and are in the Kathmandu Valley this hygienic, environmentally friendly restaurant is a MUST VISIT. Oh did I mention that this restaurant is run by a wonderful couple who are dedicated in ensuring that your visit is an experience and not just a meal.  PS The cocktails were gratifying, complementing the food

I have been to this restaurant a few times and was never disappointed. Probably the best place for Indian food in Kathmandu. Even though they say Indian, the menu is different from traditional Indian menu. The items on their menu are very unique. The owners claim most of the recipes are from their family kitchens.  Loved their Chicken Multani Wings and Bohra Chicken Cutlets. Very unique that are not available outside. There are many other delicious items on the menu which require multiple visits.  Service is excellent. They make you feel at home.

column7: Absolutely the best Indian food i ever had
column8: Went here actually by mistake but i must say it was probably the best mistake we made. We were a group of three people and met Tasneem at the door as she greeted us in. Amazing hospitality, great decor, amazing service, but on top of all of that, the food was amazing. I travel for a living, and have been to over 17 countries this past year and i can say without a doubt, this was the best Indian food i have had. a must for everyone in the area. Even if youre not in the are, make a trip out there, you will not regret it. We went in very hungry and the people i was with including my self, are big eaters, we had Tasneem recommend things of the menu. And i kid you not, everything was amazing. From the Biryani to he tikka masala to the kebabs, to the goat (i am telling you we ate a lot) it all was all amazing. A must try!

column7: An authentic Bohri Cuisine available in Kathmandu - very unique. Must go for all
column8: Normally there are very few Indian restaurants in Kathmandu which can serve authentic cuisine. TKK is one such restaurant which gives a feeling of delicacy and elegance. There Mutton Sigdi & Chicken Mughlai Tikka are mouth watering and Chicken Angara was quite a findings. My friends loved their Mutton Dum Biryani. The Decor and ambiance was quite interesting and innovative.
To write good about tasneem's plz taste mutton platter then you guys understand the real tast of mugalie food.plz don't order platter .More

I like non veg mughlai and prefer it when it's chicken speciality and love it the most when it's typical Delhi halal delicacies.  Tasneem's Kings kitchen in Pulchowk, Lalitpur is one such restaurant that serves authentic Delhi food on a plate in Nepal. What's more the food comes with same personal one on one hospitality that makes the experience even more enjoyable. You may taste the spices and the different flavours, but according to me they serve their heart on the plate.  The butter chicken is delectable and so tender and spiced so perfect it is like perfect balance of mother's love and traditional cooking skills. The biryanis are perfection in traditional dum pukht cooking.  I would definitely recommend a visit once, from then on you will make it on your own once a week at least, can bet you on that.

If you are in Kathmandu and happen to be connoisseur of good food and that too Mughali, you must visit Tasneem's Kings Kitchen. Pure gastronomic delight with excellent ambience. Lip smacking biriyani with Tasneem's signature butter chicken is really something you shouldn't miss. Naan with mutton nithari is another combination should definitely need to try. Kebabs and dessert as we were spared for some other day. Overall a great experience at decent enough cost and must go place for food lovers in Kathmandu.

Tasneem's King's Kitchen is a great place to have the best food in Kathmandu.The Ambience is awesome as if one has reached a resort outside the city with some coolest music playing in the background. I tasted the most mouth watering Vegetarian kebabs which just melted in the mouth. The Paneer, the dal and the breads had some exotic flavours and above all the loving personalised hospitality just leaves you with sweet memories to visit again.

Ambience & Aura: Calm, Soothing, Very Positive and comfortably full with seemingly satisfied patrons : -)  Decor : Elegantly allows the simplistic beauty of food to really shine : -) Owners & Staff : Incredibly kind and accomodating :-)  Menu : Interesting and Very Tempting Starters, Flavorful Curries, Mouth Melting Biryanis highly recomended and The Lovely Gajar halwa :-)  To Look For : Would recommend to follow TKK on facebook and instagram for Exciting offers and discounts :-)  Last but not least ones visit to nepal would be incomplete without experiencing TKK.

column7: Best Indian food and Kebab in town
column8: I am sorry to Tasneem for fake feedback under my title. I visited Tasneem's to celebrate my 10th annaiversary and the food and the environment was awesome. Specially the Biryanis and the Kebabs. The Kebabs reminded me of the one I had in Kebap House, Taksim Square, Istanbul. The service was excellent and even my 6year old daughter loved the service and the environment. The discount offered by dice roll was exciting. Enjoyed a lot.

If you have to try Biryanis in Nepal, this is it. While others just slap coloured rice and par boiled meat and cook, Tasneem's serves authentic dum biryani cooked on slow flame over coal. The result; succulent meat with rice that captures every aroma you can imagine. Take it from me, did check out the kitchen to make sure of the cooking process and gracious Tasneem was kind enough to oblige and explain the intricacies of traditional Dum cooking style of Audh. Thumbs up for the biryanis. Will be back for more!

Any restaurant where the owner happens to be the Chef, you can expect pure magic. Chef Tasneem as in Tasneem's Kings Kitchen pleases your taste buds to the max. She serves a gastronomic delight that pleases all your senses. From starters such as Mutton Sheekh Kebaba and succulent Chicken Mughlai Tikka to the sinfully rich Butter chicken and top it with light and heavenly Biryani and for encore don't forget the Gajjar Ka halwa... each dish compliments the other. In the end you would be licking your fingers in delight as I did and so did my family.  Thanks Tasneem, we will be back to savour more of your delicacies and look forward to your charming visit to our table.

I usually don't do reviews, I am forced to do so as it made me sick after eating here. I think it was the mutton sheek kabab. Firstly, I didn't like the smell of the mutton kabab to begin with it smelt like a lamb meat and I believe it was old. 1 day after eating here I am feeling the gas and nauseated. Lastly, this restaurant needs to cut down on their oil/grease usage to prepare food. How can you make a dish with so much oil.

This place is a godsend for those of us in Kathmandu who sometimes finds ourselves looking for authentic Mughlai food. Unbelievably delicious Bohra Muslim cuisine food at very affordable prices. The host and waiters are very attentive and service is good n friendly. Food arrived quickly and everything was made really well. We started our meal with Mutton Sigdi and Chicken Tikka kebabs. They were flavorful and moist; marinated and spiced just right. My fav dishes are the Butter Chicken and the Chicken Sheekh Biryani. The ingredients were fresh and cooked in an authentic dum pukht style. This place is a true gem and perfect dining experience!

Order the butter chicken and that alone will make your visit worthwhile. It's the signature dish and it's delicious. As are the biryanis which are cooked in a traditional oven. The service is excellent and if it's your first time, Tasneem will visit your table to say hi. Definitely one of my favourite places to eat in the city.

column7: TASNEEM'S KINGS KITCHEN WAS AN ABSOLUTE DELIGHT!
column8: A must-visit place to experience fine Mughlai food lovers. Setting is just perfect. Mainly catring to non-veg- tikkas and kababs are just perfect. Setting a benchmark for non-veg appetizers. This place and its breathtaking ambience call for a memorable dinner with friends and family! to sum things up, Superb ambience, Great food and Courteous staff. Must-Go!!

During my visit to Kathmandu for business. I had the opportunity to visit Tasneems Kings Kitchen restaurant...... Must say the experience left me delighted. The food was awesome !!! It was rich in taste & the portions were really big. The food was cooked in traditional manner & rich in spices. The authentic favours were mind blowing to say the least. Chicken butter masala is their signature dish & it wont disappoint you. The freshness & tenderness of the meat is to be experienced. It melts in your mouth & the flavours of the spices just take over all your senses. It really goes well with indian bread like nan or tandoori roti...... Now to their magical dish the biryani...... Its wow !!! I can endore that it was the best biryani i ever had...... Magnificent is the word to describe their biryani. Food is amazing so is the ambience & their service is fantastic. I wouldn't ask for more....... I can't wait to visit this place again. When in Kathmandu, those looking for authentic Indian mughlai halal food. Look no further than Tasneem's Kings Kitchen..... For foodies like myself, its an exhilarating experience......
