column7: Awesome Halal Food....an absolute delight at Tasneem's kings kitchen.
column8: Visited with a few friends in Nov. A absolutely amazing place for curries, kebabs and some awesome biriyani. Some of us who came from the middle east could dine worry free as the food is 100% halal compliant. TKK...must visit and definitely recommend. Cheers.

column7: Some of the very few Halal restaurants in Kathmandu
column8: My friend was very particular about food being Halal and that's how we reached this restaurant. But the place has real good out door and indoor dining space though they are limited and small. The service and food was awesome.More

column7: Best places to Eat Indian Cuisine in Kathmandu
column8: Recently visited Tasneem's with friends on my trip to Nepal. This visit was the second time in past year and have to say each time the food has been really good and consistent. This place is a great place for savour Indian (Bori) Cuisine in Kathmandu!! And to my surprise I found my favourite Kings Beer from Goa at this lil gem in Kathmandu.  Highly recommended for a lovely meal.

column7: I love this place for their traditional Indian food.
column8: I have heard about Tasneem Shahani's biryani years ago when she was doing it from home. When I heard that she has opened an outlet, I was one of the firsts to visit and I and my family are a regulars since then. The food is traditionally cooked and is rich is spices. This is not something we would eat every other week but it is the best way for us to celebrate an occasion. If you love Indian Muslim cuisines then this is the authentic flavors you get in Kathmandu. I have tired Biryani is different cities of India and the cooking process and the ingredients are different. You have to try Tasleem's biryani to get the taste of Muslim Bohra cooking. The Chicken Butter Masala Boneless is their signature dish and it just melts in your mouth. It has a dash of sweetness to it but it goes very well with Naan or Tandoori Roti. I have tried a lot of Indian restaurants in Kathmandu but definitely this place has satisfied my foodie taste buds.

column7: Traditional and good, closed on Sunday's
column8: Went there on a Sunday just to find out it's closed, so be carful when you plan to go on Sunday. The day after I was close by and decided to have late lunch. Ordered some butter chicken, chicken tikka, dal and naan. The chicken tikka I have to say are the best I have ever had so I needed to order one more. The dal only so so. The butter chicken is very different to what I used to have but good as well. All in all a good place to go in a comfortable environment. This restaurant has no wifi which for me it should have as tourists want to check some trips for the days.

column7: Authentic Indian Food by An Amazing Host
column8: Had an amazing dining experience with friends and family at this beautiful, cozy Indian restaurant in Kathmandu. Food is original and wonderfully flavorsome - even the mint chutney served with variety of Tikkas is super delicious. The spicy Mango Panna and Gazar Halwa was awesome. The highlight was the authentic butter chicken which is served by almost every Indian restaurant but not many have got it so right. A must experience for anyone visiting or living in Kathmandu. Our special thanks to the wonderful host Tasneem who goes out of her way to ensure that every guest is truly delighted.... so are we.

TKK is a restaurant that is difficult to miss on the Jhamsikhel Road in Patan. The restaurant offers both outdoor and indoor seating. The ambience is subtle with modest cots placed at the entrance and simple yet comfortable furniture to seat you. The decor is minimalistic, creative and tastefully done to present a unique dining experience. Rainwater harvesting at the restaurant speaks volumes about the owner's commitment to offer a sustainable culinary experience to it's customers. We have been to the restaurant twice and have already become great admirers of the food that they serve here. The chicken butter masala is a speciality of TKK and it's delicious. You have to try it to experience a whole new taste for this otherwise run of the mill dish. You can request for the dishes to be made spicy or not so spicy as preferred by you. We had also ordered for some chicken biryani and the chicken in the biryani literally melted in our mouths. I have never had chicken that soft ever in my life. My dad does not normally like eating outdoors. Even he ended up having more than his normal share of the food! The most important part of any dining experience for us is the hospitality. The TKK staff does a fine job here. Beginning with getting your hands washed using the bowl and pitcher, already makes you feel special. This is an experience you probably wouldn't find at many restaurants. Dishes are served with a smile and the owner, Tasneem can often be seen interacting with the guests at the restaurant. This restaurant has several items to offer and we have only explored a few. There's a lot more still remaining to have us visiting the place several times over!

TKK is the place to go especially if you want to impress your family and friends with the Indian cuisine where prominent flavors of exotic spices blend together with the main ingredient in such harmony that the luscious taste of the final outcome lingers on to their memories for long.  I love the way chef Tasneem comes over to each table once the guests are seated, to make sure that their expectations are met, with care.  My own experience with TKK regarding their service for home parties has been very pleasant, every time I sought for it. This is mainly because chef Tasneem loves to consider every little details that are important for you so that you get to host your parties with least hassles while reaping up raving reviews for the food :-)

Had the pleasure of stopping by for dinner while in kathmandu. Wound up spending a couple of hours in the delightful company of the owners and feasting on foods that reminded me of Bombay.  Thank you for keeping it real.  Nice ambience and I like the eco consciousness. Little things that go a long way.  Traveler tip :: butter chicken and kebabs.
Great indian food. Can't say more apart from was perfectly cooked in aromatic spices. Beer was real cold and the staff were incredible. 10 out of 10

The building & premises of the restaurant is well maintained. Still gives traditional look . Enjoyed staying at courtyard. Also admire the ecofriendly settings. Food was tasty & nice presentation . The owner was very attentive ! To go with the concept or theme of restaurant it could make it more meaningful to have relevant music played rather than western ones !

column7: Simply best indian food in town at resonable price
column8: I visited Tasneem's King Kitchen during lunch hours. Owner personally greets all the customers at the restaurant. Place is beautifully set up with traditional indian and middle east theme. I ordered regular vegetarian mini meal which has everything required for a great lunch and is totally value for money.About the food , I must say I had probably the best palak paneer in ages. It was creamy and panner used was of great quality. I liked the dal served with it but i wised it could be more spicy like the ones we get in delhi. Roti was soft and great. There is no words to describe the briyani. Tasneem's Briyani is best known in town and it never disappoints. Thank you for the great lunch and would like people and tourist visits to Patan to definitely try Tasneem's restaurant.

Myself & my husband ordered mutton kebab and butter chicken. The kebab was so very dry we couldn't eat it, and the butter chicken was swimming with grease & the "meat" was like it had already been chewed , without a single "piece" of actual meat in the sauce. Very very disappointed ...

I cannot say enough good things about this place. This is by far my favorite restaurant in Lalitpur. I went for the first time with my husband and 2 kids last night. We had a couple appetizers, Kashmir Chicken and Palak Paneer, Jaree rice and chipati bread. They also gave us a sample of their signature dish, Butter Chicken. The food we ordered was fantastic, but the Butter Chicken was divine. If you go, try their signature dish, but based on our experience, you cant go wrong no matter what you order. I get the impression that our dishes were not as spicy as they normally make them as we had two small children with us and we asked them to keep it spiced for the kids. My husband had gone with a friend on a different occasion and he said that the food was much spicier (and delicious!).  But the food was only the half of it. The owner is so kind and engaging. Made us feel so welcome. Our waiter made recommendations on how much to order (perfect amount!), the food came out fast but without making us feel hurried. The best part was that we had brought our 16 month old and 3 year old with us, and the staff helped us entertain them so we could enjoy our meal. I don't expect that can happen every time (eg if its a particularly busy night), but it made the whole experience perfect.

My husband and I went there a week ago for the second time..the food was simply delicious, great tasting, well cooked and hygienic. Tasneem offered a complimentary taste of a mouth watering and very tender chicken dish which name I have forgotten even after asking twice...So sorry!!! The eco friendly and clean environment and the nice hindi lounge music, loud enough to be enjoyed and low enough to allow conversation, made the experience even better. Of course you can find cheaper places, but having been living here 8 months now, I prefer to cook my own food in order to save my money and preserve my health, and go to a restaurant only when it's worth it. Tasneem's restaurant is definitely worth visiting! Keep up the good job!

column7: Real food from people who care
column8: Two of my friends and I arrived in Kathmandu, and we were very hungry. We were told to go here, so we made the walk. Upon arrival, we were greeted by a friendly hostess and promptly sat outside in the patio area. The decorations and aura gave this place an authentic feel for an Indian restaurant.  We got our menus and started thinking about our order, when a lady (who turned out to be Tasneem herself) came by to help us decide what to order. I am an American who cannot normally handle a lot of heat from the spices, but I was traveling with two guys who love spicy food. She encouraged us to get a couple appetizers as well as some different dishes.  My absolute favorites were the Mutton Appetizer and the House Special Butter Chicken. The Mutton is pounded flat, then spiced and fried. It is still moist, but crispy. The flavour seems to just be jam-packed in this bite. Then came the Butter Chicken. I haven't had a dish that tasted this delicious in a while. The food textures of meat and gravy melt together leaving this savory experience. Pair this with their garlic butten naan, and you have a winner.  They had some happy hour specials on local beers and cocktails. The mocktails are made with fresh juices.  We then met Tasneem's husband. They were very kind and gave us recommendations for things to do in Kathmandu and surrounding areas. I strongly recommend going to see Tasneem if you visit. You will not be disappointed. We liked it so much, we came back for a second meal in 4 days there.  The second time, we ended up ordering pretty much the same; we just knew what to expect. We were able to add a little heat to the dishes this time, and it was still amazing for all of us.  It is nice in the patio area, with the cool breezes and the ambiance. There is no wifi as they encourage you to talk with your table, but this does not mean that they are not engaged with their customers. The owners take pride in the ability to listen to customers and their experiences.  Do yourself a favour and check this place out.

Yummy all the way!!! makes you want to come back for more pronto. Had taken my mother-in-law who is most finicky about eating out. If she loved it then no more to be said. Even doggybagged her mutton sheesh kebabs!! The veg biryani was a real treat for veggie me. Going back soon with more family and friends. Love their mini meals.

You enter through a old style house by the road and on either side of you are traditional day beds, you will need these later. Ask for Tasmeen herself, and let her know what you are in the mood for and she'll put a spread of food in front of you like you wouldn't believe. She knows her menu intimately, and she knows what will go together. I believe in giving her free will to put your table's dishes as she likes. Also trust her as unlike other owners she won't just say have the most expensive dishes. After one meal you'll be hooked. And heading for the day beds...

column7: Best indian food and very attentive service
column8: The restaurant is decorated in a minimalistic, modern and refined manner. Not much plush and plunder. Only the stuff itbrealy needs. no WiFi as concept: people should enjoy the food and communicate with each other. Nice little courtyard. The staff withoutbexemption was very attemptive, friendly, and flexible. That contributes well to the unique atmosphere. All the food was extremely tasty and all was prepared fresh. What we can especially recommend: chicken tikka, kadai ghosh, mutton birvani (as soft and tender as it can be), paneer tawa, navaratna korma and Kashmiri aloo.  We will certainly come again!

column7: Great food served with a smile.
column8: Many placesserve good food here in kathmandu, what's different at Tasneem's Kings Kitchen is that it comes with a smile and with warm personalised service.  From starters that include amazing chicken sheekth kabab, onwards to main course of chicken angara and topped with biryanis every morsel is pure joy.  I entered this place with lots of expectations after reading the reviews, left with a grin ear to ear. Shall be back soon Tasneem. For the pineapple halwa i missed cause uou were sold out.

Tasneem's Kings kitchen in Kathmandu is one of the most authentic restaurant to taste genuine halal chicken biryani from Mumbai. Super tasty snacks served by the professional and ever smiling staff. A must visit.

We've been to Tasneem's several time, the first out of curiosity as it was the newest restaurant in the block. On our first visit with friends and our children, we liked the food but were so distracted by the fumes from the generator which gave me a gas pain post-dinner. I wrote to them in their Facebook page and right away they replied they will do something about it. We came back some more during day time and we kept on coming back mostly for their butter naans. The best we have tasted. And the gravy dishes-- you will end up scooping every drop from the bowl. Recently we went back again at dinner time and the friendly owner was at the reception area and recognized me. Right away she mentioned that they already remedied the generator. True enough there was no more fumes! We felt so grateful for their attention to those details brought up by their clients. And they also added plain rice to their menu! Much to our delight. It goes well with any main course or gravy dishes as well.  The staff, manager are just too friendly. Even the owners come all the way to our table to ask how we are.  So for every Indian dish craving, we would go back to Tasneem's.

Cute and tasteful decor with attentive staff who are not staring down your face and lovely ambience with delectable bohra muslim cuisine. Yes - this is the perfect restaurant for families. Small touches like the table mat with the history of the bohra muslim cuisine adds to the entire affair. And most importantly as the owners Tasneem and Harsh specifically says - we want guests to come here to dine and enjoy the food and conversation rather than look for free wifi and be glued to their sets holds true.

Pure Indian cuisine just like home cooked. Mainly because the owner Tashneem herself is overlooking each and every dish that is being ordered. Most Indian restaurants in town are very common in style and taste. But at Tashneem's the food is uniquely satisfying. It stays in your memory for a long time till you need to go back again. Ambience is simple and clean. Its just about the food.

column7: Mumbai at your feet... in Nepal
column8: This goes out to a place which stands out like a red rose midst of an arid desert of food world in the himalayan kingdom, just launched called Tasneem's kings kitchen. The name might seem synonymous to a cigarette brand with the 'kings' making appearance in the restaurant name but the food seemed rich and healthy as it gets. This comes perfectly at a time when I had given up all hopes in the country to find decent food (barring the quintessential masu bhaat and defacto nepali national dish momo) forget a stellar biryani which comes across as the most celebrated food article of my existance.  Tasneem's name popped up through referrals from the limited social circle I maintain in the city and stumbling upon a tasting session which introduced me to Seekh Kabab Biryani (not sure mutton or chicken) which left me spellbound until I could have a more heartier meal from the lady's 'kings' kitchen.  Lo & Behold... comes my sonny's second birthday!!  Whats for the menu?? with a pretentious hesitance (considering my unfaltering suggestion 'Biryani') I suggested 'Biryani' to my wife from 'kings' kitchen which all my desi and Nepali friend circle would wholesomely enjoy a cuisine from my birth place 'Mumbai' which I could show off without being failed upon through the 'kings' kitchen by the first lady of biryani 'Tasneem'; given a rare free hand by the DMA of my household I grabbed my opportunity of placing the order for my guests liberally and as I willed. The menu for the party was Chicken Biryani, Mutton Korma, Chicken Cutlets and grilled chicken legs. So let us categorically go through the real epiphany of the gastronomical trip...  1. Chicken Biryani: meat a little too well cooked with well endowed flavors that reminded me of the scene from 'ratatouille' where the critic is pulled back to childhood which was a similar emotional shockwave I went through with the first morsel with the scent of Mumbai. Quality of rice was as authentic as it gets perfect long grain with the right girth.  2. Mutton Korma: the taste still lives on my taste buds tickling the neurons every time I think about it. Slightly spicy with amazing quality of meat which is a rare feat in this country, worth a try.  3. Chicken Cutlets: a little less oil than produced by the kingdom of Saudi Arabia which dripped out of each piece but tasted great, I would suggest it to be had right at the restaurant considering the egg batter it was fried in retained much of the oil and turned it soggy by the time they reached home.  4. Grilled chicken legs: were as good as one made at home with utter amount of care and love (through liberal amount of masala) before it was grilled. Still I would say a little overcooked as the meat left the bone while it was picked up from the plate.  5. Paneer Chole Biryani: was for one lonewolf in the gang who was a vegetarian, where the verdict was pretty clear when she requested for a doggy bag of remaining biryani. Since I hadn't tasted it, i cannot brag much.  All the dishes were accompanied by copious amount of Kanda (like we call in Mumbai)/Pyaaz (for more North Indian expose) and other salad items.  Nevertheless, Tasneem is going to see a lot of me in her 'kings' kitchen where I would wish to sample every dish on the menu before I leave this country.  The place would definitely has the potential to be an iconic (the bloody real deal not the Nepali excuse for) Indian cuisine in the time to come. So brace up you lady, I would be recommending the place to every person I come across preaching it like a religion.

column7: A century old recipie relived.A legacy. And the taste of the royals. Muhglai Extravazanza
column8: Ooh god when will Nepal start having good Indian Restaurant. Guys any place for Biryanis??  These are juz a couple of questions we discuss thinkinhthinking about Mughlai food in Nepal.  Tasneems is now open for a mouthwatering experience. A place where your tastebuds starts dancing. dekho kaise Jeeb Laplapai Is a statement for Tasneems.  Wonderfully designed menu and magic of the Indian Chefs specially who bring the legacy of Bora Mughlai Food. A blend of taste and tradition.  Go for it and see .

column7: One of the best in town with an unique menu.
column8: If you want an unique menu this is the place. The ambience is very creative. I have been to many restaurants during my stay in Kathmandu in the past couple of years, but I haven't come across a menu as in Tasneems. I understand it changes daily. Chicken cutlets melt in your mouth. I would definitely go back for Chicken tandoori drum sticks and chicken-sheekh-kabob biriyani.

I've been staying down the road from Tasneem's since the day they opened last month. I stopped in one fateful day just to look around, stayed for lunch--and have been back a dozen times since!  Each and every meal has been exquisite. The select menu changes regularly, and I have not been disappointed by any of the new offerings. I've been working in Kathmandu off and on for nine years, and this is nothing like other food available in the city.  Jhamsikhel has become known for good restaurants, but Tasneem's puts all the old stand-bys to shame.  I don't have enough space here to go on about the beautiful building, comfortable courtyard, and of course delightful hostess, Tasneem herself...!

This cafe takes pride in customer service and it shows in its employees. I visited four times in one week and they were always courteous, prompt and attentive.  You’ll have plenty of food options and breakfast is all day. Unique drinks like the turmeric twist add a fun alternative to other local cafes. However, the delivery of these items always felt a little slow. Maybe it’s because I’m American but 5 min for a latte and 15 min for a sandwich at such a small cafe seemed strange.  Indoor seating will be very limited but if it’s warm outside they have a great covered outdoor seating area to include a couple comfy couches with room for up to five people.

I don’t think I’ve ever ordered something from Kairos I didn’t absolute love! The breakfast here is delicious , especially the French toast, and the coffee is amazing! All the staff are great and are always so friendly!

column7: Fantastic cafe with friendly staff and great food and coffee
column8: I've loved stopping in at the Kairos cafe the past weeks when I am in KTM for either a quick morning cup of coffee or to have lunch with friends. They have filtered water available for free, friendly staff with great English, good wifi and the food tastes great without fail (and is clean!). The cafe has a great atmosphere, although there is a bit of noise from the street on the other side of the wall and there's a variety of seating. I for sure recommend this place to anyone - especially if you're looking for a bit of an escape from the craziness of KTM.

My friends and I have been coming here daily the past week or so and I must say I've been absolutely blown away by the staff and their radiant personalities. They are so attentive and eager to accommodate. Their food and drinks are stellar - great prices and excellent quality. I certainly plan on being back again and will undoubtedly come here!

In a part of town where brunch options are relatively plentiful but largely hit-or-miss, and even the "best" places are just "acceptable," Kairos is a beacon of brunchy delight.  They serve fresh roasted Himalayan coffee -- not unusual in this part of town, but in this case, it's mighty good. French press or pour-over. Fancier coffee drinks available too. The iced lemon-mint is also quite nice. Plenty of fresh mint, but without coming across as an over-hydrated salad.  I'd consider the Gurkha Wrap to be their unofficial house specialty. It's chock full of delicious morning munchies, and accompanied by a bit of spicy sauce and sweet yogurt.  The English Breakfast is exactly what one should expect. Perfectly runny eggs, real pork sausage with real pork sausage taste, and tender breakfast potatoes. The baked beans, though likely from a can, are accented by a few tweaks from the chef, which makes them downright respectable. The chef, by the way, is a veteran of Radisson, so he has a decent idea of what westerners want in a late morning, lightly hungover meal.  On the topic of staff, I can't say enough nice things. We poked our heads in through the gate to ask if they served breakfast, and if they'd mind our dogs on the patio. The waitress, sunny as day, replied, "Oh DEFINITELY! Welcome to Kairos Cafe!" Her cheerful countenance didn't diminish for even a moment during our entire stay. And it was genuine. Like she enjoyed working there!  Feel good about eating here. Part of your money benefits their efforts to stop human trafficking. As if you didn't feel good enough about how that Gurkha Wrap filled your belly!  The ambient music is just that: ambient. None of this trying-too-hard downtempo house. Simply, it's brunch music. Easygoing jams that your girlfriend / wife enjoys... and you secretly sing along to when you're the only one home. Were you thinking of Jack Johnson just now? Ben Harper? Ryan Adams? Me too.  The only negative is the relative location. It's across from that high school by the zoo. They're doing construction, so our brunch-time conversation was accented by clanging and crashing of steel beams from just over the wall. Also, there's that dust pit of a road.  I almost hate to review this place. I don't want it to become the next Soma, where I'm doomed to run into everyone I know, when all I crave is french press coffee and a (complimentary) copy of the Himalayan Times. But a business with the sensibility of Kairos must be celebrated and supported. And with the current fuel shortage, they may be the last place in Patan where you can score a decent brunch. They had the foresight to stock up, but who knows for how long that will last?

We came here many times on our stay in Kathmandu. It allowed us an escape from the busy streets and has a very relaxed and chilled atmosphere. We also love coffee and struggled to find a good coffee anywhere, so this is an absolute gold...More

Very nice relaxt coffee place with hangout spots, music, gift shop, various type of food and snacks and... most important... Really good coffee! Nice to see that you can escape the busy dusty streets and relax in a place with real atmosphere :) Prices for...More

It's a place where I feel myself at home. Very pleasant staff and interesting menu. You need to read the "kar.ma coffee" book to get in touch with the history of this place and to discover how and where all the ceramic pots are made, how everything related to coffee is handmade.  The organic coffee beans are provided by local farms located over 1000m altitude.  I already spend a couple of hours here chilling out from the perpetual Thamel rush.  You can buy from here coffee related stuff, even soap and candles made from grounded coffee.

I've been there twice already and I cannot wait to go back. kar.ma COFFEE stands out among all the Coffee places because of its unique interior and a very laid back atmosphere with very pleasant staffs and one of the best coffees in Kathmandu.

column7: Cool coffee place run by very nice people
column8: Look, I come from 'Merica, home of the small mom & pop coffee house before Starbucks ruined it all, and this place is reminiscent of a time when real people ran an establishment well and gave good service and offered a quality product at a decent price. That's what you get here. So go.

Definitely set out for coffee afficianados. They know how to brew here in traditional ways. It's difficult to find as their signage is quite poor but it is located on 3rd floor across from Moksh.  The nice thing about the atmosphere is its location in a quiet dead end parking area. Expect a more student, casual atmosphere. Not a place a to sit down to do work but more to hang with friends. Some of the decor is quite funky, i do like it, albeit its maybe too 'busy' with all the posters and leaflets.  As it was our first time, we were totally confused what to do. The person didn't communicate very well when i asked what to do. Apparently you order the coffee and pick it up yourself, paying later but there are no prices...you pay what you think its worth. However any sweet snacks have to be paid up front. This is all good when someone explains it, otherwise you are left feeling awkward.  Not exactly my style but I will return quite simply for the great tasting coffee.

column7: Best Coffee, Best Atmosphere, Best Concept.
column8: Coffee is served up on a donation basis, pay what you would like. However, this is only for a standard cup of hot coffee. Ice Coffee is 70 rupees, but this is still the absolute best deal on coffee in all of Kathmandu. They have delicious cookies for sale and the staff are all very sweet. Free wifi and a great environment. Located below a Jazz Conservatory so there is a great crowd of people and you'll likely hear some great live music being played upstairs.

Really great coffee and a lovely relaxing place to sit. Love the products and havent seen anything like it in Kathmandu but it was a shame that there weren't many biscuits without nuts in as I'm allergic.

Even though I am not a "coffee drinker" but rather go for tea, I keep on getting stuck in this coffee shop since it opened a few months ago. It is run by an Austrian lady and she keeps on adding new products to her portofolio constantly. The place is coffee-shop and showroom at the same time, where you can not only drink coffee but also shop for locally produced, recycled or imported products related to coffee. Lucky for me, they have added tea to their menue some time ago, which is also grown in Nepal - like the coffee - and of outstanding quality.  The "kar.ma" in the name probably refers to the pricing system for the coffee specialities - there is no menue - you just pay what you think it's worth. Because of that it's not one of the many overpriced restaurants in the area where you usually only meet foreigners or rich Nepalis, but just about everyone that likes to have a coffee or tea once in a while. The coffee-shop has quickly developed into a meeting place for many ex-pats living in the area and people working in nearby offices. Many customers are also coming from the "Pranamaya Yoga Studio" below the place or the "Kathmandu Jazz Conservatory" right above. Interesting conversations and new friendships are nearly inevitable which makes it a perfect starting point if you are new to the area. If there is no one around to talk to, you can always use the free Wifi to surf the net until somebody interesting shows up. Be careful as this place is somehow addictive. For me and some of my friends it has become something like an external living room!  They don't have a food menue as such but sell various home-made organic cookies. As they cooperate with nearby restaurants, you can ask them to order sandwiches or other simple foods which are then delivered to the coffee-shop.

column7: Clean fresh authentic pizza and fabulous service
column8: The restaurant is situated down a road that by comparison to the Main Street, is quiet and touristy. However, it was a welcomed change to enter into this pizzeria and feel welcomed and not harassed and served with genuine heartfelt service. The staff were attentive and had this glow of positive energy about them and we really enjoyed every tasty mouthful. I have a home in Italy and my own pizza oven and this was better!
We are in our winter vacation at Katmandu we are travelling so many ancient places and restaurants now finally we are here to experience Awesome coffee here we enjoying a lots nice coffee.

column7: Safe for westerners. Good Pizza and Pasta.
column8: This is one of my safe hygienic restaurants. They are a bit expensive. However, if you share a Pizza with someone, Pizza and drinks will cost about $12.00 after tax and service charge. They have a great Mexican Pizza and good build your own pizza (4 toppings.) Their double shot Americano is good for a coffee break. They are pretty big with a large, elaborate area min the back. I prefer the more simpler, traditional area in front where I can watch the people outside go by. Service is excellent. The only ding is the VAT charge (17%) and service charge (10%) that can add up quickly.

column7: Prefect pizzas, great grills, So-so service
column8: I love it when you can watch the pizza being prepared and cooked in a real wood-fired brick oven. I had a twist on the traditional 4-cheese pizza - where else would you find Yak cheese, along with goat's cheese, mozzarella and parmesan on a fresh crispy dough? My friends had grills - chicken, fish and pork ribs, and one had Mexican wraps. We also had some chicken momos for starters ... but they arrived with the main course in the end. It's a popular place with good decor and a great atmosphere, though the service is slow and it's pricey by local standards. All-in-all though, a really good and enjoyable meal out.

When I came inside the cafe and there was a waiter standing on the corner.I told him 1 person and than he pointed other direction to go.I could I know there's another place to sit.What a mannerless guy. Anyway I ordered the pasta chicken with a Rosemary.OMG the pasta was not boiled or must be frozen it was chewgum and may be a few small tiny tiny piece of chicken. Here is the pics. I was hungry so just ate a little bit of it. First time here and will be the last time too. VERY & AWFUL.

I am Italian and I loooove Italian food but while abroad I am always afraid to try Italian restaurants. Pianob is an exception the food is simply amazing. We tried the pasta, the meet, the pizza. Everything just perfect. And the wineee... you can drink real Italian wine and the prices are really affordable. The restaurant is super clean and Gian the owner takes care of every detail. Highly recommended

column7: The best italian restaurant in KTM
column8: The best italian restaurant in KTM. Good food mostly with original Italian products. Professional service. Recommended.

Whether you are just passing through KTM or a resident, Piano B is the place to go for the best informal dining in town. It has an understated Italian bistro vibe with excellent service, and a menu that reflects the owners real understanding of pairing fine Italian food with great wines.  It's a place for a celebration, a date or just an impromptu meal with friends. The appetizers range in price and size and are great to share and the main courses are hearty but not overbearing. And of course there are amazing desserts!  Yes, I've been a lot and love that you can also buy meats and cheeses from their deli counter.  Go and enjoy a real treat in the heart of Patan.

I really enjoyed our evening at Piano B. Great food on a daily changing menu. I had duck breast which was superbly tender, juicy and beautifully moist. Didn't expect that in Kathmandu. Good range of dishes. Superb ice cream. Service was slow on a busy night but staff were very pleasant and helpful. Not cheap for Kathmandu but great value.

With great ambience, this little eatery is a real find in Nepal. Plenty of wines and interesting Italian style meats and cheeses are on offer and understandably this restaurant seems popular with the ex pats.

There are very few places in Kathmandu where you can go when you're past the 'branch' stage and don't really want to end up with Dal Bhat. Unfortunately, this can happen quite often.  And therefore, this is where Piano B comes in. Good food. Good quantity. Reasonable prices. What's not to like?  Parking on the street, so be a tad careful if you're showing up in your shiny new cars (although I've parked my car on the streets every time with no problem, or harassment from the traffic police).

column7: Cosy Italian Trattoria style ambience at its best!
column8: Piano B is the place to go in Kathmandu for genuine Italian food wine, coffee and homemade ice cream! Small place with a typical Italian ambience and family style friendly services. The menu is limited and changes daily but has always classics like homemade pasta, pizza or roast lamb, prepared with great care and fresh ingredients. Very attentive and friendly staff add to the experience and the world class top of the line homemade chocolate ice cream rounds it up as a no miss out Kathmandu experience! Open all days from lunch until 10pm except Sundays when it’s closed!

column7: Classic Italian set up but food so lala
column8: If you enter the small restaurant, you feel at home if you are in favor for Italian cuisine: red wine bottles exposed at the shelf, simple tables, all Italian featues. The menue is not offering too many pastas or main dishes or entry, so you are in the attention of high quality food. I took a cotton cheese with asparagus... and Gnocchi with lamb ragou, however was a bit disappointed, considering the taste and given the price. May be it feels better if you not arriving straight away from Europe and have past some days in Italy recently. The PRIMITIVO however wasn't simply good. You better got a beere.

This charming place is a true gem. Delicious food, great wine, relaxed atmosphere, courteous staff and soothing music. A perfect place to end a busy day of sightseeing in Kathmandu. I have already visited it twice this week, and I may go one more time before returning to London.

column7: BY FAR THE VERY BEST ITALIAN FOOD IN ALL OF KATHMANDU
column8: Real Italian food by real Italian who knows how to prepare the best dishes Italy has to offer. They use italian products, the place is delightful; the head person is charming and helpful and you will never be disappointed by PIANO B

Piano B is a hidden gem in Ekantakuna, Patan with an ambiance that takes you almost back to Tuscany in second! Charming, friendly and great value & their chocolate ice cream is absolutely world class, don't miss it when in Kathmandu!

column7: Best Restaurant in Nepal - Hands Down
column8: Where to begin?  I arrived on a Sunday evening (I was staying at the Piano B&B above the restaurant). I walked in and instantly knew this was somewhere I could trust. I told the owner, Antonio that I was too tired to think and to just choose what he thought I should eat. There are very few restaurants I would be happy to have choose the food for me, Piano B is one of them. The food is absolutely delicious! I mean every single thing they make is delicious, from the fresh bread, olive oil and balsamic to nibble on while you order, to the cheese and meat plater to the perfectly al dente pasta dishes to the high quality wine they store.  Antonio has established an amazing little restaurant and to anyone in Kathmandu who has heard of Piano B but never visited, you really need to go there. This guy is working his butt off to deliver quality and having spent 7 weeks in Kathmandu this summer, I have seen the time and effort he is putting into his place.  Having stayed at the B&B above I had the pleasure of eating many many times at this restaurant, its hard to find food this good in my current city of Boston, never mind Kathmandu. And if you're reading this thinking, "Italian food? In Nepal? Why?" then you've the same thought my colleagues had when they travelled to Nepal for 4 days last week towards the end of my trip. After I took them there, one commented in the morning that he dreamt of the Spinach Ravioli and despite the two thinking I was crazy to take them to an Italian on their four day visit to Nepal, they insisted we go back the very next night, and were again served with the same amazing food.  Like the B&B the restaurant is well managed, the staff are polite and professional, the ambience is tasteful as is the music. They stock real beer, real wine, real COFFEE, and trust me all of it meets the highest of standards of a classy Italian restaurant. I would say this is the best restaurant in all of Kathmandu and probably Nepal, yes its not traditional Nepali food, but quality is quality!  So just go there! And get the little onion dish starter thing. Oh and the chocolate lava cake. And an espresso to finish. And drink their house white.  I'm coming back!

Reviews of this restaurant have been glowing, but as a former professional restaurant reviewer and wine writer, I have learnt not to take them verboten. It was good to walk into this buzzy little place on a Friday night and the food was indeed good but the big disappointment is that for a wine bar/restaurant with a reputedly serious attitude to wine, the wait staff have no basic training in understanding wine. When I enquired what grape variety an unfamiliar wine on the list was, I was told it was "dry." When I repeated my enquiry about which grape it had been made from, I was told "No grapes - dry." What a shame in an otherwise commendable place. Disappointing also was the lack of contact from the (presumably) owner manager. I tried two or three times to make eye contact to exchange pleasantries with no success. After reading the reviews, I had assumed (bad idea) that he would understand the importance of relationship-building and hosting in the hospitality industry. The ambience was very pleasant and there is an excellent list of imported food and wine items which must be a real achievement in Nepal. The Friday night buzz was high but personally too noisy for a mature age quiet enjoyment. An excellent wine bar, but as a passionate wine love, please educate the staff.

column7: The ONLY Italian place in Kathmandu
column8: Piano B is the only restaurant in Kathmandu where you can find real Italian food, and a real Italian atmosphere as well. FRESHLY made pasta is available, and you will tell the difference...The selection of cheeses is making some justice to the incredible variety of Italian cheese (from mozzarella, to taleggio and gorgonzola) and you can find fresh salame, prosciutto, mortadella and more. The oil is of good quality and they make a fresh gelato (ice cream) as well as good tiramisu. The restaurant is run with passion, and the idea is one of reproducing Italian food as much as possible. Here, luckily, you would not find things like "spaghetti bolognese" that ARE NOT ITALIAN and are honestly disgusting, but tagliatelle with rabbit sauce, or freshly made pesto, or spaghetti with bottarga. THIS Is Italian. They are using real olive oil, and also real Italian cocktails, like "spritz" are available. PIano B is highly, higly recommended.

column7: Like an oasis in a desert
column8: I stayed in Piano B&B for two months (March - April) this year and as a first time visitor to Nepal having fantastic meals every night was a real life saver. Antonio (the owner) and his staff go to lengths to ensure that your experience in Piano B is a pleasant one. The food is fantastic, the pasta (on many occasions home made by Antonio - his ravioli are 5 star) is delicious, the restaurant has a very fine selection of beers and wine which although might seem expensive to some (based on some other reviews I was reading) is still cheaper than other places in Kathmandu. Highly recommended!

Piano B is one of the best restaurants in Kathmandu. It is expensive for Kathmandu standards, but well worth the price. My partner had veal (an absolute rarity in Nepal) and it was fabulous. Pasta is good, wine is good, dessert is good. Overall just fantastic!

I believe this is the only real Italian restaurant other than the great pizza places in Kathmandu. So on that basis there is really no competition. You can tell they really try their best to serve authentic Italian dishes and use whatever fresh produce they can find. The couple who owns it are eager to please although they really need to train their local staff more especially when it gets busy. 3 1/2 stars because of the wait times and service..

After trekking to EBC we have beeb trying a couple of renowned Italian restaurant, one in Thamel one here. Piano B wins with any doubt. Real italian quality, ambience, good wine. Prices are ok! Next trekking will come here again.

column7: BEST PLACE TO EAT IN NEPAL
column8: Firstly I will start by saying this is a genuine review. Piano B is our favourite place to eat in Nepal never mind Kathmandu, the food is first class, full of flavour and taste amazing. My husband and I go on a regular basis because...More

column7: Hot hot hot but nice atmosphere and food
column8: Its a small eatery so don't come on Friday night at 7:30 and expect to find an empty table! It is very popular with the expat crowd and easy to know why - fresh daily specials, - good choice of wines and beers - and a very pleasant - tho HOT - ambience. I had a spinach ravioli and my husband had tuna steak. Both well prepared. Couldn't manage the chocolate mousse but looked wonderful. If you're a touristi, the location saying "Patan" may be confusing as Patan is generally the area where the temples are found and it is a good 3 miles away from Piano. If you're getting a taxi, say "Jawalakhel Chowk" (roundabout) - all taxi drivers know this. Beyond that, it is almost opposite DFID offices which some taxis will know. The map on trip advisor seems accurate so once you reach the chowk, take the road that the zoo is on and continue for about 1/4 mile. The road bears round to the right and Piano is just past the bend. It is a convenient place to go to if you have visited Patan temples - currently closed due to earthquake - or the free trade shops along the Pulchowk road.
Real Italian food in Kathmandu with relaxing background music. Order Bruschetta and you will understand what I mean for real Italian food!
That is it. Try it for yourself. Charming, Italian, tasty, trendy. Still good old Europe. Well done!

column7: A friendly, charming and delicious option In Kathmandu
column8: A true neighborhood trattoria, with a deli, bar, reasonable wine list and daily specials. Everything is homemade and you can see the pride that goes into the fresh ingredients, ambiance, and welcoming atmosphere. Desserts could use a little work, but hey, after the ravioli or slow cooked pork, maybe another glass of Prosecco would suffice!

I guess I had the best pasta for this year. The ravioli with salmon filling just blew my mind. The staff just handsome; the wine paired with the authentic atmosphere and a chef who knows what he is talking about just makes this restaurant the best in the country. If you are looking for real Italian food go there!

column7: Very-very good iatalian cuisine in Nepal
column8: Not very large space but very nice environment to have some real Italian food. the owner is Italian as far as I know and keeps it well. the menu is not vast but you can find there many dishes to your selection. the salads are absolutely great. they also have good coffee. prices are not high but not low as well, the food deserves to pay some extra. PS: the waiter was not speaking English and didn't know the menu well and didn't put some items into the bill at the end ... ;)

We have only been here one time but are really eager to go back! It is a little bit of a splurge, but it was genuinely the tastiest meal I have had in quite awhile! The atmosphere is clean but cozy and perfect for this little Italian treasure! And, the food...the food was truly excellent! REAL Italian, which is a rare find here! They have a nice selection of wine. I had the ravioli, and the flavor was wonderful! I can't say enough what a treat the food was! It will be a bit of a special occasion place for us, as it is a little more expensive than just an average place, and I probably wouldn't take my kids there, but for a special treat...WHAT A TREAT!

We discovered Piano B while searching our hotel in Patan, after a long motorbike ride on the mountains. It was dark in the evening, but we recognised something familiar, this little, cozy and modern italian restaurant. Nice atmosphere and excellent food, just like in Italy, very unusual to find outside Italy, homemade pasta cooked "al dente". A very friendly place and nice host, like an old friend. Very recommended.

The warmth and atmosphere of a real trattoria welcomes you as you get in, indulge in Gian' unique Venetian spritz aperitive, the rare selection of Italian affettati then is a logistic miracle, the large collection of Italian wines, taste the Apulian Primitvo. And then indulge in the unique selection of home made pastas, my favorite, the crespelle ai funghi. Generous with portions and table space Piano B was the missing item of the menu in the endless list of places in Kathmandu, a definite must, worth a visit and even more a relapse.

I just wish I lived closer to Piano B - really the authentic Italian taste - all exceptionally fresh ingredients and anything that is not available locally, is imported from Italy eg. the salame. I loved the antipasto - vegetables pickled in olive oil and the perfectly cooked pasta (al dente) with a delicious funghi sauce. The creme caramel was also a real treat. The ambience is like an Italian bar. It was a great experience with a group of friends and a few glasses of wine.

column7: real italian food not similar food
column8: I had LasaGNE it was great and specially the way of prepare food i like most and very clean and hygienic the place of restaurant is in downtown and decoration of the restaurant is awesome. I recommend everyone who really want real Italian food not similar food then defenetely try this.

This romantic restaurant has a wonderful atmosphere. Our waiter was humble and unobtrusive, a true professional. We had spaghetti bolognese, corn fritters with spicy tofu and rice pancake with veg topping . Also an amazing desert consisting of a steamed dumplings filled with molasses and...More
Really traditional, authentic and delicious Newari food! Such incredible flavours and variety - get the Newari set menu! Lovely little courtyard at the back with a tree growing up through it.

column7: Nearly authentic Newari food (if it were more so, they would probably lose customers).
column8: Very satisfying, the Newari set meal with beaten rice (baji) recalls Newari party food, good quality, and if you want some true local specialities such as goat brain, or dried buffalo flank, or buff achar, that is also sometimes available (ask what the untranslated items on the menu are and if they are available). Lapsi achar was excellent, as are the chatamari. Yomari dough a bit thick and chewy. Service is good, the outdoor patio a pleasant place to eat. Relatively inexpensive, and they are willing to give you seconds if you ask for them, along with extra roasted chili peppers if you want it to be more authentic.

The owner is very helpful with the food order. We decided to sample several types of Newari food and he helped choose a variety of dishes for us. Everything was very tasty and the service was fast. The atmosphere is very pleasant with lots of seating choices.

We ordered a large number of small dishes and loved every one. We tried the rice wine, momos, kuwati soup, skewers, platters, every mouthful was delicious! My new favourite cuisine! Great selection, warm atmosphere & very comfortable, choice of cushion or chair seating.

Wandering through the streets of Patan on our way to Durbar square, we discovered this understated gem (just past the mall). Rajiv and his lovely wife, greeted us with the warmest of welcomes. With a charming atmosphere, attentive service with fresh and delicious food. Great for couples and small groups with a rooftop terrace.

This zoo should be called an exotic animal prison instead. There is a clear disregard for animal husbandry and a complete lack of conservation education. I wish I hadnt gone and I employ you not to go. The animals enclosures are pathetically small and covered in feces. There's no attempt to create natural environments for the animals; further thers no attempt to even have clean and proper enclosures. The animals are in poor health and terrible conditions. If you have a geart at all then dont go!!!

Central zoo of kathmandu valley is located 30 min drive from kathmandu Durbar square to Lalitpur. This zoo was establish more than 100yr old is by Rana primeminister. At that time it was one of the best and lovely place to visit for the animals of Nepal. In the courses of time it could not be modified only very little changes are done to accommodate more animals. Instead of more animals in the zoo we found less animals but more people due to the growth of population and there is no place for children to take. People come here to see people instead animals. Unfortunately one of the beautiful historic zoo of Kathamandu turned ugly zoo.

column7: bad condition of animals and enclosures - stealing from foreigners
column8: we went with the intention of showing our 22 month old son the animals he was learning. We made a big mistake, the animals are few, unhealthy and in prisons - my son did not reognise anything. we were also told there was a child friendly environment, again we were shocked as it was some dirty shutes and no grass, food, shade, or anywhere for him to play. most annoying was the fact that I am British and my wife Nepai - my son is Nepali, and for the elephant ride they wanted to make him - 22 months old - pay fives more than Nepali children, he is Nepali! so the fee for Nepalis is good for the bad environment, charging me four times more as a 'foreigner' is annoying but ok, but asking my Nepali son to pay adult white foreign price is insulting and racist as he just - by accident - looks like his father and not his mother - we are not tourists as live here, pay tax, and work - so not only is it a good example of the cruelty animals suffer here, but a good example how people are exploited and everything is about money here

My husband and I spent a very enjoyable morning with our 3 grandsons (5, 7 and 9 years old) walking through this shady, well-laid-out zoo. We felt we could observe most of the animals well and were impressed with the variety. Seeing the elephant take a stroll through the zoo was an added surprise.
Pretty run down and depressing to see the animals in their small cages. This place needs to have a private company take over and make it a proper zoo since Nepal has so many exotic animals.

Unless you have experienced all that Kathmandu has to offer, you might want to skip this one.I was told the zoo here wasn't really great, but thought it was still worth a visit. Unless you have already done everything there is to do here in Khatmandu, you might want to skip this one. I really hoped that the display of asian and Nepali wildlife would be worth the visit, but , ..... There were very few photo oportunities here as everything was through chain link fencing, very old school zoo and cages. No beautiful Tigers, no Snow leopard. A very old and tired looking elephant, many animals alone in cages without companions, overall kind of a depressing display. The highlight were the two huge Pelicans that had just been fed , they were trying to swallow these huge fish, and also escape the person, Me, who was standing between them and their destination their lake. wingspans had to be close to 7' across, they were actually quite intimidating.

column7: Great little zoo despite the challenges
column8: We went to the zoo on our second day in Patan. It was about a 20 minute walk from our hotel. I was not expecting much, especially by "western" standards but was pleasantly surprised. Despite many challenges they are doing their best and improvements have been made.  Almost all of the animals are native to the region which was nice.  And despite being in the middle of a dusty and noisy area it was surprisingly fresh and green and lush a true little oasis.  I would recommend visiting and therefore supporting this zoo and it's care for the animals.

I love visiting zoo in every country and this one is definitely the worst. Most of the animals are kept in small cages. The variety of animals is small and the entry fee is relatively not worth for a foreigner. It costs 500 Rs while you can have a good meal with this amount of money in Kathmandu. In most of the zoos I've visited in the past I could spend at least 2 hours but for this one 0.5 hour is already enough. If you want to visit a zoo in asia, tai pei or ho chih ming city has much much much better zoo than this one. And the visitors really need to be educated as I even saw a man feed the cheese ball to the goat!!!
Great coffee and delicious food. The 1970s music is amazing. A lovely relaxed atmosphere and local craft products supporting womens' handicrafts.

column7: Top of the coffee chain in Kathmandu
column8: Top of the World is an authentic coffee shop. They take care that their coffee is sourced with fairtrade practices in mind.  The shop is a cozy spot in a nice location. It has a true coffee house atmosphere.  The food here is great, too. We have never been disappointed with a meal here.  They also sell handicraft and clothing items made by women from marginalised backgrounds.  This is a great place for a relaxing stop between activities.

We are biased, as Dale is an old friend. He set up the coffee shop to sell locally sourced food, especially fruit juices and coffee. The shop sells a range of local and international snacks, as well as a wide range of coffees. They also sell items made by local people. It seems to attract visitors to Kathmandu, mainly Americans, who enjoy the relaxed atmosphere and the good coffee.

Professional service with a smile, an ethically-run outfit that benefits local businesses and a great selection of coffees, hot or cold. Excellent cinnamon rolls, too. (And be sure to try their pure Rasilo juices.) And if you need decaf beans, this is the place.

Agftet a beutiful flight with Tai. Airlines, i fonally got here. And very hungry . I am lucky to have a good friend to let me use his home and gave me all the information i needed. Off to find food, top of the world is a nice caffee that you can find in many Asian coties, Penang,, kuaA or KOH Samui. The decore is pleasent and the pastries good.. i had a dahl and rice, Ok it was , ok, but to be honest, i would not fly just for that. Still i give them a 5 star tateing, their kindness, and sincerety. And ok the food was,NOT BAD paradox !
Food is not really good and expensive. There are better places in the area to have lunch and coffee. The lasagna was still half frozen. The staff are nice.

column7: This is my coffee of choice in the Doo!
column8: As a long time resident of KathmandDOO, this is my coffee of choice. Owned and run by an American, TOW serves great organic Nepali coffee. In fact, I get a bag delivered to my door, fresh roasted every week. During the fuel crisis this winter, the old-fashioned wood stove kept everyone warm as well.

Top of the world coffee has provided the best breakfast experience for the ever developing Patan area. It Has got beautiful ambience, great choice in breakfast menu and great and polite staffs. Just 10 mins away from the Patan Heritage site, they provide one of the best brewed coffee in Kathmandu.

column7: Great Coffee Place, reminds me of home
column8: This is a great little place for Expats to go and have their morning joe. Good selection of coffees and breakfast. At first glance it might appear expensive but they include their service charge and tax in the price. I have enjoyed going here almost daily for the past few weeks. Good strong WiFi and like I said a good place to network with other Expats
The main thing about this restaurant that i most liked is the feeling of comfortness. That is the best essence that every restaurant should have. 😊
The original sustainable, socially responsible and local coffee in the Nepal! And the taste is rich and not bitter at all. What a welcome change from the Nescafe instants elsewhere.

a breath of fresh air - right on the street as you approach Top of the World - pretty outside seating area, inside decorated with original Nepali art and handmade items are for sale. place to meet and greet family and friends for a meal of fish and chips, local Nepali fare or fresh ground coffee and homemade baked items. sofa's are comfy on the ground floor or there is a upper room for private parties and gatherings.. music night is a delight with local musicians .. what more could you want after a hetic day of sightseeing in Kathmandu ... just to relax at Top of the World Coffee and enjoy what it has to offer.

column7: Relaxing environment, Good coffee, Good for Business meetings, Wifi
column8: This is my local cafe which was introduced by a real estate agent. There are a few tables outside which have a nice atmosphere but it is close to the road. Otherwise inside is nicely decorated with a relaxing atmosphere, a two sets of couches when you want to hang out with a group. The coffee is good and I have had the Thali set which I really enjoyed. I have to say I mainly go here as my backup for Wifi when my temporary apartment wifi is down. The speed at the cafe is much quicker although they are affected by internet maintenance at times so don't rely on it. I met the owner who is American and a great person to talk to. He is proud of his cafe and helpful with local knowledge as he has been in Nepal for many years. Business meetings: there is a private room upstairs in the case you need a meeting room and it is free to book and staff will accommodate food and drinks and the wifi is available from there as well. My only complaint is a couple of times the staff (whom all get along very well together) tend to forget about the customers and become rather loud when they are joking with each other. So much one day, I had to forfeit an important meeting on Skype to ask them to quiet down.

Pretty sweet place with a real nice atmosphere. The coffee tastes great but it more expensive then other coffee shops in the area so if your just wanting coffee than there are some other options around for cheaper prices but this definitely has the best atmosphere. Great for travelers or students because they have free wifi.

We went to this place because of the rooftop. Of our dishes two were correct but the vegetable sandwich was a real disaster, we had to send it back. While prices were already expensive, there was a 13% tax AND a 10% extra service fee....More

We came to Cafe du Temple for a mid morning cup of coffee and a cup masala chai. Service was ok and we had a lovely time sitting on the roof enjoying the view of Patan Square. Then we came downstairs to pay the bill and the staff presented us with Rupee 1950. We asked them why the bill is rather expensive for just two cups of hot drinks. They said it’s because of the gov tax and 10% service charge. We politely asked them to recalculate the bill and it came up now to the same price. So we checked the menu and did the calculation ourselves. Alas! after 13% gov tax and 10% service charge the total bill was Rupee 175. We mentioned it to the staff and they did their calculation for the third time using the same calculator and it was just Rupee 175. No apology comes with it. I would like to give them benefit of the doubt because people in Nepal are honest and friendly. Sadly the staff in this place doesn’t live to our expectations. We won’t be returning to Cafe du Temple.

Our visit was on sunny days so we stayed on the rooftop for warming sun.the few was beautiful looking at old palace and many temples. We enjoyed the view as well as the food they serve . This restaurant serve nepalese cuisine and continental both serve with quality. Location is at old Durbar of patan wihich is 15 min drive from kathmandu if no rush traffic. Restaurant is busy and popular for travelers.

We stopped here to have lunch. As it was included in our tour, I can't give any reference for the prices they have, but I assure you that the food was tasty. We had their traditional plate: Dal Bhat. In case you don't like spicy, make sure you tell them in advance. The pickles were great!

We came in as a group of 5, expecting something unique given the pretty exterior. Below average food which we were then overcharged for. Didn't feel like the place was hygienic and we definitely do not recommend. Can see some OK views from the rooftop but not worth the bill.

column7: Great view of Durbar Square from the roof
column8: We had ring side seats and enjoyed a great view from our table. The restaurant caters entirely for tourisits but it does it very well. We enjoyed a decent lunch with good service in a unique place

column7: Lovely views of Patan Durbar square if you can get a good table
column8: Our guide took us to a Café du Temple on the edge of Patan Durbar Square with, of course, excellent rooftop views of the temple. A cold local 'Everest' beer to accompany a traditional Newari meal sated us as we sat under the red umbrella and took in the view. Of course it is aimed at tourists, but the pleasant view, good food and friendly service made it a lovely spot for lunch.

column7: Terrible food, Annoying staff, Good view of Temple, Disgusting bathrooms
column8: Have to say firstly Durbar Square Patan, although old isn't that impressive but even disappointing as there is nothing in place to preserve it. However it is beautiful to observe the Nepali people socialise in the evenings. We chose this restaurant because of the rooftop balcony view - a good view over the temple. The menu is vast and what we ordered (Chinese) was really bland and terrible. We had 3 dishes all disappointing. The wait staff for some odd reason kept staring at me the entire meal and I felt very uncomfortable. I even suggested to them we didn't need anything but they didn't take the hint. This really spoiled the atmosphere and romance of the evening along with the food. On the way out, I used the toilet and after having been in Kathmandu a month now, this is the most disgusting toilet I have seen here yet. Really. There was no effort to paint or clean the toilet room probably for the last year; and to boot, there was piss all over the walls, seat and floor. Had I used this at the start, we would have walked out - no question. There is no reason to go to this restaurant as there are a few other rooftop restaurants.

column7: Goodview, good food, toilet cleanliness bearable
column8: good view of the stupa at this rooftop restaurant. Food is clean and quite good tasting. Good service. Toilet is clean by kathmandu standards, though very old and dated. Went there twice while in Patan. Good place to take a drink and rest

column7: Cheese & veg Sandwich was Delish. Tea was Divine, Spaghetti was Rancid.
column8: I ate here 3 times during my stay in Kathmandu. The Inn Cafe came highly recommended by the place that I was staying. Ended up have 3 meals here. The place is historic and beautiful so it's a nice cafe just to hang out in....More

The inn Patan is an excellent place. In my opinion it has the best food in Nepal. The cafe serve delicious Burger, Nepali Thali, Steak, etc. The place was very clean and peaceful.the architecture of the place was kind of old Newari style. The price...More
Lovely traditional building with reasonably priced food - 2 beers, 2 steaks and a dessert came to equivalent of £25

Patan Inn is a BNB and also has a outdoor/indoor cafe. I usually drop by here for tea and snacks whenever i want to feel the traditional patan side. Take a book and you can laze around the sunny courtyard! Its secluded yet close to the cultural side of Patan.

column7: Real peace and kindness in Patan
column8: Best place in Patan! A fresh refurbished ancient building that carries all the tradition of this spiritual land. The staff is so kind and really takes care of the costumers, I even forgot my wallet in the room and they kept me for me.  Amazing breakfast included and working wifi.  Strongly recommended!

column7: I asked the waiter: would you rather I not eat here?
column8: The Inn Patan is just past Cafe Swotha and, shockingly, the same inflexibility. I got seated, they rolled out a heater for me, a nice menu (many more options than Swotha), and then it all fell apart. The thali looked good, but yogurt for desert? I asked if I could have a substitute. Yes, Swiss roll. I looked on the next page and Swiss roll was 200 Rs and above it was apple pie, 200 Rs. Can I have apple pie instead? No, only Swiss roll. I asked the waiter: would you rather I not eat here? He said yes. So much for that bargaining chip.

column7: Cute little place in perfect location for Patan
column8: Old beautiful building, super cute and with a nice vibe.  The location is excellent. You walk out and you are in Patan Square so for that area of the city it is ideal.  The room - we had a room up on 2nd floor looking into the courtyard. It was extremely spacious, nicely decorated, good shower and a unique style.  The staff - we didn't really interact with anybody too much but overall they were all very polite  Breakfast - very decent, ok coffee  I would definitely recommend for exploring Patan.  Tip: there is a nice organic restaurant just outside Patan Inn. Nice food and friendly staff

The Inn Patan is undoubtedly a hidden treasure of Patan. It is an example how local traditional house can be turned into a boutique Hotel.  As soon as we enter the Hotel gate, we felt that we are entering to local house but once we checked in to our room, we are amazed to see how beautifully the rooms are decorated with local touch yet blended with modern facilities.  The food and service are good. I liked the friendly staff.  We are more than happy to spend time in this hotel and highly recommend this hotel to check it out. I am sure that nobody wants to leave this place simply.  Keep it up the great work.

We arrived tired and somewhat spaced out after a long journey from the UK and a manic drive through the chaotic and dirty back streets of Kathmandu - and stopped in a very unlikely narrow, unpaved street with no sign of a hotel - just a mass of run-down over-crowded houses squeezed all together haphazardly. We wondered where on earth we were going to be left for our first night in Kathmandu! So it was a surprise to be led down an alleyway - and into a completely different world, to the beautiful and quaint old-world charm of the courtyard of The Inn. Much of the timber construction is beautifully carved. Our rooms on the first floor, looking onto a roof garden and a back courtyard as well as the central courtyard, were beautifully furnished.  The meals were excellent, eaten under balconies around the courtyard.

I really love this cafe so much. It's so antique and once we reach inside the gate the atmosphere that this place has is so amazing. Great hospitality and great service with such a great antique interior and design. I would definitely visit again and recommend others to visit this place aswell. Every corner is so beautiful .

column7: An oasis in the chaos of Kathmandu
column8: New restaurant next to Cafe Swotha (also good). Restored 150 year old house with lovely balconied seating. Lovely staff, good food and attentive manager. Would recommend. Just off Durbar Square in Patan. They also have very nice ensuite rooms.

column7: Good dishes, nice & quite place with attentive staff
column8: We are staying at the neighbours Swotha Traditional Homes and were very much surprised by the fine and cosy atmosphere at the Inn Restaurant. The Nepali Thali dish was good, but not the best we tasted. Flavours were in order but on the safe side. The Marsala tea was refined and staff was very attentive. Certainly a place to recommend.

column7: Manny's brought tapas to Kathmandu - and it's a restaurant with a heart
column8: A lovely setting surrounded by trees, a great location, Manny's offers really delectable Thai dishes made by his chef who is passionate about trying new things. The special tofu dish is not to be missed while the cocktails are made with a real expert touch...More

I have eaten at Manny's numbers of times over the past few years when in Kathmandu and every experience has been great. The food is great with good diversity including local delicacies and more western options and the staff is extremely courteous and friendly. I...More

column7: Very reasonable and delicious drunkard noodles
column8: This month been there more than 3 times and the food is awesome, specially thai dishes . Will definitely visit again & try all the food.. chef is a great guy to talk to if u wanna know about the history of nepali food culture or any..

UNESCO had designated three (3) town squares in Nepal as World Heritage Sites (Cultural): (1) Kathmandu Durbar Square, (2) Bhaktapur Durbar Square and (3) Patan Durbar Square - all three of these Squares are must see places while traveling through Nepal and they are all different in their own way. The Patan Durbar Square has many distinctive and interesting temples and structures: Krishna Temple, Royal Palace Patan, Jagannarayan Temple, Keshav Narayan Temple, Char Naarayan Temple, Golden Temple and others. When we had visited Patan Durbar Square on November 2019, we found most all of the structures here had been either not affected by the 2015 earthquake or were repaired quickly - we saw only a couple of structures that were being "repaired". This is in contrast to the Kathmandu Durbar Square which had multiple structures that are still in need of earthquake damage repair when we had visited that location. In summary, the Patan Durbar Square is in excellent shape - almost all the structures show no earthquake damage and the whole area is visually quite stunning as you enter the Square. The Ancient Nepal architecture here at the Square looks very impressive and makes for good photography. Highly recommend seeing the Patan Durbar Square, and if you have time walk down through some of the side streets to see the residential areas that surrounds the Square - interesting!

Square is surrounded by ancient buildings, some of them were distorted due to earthquake. Place is nice to walk around, people will offer guidance, etc. So many pigeons and some people feeding them. Square is closed for cars and other transport which is good as you can walk without any stress.

Patan Durbar Square gives a nice insight into time gone by in Nepal. The old Temples and Palace Buildings are classical examples of Newari architecture and have exquisite craftsmanship. Surrounding the Durbar Square are alleyways filled with shops displaying the tremendous artistic heritage of the Newari artisans.Very worth a look and spending time meandering.

The number of amazing buildings, both ornate and ramshackle, in such a small area makes this square an absolutely essential visit to Lalitpur from Kathmandu. Preferred it to both the main squares in Kathmandu itself and Bhaktapur Loads of pigeons to contend with but still a great place to wander round.

column7: Don't miss this when visiting Kathmandu
column8: I would highly recommend to get a guide for this tout as there is so much interesting history associated with this site. Truly wonderful examples of Patan's heritage of wood carving.

Durbar square is a beautiful place full of history and magic . Though is a tourist destination is part of everyday life in Patan, with people worshipping at the temples , others selling vegetables and going about they're business

You have to go to Patan Durbar square. My advice would be if you are staying in Patan, go to see it as soon as possible. There is no need to pay for a guide (but do if you like) because all of the information is provided in books or online.  A lot of museum is about the reconstruction of it after the earthquake. But it is great to see such beautiful structures.  The square also has loads of market/shop stalls with people selling loads of stuff. Haggle and negotiate, but not too much because the prices are already quite reasonable. Beware, most of the “North face” jackets are fake, still very warm and decent quality but not good if you’re gonna go mountaineering!  Just a short walk from Durbar square is the Kumari living goddess of Patan. Go and visit her and receive Tika.
Best place for visit in nepal. This place is old historical place about god shree krishna and local newari culture.

column7: Iconic square with several historic and religious buildings
column8: I explored with a guide during the festival and the place was fairly quiet, affording ample opportunity to visit the museum and stroll round the square and take photographs. My wife and I returned to stay in Patan yesterday ( Saturday) and the place was transformed - not for the better! Hundreds of hooting motor cycles and hawkers plying their trade spoiled the atmosphere I had enjoyed the week before, nevertheless it is a must see in Kathmandu

column7: One of the 3 Durbar Squares in Kathmandu, Arguably the Best
column8: A Unesco world heritage site. This is arguably the best Durbar square in Kathmandu. It is littered with Hindu, Jain and Buddhist temples and has the royal palace which has now been converted into a museum. The place has been pretty much restored to its former glory past the 2015 earthquake.

Foreigners enter for 1000rps. Small space to walk about but beautiful despite extensive damage and slow restoration process. Intricate old architecture. Some guides will come along and offer guided service for about usd 20, . It’s a nice walk and a good way to spend an hour and also some time for the shops and cafes nearby.
Despite the ongoing restoration work following the devastating earthquake, still a breathtaking historical and cultural area. Worth a day (or 2) on everyone's itinerary!

column7: Most visited place by tourists in Kathmandu.
column8: Darbar Square is a nice place to see culture and history of Nepal. Got many suevenure shop. Its one of the must visited place in Kathmandu. We enjoyed our time with this historical place and also bought suevenure for friends.

column7: Not to miss but crowded on the outside.
column8: We arrive in KTM today and our first stop was Patan Durbar Square. A not to miss place in KTM as it displays the history in Buddhism and Hinduism however, the square is to crowded which makes less interesting. The temple outside was full of people even sitting on the temple itself. Too much construction going on.
If you visit Kathmandu you must visit this place. An ancient part of the city with beautiful architecture elements.
What a pity the earthquake damaged so much of this lovely area.The history of the area is amazing.Long way to go in the rebuilding process.

A great place to see first hand the culture and religious beliefs that bind the city of Kathmandu. Although there is a cost of 1000NPR to wander around and see the centuries old temples, it is I believe a great opportunity. The money you pay goes to the restoration of buildings affected by the massive 2015 earthquake. If your lucky (like I was) you may even get a glimpse of a living goddess which unfortunately you are not allowed to photograph.
walked around the square.having an local guide might be advisable to help you understand the history of the place. they are still in the midst of rebuilding after the quake.

column7: Badly damaged by the earthquake but painstakingly being restored
column8: The squre has many highlights, especially the museum but many of the old temple buildings have been badly damaged
