this one may be a bit smaller in scale than the kathmandu or bhaktapur one.. but i felt it had the most beautiful architecture and was compact enough to not lose yourself. i felt this one was least affected by the earthquake and had less crowds too.. you really can imagine how the ancient times must have been like visiting this one

column7: Excellent Place for Discover Ancient Architect
column8: Lalitpur is Excellent Place for Discover Ancient Architect. Temples, Museum, Krishna Mandir, Kot Garden and more can be discover here. You will smell great in rainy season here.
Many beautiful historic buildings and temples to see. An interesting view of this old city. Worth a visit.

Being an old area, Patan Durbar Square is an extremely interesting historic square with many temples including the three-tiered Krishna Mandir Temple plus other buildings. On one side of the square is the former royal palace which dates from1734 and is nor a museum. It is also interesting to wander up some of the narrow streets leading off the square where there are shops and homes.

column7: Heart of a centuries old kingdom
column8: Many places and things to see in this square outside and inside buildings. A must do in Kathmandu. World class Patan Museum

A must-see place. Despite the fact there was much repair work in progress, the beauty of the place is unique. After completing your tour, take some time to enjoy a coffee at the top roof of the restaurant/cafe on the square and have views from the top.
If you are a interested in history this complex is a must visit. Though damaged by earthquake and being rebuilt the history can be felt. Museum has be closed for renovation.
The Durbar Square shows the nepalese history. There are many places to visit in this top touristic attraction in Nepal.

column7: You need aguide to get the best out of this
column8: The square itself is manifestly devastated by the earthquake, all compounded by the extensive renovations. There is actually a lot to see here but it is not obvious and you have to pay even to be in the square itself. Whilst it is expensive, to get value for money from this area and to get the best out of it you need a guide because the buildings can be visited and it is worth it. Preferably one recommended by your hotel and not one of the touts. There is a lot of history here

column7: Extensive damage here from the earthquake but still worth a visit
column8: This is a nice square despite the earthquake damage. Our guide spent a lot of time telling us about the reconstruction, and it appears that it is going well and will look as it did before the earthquake when finished. Almost every building is propped up with huge boards to stabilize them, and large cracks are seen everywhere.  There are still plenty of beautiful carvings to see on the buildings and carved stone figures and statues throughout. We went to visit the house of the Kumari Devi (the Living Goddess). We could not go in but were allowed in the courtyard to see if she would make an appearance at a window. No photos allowed if she appeared. She did appear and looked out at everyone. This goddess is a 5 year old girl who lives apart from her family until she reaches puberty. It was quite an interesting story.  Worth a visit even though some people complained about the entrance fee. The entrance fee is worth it if this trip is something that you will probably never do again, so why not?

column7: How My Architectural , Cultural , Historical and Spiritual Understandings Were Enhanced
column8: Patan aka Lalitpur probably one of the oldest Buddhist City in the world is surrounded by 4 Stupas constructed by Emperor Ashok . We visited the Patan Durbar square in the morning of 5th Nov . All the three main courtyards i.e. chowks : Mul Chowk , Sundari Chowk and Keshav Narayan Chowk were easily accessible . Sundari Chowk boasted a masterpiece of stone iarchitecture, the Royal bath called Tushahity .  There are 136 historic chowks and more than 50 temples including the Kwa Bahal or Golden Temple within walking distance of the Durbar . The not to be missed places are Bhimsen Temple , Hari Shankar Temple , Krishna Mandir , Manga Hiti , Patan Gate , Patan Museum , Patan Royal Palace , Taleju Temple , Temples of Machchhendra Nath and Min Nath . We visited , highly appreciated and enjoyed most of these places . I have reviewed these monuments elsewhere .  This square highly enhanced my architectural , cultural , historical and spiritual understandings .
the square and surrounding area suffered immensely from the 2015 earthquake it is slowly being restored but it still has a unique atmosphere with the little stalls and the lovely people

column7: Patan Museum is a Big Plus
column8: They say that the Patan Durbar Square is the best of all three in Nepal and after visiting the outskirts of the Kathmandu Durbar Square, I would be inclined to agree (can't completely do so since I haven't been to Bhaktapur.) I didn't enter Kathmandu Durbar Square cause of the expensive entrance fee but it seemed in complete disarray and didn't think there would be much to see.  The Patan Durbar Square also has a lot of rehabilitation going on but it's not as tight and stressful to get into as the Kathmandu one. There's a lot more space to move around and most of the main building has been preserved.  A huge plus about going to Patan Durbar Square is that it houses the Patan Museum, which is easily the best museum I've been to in Nepal. It was very informative and described facts about Hindi and Buddhist history, iconography, symbolisms, and belief systems. I really appreciated that. Because of this, you wouldn't need a tour guide anymore.  Some groups got a tour guide and they sometimes spoke loudly to be heard. Because of that, I would get some interesting new information at random and that was a nice little surprise.  I highly recommend going to this place!
This place is lovely and lively. Lots of things to see and do. A great place in the evenings to have a walk around. Revommended

After visiting all three Durbar Squares, Patan, Kathmandu and Bhaktapur, this was certainly the nicest out of the three. We had a local guide that was organized for us through Global Holidays (also, highly recommended) and he was very helpful in guiding us through the square and telling us the stories and history of the place.  The old palace is amazing, and has been turned into a very informative museum. The detail in the wood carving is ridiculous! It must have taken many hours of work to do all of the fine etching that is evident. The details are incredible. The Newari architecture is very interesting and picturesque.  The area was hit by the earthquake and is still evident, but much of the restoration has already been started, The 1000 Ru entry fee is well worth it, especially if part of the money helps the locals restore the site (which is all being done by hand). Definitely worth seeing.

while visitors see the square as history those that live there are just busy living. when you visit remember this is not jus history- this is alive and living - take a moment to look around and notice

column7: Great To See Durbar Central Square Building Being Preserved
column8: Arrived at Durbar [Central] Square on Thursday 05/07/18 with my driver & tour guide named Shyam. Some difficulty in finding a parking slot close by on arrival. However after paying my admission fee [Foreigners Rate] NR 1,000 at the ticketing booth I noticed my driver chatting with another young man & verbally disagreeing in their own language, on explaining the situation from the driver this young man wanted me to pay another admission fee of NR 1,000 due to my driver not being an offical registered or licensed tour guide. I ended up walking around the Square on my own after expressing my opinion to the difficult young man interfering without any signage about tour guides / drivers etc . After one hour I left still annoyed. The Square is a busy area with many locals & visitors & great to see that many of the buildings that were either completely destroyed or partially during the 2015 earthquake were being re-built or structurally renovated with strong support beams throughout the process. Architectural history with hundreds of years all around you.

Patan Durban square is quite well preserved. It’s a small short walk relatively. You can see the magnificent buildings well preserved . The museum is on the way and worth visiting. Pagan was one of the previous kingdom capital on the valley . A must visit . If you are there and want a quiet nice place to drink or eat go to the Swotha. And not to one of the cafes at the center.

History in a nutshell. This place has some of the best restored temples in Kathmandu, Nepal and probably the best museum of all places of interest in Kathmandu. One can discover the place on foot but a guide is recommended as they come cheap and give some delightful insights.

The durbar square of Patan is better preserved than the one in Kathmandou center. Patan is quieter and cleaner and you can enjoy a whole day exploring the region. There is also the Patan museum inside the square were they explain the evolution and history of metalcrafts in Nepal with explanations of the famous hindu/buddhist bronze sculptures. For religious figurine lovers it is the perfect spot to get some souvenirs. You can catch a local bus ride from Ratna park to Patan for 15rps.

Magnificent central square in Patan. A number of structures devoted to different deities, some destroyed by the recent earthquake. But still imposing. Some shops selling beads & other trinkets. A UNESCO heritage site. There is also a wonderful museum.

Kathmandu Durbar Square: Located in front of the old royal palace of former Kathmandu Kingdom is one of three Durbar Squares in the Kathmandu Valley in Nepal, all of which are UNESCO World Heritage Sites.

Many temples and interesting things to see in the museum. Sadly there is a lot of damage from the earthquake which is sad to see but you can see the restoration work being completed and there is an informative exhibition detailing the earthquake and rebuilding of the square. Tourist price is quite high but you can get multiple visits with it for the duration of your visa. Definitely worth visiting while in Kathmandu .

Super cool to learn about history in the square and in the nearby museum. Marvel's movie Doctor Strange was filmed here! Definitely full of tourists. You could do this site by yourself, we went as part of a tour with a guide and felt like we were herded through a bit. Most of the museum is in English so you can read all the wall text without help.

It is a culturally & historically rich place to visit. Our guide Mr. Kesar gave us very good details about the place & its history. Although some of the temples are destroyed in 2015 earthquake, still the place is worth visiting!

restoration is on-going due to the last earthquake. there will be tour guides approaching you for a fee you can do the tour alone, but if you want some history while sight seeing then hiring a tour guide is worth it

The cultural and historic significance of this place is evident at a single look. Although the 2015 earthquake has taken its toll on it. this place is perhaps the best maintained among all three durbar squares.

It is the best representation of Nepalese art and architecture. It is very interesting ancient temple represent world heritage site. There are very interesting art about god and goddess. Some of the common monuments are Krishna Mandir, Patan durbar square, Mahabouddha, Hiranya Verna Mahavihar, Kumlwshwor.

Patan Durbar Square is situated at the centre of the city of Lalitpur in Nepal. It is one of the three Durbar Squares in the Kathmandu Valley, all of which are UNESCO World Heritage Sites. One of its attraction is the ancient royal palace where the Malla Kings of Lalitpur resided.  A marvelous ancient architecture, this Patan Durbar Square is one of the three Durban Squares in the Kathmandu Valley. The Square floor is tiled with beautiful red bricks. You will find many temples and idols in the area. The main temples are aligned opposite of the western face of the palace. The Square also holds old Newari residential houses. There are various other temples and structures in and around Patan Durbar Square built by the Newa People. It is slowly recovering after the earthquake. There are also nice restaurants. Must see place!

Near the main city of Kathmandu, this is a charming place. Reminds you of a magical era that almost borders on fantasy. Accessible for a quick trip, the whole are has lots to offer, from small charming shops, to historic monuments, and great places to eat and drink.

If you are in Kathmandu and have 4 hours to spare..this is a must visit. Old world charm, beautiful buildings and architecture, buzzing bazaar around makes this Durbar square a must visit. There are few ATM's around for those who need cash as KTM business is infamous for refusing to transact through cards.
This place very iconic old city - very interested and beautiful area - you can see ancient culture and architecture

The ancient city of Patan .  Patan is situated in Lalitpur ,a town ,a few Kms from Kathmandu. Known for beautiful palaces and temples side by side ,it's a UNESCO World heritage site. Interesting mix of Hinduism and Buddhism ,it has 136 courtyards and 55 temples of various Gods of Hinduism and incarnates of Buddhism . The Krishna temple is most important one in this complex . Built in 16th century by the Malla king ,it has three stories and temple of Radha Krishna on 1st floor , Siva on the second and Buddha on the third . Unfortunately , in the 2015 earthquake ,it was badly damaged , and is being renovated now . Bhimsen temple was built by Srinivasa Malla in 1680. It is renowned for its three interconnected golden windows. Bhimsen is a great hero in Mahabharata. He was known to be very brave and strong. In Newa tradition, he is worshipped as a god of business and trade. (Wikipedia) The three main courtyards in the palace are Mul Chok, Sundari Chok and Keshav Narayan Chok. Besides these courtyards, the complex boasts impressive temples, religious shrines, and historical places, all noted for their exquisite carvings and beautiful display of ancient Newari architecture (Wikipedia) Hiraṇyavarṇa Mahāvihāra (Nepali: हिरण्यवर्ण महाविहार), also Kwa Bahal (Nepali: क्वबहा:) informally called The Golden Temple with literal meaning "Gold-colored Great Monastery" is a historical vihara (Buddhist monastery) situated in Patan, Nepal. It is known locally as the "Golden Temple" and it is famous for feeding rats. This three-storey golden pagoda of Shakyamuni Buddha was built in the twelfth century by King Bhaskar Varman. Inside the upper storey of the pagoda is the golden image and a large prayer wheel.(Wikipedia)
History is embedded deep within Kathmandu and the people interact with it daily in many ways. This is a good place to learn about Nepal and its history as well as how people interact today.

column7: Scaffolding abounds, but the sights are amazing
column8: Do not mis this. Yes, there is a lot of renovations going on. But, this is a hub of lovely carvings symbolisms and many other worthwhile things. Not the least of which is the palace and museum. The people sitting outside are very friendly and amenable to getting their pictures taken. Hint: Get a guide for this area. You will miss out on so much history and facts, if you don't. Definitely recommend.

column7: Not to be missed when visiting Kathmandu
column8: Even though earthquake damage is still very visible, this area should not be missed when visiting Kathmandu. The old city center, the number of temples... do go there!

column7: A Jewel of The Kathmandu Valley
column8: I love all of the ornate design of the buildings here. The carvings, the architecture, and the artwork really let you know that you are in an exotic place.

This is a lovely square which has ongoing reconstruction due to the 2015 earthquake. However, this does not detract from the visit, rather it is great to see that this work is ongoing and there are many areas that are intact. Very pleasant to stroll, explore and we were not approached by anyone.

column7: Too expensive for the amount of restoration going on.
column8: Yes it is an interesting place to visit but all five people in our group felt that the entry fee was quite expensive for the amount of intact buildings standing. We could however clearly see that real effort is being made in this area to restore all affected buildings.

Wow, amazing to see such old architecture, especially bearing in mind the recent earthquake damage. There is a lot of reconstruction going on, but it doesn't detract from the magnificence of the place.

Admission 1,000r. Much more intact than Kathmandu’s Durbar Square, more interesting, with far fewer trinket sellers in the main area. There is also included in the admission cost a very interesting museum including depictions of various deities. We were approached by a guide who offered his services for 2,000r, we declined this offer.
me and my husband visited here one year ago,this is one of the beautiful historic place.our guide was good.had great time with my husband.

column7: one of the major attractions in greater Kathmandu.
column8: This is one of the major attractions in greater Kathmandu. All tourists visit this ancient landmark. Some places inside are free to see, most of those require entry fees ; foreigners from SAARC nations need to par NRs 175, Other NRs 500. It is a must see. From Thamel taxi is required, otherwise buses and tempos are there.

This square was damaged in the last earthquake but they are in the process of rebuilding and there is still a lot to see. We spent a whole day exploring the square and it's buildings. The museum is well worth the time and there are far fewer tourists and vendors hawking their wares here then in Kathmandu's Durbar Square. I was very pleased to have chosen Patan as our point of entry to Nepal particularly because this square was so interesting to visit.

We visited from 10.00am so it was nice and quiet peaceful and enchanting. The architecture is stunning, dates from several periods in history and reflects the melting pot of faith in this city. Truly beautiful ornate buildings, pools and sculptures of Hindu/Buddhist gods. As some of the structures were damaged in the earthquake and are being repaired you can see the stored pillared up close inside the first building. Uniquely beautiful. A lovely shaded restaurant serves refreshments including light lunch in the third building. Nearby there is a very good shop where you can see ringing bowls demonstrated for aligning chackra. No pressure to buy at all. Carry on 50m past the third temple building, left hand side of street.

I loved this place. Very typical Nepali architecture and symbolic of its tradition and the rich cultural legacy. A walk around the durbar is really awesome. And it is great to see so many people in the area still on to their ancestral trade. I went to a small restaurant in the area and had a traditional Nepali meal. The owner claimed that his family has been running the restaurant for more than 300 years. Amazing.  This place is a visual treat. I would recommend all tourists to visit this place.

column7: One of the ancient must visit sites
column8: If you are visiting Nepal, you must visit this place. A castle from 11-12th century with amazing history. Cannot miss. You pay 1000 rupees for a 4-day pass. Well worth it
Amazing to see and experience the cultural marvels that have withstood time and earthquakes.  Definite picture worthy moments!

We took a 2 hour tour of this area and it is probably the best way to do this. So many back alleys and little turns I would have never found every place we saw on my own, as while as to have a history of each place we stopped along the way it way truly a great way to spend a afternoon.

This is a national heritage site unfortunately motorbikes and vans scream pass you on very narrow streets we witnessed more than one person being hit by these. Because of this the smoke and pollution in Kathmandu is awful and everybody I saw was coughing and choking it is such a shame because it wouldn’t take much to block this square off then it can revert back to its natural beauty

Place is awesome filled with so much history.One should take a guide who would explain in detail the history of the place.Sadly hote a bit has been damaged due to the earthquake in 2015.Nevertheless this place is a must visit during one's stay in Kathmandu.Beautiful intricate designs in wood each detailed so magnificently that one can easily visualise the culture of th people who have lived there.

I have no doubt that this place was beautiful, but sadly following the earth quake a few years ago much of the historic buildings are now in rubble.  Still, the government is charging an entrance fee just to step into the area, which seems to only be enforced on western tourists, with locals and Asian tourists seemingly about to enter at will. I had no problem paying the fee, assuming it was going towards the restoration, but we heard much to the contrary from locals.  The big issue with this area are the guides waiting around. These are not the friendly Nepalese people you are used to. One guide, after we told him we weren’t interested in a tour, immediately called over the ticket officers to check us. A second berated us for “wasting our time and money coming there” if we weren’t willing to hire him. Just be polite, smile and move on.

I been this city with my girl friend.i felt incredible here with amazing and historical art of these temple ,museum and the houses surrounding here ,when you go go there just take a tour guide who tell you tell to interesting history of this city.

column7: Residence of then Malla Kings, a UNESCO world heritage site
column8: This like the other two durbar square of Kathmandu valley, Kathmandu and Bhaktapur, is also a world heritage site listed by UNESCO. Presently major part of it is under renovation after the massive earthquake of 2015, the Krishna mandir is not open for the tourists. Major part of the patan museum also is closed.  Foreigners need to buy entry ticket, valid for all the monunents and the museum. The tickets are of two categories, SAARC and non SAARC, the former's price is NRs 250, the other NRs 1000 per person.  This durbar square was the residence of malla Kings of Patan, the rulers in the valley before the Shah dynasty, though debatable, but on some accounts, from 10th century AD to mid of the 18th.  Parking is available outside the durbar area. It is a couple of hours activity. Taking a guide is helpful.
This place is amazing.. Kathmandu Durbar Square in front of the old royal palace of the former Kathmandu Kingdom is one of three Durbar Squares in the Kathmandu Valley in Nepal,

We were dropped by taxi in the middle of the square (unbeknownst to us), and were surprised that after paying for a ticket (having been noticed by a security guard) that we had already seen all the main sights.  Let's be honest here. Patan's Durbar Square is a shadow of its former grandeur, and every structure is largely hidden under extensive scaffolding. The Museum (which is part of your 1,000rp ticket) only had 1/8th of its exhibition space open for public use, with the rest being refurbished/repaired.  My partner and I are empathetic with the earthquake repair process, and are happy considering our payment there as a donation. However, it is disingenuous (and honestly somewhat manipulative) to pretend otherwise.  The very high price of entry is a donation towards mending the damage of the earthquake, and should not be taken as indicative of the quality of the experience in Patan's Durbar Square.  Left feeling quite deflated and disappointed.
Patan Durbar square is one of the world heritage site in Kathmandu Valley, which is most recommended

This place is outside of Kathmandu so is much quieter than Durbur Square in Kathmandu. It's stunning in all aspects but a real shame that the Earthquake has devastated much of it so there is a lot of construction work going on. I'd still plan a visit here if you're staying nearby as the architecture is amazing. Hopefully it will be restored to it's former glory.

column7: A hub of activity and history
column8: So close to Kathmandu itself, Patan's Durbar Square presents a more manageable, rich cultural experience. The streets are busy and definitely touristy, but strike a balance between commerce and history and culture.

Durbar Square in Lalitpur is an area full of beautiful temples and other historic buildings. There is still some restoration going on, but work seems to proceed slowly. The King's Palace and the three-storey building on the right hand side are particularly remarkable. Don't miss the inner courtyard where there is a good restaurant with wonderfully quiet spots for a cup of tea. But be careful : we ordered two large pots of tea and were charged for 4 cups, the first cost 400, the second 600. We were too tired to argue and obviously paid some money into his private pocket. We went on to see the golden temple, something not to be missed. Wonderful cultural heritage.

Really impressed with the arts, architecture, stone carving and wood carving. Besides this, it's a place to spend leisure especially at late evening; I got change to observe devotes chanting Krishna Prayers for once. Overall atmosphere was exquisite. Museum and water spout;not to be missed.

This square is so close from my friend’s place so he took me there when I travelled to Kathmandu. Patan in Lalitpur is much nicer than Kathmandu city, yes high population but cleaner and nicer. You can sit and relax for hours here talking with friends, or just relaxing seeing people passing by. The beautiful temple and ancient buildings surround, and historic site. And there are also many street food sellers and I gave the food a try, and it tastes good. While my friend worry about my stomach can not handle it, I definitely OK and had no problem with street food in Nepal. I love Patan....

It is a complex of ancient city. You will love the architecture and the details of its pilars. Some of the constructions are still under development due to the massive earthquake experienced last time. You can read all information about it in their museums so you will know the history. The complex are surrounded by local shops and restaurants. You will find yourself lost in an ancient time.
Patan durbar central area is the best area in patan. if you visit patan dont miss that central part of durbar area
Beautiful historic place with beautiful temple and pure Newari Culture. Wood work on the temple are very unique and creative. Its a must visit place if you are in Kathmandu.

Visit Patan is a special experience. The central square is interesting, full of magnificent buildings, temples, shops and always a lot of people. It is located 5 km south of central Kathmandu, across the Bagmati River. Like everything in Nepal and this city has a rich history. Patan is founded in the 3rd century A.D by King Veera Dev. Durbar Square is enriched by the magnificent ancient Royal Palace. The monuments in this square date back to the Medieval Malla period from 16th to 18th century. Bhimsen Temple, Vishwa Nath Temple, Temple Jagnath leave visitors breathless.

We got to know that the Patan durbar square was in relatively better condition than the one in Kathmandu post the earthquake. Though quite narrow and crowded at times, the alleys are full of sudden discoveries of temples, courtyards and other old buildings. The work on some of these entrances and doors is exquisite. Patan is a great example of the old and the new coexisting seamlessly almost to an extent where they become part of each other. An old building becomes a new coffee shop. A temple yard is occupied by a bunch of youngsters meeting to chat about their weekend or a central pond is fringed by vendors whose wares are reflected in its dusty waters. Worth walking around here for some hours to chance upon some truly spectacular pieces of art and sculpture.

This was absolutely stunning. Much less damaged than Kathmandu Durbar Square. We visited this with a guide, so weren't hassled by other guides like we were in Kathmandu. The museum inside the old royal palace was well worth a look.

Dubar Square in Patan is a high light of touristic attractions. Several old monuments are assembled in this square. It is like a museum village, and you might feel as if the time stopped forever. Some monuments were damaged by an earthquake, and the repair work is currently undertaken.

Go to Pagan Durbar Square, see the cruel fate of nature; the damaged buildings, the work of man over the centuries dashed in minutes by natural forces. It is a cruel world yet the square bustles with people, regeneration can be seen, the spirit of man is not broken, like a phoenix rising from the ashes. It is still awe inspiring and provided tourists continue to visit it will one day regain its full splendour. If we fail to visit we'll fail both the past and the future generations as repairs will not be completed.
UNESCO WORLD HERITAGE SITE Lots of ancient palaces, temples and shrines Ancient royal palace with 3 courtyards Triple roofed octagonal tower

Durbar square has a lovely ambiance, and the restoration after the earthquake is under way. The fret work and wooden pavilions are beautiful and intricate. Small shops and handicrafts are typically priced for tourists but some of the women selling trinkets around the square have lovely items for sale. Perhaps the most interesting part of the visit was the walk through the old town, where you can see the real day-to-day lives of Nepalis and even taste some famous (and delicious) yoghurt typical to the region.

column7: Overpriced for a walk down the road
column8: We stayed in Patan next to Durbar square for a week in October 2017. What must have been an incredible sight has been mostly reduced to rubble by die massive earthquake that destroyed alot of traditional heritage sites a few years ago. One beautiful temple remains.  A fee of Rs1000 per person is required to walk down a road of mostly rubble. If you wait until dark, you can walk down the square for free, alternatively just walk past the entrance to to the square take a right past the shops and walk down to the end of the square. Lovely little shops, and great rooftop restaurants /bars from where you overlook the whole Durbar square.

You will not fail to be inspired! I especially enjoyed seeing the renovations underway. The 2015 earthquake damage was devastating, yet the community is responding with an enthusiasm and vigor. Your visit helps support that revitalization.

column7: Good bit of history in Patan Durbar Square
column8: There is an excellent museum in the square that has lots of info on Hindu and Buddhist religions and traditions in Nepal, including artifacts and information on architecture. You don't need a guide for the museum, but it might be helpful to have a guide around the general square to provide history and information regarding the old buildings and temples.

column7: Great visit but earthquake caused significant damage
column8: Great to see repairs underway to these significant cultural structures.  Of course it will not be the same as original but it will be nice nonetheless.  A number of countries have stepped up to assist which is great.  A visit here is so worth the time and effort.  Great people with great heritage.

column7: A must visit place if you are in Kathmandu.
column8: Kathmandu valley is divided into Kathmandu, Patan (and lalitpur), and Bhaktapur. Each has their own Central Square. It's a great place that carries history of the valley. Your guide will give you all the fascinating stories about the place.

In 2017 foreigners have to pay 250 for SAARC member countries and 1000 for non SAARC member countries. Glad too see there's a tourist Police office. I enjoyed walking around the alley ways that surround the square. I remember the place used to be cleaner back in 1987 and there were more old houses

I went to Patan Durbar Square as part of a Kathmandu sites tour with a private car. It is not very far away from the Kathmandu center. The square itself has the effect of the earthquake in 2015 very visible. A lot of construction work. There are tons of people from tourists to locals to street vendors. I did not venture a lot into the side streets. The square itself is not very big. Maybe requires 20 minutes to wander all around it. The best thing about it is the museum. It is a must go. With history of Buddhism and Hinduism beautifully explained. I loved it! Entrance fee for foreigners is NRP 1,000 including the museum.
Located just in the heart of Lalitpur, Patan Durbar Square is a historical site which tells you stories of the past. It is a living museum and a must visit place in Nepal.
very nice old tempels, so much to see! (next to Durbar square there is a market with cheap gifts, handy befor getting back home)

Situated around 30 minutes drive from Kathmandu, Patan (Lalitpur) is one of the three old cities of Kathmandu Valley. The building patters are somewhat similar to Kathmandu and Bhaktapur Durbar Square. The Patan museum is very informative and located at the entrance of the square. Some of the structures and temples are going through renovation works since the 2015 earthquake. Need to study about it before going there to have a through look otherwise it is better to take a local guide which is not that expensive. There is a golden temple inside which is very popular among both the locals and tourists from abroad. Too good a place to miss once you are in Nepal.............

column7: A Square full of ancient monuments, Temples and chowks in The old Royal Palace
column8: Patan Durbar Square is even more interesting than Kathmandu Durbar Square. Also here there are damages from The earthquacke in 2015, but The Royal Palace with The 3 beautiful courtyards (chowks), and the Patan museum still stands, and the restoration of the area is in progress, so all the Temples Will be rebuild.  The Square is in centrum of Patan, and "runs" in an acks from north to South. And this Durbar Square is without influenze from Europe, (The two other Durbar Square Borth have a little European arcitecture also).
Fun experience for a taste of traditional Nepal. Good shopping options & friendly locals. Tasty eatery snacks & coffee along the way

The place is still under renovation but its charm and historic vibe can be felt in the area. Be prepared to pay around 1000 NPR for foreigners. Tour guides are all over the place if you want to avail one.

column7: Darbarmarg square for old sculptures and monuments in nepal
column8: Really amazing old sculptures and you will love to be here for at least one weak to see around and all
I am so happy to be a part of history by being amongst the people and the history behind these marvelous historical structures. One just needs to visit to appreciate.

column7: A Must. First determine with temple will visit!!
column8: There are a number of it as mini stuppas as well scattered around. If you don't have a guide ( i wouldn't) take care to visit all important hidden places like the BEST thing may be the courtyyards! Or the Golden temple 3 blocks away and I was missing it. There are good restaurants in the square. What is unvelibable is that are MERCHANTS in the small heritage buildings! And even people living there. Chaotic as the rest of the city

In Patan Durbar Square, its like stepping in a new world after a few steps away from your ride. Terra-cotta colors are everywhere and you are brought back to the ancient time.  The Carvings are exquisite, the arts are amazing. the colors are good for the eye and will make you want to wonder on how talented the people from before are.

column7: A typical beautiful square world heritage site
column8: Costs RS1000 (about usd10) to visit and worth paying as the buildings are excellent although still earthquake damaged. A must if you are in the area

column7: Beautiful, historical site, worth a visit
column8: Visited many times, including just after the earthquake. Rebuilding is progressing well. Beautiful place full of history and atmosphere. Definitely a must visit if you go to Nepal, it is the cultural heart of the country and the iconic landmark of the people of Nepal.

column7: Full of history, but also full of ...
column8: I had a wonderful guide with me to visit Durbar Square. Still I found it a challenge to fully fall in love with this site. The temples are interesting, but after earth quake, the buildings are in rather poor condition and are crying for a proper restoration.  I am also scared by a massive group of pigeons. You can feed them with corns and there are quite a few vendors at the square. But pigeons are not good for the buildings and temples at the square.

column7: A little history, a little shopping
column8: Durbar square is one of the historic parts of the city. After the earthquake that brought this place down, it's good to see that a lot of it still exists, and that the reconstruction is going well. Housing the residence of the Kumari Goddess, as well as the wonderful architecture of the region, this is a must visit place. If you're not into too much history, there's a market that opens up in the square that sells curios and handicrafts of various kinds. I managed to pick up some really nice jewellery for friends back home. Must visit atleast once for sure.

column7: Historic and UNESCO World Heritage Sites
column8: On April 4, 2017 my friend and I visited this square as part of our journey in Nepal. Patan is also known as Lalitpur. Both names derive from the Sanskrit word "Lalitapattan". Locally many people still call it Lalitpur while tourists sectors refer to it as Patan. Nepal was hit by an earthquake on April 25th 2015 . It was a magnitude of 7.8, followed by aftershocks including a large magnitude 7.3 quake on 12 May. This earthquake it is also known as the Gorkha earthquake. It killed nearly 9,000 people and injured nearly 22,000. The Dubar Square is a UNESCO World Heritage since 1979.It is a historical square with beautiful religious and historical monuments that reflects the history of Nepal despite the earthquake damages. Many monuments are still awaiting restoration, and thousands are still waiting for permanent housing, the scars of the earthquake are slowly being erased, and tourist as us, are returning. One of the square attraction is the ancient Royal Palace where the Malla Kings of Lalitpur resided. The Durbar Square is a marvel of Newa architecture. The Square floor is tiled with red bricks. There are many temples and idols in the area. The main temples are aligned opposite of the western face of the palace. The entrance of the temples faces east, towards the palace. There is also a bell situated in the alignment beside the main temples. The Square also holds old Newari residential houses. There are various other temples and structures in and around Patan Durbar Square built by the Newa People. The Square maintains its legendary atmosphere. We’re amazed by the carved wooden details on the buildings and the intricate designs of the temples. Foreigners now have to pay 750 NRs.
don't miss the squares inside the palace walls with amazing sculptures and the museum inside the palace walls that shows history of architectural details

column7: Interesting Place but now being rebuilt
column8: The Durbar square proclaims the history of Kathmandu but the place is being rebuilt and so is dusty( like the rest of the town). Good place to walk around and observe the Nepali heritage and the damage the earthquake did.

UNESCO world heritage site you know more about Nepal's history and culture. Old monuments, temples ,archaeological place of interest, though earthquake hit it hard but it's still standing and renovation going on. Have good cafeteria around 👌👌👍👍

In Kathmandu valley where 3 kingdoms: Kathmandu, Bhaktapur and Patan and all 3 have a Durbar Square. Bhaktapur was most hit by the 2015 earthquakes and Patan least. And reconstruction is actually going on here, in contrast to DS in Kathmandu. Patan's DS is also the smallest and therefor the most intimite. I really love that intimite feeling while wondering around many temples. These temples, like Golden Temple, are far more beautiful than those in Kathmandu. Art is more refined and richer. And you'll find Patan museum here. I think the most beautiful museum in Nepal. But read separate reviews on this one. Also take a stroll thru the small and narriw streets surrounding the square. Here you'll find high-end and low-end art. Just love this place!

Wonderful spot to visit to get a sense of the ancient kingdoms that underpinned modern- day Nepal. Wonderful architecture and woodwork, sculptures and temples. Always lots of community members, hawkers, gawkers and other tourists around. Nearby markets upmarket and low-key shopping and lots more. Some of the buildings destroyed in the 2015 earthquake are undergoing restoration - note the plaques describing before and after and support received. I did not have a guide but given the fascinating concentration of structures history and culture - this would probably be well worthwhile. Worth a visit anytime you are in Kathmandu. See my pictures @antzsydney and here.
Earthquake damage has put most of this place into restoration mode but it's still worth a visit. Old square has some cute restaurants as well

column7: The architecture is heavy into details
column8: Very nice architecture, much to be appreciated. A little quieter than other areas of Nepal. So many of the highlights are so close together. Good to have a local guide at least for a brief overview. Happened upon a small area of outdoor market with mostly women selling trinkets, jewelry etc. I was in my glory. Found a few very interesting pieces of jewelry, old and new.

column7: Patan 'Historical place ' Heritage Site in Nepal '
column8: Patan Durbar Square is a UNESCO listed World Heritage Sites which is an excellent place with ancient buildings and excellent architecture with wooden carved. After the earthquake Patan Durbar Square is affected somehow , some parts are destoryed but now people are working on the affacted area. I visited Patan Durbar Square in the morning time. It was the memorable view for me from the starting point with the Langtang Mountani range overal the Patan Durbar Square. It is nicely decorated and wood carving including the combination of Hindusm and Buddhism.

This place is amazing. lots of temples and place to eat.lots of roof top cafes with great views. Not much earthquake damage merciful oh. Try to go behind into back streets and courtyards to see really old buildings and ordinary Nepali going about their daily lives. The golden temple is a must but go out the back entrance to see a spectacular courtyard

Spending nine days in Kathmandu while husband is at a conference here. Am taking half day tours to various cities and venues. Today I visited Durbar Square in Patan, not far from Kathmandu. My guide asked me "Do you want to see a living goddess?" I replied " You mean The Kumari?" He said "You know The Kumari" and I explained that I studied the Nepali tradition of worshipping living goddesses. We went to the home she lives in with her family. My guide said to wait as he would see if she was sleeping. She saw me. What a thrill! The living goddess is seven years old and two years into her "reign" and she appeared to be stoic, fearless, and very very special. She gave me a blessing and I asked for blessings for some docent friends who would appreciate the gesture. The Kumari then rubbed a red paste pigment on my forehead. I placed a small donation on her large tray near her throne. I have great respect for cultural traditions that do not harm people. Durbar Square is worth seeing. Many cities in Nepal have a square called Durbar Square in which a former palace was built. Most of the palaces in this region were damaged in,and restored after, the earthquake of 2015. Many countries and charities donated to the efforts and it is remarkable how quickly buildings were restored. Stroll through the side paths of the square, get "lost" alone or with a guide, see chickens, people working, people making food, embroidering cloths, eat at a local place to taste their cuisine, TALK to the people, at least try. Students like to practice their English with tourists. Yes, as others have noted, pay the 1000 or 1500 rupees entrance fee to these UNESCO sites and take it all in. They are worth every rupee!

Build by malla dynasty the wood and carved temple are the focal point of this ancient palace square though very much impacted by massive earthquake which occurred about 2 years back the whole sqaure is under renovation these days.

This once ancient kingdom left behind some great examples of their architecture in the temples and other buildings that are at the heart of Patan. We viewed the museum pieces and ate our lunch in the Patan Museum Cafe. While there a band in native dress marched into the area and posed for pictures...great to see!!!  The area has some great sites to see but. Be aware of the speeding motorcycles that travel the streets and narrow alley ways... much to explore I this area...

Got a guide with us. A UNESCO World Heritage site, it is a place steeped in rich history and culture. Preservation efforts can also be seen post-earthquake. A must-visit on a sightseeing day trip out of Kathmandu.

If you have to choose between Patan Durbar Square and Kathmandu Durbar Square, go to Patan! The old city is welll preserved, and you can actually walk around among the historical buildings. While in Kathmandu's Durb.Sq it is more a touristic place to watch, here you feel more immersed. Nice atmosphere!

column7: Dont leave Kathmandu until you have visited Durbar Square
column8: I don't think I really have to tell anyone not to miss Durbar Square whilst in Kathmandu.It is a bucket list thing that you cant avoid.Ancient architecture steeped in history.A MUST....

Dubai square kept a lot of structures even damaged by earth quake, the authentic wooden carvings are treasures that worthy for the trip, near by alleyways also are amazing to be explored, it's a living museum of the long history of their lifestyle

column7: Visit the Museum inside the Durbar, One of the Best in Kathmandu
column8: While it seems expensive to get in, about $10, it is really worth it. This has to be my favorite durbar in Kathmandu proper. There has been some damage from the quake and repairs are going ahead slowly but the real treasure is the museum inside with an amazing collection of Hindu and Buddhist artifacts with wonderful descriptions. You could easily spend 2-3 hours looking at this museum alone and learn so much about religion in Nepal. You can understand why they call Patan the city of the religious [people]. Reject a tour guide as the signs are very descriptive.

column7: love this unesco world heritage site
column8: historically patan is 3rd largest city.after khatmandu and pokhra and is located in south central part of ktm valley..lalit pur also known as manigal.. Durbar squre patan is situated at center of city.it is one of 3 durbar square in ktm. lalitpur is one of ancient city in ktm valley.lalitpur means beautiful city..there is good reason lalitpur is city full of artisans craftsmen and designers..whole city is abuzz with ancient streets buildingss and traditions

Though many heritage temples have been totally destroyed here, the intact buildings are in much better condition that those in Kathmandu or Bhaktapur. So its worth a visit and take about 1 hr. Also don't miss out the museum, which has a variety of artefacts.

Patan Darbar Square is listed on the World Heritage Site. There are many Pagoda style temples and visit to inner court , with a wide array of stone and wood craving is stunningly beautiful. One of the remarkable monuments in Patan Durbar square is a 17th century temple dedicated to the Hindu God Krishna. The temple is built entirely on stone. Visit to inner bahal and courtyard gives you a wonderful experience to see the daily life of its inhabitants.
Culture and religious center with many centuries old buildings which reflect unique architectural features like intricately carved teak wood panels and elaborate doors posts.

Patan Durbar Square is more compact and quaint than the main square of Kathmandu. The temples are in varying states of repair post earthquake but the general sense of the place is intact and the museum interesting, the surrounding streets narrow and full of life.
An impressive site...lots of deverstation still, but would highly recommend a visit. The museum hides a lovely cafe, where we had lunch - a real hideaway within the square.
Beautiful temple square with ancient historical temple views,Hindu gods are nicely depicted, Temple architecture is extraordinary,must visit place in life
Even after earthquake last year there is lot to see. You must hire a guide to understand the history. Worth spending few hours.

This is about a 600-800Rp taxi ride from Thamel and well worth the effort to get here. It costs 1000Rp for foreigners. From a damage point of view the temples etc have suffered a bit, but not as bad as Kathmandu's Durbar square. Across the road from the pay station there is a raised terrace that affords you a great view of the complex. As I said most of the area is intact but the Hari Shankar Mandir has gone, the Yoganarendra Malla Pillar is up, but behind scaffoldng, the Jagan Narayan Mandir is gone, the Krishna Mandir is heavily scaffolded but they let you in, and the Manimandapa Mandir(?) is gone. That said it is a cool spot to visit and much less "commercial" than Kathmandu. The Patan Museum is definitely worth visiting - lots of nice historical exhibits. You also get to walk round the Royal Palace.

One of the seven Unesco World heritage sites in Kathmandu valley. It is as good as the Kathmandu Durbar square. The temples and the buildings are badly distroyed due to the earthquake in 2015. Eighteen months passed but it seems that no repair or renovation occur. Everything is in progress, the locals used to say. One can only look the ruins and compare the temples to the pictures in travellers guidebooks ... Here, as everywhere, the local guides offer their service. I was informed earlier by my hotels manager that do not accept them. Just look around and see the destination by your own. At the end, you can approach them and ask some details and then pay for that.

it's a great place to see beautiful ancient temples. sadly, most of the temples are devastated by the 2015 earthquake. but through the effort of international communities, renovations are in process. there is one place here where you can try the local food. it is just at the back of the Durbar. you should give the tasty Pani Puri a try! there is also grilled buffalo meat. deep fried franks! also chicken lollipop! all of them are tasty !!
We visited Patan before the earthquake. It was an open museum and we had to pay a ticket to enter the main Durbar square. You will see many historic buildings

We gladly paid the entrance fee and then we were worked by a local guide and finally caved. He was knowledgable and this did enhance our experience but then we found ourselves at "the singing bowl guy" and "the mandala guy", although this may be true, both had prices well above anywhere else. The area of historical interest is actually quite small. It wasn't as spectacular as I had imagined.

column7: Wonderful to visit this ancient site, but sad to see it in such ruin.
column8: Worth a visit, but bear in mind that little has been done to repair sites since the April 2014 earthquake.

column7: Beautiful area you don't want to miss!
column8: We went to Durbar on an afternoon tour with a private guide. This area was damaged less by the earthquake than other areas but still has some damage that is currently being repaired. Very beautiful square with much history. The museum cost $10 to enter but the money goes to supporting the rebuilding efforts. Some interesting items in the museum plus you get to see the inside of the palaces. Very much worth seeing.

We decided to stay in Patan for our first few nights in Nepal and are so glad we did. We had a hotel within 5 minutes walk of Patan Durban Square and spent the whole of our first day there despite plans to spread our wings a little further. The entry fee is more than reasonable and the museum is an absolute must. The friendly locals tell you about their experiences during the earthquakes and this with the devastation on view really brings home the terror that was experienced.

Less damaged by the earthquake than Kathmandu's Durbar Square, Patan's complex is in many ways more impressive, and certainly more accessible, with the ability to enter many of the more important buildings. Well worth a day trip out from Kathmandu.

I love the uniquness of the building around this area. Outstanding architecture details and design. However, the earthquake destroy the beauty. Some renovation works are under going to restore the building. Hope to come back and see the beauty again.

The 16-17th century temples in Patan Durbar square are beautiful and atmospheric, but tragically several were badly damaged in the 2015 earthquake. Work to repair them has begun and is slow and painstaking. To help pay, there's now a charge (750 Nepali Rs / $7.50 /£4.80) which seems steep but it's a good cause. If you want to, you can slip through a side street and enter without paying. It's worth exploring the side streets anyway as they contain some stunning historic carved wooden buildings. Although the square itself is free of commercialism, you'll be plagued by persistent hawkers around it and there are loads of little shops selling mass-produced souvenirs. You can bargain prices down ... or you could buy from an excellent Fairtrade shop on the edge of the square where the profits go to remote Nepali villages.
its very good place if you are travelling to Nepal looking for traditional architecture and Patan is famous for handicrafts

I was there with my friend in 2014 and the place was a beautiful one, with lots of historic, well-preserved temples and other buildings. Of course, some repairs and renovation had to be done (i.e. at the palace), but in overall it looked really great. I don't know if any damage was done by the quakes, but I hope not much, if any. I would say a romantic place as well :)

column7: Don't leave out this square in your itinerary
column8: The square is full of temples with a very long and interesting history. It is in desperate need of restoration after the 2015 earthquake.

column7: Beautiful overall square pity some of the damage by the earthquake
column8: You can really do Kathmandu, Bhaktapur and Patan in one day the three ancient capitals of the Old kingdoms in the Kathmandu valley and for me this is probably the best Durbar square of the three even if damaged by the earthquake. Good atmosphere,very nicely renovated palace and some temples still standing. Definitively worth the visit
The Patan Drubar square is an amazing place to visit if you are willing to know about the culture and tradition of ancient Nepal

column7: A Small, Ancient Royal Palace Rich in Religious Arts
column8: Only 20-30 minutes by car from Kathmandu, Patan's preserved royal palace (durbar square) was the oldest and smallest compared to Kathmandu's and Bhaktapur's and less crowded. There's a south-north, brick-paved pedestrian road to explore. On the left row, you'll see 7 pagoda temples (Krishna, Harishankar, Vishnu, Jagannarayan, Krishna -the main one, Bhimsen and Vishwonath), a huge bell (Taleju) and metal statues of 3 Malla kings on tall monuments. On the right side, royal palaces with courtyards (Sundari Chowk - with sunken bath, Mul Chowk and Mani Keshar Chowk), the Golden Temple & Museum, 3 other temples (Taleju, Degutale, Mani) and the ancient water source, Manga Hiti. Small fees applied to enter the palaces and museum on top of the square's entrance ticket of NPR 500/US$ 5, but it's worth it. There were residential and commercial buildings surrounding and inside the square. We spent a few hours strolling down this historical site, relaxing at temples' stairs and taking lots of photos (visited 2 weeks prior to the devastating earthquake last year).
Such a beautiful and Artistic city of nepal. Amazed with international visitors.Old palace monuments including krishna mandir And temple of thousand buddha was so so nice to watch...........
Durber Central is a cacophony of activity. Ot can be very overwhelming so prepare yourself. But it is something one should experience when in Kathmandu.

We were prepared for a Kathmandu recovering from earthquake. We were prepared for a nation faithfull and away from modern world. But somehow, when i stepped in Durbar Square , saw that dust everywhere........ my eyes got dusty. İn the pictures i could see how should be the temple i was looking at, wonderfull craft, authentic architecture,years of work but in front of me was a mountain of bricks. That moment i wished i would come years before. İ am sure by the time things can recover , but this spring Durbar Square looked dust in the wind. We decided to drink a coffee somewhere upstairs to admire the view of Durbar Square. The place we choosed was at minimum level we are used with, but surprised us with a real cold beer, things difficult to achieve in some parts of Europe.

So glad we took the taxi from Thamel out to Patan the scene of century old structures was incredible and a must do for any visit to Kathmandu Valley. The taxi trip was NPR500 so dont pay more! The entry fee is NPR1000 quite steep but if you are visting Nepal you'll only see bis place once Next time you'd sneak in the back entrance where there are mo ticket offices. Just make sure you leave that way or the guide touts that hang by the main entrance will spot you and could cause embarrassment

Much better than Durbar Square in Kathmandu where the splendour of the ancient temples has unfortunately gone lost with the earthquake. In Patan the Durbar is istead quite intact, maybe smaller in size but enchanting. Worth visiting is the Museum and its gardens, don't miss the peculiar woodcarving and engravings, which are also very important Elements of the typical newari houses and buildings. The fountain with a princess' busto has a memerizing legend story. Long Story, short: She was an untouchable (caste) and beautiful, sitting at edge of the road in her poor garments. The prince passing by on his horse saw her and fell in love at her First sight, even though she was an untouchable, and wanted to marry her. She accepted on one condition, everyone in the reign would have had to Drink water from her Hands, breaching thus the caste System. I like to think of her as the Joan d'Arc of Nepal!

If you have time to travel to Kathmandu, be sure to visit this place. This place is rich in history and culture and has been well preserved and well maintained through ages. Beautiful and picturesque.
A little damaged as a result of the recent earthquakes, but a must see to get a feel of the real Kathmandu
It should a must visit place in your Kathmandu itinerary. A lot of damage has been done during earth quake. Campus had got many lot of thing each having its unique history. Better to have a guide

column7: Must not miss when in Kathmandu
column8: It takes 20 minutes from Thamel to get to Darbar Square. I suggest you go with a guide because there is so much history in this place. From the Kumari Ghar to the Royal Palace, each temple or landmark has its unique story. The major repairs post-earthquake are well under way. This is definitely a place not to be missed as it is a beautiful mix of pan-Asian architecture and art. We will definitely have to come back to see the hippie temple where Jimmy Hendrix used to hang out at. The re-construction has not started.

Patan is an ancient historical place located in Lalitpur city, 30 minutes far from Kathmandu.It is a beautiful place listed in world heritage sites by UNESCO. This site is very much rich in Hindu temples & monuments which are wonderfully carved with stones, the beautiful fine arts, & ornate architecture. The visitors can enjoy the scenic view of area, Krishna temple, golden temple, mahabouddha temple, Golden window, Patan Museum, Bhimsen temple, are the major attraction of this place. More Newar peoples are the resident of this area so, it is rich in Newari culture, and visitors can also enjoy the taste of Newari street food. Overall Patan is beautiful area with lots of things to view around in a peaceful & calm area.The eartquake hitted some parts of Patan but not all, it is still worth to visit.

One of the most elegant among the Durbar Squares. You can spend at least half a day to visit this architectural heritage. Even though some sign of destruction by earthquake is still visible this place is worth a visit.

column7: By Going Now - you support post-earthquake restoration
column8: Nepal's massive earthquake and aftershock was one year-ago. The is the perfect time to visit Kathmandu and the nearby, world heritage site of the old city centre of Patan's, Durbar Square. A trip there is now especially gratifying, as the local economy is heavily dependent on tourism, which has significantly fallen from pre-earthquake days. From Kathmandu, it is an easy, thirty minute taxi ride to this living museum. While there is evidence of earthquake damage, most of the splendid buildings remain intact. There is a palpable vibrancy and optimism that adds to the energy of the place. Walking amidst the magnificently carved ancient wooden temples is a powerful experience. The very impressive Patan Museum in the historic town centre is not be missed. (And the delicious veggie momos in the museum's terrace café make for a splendid break!)

Located south of Kathmandu this ancient city is in Lalitpur. The square has a number of temples, palaces, ancient monuments noted for its architecture and craftsmanship. Plenty of good and restaurants to spend time while visiting the Pathan Durbar Aware.

Patan Durbar Square is one of the most see attraction among three Durbar Square from Kathmandu, Patan and Bhaktapur. One can spend whole day exploring this Heritage Site. Simply loved this place and should be here at least for one in lifetime. Thank you Distinctive Nepal for including it in our program.

Not as much major damage as western press try to sensationalise. Most buildings are standing and still in use, albeit some supported by wooden props. Few apparent ongoing repairs to, or rebuilding of, small shrines and certainly not on a scale that could be expected from the amount of disaster aid donated. Over a year on, there’s many people still living in tents and temporary shacks.

I've heard Patan have been one of the wealthiest cities (kingdoms) in Nepal. They have had the culture of traditional architecture and sculpture that brings more beautiful town sight than Kathmandu. You must visit here if you want to feel Nepali Beautiful Tradition.

column7: Amazing square with so much history
column8: Patan really is well worth the short 20 minute drive from the centre of Kathmandu. Although damaged by the 2015 earthquake many buildings and monuments are still intact and have their own unique story to tell. The atmosphere was relaxed and peaceful and we were able to wander around and enjoy the sights. Only negative is that some of the debris from the earthquake is still scattered around and could be cleared up.

column7: A good historical place torn up by small shops
column8: I think this place had great potential! Some great old fort buildings which should have been left alone and not made into a mini shopping mall!!! Such a shame! The yougurt icecream outside the door was very yummy though! Food inside is over priced! And apart from the pottery shops inside, the rest should be removed from there!

column7: lovely walk in the old city around durbar square
column8: we did the walk recommended by lonely planet and thoroughly enjoyed it- great to see local life at close quarters. we had just done bhaktapur previous day so perhaps this seemed less than that. maybe if we hadn't done bhaktapur -tthis would get higher rating!

Nice place to see ancient newari culture that also still lies with the newar community. Krishna temple, and other monuments generates pease while you stay here. Nice place to forgot the tiredness within you. You should also taste the honacha, typical newari food behind the central square

column7: Cocktail of History and the future
column8: So many historical places, with so many stories in every corner of it. You can see people of all the ages hanging out here. Still peaceful and mesmerizing even after the earthquake devastation.
Great area to explore old temples, historical sites, shops and local handcraft. I loved walking around this part of town.

I paid NPR 1000 (around USD 10) for the entrance fee, it was a bit expensive for me. Here you can find very nice heritage from the former kingdom of Nepal. The management authority was struggling hard to renovate most of the building there which impacted by the earthquake in 2015. It was one of the tourist spot in Kathmandu. it was a good experience for me.

Old town with old architecture which is still intact post earthquake. You see certain buildings and school destroyed by earthquake but still the spirit of the people keeps the place alive and buzzing.

I was here in October/November 2015. Different than the squares in Kathmandu and Bakhtapur, the Durbar Square of Lalitpur hardly shows any signs of the destruction anymore, rubble has been removed and buildings are being rebuilt. The super interesting Patan Museum and its nice (and a little expensive) garden café was open (apart from a few, destroyed parts of the building everything was accessible) and the square is less busy than its two counterparts in the valley. It is a great place to hang out, stroll around and witness everyday life in Nepal. Across the street, above the market stalls and up a narrow staircase, there is an amazing café/restaurant (sadly, I don't remember the name) with the most beautiful woodcarved windows, through which you can watch the square and its inhabitants while enjoying a plate of momos and a cup of sweet chia. You'll have a great view of the central Vishnu temple and the Garud statue, as well as most of the old palace, which is now the Patan Museum.

column7: Patan Durbar Square - post-earthquake - A MUST DO
column8: After the April 25, 2015 earthquake (I was here in Kathmandu) the foreign news carried reports of massive destruction for this site. Inaccurate reporting also said Kathmandu was leveled (it wasn't).  I was not able to get to Patan in May of 2015 but just did so on my return to Kathmandu in 2016.  The central district is a treasure trove of what did NOT fall down. Walking the narrow amazing side streets with the rare Nepalese architecture of intricately carved dark wood and red brick - my heart beat with joy. Yes, there was damage and I expected to see huge now vacant areas where there once was something and now there is not. But in the main square area I did not find evidence of this anywhere.  The entire central area deserves your slow, intricate wandering. It is quieter, more restful than Kathmandu Durbar Square. No taxis and motorbikes allowed in the main square.  Have a Lavazza coffee, sit in a rooftop cafe overlooking the square, sit with locals and have a tea or coffee with them, ask them where they were at earthquake time - they will love to talk with you. Wander the antique and souvenir shops, have local food on a side street, stay in a hotel or bed and breakfast - there are some great ones. Go into the several beautiful temples just off the main square. Go into the museum.  Do not hurry when you visit this site - there is a feel you want to capture. It is ancient and it is alive. You will feel blessing here. Guaranteed..  HIGHLY RECOMMENDED

column7: Amazing place to visit in Kathmandu
column8: If you love history and architecture, this is the place MUST visit in Kathmandu. The place is certified by UNESCO Heritage Site as World Heritage Place in Nepal. Admission is Rs500.

column7: Less busy than Kathmandu Durbar Square
column8: I really enjoyed visiting this square and felt it was really worth a visit, despite the earthquake damage. It was a lot less busy than Kathmandu Durbar Square, which made it easier to relax and enjoy the environment and hear about the history of the square (well worth hiring a guide for this). The surrounding areas have lots of local artisans who do metal work, so it is worth a wander around here (if only to admire their skills, even if you don't buy anything).
Everybody knows that lalitpur is the city of Art . This ancient city is famous for metal art. All temples are really beautiful with Newari art and style .
this is a ancient place which was is beaitful place and i had visited this place by @Rosha Trek & Expedition P. Ltd.
We did hire a guide and I'm glad we did as he told us a lot more history than we would have known otherwise. We did end up in the obligatory singing bowl display but it was worth a laugh.

column7: Patan Durbar is a main attraction in Kathmandu Valley
column8: This Durbar consists of various pagodas (two of them damaged by the earthquake of 2015) and stone temples. Entering from the main gate, on the right Hand side there is the mighty King's Palace, which includes a rewarding Museum at his end. The place lives, locals are coming and going, children play and foreigners admire the beauty of the unique Newar architecture. Entry fee is asked for at the gate.

column7: One of the beautiful squares from the Kathmandu Valley.
column8: I went to Patan Durbar Square with my family on 20th December 2015 especially to see the Patan museum which was established with the help of Austrian government. The museum was superb with the collection of both the Hindus and Buddhist artifacts. Despite some damages done by earthquake to some temples the Durbar square was still beautiful to watch. We also visited the 3 courtyards of the old palace of which Sundari chowk was the best.

The whole 'old city' of Patan is fascinating, not just the Durbar Square. There has been quite a bit of damage from the April 2015 earthquakes, but repairs appear to be underway. If you are in the market for statues, thangkas, jewellery etc do it here, not Thamel...MUCH cheaper and greater variety

Patan Darbar Square is situated in the heart of Lalitpur, Mangal Bazar. There are a lot many tour places near by,i.e Patan Musium, Krishna Mandir,achyasin Dewal and manyother historic places where people keep interest to have experiences. Furthermore within 5 minute walking distance we can reach Hiranyabarna Mahadihar, the Golden Temple of Gautam Budha. Irecommend people to have heavenly experience.

The most important monument of the city is Patan Durbar Square, which has been listed by UNESCO as one of seven Monument Zones that make up the Kathmandu Valley World Heritage Site. The seven monument zones were included in the World Heritage List in 1979 as one integrated site. The monument zones are declared as protected and preserved according to the Monuments Preservation Act of 1956. The Square was heavily damaged on 25 April 2015 by an earthquake
Patan has suffered much less than Durbar Square in Kathmandu and most of the temples are intact. There are many interesting temples here and a lovely garden

column7: Plenty to see but Bhaktapur better!
column8: Most temples are intact after the earthquake and we thought it was fantastic until we went to Patan which has slightly more to see and Bhaktapur which is much bigger and better.

column7: One of the must visit in Kathamandu
column8: A very friendly guide called Raju showed us Thamel/Durbar square one structure at a time briefing us on each of those structures. Sad to see many beautiful age old structures destroyed in the April 2015 earthquake. A lo of standing structures stand shaken and broken being supported by pillars. Thamel is home to a number of cute boutique cafes, pubs and clubs. All in all a must visit.

column7: Great to see repairs going on at this great site
column8: It is sad to see so much damage in Kathmandu after the earthquake, but as well it's great to see so much repair work going on. There are still hundreds living in tents around the city, and this is a dreadful thing that needs attention. But there is support from the Japanese and the Germans (among others) to repair the ancient sites in Kathmandu, and that is marvellous. You still can experience the wonder of this place, and there are very few tourists at the moment, everything is extremely cheap; it's a great time to visit!

We visited this during our Nepal trip in December 2010. This is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and is a marvel of Newa architecture.We were amazed to see the old temples since the architecture was very different from what we get to see in India.Main attraction is the ancient royal palace where the Malla Kings of Lalitpur resided.The main temples are aligned opposite of the western face of the palace and there is also a giant bell situated beside the main temples. The Square also showcases old Newari residential houses.
Know that there's a little old temple in front across the street, the small gate would be close but you may open and climb up and get a good view of the square.

column7: A fantastic place to visit, though very damaged in the earthquoke
column8: A beautiful site with fantastic temples. Was amazing before the earthquake, but very damaged after. Still totally worth visiting. Recommend getting a local guide to tell about the history and the temples. There is usually one or two by the ticket booth.

Typically I get bored of 'sight seeing' type locations, but this is one place you can sit all day and people watch among the busy streets shadowed on all sides by intricately designed historic temples.

This is a beautiful piece of history. It is sad to see the damage from the earthquake, but it is nice to see the locals rallying behind and helping to clean it up. The architecture and sites are worth the visit. Details all the way down to the carvings on the doors and windows are immaculate.
Great Place. An absolute Must See in Kathmandu. Some sites are not open after the earthquake. Too bad...!

One of the best places to be. Has a wonderful blend of History, Architecture, Temples and peace. A place where you would love to end your day with a coffee or just a stroll with all by yourself or with family and friends.

Possibly the highlight of Kathmandu, Although a bit smaller than the other Durbar Square, Durbar Patan is awe inspiring. There's a great museum, which is Rs400 to visit, but otherwise, almost everything else is free to wander around. Alas, that's because of the earthquake. Normally, there would be a fee for the site, but almost all of it is closed or fenced off. That doesn't stop it being an amazing area and the outside of the temples and structures are really impressive.  The small Golden Temple is still open and only costs Rs50 to visit and is quite stunning. Very ornate and beautiful. Other than the museum, that is the only inside place available currently.  There are many, many hawkers around and many 'guides' who will pester you all the time. Since they are really struggling for work since the earthquake, it is completely understandable, but nonetheless tiring.

column7: If you have short stay this is place to go!
column8: My high profile friends have limited time between flights and she wants to see something unique to Nepalese art, culture and way of life. I took her to Patan Darbar square for quick snapshots of Nepal. She was so happy to see landscape of Darbar square, life around there and museum in side Darbar square. Stone, metal and wood carving skills are astonishing.

of all the Durbar squares in Nepal, this one is the best. relaxed , beautiful and welcoming. you will not get hounded by merchants and can spend your time walking amidst the ruins and the still standing temples and museums or walk into the quite streets where people actually live. Some real nice places to eat too on the rooftops. great way for a quite afternoon

it was was a nice experience for me to visit. very traditional buildings and liked the structure. took lots of photo. but I went there after the earthquake.. so found some buildings being supported with logs or iron rods... overall it was pretty cool experience. I will visit again once they repair the damage caused my earthquake...

column7: Among rubbles,But Still a magical attraction
column8: We walk here on a drizzling Friday,nb4 heading to Swotha Home for breakfast. Clear sky followed after 9am, many local-students, couples & old folks hurrying about their lives, cycling by...some stopping by to pray These complex of temples,shrine & museum are still standing sturdy amidst the quake, few buildings are affected,few place are cordon off for renovation work&safety issue.

Walking around the square takes one back to a time where life was less chaotic.  Make sure to purchase your ticket before you go into the various buildings. I had the fortune to actually see a taping of a show where the actors all wore period costumes. It was a sight to behold. To see people dressed in costumes amidst the setting, it was definitely an experience.  The place was crowded during my visit, but in spite of the crowd, once can still feel the history emanating from within the walls of this sacred place.
like i say.. the beauty is still there even after the earthquake .. just stunning. Lots of pigeon which adding to the unique beauty of the place

Patan One of the three royal cities in the Kathmandu Valley has a rich cultural heritage known for its fine crafts, evident in the elaborate architecture, stone carvings, and metal statues found all over the city. A centre of both Buddhist and Hindu culture in Tibet, Patan is home to more than 1,200 monuments. One of the most stunning is the Krishna Mandir, a stone temple with magnificent friezes built in the 16th century. Patan Durbar Square is also a good place to see beautiful examples of palaces, temples and shrines, and the stunning stone carvings in the Sundari Courtyards. The entire city of Patan was designated a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1979.

It's still possible to imagine what Durbar Square was like, the previous place of Kings, but following the April, 2015 earthquake much of it is now lies in rubble. Huge piles of debris litter the square as military police guard the damaged historic sites from potential looters. The area is still active and local life continues but the, as is the case across Nepal, much of the nation's cultural heritage has been severely damaged,

You will feel on the sets of a Hollywood blockbuster or if more imaginative, the place will take you 200 years back in a blink of eye. Spare and spend some time sitting in a corner and imagining life of that time. The place does not look like a historical monument because life goes on in around it.

This is (was) an incredibly beautiful group of buildings with intricate details and carvings in teak and stone. it is a square full of ancient palaces, shrines and temples. We were there just before the earthquake so not sure how much has survived.
