As with Ronni W's review, I write this to remember the historic Patan Durbar Square was until the devastating earthquake on 25 Apr 2015. I hope the wonderful museum has survived in tact. One assumes the renovations included suitable earthquake protection elements.

column7: A wonderful range of ancient buildings and museum
column8: Durbar Square in patan is well worth the 300 Nepali rupees Westerners must pay to walk around. The buildings are a wonderful mix of Buddhist and Hindu monuments and the museum is excellent for those who want to delve further. There is a lovely cafe at the back of the gardens and worth wandering to after a good look round.

column7: A marvelous mix of Hindu and Buddhism
column8: There is more to this place than meets the eye. We are glad that we got a local guide, available at the entrance to the square. Well worth the 1000 rp we paid for the hour and a half tour. He spoke English well and took us to places we would not have found, explained lots of the Hindu carvings and history and then took us off to some Buddhist temples out of the square. Could have spent more time there. Had lunch in the tranquil cafe attached to the museum.

column7: Good place to visit and easy to access from Kathmandu
column8: This square is very much worth a visit as it is only a 20 - 30 minute taxi journey from Kathmandu. There are a number of historic temples including some extraordinary erotic (and not for the faint-hearted!) carvings on one of the temples in a traditional South Asian style. The square also houses the Patan Museum, which is simply amazing. It is easy to walk from here to the nearby Mahabuddha temple. There are fairly regular religious processions and performances in the square as well. Overall, I strongly recommend a visit to this square and the surrounding historic neighborhood - many of the buildings are remarkably old, featuring period carvings and architecture.

After visiting the square in Katmandu at the start of our trip in Nepal, we visiting Durbar Square in Patan at the end of the trip. It is a lovely quaint place to be and although there is a fee to pay it is worth it. Again I would suggest a guide who can explain the meanings of the temples and symbols and gives you a history of the architecture of the many buildings. The square is surrounded by many restaurants and cafes where you can have a drink on the rooftop with a view of the temples and buildings of the square.

column7: Historic Square with an authentic feel, far far better than Kathandus Durbar Sq
column8: We visited the Durbar Sq in Patan the day after we visited the one in Khatmandu and the difference is immense. You still have to pay to get into the area of the Square - but all the sourrounding streets are far more welcoming and you are treated as less of a target for touts etc etc in this square.  A relativeley small area the square is a rectangular shaped area bordered on one side by the old Palace and on the other side of a wide thoroughfare are a variety of temples. The locals transit through the square and it does have a genuine local feel to it.  Unlike Kathmandu this square is blocked off for cars and mopeds, and it does look like they have spent some of the entrance fee on improving the infrastructure.  Concidering the short distance from the centre of Khatmandu I would thoroughly reccomend a trip here - it's a far better Durbar Sq (Although not quite as good as Bhaktapurs).

For this attraction it is a good idea to get a local guide when you pay your entry fee. Remember, these attractions demand payment from foreigners but not locals. Negotiate with the guide first though. I paid 1/2 of what my guide was asking. In addition, confirm how much time they will be spending with you. The reason to get a guide is to ensure you find the Buddhist Golden Temple which is hidden down some side streets from the primarily Hindu buildings. 500 Rupees for entry fee. The architecture is very cool and about 500 years old. The Golden Temple is worth the extra 50 Rupees entrance fee. Gold-plated and from the 12th century. Be ready to say 'no' to being taken to more shops as that is common with these guides who receive a kickback.

This is a must visit place if one need to see the old part of Nepal, its art, architecture and old buildings, a guide can help you to see places quickly and it is not expensive 500 NPR will get you guide for 30 min

There are three Durbar Square in Nepal. Beside this two more are-Kathmandu and Bhaktapur Durbar Square. Plazzas and opposite area of Palace is Called Durbar Sqare.Here there is best remaining example of Newari architecture.Most of buildings are erected between 16th to18th Century. Most temples are dedicated to Lord Vishnu/Krishna.Some temple opens only once in a year.Here there is a museum also with all details. A Nice Place.

column7: Best of the Three Durbar Squares
column8: Part of seven archeological and historic UNESCO sites in Kathmandu Valley, Patan Durbar Square is a must see. Westerners pay a higher entry ticket price (roughly 1000Rs), but the day-ticket can be extended for several days until the end date of your visa if you bring it to show at the ticket counter. This square seems to be the center of business as well, so taxis from here are easy to find. Don't miss the museum and the Museum Cafe! You may be approached for tours of the area that usually start at 1200Rs, but negotiate hard. Some tour guides will take you to Tibetan shops to sell you singing bowls and paintings--all beautiful and whatnot, but steeply overpriced. Be sure to negotiate very low for these if you do want to purchase. Otherwise, don't cave in to pressure or let your guide know you aren't willing to buy before entering.

column7: History Past and Present in Dubar Square.
column8: I enjoyed this day very much. A day filled with history. I went with a Nepali friend and an english speaking guide. For me, this was a great introduction to Nepali customs and culture.
A wonderful place to go and see old Kathmandu. Very interesting and beautiful place to walk around. Tourists do have to pay to get in.

When we first got to Patan Square, we thought the picture in front of us was just amazing. The brick buildings were completely mazing. One side of the road was a row of palaces which were 400 years old. The other side were all temples about 900 years old. According to our guide the street use to be a river. The area is completely alive. Once a year, at the palace courtyard, they still sacrifice 108 buffalo and they hang the intestine on the door. The local Nepalese are every where, sitting around, chatting and watching the world go by. Down a flight of stairs, women are busy filling up their portable water into jerry cans and then carrying it around their heads back home - absolutely back-aching work. Some tips: 1. Across the street is a store and if you go up the stairs, there is a picture perfect opportunity for the entire street scene. 2. No point to pay for a guide. Ours charged us USD20 and the information was simple. Of course it saved us reading up on things on looking for the small nooks.

Actually square is no big. It is big money just for the small square. HIsotry , temple tropical. Marvelous Krisna temple made from stone. There is extra fee for museum. Even management are expensive, it is best look around temple enrich for the metal craft.

Really cool to see the day by day activities between these age old buidlings. Not really necesarry to get a guide, at least ours didn't have much to add. They are insistent though. Lots of souvenirs to buy, do remember to bargain heavily.

No visit to Kathmandu would be complete without visiting Darbar Square. For a taste of the non-tourist experience, visit the museum in Hanuman Dhoka: with its (somewhat dusty and not exceptionally artful) displays of old armaments, coins, and an exhibit dedicated to the Shah kings, it is more popular with locals than with tourists. The views from the inner towers, too, aren't to be missed.

I think you'll notice that most of the Dunbar Squares share quite a few similarities, but it's still worth the visit. It's always great to see locals, and witness part of culture/history. Worth the visit--great pictures!

column7: Second best Durbar Square in Kathmandu
column8: I would rate Patan as the second best Durbar Square in Kathmandu after Bhaktapur. The architecture of all the three durbar squares are similar and all three are UNESCO heritage sites. Patan is a quick ride from Kathmandu city. All the main attractions are in relatively smaller area compared to Bhaktapur. Like other squares, you have a palace and surrounding temples. Some of the temples have beautiful intricate work. All the squares have an animated atmosphere with locals and tourists alike.  Definitely worth a visit if you have time for all three squares.
While the basic structure of all 3 Durbar squares of Kathmandu valley are the same, each of them have their own charm. A must see for its unique temples

I loved Patan so much I stayed a few extra days. Looking at the same temple every day I saw something new each time. Check out the small carvings below and in the corners. As a solo old woman who loves getting lost, I noticed the locals avoiding eye contact with me until a Namaste on my part gave me a wide smile and welcoming demeanor. Crazy motorcyle drivers in small alleys, the Nepali locals gently shoved me aside until I learned to adapt.

column7: Blending Lalitpur's history with today's vibe
column8: Thanks to our guide, Prakash Chaulagain. We met him at the entrance of Durbare Square (south side near the former royal palace). He is well educated and well spoken in English. He studied tourism and is officially licenced. Prakash dragged us into the history of Lalitpur and knows all ins and outs of Durbare Square and surroundings. The buildings are generally well preserved and we believe this area is a must see when you visit Kathmandu and/or the former kingdom of Patan

This durbar square is lovely place in Kathmandu. I have visited this place late November 2014. It is great combination of tradition, culture and history. The museum is great. The atmosphere around the place is amazing. Beautiful architecture, must to visit this place!

If you cannot get to Bactapur, Patan will show you what old Nepalese architecture and regal style existed once upon a time. Elegance and spatial design provide a real wow factor. Add nearby boutique hotels, good eating options, laneways and retail to the mix for a pleasant half day experience

Don't get confuse as there are many square in the whole Nepal and just in Kathamandu itself there is another Durbar square. This is in Patan but they call it Durbar square too. The square is full of ancient monuments, temples and shrines, noted for their exquisite craftsmanship and architectural beauty and varieties of shops around it. There are those ancient monument that they convert to restaurant so is nice to sit in and dine while enjoying the view. Lots of stuff to buy so if you are the shopping type then the whole day might just be enough to spent here.

column7: I was luck found this city
column8: Base on my previous plan, I just visit the Durbai square in Kathmandu. Recommended by hotel staff, I went to anther Durbai square in Patan city(6 km from Thamel). I really love the city, every thing was filled of the feeling of history. There are many temples, Hindoo and Buddhism. People were really friend and peaceful. You can find a lot of hand-made local product stores with better quality and price.

column7: A busy place full of interest
column8: Its World Heritage site status is well deserved. A ticket is required to gain admission but costs are reasonable. There are a few hawkers of street souvenirs but none are overly pushy. A great place to spend the morning soaking up the atmosphere and taking photos.

A site that keeps captivated for whatever time you are there. Durbar Square is a complex full of temples, restaurants, shops of local production. Narrow lanes remind of Chandni Chowek in Delhi India. Its a living museum. Shops have antique stuff including showpieces, windows, cloth. Art and craft like paintings, khukri, pottery are must see. Intricate carvings on temples and pagodas keep you staring and wondering. King's curd is very famous. Must visit place.  Nidhi KM  Viharin.com A glance beyond your window, come have a look!
This is a part of Kathmandu that you cannot miss - the depth of history is staggering, and the atmosphere is intoxicating.

This is a superb place, not to be missed. There are a series of temples, all well preserved and lined up. The woodwork on the outside of the Palace complex is incredible. Unfortunately the Museum was closed as it was a holiday but the whole complex is dazzling and there is so much to see. We had a guide with us but you could do it on your own, though our guide also showed us some courtyards and old monasteries we wouldn't have known about.

This place is amazing. Be sure to consider the wood you see is centuries old. The Teak is amazing that it does not decay. This is a World Heritage sight and many of these reviews cover the same thing so I will not go there again. Go see the Love Temple and be sure to see the carvings around the top. Maybe you will be inspired a bit.

Patan is one of the ancient capitals in Kathmandu Valley and has a splendid temple complex in its Durbar Square. Founded in the 3rd century, Patan is also called Lalitpur or 'Beautiful City'. According to my guidebook, there are 55 major temples in this city alone and 136 courtyards many of which make this beautiful section of the city a photographer's paradise.  We strolled through this marvelous square and spent about three hours enjoying the sights, sounds, smells, and colors of this magnificent World Heritage site. We started with the Royal Palace to our right and moved on to the Sacred Well just beyond. The water that comes out of the spouts comes from a water source miles away. There is the pillar surmounted by a gilt statue of King Yoganarendra Malla shaded by the hooded cobra that hovers over him and the simply splendid Krishna Mandir with its colonnades and porches and a huge dome over all.  I really wish I had the time to come back here because there is so much to see that I probably overlooked a lot. On the day of our visit, the square was very crowded because there was an election rally with thousands of people waving flags and listening to the speakers. There were pilgrims and monks visiting the religious sites and temples, shoppers bustling about, and tourists dining at cafes and restaurants. The place has an energy level that can't be beat.  We also moved on to the Golden Temple in the north part of town. Again, very exciting. See my photos as these are worth a thousand words. Note that there is a small fee to enter this area of the city. Pay it without complaint as it helps to preserve this marvelous complex.

column7: A living thriving view of history
column8: Walking through this square is like walking through history, the old palaces, temples, pathways..... i wonder if the people living here realize they live in this place where timelines have just blurred and past is present in the today. Amazing architecture and sculptures adorn this beautiful piece of the past. Here you will see the statue of the reigning king who disappeared with his family a 100s of years ago, the bird on his head which is symbol of Patan's survival, the kali temple temple with the door adorned with buffalo intestines, where 108 buffaloes are sacrificed each year, the queen's chambers, the water faucets which get their supply from river 100 of miles away and the temples dedicated to Krishna, Shiva, Pandavas and others.

Most people arrive and leave from Kathmandu. If you can take a day to see nearby cities in the valley, you'll get a broader view of the history and culture that are unique to the Nepali, and particularly the Newar, people. Patan (Lalitpur) has a beautiful, compact, and well preserved durbar temple complex that is well worth the visit.

We visited Durbar square, Patan on the Dussehra day- the most important religious day of the year in Nepal. It is one of the world heritage durbar squares in Kathmandu area, the other two being Thamel and Bhaktapur.The place was decked up and full of tourists, the atmosphere festive. We could see some signs of the animal sacrifices that had taken place in the morning.. The museum, however, was closed as it was a national holiday..  The architecture and layout of the square is fascinating. Most of the monuments were built in the 17th century by Malla Kings. Newari architecture at its best. Red stone and bricks and intricate wood carvings adorn the numerous Hindu and Buddhist shrines and monuments. The Krishna temple- the only 'Krishna' temple in the area, as Nepalese Hindus traditionally worship Durga/Shakti- is a fine example of Shikhara architecture.  There is a small entry fee for foreigners. Take a leisurely walk and as you soak in the beauty and the atmosphere, and enjoy and admire the art and architecture. My preferred method in such places is not to try and see everything but enjoy bits and pieces as the excess of sensory stimuli can be exhausting! The quaint rooftop European cafes that dot the area are an added attraction and are great for a coffee (or beer!) and snacks..
It feels like you are back to past when you are there. Masterpiece of wood art of medieval period. Living Goddess Kumari.

column7: An absolutely stunning contribution to World Heritage
column8: Patan Durbar Square is in my opinion the best Durbar Square in the Kathmandu area, because its incredible architecture and sculptures are complemented by how integrated the area is into the daily lives of people in Patan. Though it might give apoplexy to conservators, the fact that you have kids playing amongst priceless treasures and lovers canoodling under the watchful eyes of idols everywhere, brings it alive far more than a sterile Western museum presentation can!

The drive to get here is totally worth the spectacular architecture, history and the museum. It is much better kept than Durbar square in Kathmandu and it's a good place to simply wander about and let the detailed ornate carvings and extravagant decorations sink in.

Smaller than Bhaktapur but worth the trip. Patan is teeming with local life, history, and culture. There are many temples that have been built hundreds of years ago. Like in most places in Kathmandu the place was chaotic but culturally significant.

column7: Great Way to spend half a day - definitely include the museum!
column8: The Patan Museum is a great add-on to Patan Durbar Square. Beautiful architecture and lots of history! a great stroll!

column7: A good happening place in Patan
column8: I went to this place along with my friends and course mates as a part of a cultural outing. Before we were there, we didn't know what to expect for and then we were there, we were like, 'wow'. The atmosphere around the place is nice and has an ancient vibe in the wind. There are clothes attached to the roofs of the castles which dances as the wind blows which gives a feeling of peace. There are plenty of food stalls around. The day we were there hosted a public performance on interactive theater by this local group. I would recommend people to visit this place if they have the opportunity to.  Oh and there are admission fees to enter this facility. The rate however is different for the natives, South Asian citizens and others. I do not remember exactly but I think we paid 150 NPR (US$ 1.5) for South Asian passes.

Kathmandu is known as Kasthamandap, the source of the name Kathmandu means ‘made from the timber of a single tree’. Also known as Kantipur, the capital Kathmandu is the hub of Nepal's art and culture. It is a place for rest, relaxation and easy-day sightseeing of historic and artistic temples and monuments. Kathmandu Durbar Square with its arrays of temples, Seto Machhindranath and the ancient palace of the former Nepali Royals enriches your experience of the centuries old civilisation.

You'll know if you walk the busy city 'roads' of Kathmandu, that the prophecy of mankind having to "buy" breathable air in the coming future might just be a reality! In such a scenario, the Lalitpur Durbar Square is a breather. Although, the bikers and mopeders will blow its horns and exhausts till the fringes of the square, but once you're there then you'll be absorbed in the history of dynastic rules in Kathmandu valley with a much needed relief!  Please visit here and escape from otherwise "filthy" Kathmandu city.

If the hanuman dhoka durbar square has unique combination of malls and shah period architecture,patan durbar square on the other hand reflects singular malla architecture.It has a unique architecture style manga hiti,the sunken stone water spout and the magnificent Krishna temple,a shikhara style temple built of stone are really perfect.  I enjoy a lot, visiting different courtyard of patandurbar square.The mangalbazar where square lies is very good place to see the monument and different arts and different temple in different style. I love to visit and enjoy this place so i often loke to visit here when i am in Kathmandu.

Patan's Durbar square truly deserves it's World Heritage status. It is an amazing collection of Buddhist and Hindu buildings. Patan / Lalitpur is 15 minutes drive from Kathmandu south across the Bagmati River. Its a wonderful place to wander for a couple of hours, with no cars in your way. There is a ticket kiosk at the entrance to the square, it costs 500rs and you have to wear a sticker. Around the entrance there are pushy people wanting to be your guide, even small children are in on the act. One said to me "sooner or later you will have to give in". You don't need a guide, I found them so persistent I headed straight for a rooftop café called Café du Temple and just sat there reading about the square and viewing it from afar. The square can be very relaxing if you find your own secluded spot. Children play badmington, people wash their clothes in a nearby well. Make sure you set aside a couple of hours for the museum. Look out for some Bull's instestines hanging over a door near the museum.
Lalitpur Durbar Square is amazing, I only wish non-hindus could go inside temples.... Anyway here you feel the charm of ancient times...

We were sceptical to enter the museum at first but real glad that we did. The museum was well maintained and there's many interesting exhibits. There's also a restaurant at the rear courtyard, while the food is average, it has a nice atmosphere.

After visiting Durbar Square in Kathmandu the square in Patan, although the buildings are of the same style, it feels a million miles away. If you are staying in the area, I would recommend this, Ask them to stamp your ticket on the back, you will need your passport for this, your ticket then lasts a week so you can visit or walk through the square as often as you want. Make sure you keep your ticket with you, staff are around checking and if you can't show it you will be taken to the ticket booth. Take time to wander through the side streets and see a little more of Patan, there are some great value little craft shops. We had some wooden gifts made to bring home for a really reasonable price and watching the craftsmen work on them made them extra special. Great for people watching and watching life go by.

Patan Durbar square is likely the easiest to get around, well maintained and less chaotic then the other durbar squares. You can even stay in any of the hotels in the larger area with easy access to modern amenities just a few minutes away. In short, it is the closest to being a living, breathing museum with as less touristy features as can be possible in such historic sites. Think of a mini Angkor Tham without an international company selling the whole package to you. There are actual people who live and breathe within these grounds same as they did thousands of years ago.

column7: Beautiful square with temples and stupas
column8: It is not a large area, and quite crowded with temples, stupas, and people. The only real complication is the entry ticket, as the area is open and you could easily walk in without realising you've missed the ticket booth. As others have mentioned, the ticket checkers who come around can be annoying but once you have a ticket it lasts a few days. If you've seen other Durbar squares, you can just get a drink at the terrace of one of the cafes overlooking the square and appreciate it from outside. Worth seeing if you are in Patan.

The only real reason you come to Patan.  The entrance fee is pricey for the western tourist but so worth it when there are so many temples, stupas and sights to see.  We got a guide who came in pretty cheap and was totally worth it for the hour.

column7: Very nice place! You can't miss it
column8: Patan is near Kathmandu, in Lalitpur. Is an old little place, with a few blocks, with incredible temples, squares, alleys where you will see incredible places. You have to pay to get inside this place. Inside Patan you will find de Golden Temple is an exquisite place. The Museum is very interesting but I didn"t have time to visit it. Very interesting. it's a nice place to walk for a while...if you can sit in a stais or in a temple to see people going by is a nice sempsation, kids playing, Old people sitting in benchs each aafternoon to see life passing by....a really good choice!!!

There are two, if not three, Durbar (or Darbar) Squares in what one thinks of as Kathmandu. This Durbar Square is, however, in Patan which, at one time, would have been separate from old Kathmandu. Kathmandu has extended so much it has now swallowed areas that might have, historically, been townships in their own right.  Patan Durbar Square has more impressive temples and historic sights than its counterpart in Kathmandu. Don't visit Nepal without seeing both, however, as each has something to offer.  A pleasant thing about Durbar Square is that one isn't hassled, or at least not too much, by persons offering to act as a guide, sell one souvenirs, etc. Be sure to bargain with taxi drivers, as they will almost inevitably try and overcharge you. The same applies to shops and stalls selling handicrafts, Pashmina shawls and souvenirs. One can end up paying very considerably less than what the seller initially demands. A good time to buy is nearing the end of the day. Traders find it hard to avoid the temptation to make one last sale and some real bargains can be obtained in these circumstances.

column7: One of the best durbars (local squares)
column8: Patan is a 13th century village now protected as a Unesco World Heritage site. The central square was busy but not crowded for our visit and we enjoyed the friendly atmosphere

Make sure your batteries on the camera are charged as there are many photos to be taken here. Although it make seem similar to other temple complexes around Kathmandu, the air here is buzzing with locals enjoying. Chat and meeting up with friends. There is a vibrancy to this location that makes it a real attraction. The museum here is a must see, and there are few hawkers or guides here to hassle you, although they will ask, they are happy when you politely decline there services. It is easy to wander around. We were there on a Friday and there were several school groups were about. A little walk from the main square is the Kumbheshwor temple. Here we came across a school group playing games with their teachers. They were all having fun that it is became a real highlight of the day.

column7: Up there with some of the best sites in the world
column8: This was really quite an experience. There's a real awe that hits you as you walk in and you're instantly transported to a time when this would have been the central point for this ancient kingdom. It's a feast for your eyes and camera! Would be silly to visit Kathmandu and not at least see this. On par, if not better, than the central durbar in Kathmandu

Try to visit this place when you have some spare time. The temple at the square is very old and the carvings are erotic. Have a good look. Vendors and shopkeepers do not overcharge if you can bargain. I find it bad that western tourists have to pay to visit this place when anybody else can walk in and out. School kids are everywhere, one cannot take a decent picture of a monument or statue without some kids sitting on it. This was the same in Bahktapur where I had regretted that I had paid 10 euro when I saw that so many walked in without paying. A visit to the museum still has to be paid extra anyway. In Patan, they try to avoid that people walk in without paying (only if you look western, speaking of discrimination) by obliging you to hang the large ticket around your neck. Just awful. It spoiled my appreciation of this wonderful old place, having this thing around my neck. I felt like an animal for sale. Why not make the entrance free for all without discrimination and charge for separate visits of the temple, the museum, etc... Tourists are more than just milk cows that are only good for their money.

Very well preserved area. It keeps the original texture. Gorgeous monuments. And people are Really fighting hard to restore and maintain these buildings. So do buy tickets to support funds of Conservation. 200 rupees is nothing, just around 2$.... To see a World heritage.

column7: Patan’s Durbar Square has its fill of lovely old temples and palaces and sculptures.
column8: Patan’s Durbar Square is less crowded and chaotic than the one in Katmandu but it has its fill of lovely old temples and palaces and sculptures. At the entry you pay (I think it was 1000 rupees) and then you can either choose a guide or navigate away from the steady stream of young men offering to inform you of the history and culture of the various buildings you’ll see. Since I was there mainly to take photos, and a constant commentary is a distraction, I said no. Once you’re past fifty yards or so of the entrance, you’ll be approached only occasionally. There is a rest room near the entrance (ask at the ticket counter) and it’s the only one I noticed.  Like the durbar squares in Katmandu and Bhaktipur (durbar means “court”), royalty of these ancient kingdoms built palaces to live in and then temples in honor of their gods. Most of the buildings are from the 17th century. The temples are built of red brick and wood and are notable for the use of carved wooden struts to support the roof. Several have stone or metal elephant statues on either side of the staircase in front.  It’s advantageous to follow the map and wander away from the main area to find the temples that are not in the “square” itself. Not all temples stand out. I was walking up an under-construction street far away from the center and asked a man where the Golden Temple was. He pointed up to the next street. I kept on walking and then stopped when he came running up to me and pointed back half way from where I first encountered him. I had to walk almost to the entry to see the way in.  If you’re staying in Thamel you can get to Patan by taxi for about 250-300 rupees. It’s worth half a day or even more. You can climb up the steps of a temple and sit and people-watch or read or just enjoy your leisure time.

column7: Maybe the Best of the 3 UNESCO Durbar Squares...
column8: Patan Durbar Square has all the best of the architecture and history without the crush of traffic and crowds who gravitate to the other two. Also Patan is free - i.e. no entry fees unlike the biggest one - Basantapur.  Also, you have guest houses like Hira Guest House that are located in and around the square.  Make sure you visit the Golden Temple as well - 12 Century Buddhist Temple.

column7: beautifully maintained, extraordinary glimpse into ancient Nepal
column8: Durbar Square in Patan features many examples of temples built to honor the primary deities -each with distinct character. It is well maintained, clean, and considerably less chaotic than Durbur Square in Katmandu. The former royal residence has been turned into a wonderful museum, with comfortable café in the rear gardens. One gets a sense of the depth and splendor of the Nepalese culture in Patan. The photographic opportunities are endless, well worth a visit.

column7: Nepal City of Traditional Art and Architecture
column8: The Patan Durbar Square is way better than the Kathmandu Durbar Square for us. Maybe it is something to do with the architecture or the atmosphere, we enjoyed the Patan Durbar Square more than the Kathmandu Durbar Square.  It is much smaller but we get in touch more with the temples and museums abound.  - The palace square and residence of the Malla rulers of Patan state which now houses a museum, Patan Dhoka: One of the historical entrances to the old city - Krishna Temple , Hiranyabarna Mahavihara: A Buddhist temple known locally as Golden Temple - Mahabouddha Temple: Also known as temple of 1000 Buddha - Kumbheswor Temple: A Shiva temple with two ponds - Ratnakar Mahavihar: also known as Ha Baha, the complex of the official residence of the Living goddess of Patan and The Tibetan Refugee centre .

column7: One of the best place to explore Nepalese Architecture
column8: It is one of the best places to observe Nepalese ancient Architecture. It’s peaceful palace and surrounding areas is well cleaned. It has attracted people from all around the world because of its beauty and history.

Patan, known as the "city of Art", is mainly an old Buddhist area and the first impact on us was how much cleaner the area around the Durbar Square was compared to the more chaotic Kathmandu Durbar Square. It was very interesting just walking through the various laneways and courtyards (bahals) just seeing how the local people live. One site that was very impressive but just outside the main Square was Mahabuddha Temple where there are according to the locals more than 9,000 stone carvings of Lord Buddha. We had a nice lunch at the Vala Layekh Kitchen which was just opposite to the main entrance and overlooking the Square. Highly recommend a visit this Square ... more impressive than Kathmandu Durbar Square.

column7: Felt like walking into a history book!
column8: Beautiful historical square couple with fascinating architecture of the temples. Great place to spend the afternoon, immersing in the local history, culture & people-watch. If you only have 1 afternoon, I would recommend Patan Durbar Square instead of Kathmandu Durbar Square!

Durbar Square emerges out of nowhere in Patan. If you visit in the afternoon, it's usually quite deserted. In the evenings, it's a great place to people-watch, as people of all ages and incomes seem to show up to sit and watch other people. Read up about the architecture before you go, as I found no signs there explaining what the different buildings are. I didn't have time to visit the museum, but heard that it's great.

column7: A pleasant surprise in the middle of chaos
column8: Architecturally intriguing and strong - neat and clean - well maintained - culturally recognised - aged heritage.  Worth a visit and I hope I get to organise an event at this venue some day. :)

column7: Ancient city in the middle of the modern city
column8: This place has once been partially destroyed by an earthquake. However, it has now been brought back to its original position. There is an entrance fee and if you are from a SAARC country, the fee that is charged from you is very much lower than what is charged from Western tourists. There is a museum inside the square and many shopping complexes as well.  In Nepal there are so many religious festivals and one the day that my husband and I visited this place, there was a festival. They played religious music and the women were dressed in red. It will be great if you can visit on a day of a festival as the place is very colourful on such days.  The history of the place is displayed and you can take time to read it and I suggest that you do that because then you get the real feel of what the square was and what it means to the Nepali people. The Hindus believe in Gods and Goddesses in the modern context as well. A young girl who is referred to as 'kumari' that translates as 'princess' stays in the palace in Durbar Sqaure and it is believed that she is a reincarnation of 'Kali'. You will not get an opportunity to see this princess. However, there are so many little temples all over in the square and it is worth a visit.

Shopping for fabric, spices, statues, cooking ware, and jewelry can all be found in this area. There is more of a variety in Thamel shopping district, but this area is important to see because everybody has been here and the city is ancient with temples all over the place. You will just find yourself with your head down, walking quickly through the streets because the pace of the area is quick. Motorcycles are zipping in and out and cars are honking to get through and people are everywhere!

While walking down from the tourist bus park vehicles and traffic jam you need to face and after 10 mins walk I was surprise to see lots of monuments in a single place. It's was mind blowing to see the artist and architecture. It is said that patan durbar square is oldest durbar than Kathmandu and bhaktapur. While entering the premises of durbar you'll see three idiots Ganesha said to be Siddhi, Narshiama itself and Hanuman said to be Mall in combine its know as Siddhi Narshimha Malla who build the durbar. You can see the Taleju temple, shiva temple, bhimsen temple and other small small temples but eye catchy is Krishna temple said to be made of single stone where details of Mahabharata war story is sculptures very finely. But don't forget to visit the museum and if you were lucky during visit at june- July other rooms of courtyard will be open because lots of festivals falls at these mothe so you'll get chance to see the bhandarkhal garden, Mulchowk and stone bed of malls king siddhi naraingha. Century old ston tap is near by where still people queing to fetch for water during dry season. It was more interesting if you go and see by you own eyes. Must visit place of Nepal.

I loved the surrounding. I could see lots of effort for maintaining the part of history. However, harassment from street sellers was way too annoying. Something must be done otherwise the whole experience becomes bitter.

column7: Worth a look, but a Shane that I'm not sure what I was looking at!
column8: Worth a look - it cost RS500 just to walk in (locals don't have to pay) and you have to wear a yellow receipt round your neck which is a huge advertisement to all the "official guides" who are keen to show you around. The buildings are beautiful, but crumbling into disarray, and you tend to get approached by people wanting money from you! Nice trinkets to pick up on the stalls set up in the square and good photo opportunities with the old buildings, but considering you have to pay to get in, you receive no map or any information about the buildings so you come away unsure of what you have just seen. (Unless you are willing to pay someone to tell you).

I spent an afternoon in the square at Patan. It's a taxi ride from Thamel in Kathmandu but not too expensive. Lots of beautiful buildings - similar to the durbar square in Kathmandu. There are some vendors and a few restaurants where you can sit and watch the goings on in the square. If you enjoyed the durbar in Kathmandu, you should enjoy Patan. Just sitting and watching people or soaking up the culture and history was a great way to spend an afternoon.

The architecture is pretty cool, and there are a lot of shops to buy stuff at but it gets boring after being there for the whole day and you have to pay 500 rupees to actually get into the temple areas. It's a good day activity but once you've gone once then you have pretty much seen It all and it's not a quiet area at all, it's loud and crazy.
Durbar (central) Square is old palce of rular in nepal and it has the unique ancent architeque of wooden sculpture. Anybody having an interest of arts and history would has to visit

The temples and other buildings were breathtakingly beautiful when considering the minute attention to detail that has gone into constructing them.  You need at least a half day to walk though these ancient city centres.  Also enjoyed browsing among the trinkets and (supposedly old) artefacts.  Didn't like the pesky touts, though! - that's for sure. But I certainly didn't like the touts.
Love the architecture and history & Krishna Mandir. The tourist items were also of interest to me. To get more reviews, check Google.

What an amazing experience, breathtakingly beautiful temples, monuments, and museums in the square that is still the center of this active community. People worshiping, mechants selling goods, locals bathing and washing in the community fountains, friendly young people just hanging out, all surrounded by features dating back a millenium. In the side alleys that radiate out from the square there are tiny shops where craftsmen hammer metal or loom fabrics that are immediately for sale.  We enjoyed staying in Patan and we came back to the square after the tourists go back to Thamel and shared some Baktipour (sp?) yogurt from a local dairy on the steps of the temple just lit by accent lights. It was a magical memory.

We were staying at a hotel on the side of the square where there are lots of trinklets for sale and where the local took water (holy water??) from. For a start, we got up early and caught the stall owners setting up stall. We had a great time browsing and do friendly bargaining with the stall owners. After that, we strolled into the square. There were no barriers nor signage indicating that we are indeed entering the square.  A short way into the square and after 2 photos, it was just past 9am, we were stopped by a young lady who asked if we have had tickets. We didn't so we were told to purchase tickets. I went to get my Dad and daughter to go purchase the tickets but my Dad decided not to as he strolled the square yesterday evening and that there is nothing much there. Then, we were approached by the girl's superior (probably), a large young Nepalese. When we said that we have decided that we do not want to purchase the tickets, he got really aggressive, asked us why then are we in the square! (There were no indication of boundary in the first place!!!) Then he told us to leave the square immediately. The girl told him that we have taken photos and told us to delete them! Wow! What a lousy experience.  I mean, I was with my parents who are close to 70 years old and a 11 year old girl, is it necessary to be that rude? It just totally spoiled it for us.  If you have been to Kathmandu Durbar Square, I think you can skip this as this is probably only 30% the size of Kathmandu Square. The entry fee at Kathmandu Square is Nepali Rupee 750 and here it is 500.  Save your money for a nice cup of coffee or tea and avoid spoiling your holiday by a rude gorilla.  We were informed that the fees are only applicable between 10am to 5pm by the hotel operator later.

Patan is another city of Kathmandu valley which once was an independent Kingdom, lies only a few kilometers south of Kathmandu. The major attraction of this city is Patan Durbar Square; the palace of Malla dynasty ruled this city till 18th century. It is situated in the heart of the city, constitutes the focus of visitors' attraction. The square is full of ancient palaces, temples and shrines, noted for their exquisite carvings. The Patan Durbar Square consists of three main chowks: Central Mul Chowk, Sundari Chowk and Keshar Narayan Chowk. The Sundari Chowk holds in its center a masterpiece of stone architecture, the Royal Bath called Tushahity. It was listed in the UNESCO World Heritage Monument List in 1979. The museum inside the Durbar Square is considered as one of the best museums in Asia. It specializes in bronze statues and religious objects. It Opens daily from 9.00 am to 5.00 pm. It is closed only for 3 days during Dashain and for 3 days during Tihar.

column7: Lots of interesting temples to see
column8: More temples in one place than I have ever seen. The old palace is interesting and the little streets have wholesale traders in Bhudas, Tonkas as well as other interesting take-aways.

its a wonderful place, ancient architecture where windows and doors are vividly and beautifully crafted, beautiful but a little crowded at day, at evening time this place is magnificent it's less crowded then, whatever is time you can always sit on the passage of temples where many people usually sit and watch the world before your eyes, patan is a great place for shopping too and its cheaper compared to others.

Great ancient buildings, but overcrowded a bit with tourists. Also a fairly recent introduction of a 750 Rupee entrance fee only for tourists is rather a rip off... we went in another entrance where the gate was unmanned without paying. Its not worth visiting if you have to pay the entry fee.

The experience of visiting Patan's Durbar square is diluted only if you've been to Bhaktapur or Kathmandu's similar Durbar squares, otherwise, it socks you in the stomach for sheer presence and authenticity. Although the square is relatively small, the buildings are intact and so rich in detail as to keep you busy - especially if you're a photographer - for hours.  Roughly speaking, on one side are the royal palace buildings, and on the other side are the various temples, including one in South Indian or 'shikara' style, built of stone and dedicated to the god Krishna. The other wooden temples are in Nepalese architecture, some with erotic carvings on the roof struts. There are also a couple of metal statues on poles in the square, and plenty of details on the buildings to keep the visitor absorbed.  Various architectural styles are presented, with fascinating stories of various features. Pay for a local guide - it's well worth it, as much of the richness of the site is not apparent otherwise.  This is the authentic Nepal before development and traffic made the Kathmandu valley the sorry mess that it now is.

column7: Together with Kathmandu and Baktipur are the main historical sites in the valley!
column8: Patan Durbar Square is a must! I recomend to devote minimum one day to this historical place. Even if is a public square foreign visitors need to pay entrance, look for the ticket in the counter in one corner of the square. The price is 500 NRP per person. There are also tourist guides, that show you all the details of the temples and palaces in the square. The place is a unique misture of temples, places, the Patan Museum, Cafes, handcraft shops . Go there! Do not miss it!
Durbar square very historical palce with so many old arts.everyone should visit there.so many old temples made by hand &carving wood.

We only have 8 days in Nepal. And most of it was spent in Pokhara and trekking to Poon Hill and Annapurna Area. In between, we did shopping in Kathmandhu, Pokhara, Patan and in-between.  Patan Durbar Square is the best place to buy the cheapest and the most number of choices if you are looking for hard-to-find gifts when you return back home. We got traditional "lunggi" worn in Bangladesh, India and Nepal. We also brought some "dhakka topis", the traditional Nepali hats that are worn by older men. We regret buying a lot of gifts in Pokhara when we found out we can get the exact same type and quality for a much cheaper price here.  In terms of Architecture, you must visit the Patan Museum, although you have to shell our another 250 Nepali Rupees aside from the 200 NP that you paid to enter the square. The architecture and detail in the wood carving in the awnings, door, posts and ceiling is an amazing feat. You can learn a lot from the locals, guides and the information that they have in the museum.  This place is a must for every tourist visiting Nepal. You can get both the best bargains and the most preserved architectural monuments and buildings.

While spending 3 weeks in Nepal on a volunteering mission a number of us spent a day touring the country around Kathmandu. We started our tour in Patan. This durbar ("palace" in Nepali) square is like stepping back in history. Some restoration is ongoing but does not detract from the beautiful buildings. Bring your camera! As usual non-Nepalese visitors pay a fee to enter, but it is not expensive and well worth it. ENJOY!

column7: Definitely the nicest out of all 3 Durbar Squares!
column8: Patan's (Lilitpur's) Durbar Square in my opinion is the nicest out of all three similar squares in area (other two are in Kathmandu and Bhaktapur). Entry fee is only 200 NPR and ticket is valid for seven days. There is small additional fee for camera, but they will give you sticker which you need to attach to your clothes.  All area is really amazing; I would say the most real and authentic. There are not that many "local guides" bothering you like in other places. You have to take your time, enjoy every moment and every detail of this stunning architecture.  Patan Museum is worth seeing, so be ready for a half day trip to Patan. I would say Durbar Square is as well great place to buy local handicraft and souvenirs - prices are more reasonable and things look better.  On the square itself there are few different temples (usually no entry for non-Nepali people) and pagodas. That is exactly you could see Nepal on old pictures. I really like this place and definitely I will spend there more time.

column7: Smallest of the Three Durbar Square's
column8: There are in fact three Durbar Square's in Kathmandu and the surrounding areas. In Bhaktapur and the smallest is in Patan. If your driving from the centre of Kathmandu it's about 30-45 minutes by taxi depending on the traffic. The square itself is similar to the one in Kathmandu although this one has a fresh water spring where the locals go to drink and wash. The area surrounding the square is equally appealing as the square itself, with many places selling very intricate bronze work, some of which is great value for money and some are antique replica's selling for a small fortune. Well worth a trip if however you want to visit only one Durbar Square visit the one in Bhaktapur which in our opinion is the best

Darbar Square personifies Kathmandu. It has the hustle and bustle of the city, and the ambling crowds in this area dampen an otherwise unique experience. The good part about the square is the ample historical information on display. Visit the Patan Darbar which is smaller but has better character and a colloquial feel.

column7: The Beautiful Durbar (Palace) Square of Patan
column8: Take your time. This place is full of wonders -- masterpieces in wood and stone. The Patan Museum is situated in part of the old palace and is also well worth a look. The Queen's Water Tank, in the palace complex is being restored and may be opened to the public soon -- don't miss the chance to see that as it is really superb. The cafe there is also good (run by the Summit Hotel). Cafe de Patan has a great view of the temple-filled square. There is an entry fee to the square of 250 rupees (likely to go up). Whilst you're here, leave the square and visit The Golden Temple in the street parallel to the square (5 minutes walk).

I recently stayed for a total of five nights with Lalit, on two occasions as I passed through Patan. The hotel is perfectly located to explore both Paten Durbar Square and the nearby historic lanes. The family that operate Lalit are attentive, interesting and engaging. It was a pleasure to spend a few days with them. I will definitely be staying with them again on my next visit to Nepal.

I enjoyed my night's stay here, it's a charming old guest house. Great location. No heating but an electric blanket kept me warm at night. Manju took good care of me and made the best French toast for breakfast, it was delicious!

The hospitality,charm,warmth and atmosphere of this guest house makes for a memorable stay. The owners and staff could not be more helpful. The location is perfect. The bed comfortable. A privilege to stay in such an historic building in Patan. Be aware that you are entering a property of great antiquity and as such it has idiosyncrasies. The beautiful staircases are steep and narrow. The restored rooms lack modern insulation. The plumbing is not as a five star hotel. However worth everything and good value for money.

column7: Historic team in the heart of Patan
column8: This delightful guest house is situated just off the street and with a courtyard in front. It is only 5 minutes walk from Durbar Square and all the other attractions. The guest house is a 300 year old traditional building with exposed wooden beams and many other period features. The bedrooms are comfortable and spacious, and there is a reception and dining room on the first floor. The place is run by two sisters and you couldn't wish for a warmer welcome. Highly recommended for any stay in Patan.

We had this recommendation via a friend of us. Lumbini Heritage is really amazing! The staff is so kind, the breakfast is good and the rooms are amazing:) they even have an electronic blanket if you’re cold. Also the place is amazing. It is very quiet, but it’s still in the centre of Patan. I would definitely recommend the place:)

Beautiful traditional home, with fantastic location for the sights of Patan and a lovely rooftop terrace for the delicious breakfast each morning. Madan, Bisal and Pusa were all incredibly helpful, friendly and welcoming - making me momos when I arrived late at night from the airport (they lost my bag) helping me call the airline (they found my bag!) and giving me lots of great tips on what to see and do. Can't wait to come and visit again soon!

column7: A perfect little guest house in the the old city of Patan
column8: This little gem of a place offers simple accommodation, a lovely roof top terrace with great breakfasts and fresh coffee, large rooms and a great location for visiting the surrounding area of old Patan, with its temples and traditional carved Newari buildings. Above all, the staff here are wonderful and couldn't do enough for us. We felt very looked after for the whole of our 2 day stay, and the manager went above and beyond to trace my friend's missing suitcase, which had been lost in transit by the airline. Highly recommended and great value for money :)

Been here a couple of times now, once for breakfast, once for a drink and snack.  Both times no complaints, friendly attentive staff, well presented and fresh food.  Big plus is they have real (for Nepal) sausages rather than the hotdog types everywhere else seem to serve

column7: Not the best in the area
column8: Went there as I was craving for some burgers after eating only rice and noodles for the past weeks and I regret it! Had a veggie burger with a juice and was sick afterwards! Not at all what I expected as this place was recommended to me :) On top they did not have mosquito incense and I got bitten while eating ... and flies everywhere! Not going back

Café Soma first and foremost has great people especially in the Jhamsikhel outlet. You always get a big smile and they actually recognize you and know what you like which is great in Nepal. As for the food, I have to be honest I have only eaten two things on the menu, the French Toast and the Eggs Benedict, and I keep on going back for these two things alone. Both are very good and the hollandaise sauce is creamy and tangy just perfect.

I spent hours in Cafe Soma whilst living in Patan. The staff were always friendly and the food was great. Sometimes you just want a burger and Cafe Soma offers buffalo 'buff' burgers and real chips. The breakfast was especially good and it had free wifi!

Locals and local expats know Cafe Soma and the place is BUSY at weekends. But for good reason - great breakfast plates - traditional English, vegetarian options, eggs benedict or for the lighter-appetites, muesli/granola, fruits yogurts. Good cappuccino and excellent service. Toilet is not great - and the seats are not super comfortable but its still one of my favorite places to eat on this side of town and prices are very reasonable.
Very tasty food especially the rice salad with the salmon. Great carrot cake too. The waiters are nice. It went at least once a week for the past 10 months.

column7: Just returned from visiting the cafe
column8: Wasn't sure what to expect as it doesn't look like too much from the outside, but once you get the food all doubts are erased. I had a bacon burger and the beef is real. It was busting with flavor. The homemade lemonade was good but not exceptional. The warm brownie with icecream was also tasty but again not exceptional. It seems the quality lies in the hot food and sometime I want to go again and see what else they have that really is good. It is definitely worth the time and the service was excellent and food was quickly served. I waited no more than three minutes on any one item.
Have been a couple of times for breakfast and can recommend the French toast with fresh fruit. A real treat. A good place to hang out.

Our daughter, who lives in Kathmandu, let us know that in most places in Nepal a milkshake is just that...shaken milk with a syrup if some kind in it. NOT SO CAFE' SOMA! Their milkshakes are so thick they come to your table with peaks on them! Absolutely delicious. And a nice place to hang out and visit! Great fries too!!

Alright, alright I was lured here by the promise of a great cheeseburger, but that’s not what brought me back. As a matter of fact the burger wasn’t even in my top 10 meals over my 2 week stay in Patan – it had this flavor of like a packet of onion seasoning. I didn’t love it – decent bun though. What I’d come to this place for is the desserts, muffins, and drinks. The banana chocolate chunk muffins are pretty damn fantastic. The brownies had a gooey crystallized sugar that for once among the brownies I tasted in Nepal – tasted like a brownie, not some mild chocolate dry cake. But the almond cookies are really what blew me away. I’m Sicilian and my grandmother and mother make cookies like these at the holidays. You only need one; it will fulfill the craving. And upon reading another review I opted to try the thick milkshake though it was cold outside – it was thick and yummy. Now to just expand the milkshake options: cookies and cream, chocolate peanut butter, frozen monkey (coffee, chocolate and banana). And to really make this place stand out…board games…they should have board games and a few heaters! No one would ever leave!!! I’d have book club meetings, knitting club, byob girls night, etc here because they have the right formula.

column7: The only REAL thick, western style milkshakes in town!
column8: Well, the only ones I've found. I came here specifically in search of a real thick milkshake, tipped off by an expat who claimed they know how to make them properly here.  I'm ecstatic to report I was not disappointed. Thank you, Soma, for finally satisfying my half-year craving for a real milkshake. And an espresso flavored one at that! I feel like Cafe Soma should do outreach to other restaurants in Asia to teach them how to make a real milkshake instead of serving flavored lassi's.  I wasn't that impressed with my chicken burger, and the chips are potato-chip style rather than fresh hot french fries. I think this place would be great as a milkshake/coffee/dessert hangout.
visit it few times a week with friends to hang out , absolute favrouite thick shake and double soma burger with bacon
great breakfast place! good selection/options. real coffee (not just instant)! there's books as well

Cafe Soma is def one of the best in the hood! What i like is that they keep experimenting and introducing new items while sticking to some of the old so there a great mixture of surprise yet comfort every time i go there. This place is great with family, friends or solo and both for business meetings or just a casual meet up.  i particularly have a soft spot for Soma since this summer as i went into labour after having one of their awesome sundaes (now unfortunately discontinued) and gave birth naturally to my daughter 4 hours later :)

Not really much in this mall, but nice and clean, and a respite from the hustle and bustle of Kathmandu. Good eating places, cinema and some great clothes/shoe shops selling the real thing (unlike the knock-offs everywhere else in the city).

Labim mall has contributed its establishment to the clean and calm environment in the Mall history ever in Valley. From the entrance to indoor (shops, movie theatres, food stalls) everythings has got its best value out of it. Loved to be in this place.

column7: One of the best Vietnamese restaurants I have been to
column8: Especially nice for outside seating on the cozy terasse. You will meet a mix of international and local people. Friendly, however not always too attentive staff. Large variety of original Vietnamese dishes. Wine list ok, but not great, reasinably priced. All dishes were cooked fresh and all were very, very tasty! We would recommend the Papaya salad, the tofu pho, the chicken and the duck stew (duck was very soft and tender!), all the curries, the pork ribs, the summer rolls were nice, but nit exceptional,

I had heard great reviews of this restaurant. In fact i had been to the old one in Lazimpat and had liked it. I was told its the branch of the same restaurant so i ordered food.  We didn't like it at all. The noodles dish was bland with no flavor or taste. There was very few ingredients on the food and just looked white washed pile of noodles.  The barbecued pork was very dry and tough that i felt like trying to chew and tear leather. Don't know i'll order from there or go there ever.
Nice setting . Staff ok . Had to ask for sugar after coffee arrived . Frozen french fries . Overpriced. WiFi not working .Won’t return.

Delicious breakfast platter, fruit was fresh and pancakes even came with real syrup. Very nice, quiet outdoor seating with friendly staff. Coffee not the best and have to pay extra for milk, otherwise very good!

I went to Yala Mandala with 2 friends for dinner on a personal reccomendation. It has an elegant, laid-back chic vibe with a beautiful garden. We opted to sit inside in a spacious room with local photography and handcrafted furniture. There are a number of...More

column7: In serious decline from past years. Overstaffed with poor service.
column8: The "Rajbhandari House" was one of two UNESCO financed efforts in 2006 to preserve traditional Newari architecture converted to tourism (the other is the Shrestha "Newa Chen" at Kobahal, the project faltered after two houses were restored). Apparently the original owners of this one have now rented it out, and the service has declined precipitously. Note that the correct address is Kwalakhu, not "Darbar Square" as mistakingly tripadvisor lists. Visit to see the building, avoid the food and the miserable service.

column7: A fabulous way to decompress after visiting Patan Durbar Sq.
column8: First, I know this as Yala Mandala restaurant - and that is what the business card says but it is reviewed here as Yala Cafe. As I live in Kathmandu as an expat, I can say the food and service are consistently very good and it is good value for money. The dish I order most often is the Thali - they call it something different on the menu but ask the waiter or look for the description of various small dishes (cured vegetables, pickle, paneer cheese and rice) served on a platter - vegetarian or meat options available. It is delicious and presentation is super. If you are interested in trying something totally unique drink wise, ask them to demonstrate the pouring of the local Aeyla. The better quality ones Yala serves are actually very smooth to drink - the cheap stuff in other local bars tastes as if it could clean limescale off water pipes. The biggest problem is to find the place. There are no street names and local people don't know it or send you to a different place so here is my recommendation for a wonderful afternoon in Patan which culminates at Yala for dinner! First, visit Patan Durbar Square, a world heritage site of ancient temples and King's palaces. Do stroll around the nearby market - spices, metal items and flowers for temple offerings. After that, use GPS or your tour guide/ local person to get you to the Golden Temple. This is a fantastic temple to visit - one I take all visitors to - it doesn't disappoint. A guide is useful as there is so much crammed into the small courtyard and you could miss and/or misunderstand much of the symbolism. Afterwards, as you exit Golden Temple turn right, stay on this street - and it's a 2 minute walk to Yala. It will be on your left side and there is a freestanding temple structure almost outside it. The sign is easy to miss -- keep a keen eye for the word Yala! Spend your evening enjoying the great food, outdoor candelit dining available, and friendly service. The staff will point you in the direction of the best place to get a taxi. It's easy to get a taxi "from" here but not "to" here.

column7: Fresh tasty food in a beautifully restored Nepali building and garden
column8: My favourite place to eat and just generally one of my favourite places to be in Patan. Taking its name from the Newari name for Patan, Yala is somewhat hidden away in the corner near the crossroads and narrow lanes in between the Golden Temple and Durbar Square, close to the old town. The manager confirmed to me, as is visible from the outside, that the building has been extensively restored after substantial damage in the earthquake and includes a ground and first-floor shop, selling a range of traditional products and clothing, and a second-floor art gallery which sometimes hosts cultural events with guest speakers. The menu is well-focused on a short range of international dishes all made with fresh ingredients and a wide variety of drinks are available. Yala is a pleasant place to eat and have drinks particularly in the well-maintained garden with candle-lit tables at night with good service and English speaking staff. A must visit on your stay in Patan. I had the spaghetti pomodoro.
Excellent food in a hidden place that is immaculately clean. It has a wide selection of pure Nepalese food and drinks.
This lovely, restful little restaurant has a unique menu with delicious authentic Nepali food. The staff are also extremely friendly.

Truly a hidden gem. This is a unique restaurant that has a seasonally changing menu with ingredients sourced from all over Nepal. Each dish originates from a specific region and ethnic group. A highlight of my time here.

Raithaane is tucked away through a tiny passageway off a side street and opens onto an inner courtyard away from the dust and noise. Persist until you find it. It is worth it. The French owner's menu is inspired by Nepali traditional recipes, sourced with...More
small and charming place with just a few tables and an open kitchen..very interesting menu of drinks and food..starters and main courses from different regions of nepal..well worth a visit

column7: Ethnic Nepali cuisine done with style
column8: Raithaane has one of the more interesting menus you're likely to see in Kathmandu. Region/community specific dishes made with seasonal ingredients, alongside french crepes and good quality Nepalese coffee (house roasted) are all presented beautifully on unique ceramic plates and bowls. The courtyard is quiet, but not far from Patan Durbar Square, and the tables upstairs are a nice place to work your way through the very reasonably priced menu. Raithaane won't stay hidden for long.

column7: Lovely Nepali food at hidden Patan gem
column8: Well hidden in a quiet courtyard beyond a side street, this gem of a café offers traditional Nepali food (Taruwa, Rildok, Rikikur among others) for low prices. The lemon pie desert is highly recommended.

column7: Delicious! Hidden foodie treasure - fresh and original
column8: This new place, run by young people, is a true hidden gem. You really have to watch your map and look for the small entrance, leading to a little courtyard - thats where you can eat next to a tiny garden. The food is fresh, original and mixes craftsmanship, tradition and passion. They use local and special ingredients, like yak butter. If they cannot get the ingredient in the quality they want to have, they rather not offer the dish instead of substituting for a compromise. The prices are very affordable. The staff is very friendly and knowledgeable about their food and food sources. A place we certainly will want to come back to again - and again. My favorite: buckwheat & millet pancake with chaku-sesame . They even have sherpa-tea with yak butter.

column7: There is much more to Nepali cuisine than daal bhat and momos- come here to experience it!
column8: Fresh, clean, delicious and VERY reasonably priced food located in a newly renovated but cozy ancient setting of old Patan. I have tried more than half of the menu, and found everything tasty and nourishing. The partners running the place are chatty and welcoming, which...More
Ive never tasted most things that Raithaane offers, in any other place.. Love the food and the location. This place is a must-visit in Patan !
Worth the walk out to here (Its a few minutes past Patan Gate) The garden is lovely and the service excellent. I had a Tofu burger which was great. All veg grown locally and organic, I think.

column7: Peace in a bustling historic town
column8: If you want to have a hearty breakfast, nice coffee, excellent lunch or early dinner in the garden, then go to Cafe Cheeno. A peaceful garden cafe a stone throw away from Patan Dhoka, the historic gateway to Patan city.

This place is usually pretty quiet, but the quality of the food is some of the best in the city. Don't miss the steaks which are easily the best in Patan (and real beef!). The chef and owner put a lot of thought into their recipes and it really shows.

column7: Don't miss the yummy pork chop!
column8: It's a nice and quiet place to hang out with friends and relax after a stressful day. Food is good - but their pork chop is a not-to-be missed. The staff are also friendly and accommodating! If you want to help, their shop sells traditional handwoven crafts done by community women.

3 of us were directed to Cheeno for lunch after we had completed a walk around Patan outside the Durbar Square. Its larger than you would think from the outside, with pleasant simple decor, quirky objects d'artes, racks of books, comfy lounges and pleasant staff. As it was lunch we had a toasted club sandwich (chicken, bacon, egg,onion and tomato served with chips (shared), spaghetti with meatballs, a chocolate mousse, 2 mint teas and a mint lemonade. Reasonably priced for a tourist area. It was Rps 1500 for 3 or US$15. As we were leaving we noticed the outdoor area. This is beautiful with widely spaced seating arrangements, statues, a beautiful flower garden companion planted with salad greens and herbs. So peaceful and cool. And also in the grounds a woman weaving traditional fabric at her loom, small shop attached. There were activities of the spa sort advertised but not sure if they were held there or elsewhere. I'd go again.

column7: A jewel : both the people and the food
column8: We have had a few lunches and we organized a group dinner in Cafe Cheeno, and were each time delighted with the great friendliness of the people and the quality of the food. You can eat typical Nepali food but we also had amazingly good clubsandwiches or a real italian cappuccino. Sashank, the owner, is an experienced host and was able to get a good team to make this place a jewel. Sitting in the garden the busstle outside behind the walls fades away because of the relaxing atmosphere of Café Cheeno

georgous hidden oasis with lovely garden or indoor seating with beautiful symbolic art on the ceilings. The facade looks like a bag/craft shop but once inside you discover a lovely cafe alongside fairtrade crafts for sale. Just outside Patan gate and worth seeking out, couple of doors down from Daikaima cafe which is also lovely spot.

column7: Peaceful and clean place with beautiful garden
column8: Located close to Patan Dhoka, Cafe Cheeno is one of the few good restaurant options when staying in the old town of Patan. They have a large garden and a few tables inside, in a warm and pleasant athmosphere. The inside of the restaurant is shop at the same time, where books aswell as good quality handicrafts are sold - most of them related to a women's project. The food is good - European style. In the evenings, there is usually only very few people around which makes it an peaceful option. During the day tourist groups come which makes the place less interesting.

We went to this restaurant several times during my travel in Nepal and just love it! Delicious and very original food (Asian/middle eastern fusion), beautifully decorated and a lush garden. Last but not least, the staff is very kind and dedicated. Strongly recommend this place...More

The decor and outside seating is very pleasant. The food could be better. A bit too much salt in the soup, potatoes were green and greasy and a wrap with delicious ingredients but the wrapper was not fresh. A bit more attention to quality and...More

column7: Delicious place that includes vegan options
column8: My only regret was to have found this place on my last days in Kathmandu. A great atmosphere, music, with many cozy spots within. The menu is terrific and includes many vegan and vegetarian options. Their traditional masala tea was delicious! I enjoyed a generous...More

column7: Relaxing place not to be missed!
column8: Very warm and pleasant atmosphere. The menu really portrays the cultural journey that the owners (Anne and Jerome) have been on and the marriage of that experience and Nepal gave birth to Of Silk and Salt - a real gem hidden in the heart of Patan. If you want to sample a taste of their world, and at the same time enjoying the excellent service of the staff this place is a must go. Highly recommended for the curious traveller!

I went back again to this restaurant during my second trip to Nepal. Love the food and atmosphere, I was happily surprised that new recipes have been added to the menu since my last visit. The menu still propose a good range of original recipes from many Asian and middle eastern countries. Haven’t tried all but strongly recommend the betel leaves skewers and the tea leaves salad. I will definitely come back!
Delicious and original fusion food. Very large selection of cocktails and international wines. Nice experience!

column7: ❤️ Best restaurant I visited in Kathmandu
column8: Just perfect 👌🏼 Great food ❤️ the place is so clean you could eat of the floor! The staff is just lovely, they are so friendly!! The restaurant also has a shop where you can find the most unique treasures. The owners are very interesting...More

column7: Nice food near Durbar Square of old Patan
column8: The restaurant (which also is a hotel (Timila)) seems new. They have some tables outside (back yard), which is a nice way to have a meal away from the noise of Kathmandu/Patan. Food was decent. I had "Thai chicken skewer", which was minced chicken wrapped in betel leaves. Very tasty. Same for the desert (some brownie cake). The food seems to be a bit of a "fusion". Certainly a place to check out. It may be a bit hard to find, but it is actually only a few minutes walking from Patan Durbar Square (hard for cars to get there).

column7: Nice fresh food in a clean, stylish setting with a great shop next door
column8: I had heard a lot about this place (mixed reviews) so finally tried for lunch recently. The beetroot falafel was quite tasty, as were the chicken skewers. The service was quick and the place is very thoughtfully decorated. The shop next door sells very unique clothing made from fabrics from along the silk road. Not the cheapest, but if you are not on a tight budget, definitely stop by for a meal and a browse.

column7: A good find: Stylish cozy place with interesting food
column8: I went for dinner and was impressed. Tried 3 vegetarian dishes and all were tasty; I'm looking forward to trying some of the other items on my next visit. The food was creative, unique and delicious. Drinks (cocktails) were also good. I love the "silk road reimagined" concept.

column7: Styilsh hotel and excellent food in its restaurant
column8: this Asian fusion restaurant, European run, is a real hidden gem in Patan. The menu is not very large but it offers a good array of different Asian inspires cuisines. If the weather is good, I recommend looking for a table in the patio.
this cafe as unique atmosphere and decoration. Its menu is a mix of asian and European recipe! delicious!

Delicious café/restaurant near Durbar Square in Patan. Owners are from France and Switzerland but have lived all over the world and created a very unique café. I had breakfast everyday and dinner a couple times. I loved the vegetarian mezze. I highly recommended!
Nice place in a small quiet street next to Patan Durbar Square. The fusion food is inspired from countries of the ancient silk road. Very original and tasty! Nice garden!

column7: in the lap of cultural Heritage
column8: Patan is culturally historically rich and people can enjoy very ancient and antique manufactures . so patan is as it is capital of heritage and the hotel good will also trying to reflect the cultural and antique patan.

column7: A Taste of Luxury Before and After your Trek / Expedition
column8: The Summit Hotel provides a luxurious experience whilst you are visiting Kathmandu / Nepal. You are greeted by attentive concierge staff and so the experience continues throughout your stay. The rooms have an old world charm whilst having modern amenities eg WiFi. The breakfast is buffet style with plenty of choice. There is an evening menu and on occasion, a tasty BBQ. There are a number of bars and restaurants in close proximity if you fancy a change. Taxis are easily and relatively cheaply procured to the airport / cultural attractions. NB The traffic in Kathmandu can be very heavy at times. Luggage and valuables can be stored by the hotel whilst out on trek.

Imagine a hideaway inside one of the densest cities in the world. Perfectly laid out grounds, decent room, good bathroom, excellent restaurant with tables inside or out. Cabs are available right outside the gate at reasonable rates. Original building was the Ford Foundation guesthouse back in the 1950s.

column7: Good location, friendly staff but modest facilities
column8: I stayed in this hotel for my business trip. While this hotel is centrally located in Lalitpur and close to Patan Durbar Square, compared to new hotels, the hotel has basic beds - twin beds not very comfortable. Even the television set is old and it seems that the hotel room needs upgrade. Staff members,however, are growing and helpful. The hotel has an outdoor swimming pool and a garden. The hotel offers buffet breakfast and it's ok. There are several restaurants near the hotel if you like to enjoy music and foods and go for an evening walk to Patan Durbar Square.

Wonderfully homey, comfortable and cozy hotel. The owner and his family are so friendly, welcoming, and helpful. The rooms are spacious, the bathroom is great, the bed is very comfortable and the view and location is spectacular.
