Poor management  I went for lunch with my 11 months old baby as I was very hungry. I was given high chair for ma baby but the high chair that they gave me was very dangerous and slippery that my baby got an accident, felt down very badly. None of the staff including managers was bother to come and see what happened and none of the managers came and apologised. In fact I only have to call 2-4 times then one of the staff came with ice and apologised after I shouted. They could see the baby crying so badly management were not even bother to ask if everything ok with baby. After an small arguments with one of the staff, he told me they just washed the high chair so baby felt down. How can people be so negligible. Anything could happen to my baby because of their behaviour. Really so pissed of.

You will be disappointed if you are a true Thai cuisine fanatic. The food isn't bad in terms of flavor but again, since they advertise themselves saying they're Thai Restaurant, I'm unsure about recommending this. I love their combo meals and their "basil chicken" dish.

Very serene place with ever smiling staff. The jerky beef was one of its kind. Taste was simply mouth watering. Appropriate price to most of the food and real touch of care by staff makes it a great place to come by. If you are in labim mall or around the pulchowk by any chance, go visit the place.
Highly recommended!! Thoroughly enjoyed the sessions. Therapists are friendly and well trained. Very unique place and we'll kept.
There is nothing now. It is a destroyed ancient temple. It is now under renovation. Hope to see a recovered one.

column7: Local place with people specialized in stone carving and
column8: This place is mostly famous for stone carving. People here have been in stone carving business from a long time ago. There is one old temple which is said to be 1700 years old. Bhinchhebahal was also known as Jay Miskrit Sanskarit Mayurbarna Mahavihar and later it was changed to Mayurbarna Mahavihar.
This is one of the Durbar Square temples that was somewhat damaged, though not terribly compared to others. Like all the old temples here, it's a beautiful temple.

column7: A fascinating courtyard in Patan Durbar Square
column8: During my exploration of Patan Durbar Square, I had the opportunity to visit Taleju Mandir Temple. This was a real highlight during my time in Patan. Upon walking through the gate leading to the courtyard, I was taken back into time with the sight of the gilded shrine in the middle of the courtyard. The shrine was well maintained with great detail. Even more ornate were the doorway and arches at the Temple. As I looked closer at the center arch/doorway, I saw something hanging from the arch and spatters of something against the nearby wall. I was informed that entrails from a water buffalo were hanging from the arch as part of a sacrifice. The spatters were blood from the same water buffalo.  A part of the Taleju Mandir Temple complex was the Sundari Cok. This was a smaller courtyard, the centerpiece of which was a inground pool type area that was circled by ornate carvings with a very detailed gilded statue in the front center of the “pool.’ It was inspiring to see how well much of this temple, including Sundari Cok withstood the impact of the 2015 earthquake.
Heavily damaged by earthquake a few minutes walk from durbar square. IT is surrounded by old city with not too many tourists.

Machhendranath Temple was largely destroyed by the Earthquake that hit Nepal just over a year ago. We came here to visit and see just what was left, and also to make a side trip to the nearby Karyabnayak Temple as-well. The feeling of being the only two visitors to the large open square, Villagers herding their ducks and goats through the old temple grounds actually added to the experience. I have always been a big archeology fan, so ruins excite me. These are relatively new, caused by a natural disaster, not time, although the original temples were in the 6-700 year old range. Visiting here is more of an exploration into the past. If a bunch of broken stones doesn't excite you much, I would skip this site. There's a lot of history , hundreds of small temples in the Kathmandu valley to explore. Most of the old shops and restaurants are gone, there is still one wood carver left here, turning out some beautiful HIndu and Bhuddist Statuary out of ancient pieces of wood that he imports from the Langtang region of Nepal. Worth the trip just to visit his shop.

The building of the chariot to carry the small red god in is an attraction on it own - taking about 1 month to complete. Rato Machindranath's temple is usually in Bungamati but it was destroyed in the earthquake. Now Rato resides in Patan. The rath, or chariot is pulled to various spots in patan according to tradition and only moves when the priests say it is time. People come every day to worship the god and give presents to him - often for fertility. This is an 800+ year old tradition that makes Nepal such a special place. There is no charge to see the chariot and experience a traditional event.
Rudra Barna Mahavihar is very artistic and unique Vihar in Lalitpur. You will mesmerize by the statue and art made in here. The vihar is very different that other hundreds of vihar in Patan.

column7: Undeerated gem of history and art
column8: Colloquially known as Uku Baha, this monastery is an incredible site to reflect on history of Buddhism, Newar society, and brass craftwork in Patan. The oldest Newari document of Kathmandu valley was found in the treasury of this monastery; the palm-leaf document dates back to early 12th century. The full-body statue of Shiva Dev, a Licchchavi king of ancient Nepal, now appears as a Rana military general providing a keen insight into how ruling classes appropriate norms and public works to serve their interest. This monastery is also a living heritage of rituals which take place in several occasions throughout the year. The monastery complex has stunning brass artwork throughout its premises. Highly recommended. Non-Nepali visitors pay NPR 30-50 for access to this monastery.
The complex contains an amazing collection of 5 images and stautes in metal, stone and wood. Many kings in ancient times were cornwed in this monastery

this temple has been,during centuries,modified with addiction in different periods,but when you enter in the inner courtyard you still can enjoy the original old struts at your right and left sides,female figurines with less decoration and an incredible modern look. the courtyard of the temple is a show of different skills,a minestrone of styles ,stones and metal work crowded with dragons ,elephants,lizards nagas and complicated mythologycal creatures,mixed with deities and flowered branches. the total result is incredibily pleasant. a statue of a dignified noble man wearing the Rana's uniform and crown is the silent withness of all this chaos. the altar in the chapel is a masterpiece of newari art.

column7: So great Temple !! You must visit
column8: This is one where the King supported to build and practiced Buddhism here. Therefore so many beautiful things you must see. After all, a temple supported by King is very unique.

The 4 Ashoka Stupas are a remarkable feature of Buddhist architecture in Patan. Lagan Thura Stupa to the south is the largest. Recently a miniature cenotaph was added. Teta Thura Stupa to the east has fire Vedica with one Tathagata in each direction. The dome is paved with firebrick. There are three stone inscriptions which are severely damaged. Pucho Thura Stupa to the west has firebrick Vedika with one Tathagata in each direction. The dome is also paved with firebrick. The thirteen Cakravalis [rings] are constructed directly over the dome in a square shaped pyramid. An inscription reveals that the Tathagatas were in place in the 14th cent. Ibahi Thura Stupa to the north is nearly circular. It has 5 Buddha in the Vedika with their consorts except the Tathagata Vairocana. A square Harmika is constructed over the dome with 13 steps Cakravali and a parasol.

These stupas are often tucked into the urban chaos and in various stages of disarray but for a traveler who wants to get a sense of the Buddhist history of the Kathmandu Valley, they deserve more attention than they usually get.
Built on 4 corners of Patan. These stupa are the evidence to the city's ancient religious importance

Yala Mandala is not just a café, but home to a restaurant, Gallery and shop located in a 350 year old building in the historic Patan area, which has been meticously renovated with the greatest respect for the original construction materials and craftsman traditions, whilst maintaining a cool and laidback international appeal.  The food (breakfast and dinner) is excellent, the service outstanding and the garden a quiet and beautiful oasis and welcome escape from the polluted hustle and bustle of the streets of Kathmandu.  🙏🏽

column7: A secret garden you don’t want to miss
column8: We came here with a large group of friends and brought our young toddler along. Dining at Yala is fun, relaxing, and the food doesn’t disappoint!  First off, the courtyard “garden” is the perfect setting to escape the busy and noisy streets. The thick and lush greeneries will make you forget that a cloud of dust is only a few meters away. It’s serene and peaceful.  We ordered the Newari lunch with the chicken curry. The dish came with rice, lentil soup, and a variety of veggies and pickles. Presentation is too notch and the flavors truly delivers. I can not recommend the dish enough!  To top off your experience, the service is great. The owner was very friendly and recommended a few local restaurants around the Patan area. We really appreciated it!  Attached to the restaurant is a small store that sells a variety of locally made craft goods. Everything from pashmina, pottery, and jewelry.  Definitely coming back!

Multipurpose, Yala Mandala has a great setting for dinning plus in an attached beautiful old Newari house they sell arts and crafts that are locally made. Their cheese cake was one of the best I have had made from "juju dai" a type of cream cheese made in many Newari homes. Their menu is more meaty than I would like and I hope that they create more vegetarian options. I had a simple fried rice that was very tasty especially with some added chilies.

After 6 years of living in Nepal we were preparing to leave Nepal. We needed a place to transition. Traditional Stay was perfect, and we were there for three weeks. The hotel rooms were very comfortable and well appointed. The manager, front of staff, Chefs and all other staff, were absolutely fantastic. They were accomodating to our needs, they even put on a special wedding anniversary meal. They made sure our stay was warm, friendly and tried to meet our every need. The chefs are enthusiastic and dedicated to good wholesome food, and one of the meals showcased a fusion of authentic nepali food with a western presentation. We left feeling that we had left behind some of 'our family'. A wonderful experience and would highly recommend this hotel to anyone.

column7: What a wonderful Hotel in a fantastic location.
column8: Arrived at this Hotel in February 2020.Where I was truly greeted by some amazing receptionist staff. This hotel is relatively new and it showed this, with its freshness, all mod cons with its exceptional staff. The manager Rajesh was most helpful and did not mind doing things a little different than others, which was helpful to me. The cleanliness of the hotel was excellent and my room was one of the best that I had ever stayed in. Its location was absolutely the world's best. You are a two minute walk from Patan, where I was given a free entrance pass to the beautiful sights of Patan, courtesy of the Traditional Stay Hotel, with my stay here. The very best goes to the staff, who assist this modern hotel to meet the comforts of this guest .... Thank you.

It's one of the my best and special hotel experience I've ever had. Great hospitality and warm welcome right from the start. All of the staff are very friendly and helpful. Perfect breakfast at their nice terras, lovely garden (they offer you fresh fruits and juices :) ), very large, clean, well-decorated room in a traditional way, free-pick up service,restful atmosphere, great location and of course an excellent family member's of Panday's Paradise around you. What else does a man expect? :)) We enjoyed our stay in Panday's Guesthouse so much. It's certainly more than a guest-house, it is a sincere family-house. Really you feel yourself like at your own home. Special thanks to owner; dear Tethys and kind receptionist lady; dear Sangila. If you're looking for a nice place in

column7: Large house with plenty of rooms
column8: I came to this hotel during the evening, so it is very difficult to find even for our taxi driver. We had to call the hotel to help find the location, as it is somewhat hidden behind an alley. At first glance, it looks like like a nice hotel, but it is more like a large house with plenty of rooms. The room was very cold, but they have a heater that helps as long as the power isn't out. There is a sign on the bathroom not to waste flushing, and the bathroom is very small. I would recommend the hotel, but beware of the tiny bathroom because once you shower in there, the toilet and floor will be very wet. When we wanted to check out of the hotel, it took a long time to process our bill, and they would not accept US Dollars because it was "old" even though it was new money,

column7: Charming, comfortable hotel with incredibly hospitable staff
column8: Our group of 16 stayed in this lovely, traditional Newari guest house. The hotel is well-located just off Durbar Square. Rooms are quite nicely and carefully appointed and really comfortable, including bathrooms. The price is really reasonable considering location and amenities. The steep stairs were a bit of a challenge for some of us older visitors, but the rooms and rooftop were absolutely worth it, and we appreciated having the original cozy rooms and decor. The staff could not have been more helpful and welcoming. There is even a carefully hidden safe in each room for those who need one. In spite of being just off the square, the hotel is quiet. Great place in all respects!

column7: Fantastic experience as for the first time visiting Nepal!
column8: Amazing small hotel. Very charming and kept in traditional style. Friendly staff and amazing location. Very close to the square, cafes, restaurants and all necessary spots to visit. We had amazing 3 nights, feeling welcomed and comfortable.

After a thorough 3-month search through hundreds of hotels/guest houses in the Kathmandu area to host very special adoption family reunion, we finally landed on Summerhill House in Lalitpur. I cannot say enough great things about this peaceful get-away in the heart of such a busy city! Beginning with the warm and wonderful owners of these beautiful Newari style inns, it only gets better with the excellent service, ideal location, added services (touring and transportation as needed) and lovely rooms - including common space for hanging out and relaxing. And, let's not forget the delicious Nepali cooking, the brand new yoga studio and a guarded, gated entrance! It was the perfect place for us, and for anyone looking for a traditional, yet modern, Nepali experience. I highly

column7: Change of ownership of guest housr
column8: The ownership of the guest house has been change and its name as yala heritage home. Now its a nice guest house with a beautiful view of patan durbar square Vists us. Thankyou Yala heritage home family.

column7: You can explore Patannot leaving your room!
column8: Great location, very clean cozy and simple rooms. Fresh bed linen (it is not that common in Nepal) and friendly helpfull stuff. Guesthouse is located right at the hear of the old city , overviewing Durbur and you can explore Patan looking out of the window,

Location, location, location ! it is the golden rule of any business and certainly for the Yala Guest House, sitting right in Patan Durbar Square. The only option to be closer to the square is to sleep on its floor. You can almost touch the pagodas from your window. And you are just few steps away from all the other interesting walks around Patan. I climbed to the roof top terrace to get a stunning view of the square and its life. The gust house is an old ordinary building. The recent renovation of the facade could certainly have been less modernist. However, if you like to stay in an ancient house renovated to excellent taste and functionality respecting all the esthetic codes, this is not your fancy place: you got to fork out a bigger wad of cash just few blocks north of the

Such a charming place to spend six days in - clean, spacious, quiet, full of Newari atmosphere and history. One couldn't imagine a warmer welcome; it was like staying with old friends. We learned really much about Patan area and the local community, thanks to Prakash and Pramila, who were always so helpful.

column7: Dont forget to recheck your bill.
column8: One of my friends recommended this place. I was told that they served decent food and ambiance was great. Except for the ambiance everything was awful. We ordered some chicken dish i was shocked to see the portion on the plate. For the price they charged the portion was less.i mean real less. I ended up drinking few duvals and ordered some cheese cake. Haha! Cheese cake tasted awful. Seriously!! why put cheese cake on the menu when it doesnt taste like one? And the brownie, you dont even want to know. Now moving on to the worst part, i was little tipsy when the check arrived i paid through card it was around $90 usd dollars. I was in a hurry and i couldnt check my bill. I came to my hotel and checked my bill. They over charged me on the duvals and desserts. I was pissed. People should not take advantage of the guest when they are tipsy or drunk. Overall a nice looking unethical place to go eat and drink. I will never ever recommend this place to anyone i know.

There are dozens of restaurants that fit the mold out of which came Embers in Kathmandu. An old house, a yard converted to an enclosed garden, a hip new wing with well-dressed tables and a bar. Shazam! Family house becomes restaurant.  Some months ago, my wife and I watched an old house transform into Embers, hip new Krishna Galli restaurant. Embers even sports a few designer stores in front to complete the image.  On a recent Saturday, our grocery shopping finished, we headed to Embers for lunch. This was not our first time at the spot and we headed directly for the new wing and its enclosed dining room to escape a late winter rainstorm. The folk that put Embers together followed the model faithfully. The new wing is stylish with floor to ceiling windows with bar at one end, the courtyard surrounded by fountain, the bar a classic Newari design and the house a warren of private rooms with show kitchen open to the courtyard.  After a quick glance at the menu, we ordered an Embers salad and chicken burger. The menu has a familiar mix of western and nepali main dishes and snacks. As we sipped our three for the price of two Carlsbergs, we watched a waiter collect cushions from the courtyard chairs. Two other couples sipped wine and nibbled on snacks. It’s unusual to see a lot of business at local eateries early on a Saturday afternoon, but Embers was doing just fine.  Our salad arrived first and we dug in. Crisp greens, sun dried tomatoes and boiled eggs made for a welcome start to our lunch. The outdoor bar was decorated for a party as it had been on several of our previous trips to Embers. Unlike many Kathmandu restaurants that turn into catering venues on a moments’ notice, Embers seems to have figured out how to keep the two lines of work separate. Our salad finished and the plate cleared, the chicken burger landed. Multigrain bun, crispy lettuce and previously frozen fries filled the plate.  All in all, Embers is a pleasant place to grab a drink, snack or dinner. It fits its category well and is just fine.

Tanani Newa is such a beautiful home! I have lived here for over a month and have felt so comfortable the whole time. They have made a lot of effort to prepare a very welcoming and warm environment. They do not treat it as only a business but as it is their home, they make great effort to treat you as their welcomed guests. They also have genuine concern for your well-being and safety. If you need ideas of places to visit or if you need any help, they have good knowledge of the area and have many connection as their family history goes back in this area for a long time. This is the best option anywhere in the area if you need a place to stay!

column7: Tanani Newa Home is very peace and clean,the best place to live in.
column8: Tanani Newa Home is nested into community court yard where cultural activities happens. It is nearby Patan Darwar Square, one of the world heritage site. Shova is very helpful and gives every information I need. Room is neat and clean. Shared kitchen room is very clean . From roof top, majestic view of the Himalaya can be seen. Malls, bus station , taxi stands are within walking distance.

This hotel is great! My husband and I stayed here for a night, and we really enjoyed the view of Patan Durbar Square from our room and the mountain views from the rooftop terrace. The hotel is built in a traditional Newari style with a modern twist (much of the decor is authentic Newari art). The rooms are a great size. The bathrooms are super clean and very nice. There were lots of amenities, like toothbrushes, toiletries, and a hair dryer in the bathroom. The bed was very comfortable. The WiFi was excellent for Nepal. There were only two downsides. The water bottle in the room was not sealed, so we didn’t drink it. Second, the square was kind of loud early in the morning (around 5 AM), but this could have been because of the holidays. Regardless of the two downsides, we

column7: Simply Superb! Magical location, excellent accommodation.
column8: This is the perfect place to stay in Kathmandu for those interested in the city's astonishing art, architecture, culture and history. I am already looking forward to staying here next time I visit Kathmandu (this was a work-related trip). Highlights are the location, the charming staff and the 'hidden Patan' walking tour that the most welcoming and enthusiastic proprietor very kindly took us on. Rooms are spacious, comfortable, well-decorated, very clean, with amenities. Bathroom is modern, bright, wet-room style. The views from the windows and top-floor terrace are superlative - you are practically in the temples. Highest recommendations for Heraya La:Ku

I lived at Peace Guest House with a friend for eight months in 2015, and by and large had a great time. Kalpa and has family are unspeakably lovely and welcoming: better landlords truly could not be hoped for. Many times we were invited to join them for a meal or brought a snack by "Grandma", and Kalpa was very attentive to any problems we had and usually dealt with them promptly. The second story (which we leased) boasts lots of natural light, there are bathrooms everywhere, the views of Kathmandu are gorgeous (especially from the roof), and there is just enough furniture to live comfortably. The constant traffic noises typical of Kathmandu barely reach the apartment, but it's also worth noting that the windows do not seal well, meaning night time dog barking wars and

Bottom line up front? Stay here. Honestly struggling to put together words that describe how fantastic this place is. Heartwarming? Generous? Genuine. The hospitality of the staff here is amazing, and I was truly sad to have to leave. The building is brand new, clean and stylishly designed. Locally owned, which I LOVE. Very spacious beds and well designed and secure storage areas. Good food, great coffee (rare in KTM!), and lots of really comfortable little areas to settle into. Had the best yoga instruction of my entire life when they organised a few classes here. There always seems to be an event happening, so it's actually a really great blend of a relaxed chill atmosphere, with enough social vibe to make sure you have somewhere to go and feel included and connected if

This beautiful handcrafted design store is just few meters away from Patan Durbar Square. They have interesting and unique home decor and accessories with master in details and craftsmanship. A perfect gift for your home. Definitely must visit place to go when you are looking for something beautiful and change in Kathmandu!

column7: Unique, contemporary designs made with traditional craftsmanship
column8: A soothing oasis in a chaotic neighborhood of Patan. One can browse for hours and listen to the story behind each of their beautiful products. Their hammered copper collection is a must see. Charming, friendly people you can enjoy a conversation with over a cup of amazing coffee. Bring a friend to enjoy the Nepali strategy game of Bagchal with. I always leave feeling inspired.

This is a nice little place in the beautiful corner of patan to get souvenirsfromNepal. It has products that have a gist of traditional Nepali crafts but with a contemporary twist in them. Their products are one of a kind! I strongly suggest you to visit!

It is a tiny little place with a small team. Very cosy. Traditional newari style house. They also have a cafe and serve breakfast, coffee and cakes. Try their cakes and handmade chocolates. Delicious. They don't have their own parking so you might have to talk to the staff to find a parking near by if you have your own vehicles. Value for money.

I stayed at the full serviced apartment. It is a three storied apartment typical of local Newari style. Cooked most days so I could save up some money. On days that I wasn't feeling like cooking, I ordered from the hotel. They serve amazing breakfast and cakes. The staff are very friendly, so even though i stayed there for long, they made me feel like home. Convenient location is an added value and so is easy to navigate for people who are new to the city.

column7: Wonderful stay at the heart of Patan Durbar Square
column8: Pahan Chhen offered us a wonderful stay at the heart of the quaint historical district of Patan Durbar Square. The staff was very professional, welcoming and helpful. The room was clean, comfortable and well equipped with flat screen, hot water, Italian style shower and balcony. The hotel is at the heart of durbar square and near several pleasant shops and cages. The dinner on the rooftop offered us an amazing view over monuments we enjoyed from the bottom during day time. The breakfast at the ground floor was in a pleasant traditional interior design atmosphere.

The hotel is situated in the middle of primaeval city Patan. Patan Durbar Square is one of the three Durbar Squares in the Kathmandu valley all of which are Unesco World Heritage Sites. The hotel is quiet and situated near to numerous local restaurants.The main attraction is the ancient royal palace where the Malla kings of Patan resided. The hotel has roof top restaurant from where you can view the royal palace. The hotel is in great location. Wonderful experience. Good hospitality. Thank you hotel for special " MOMO".

This hotel is very new and in a great location. It is located right beside durbar square in Patan. Tons of souvenir shopping and restaurants close by. The bathroom was beautiful with a huge rainfall shower head. There was a balcony. TV had Netflix. There is a rooftop restaurant, patio and bar. A large, wonderful breakfast was included. Staff was wonderful and helpful. Great stay.

column7: The place to just take in the sights of a bye gone era
column8: Unfortunately while Kathmandu has interesting sights it is has also become very crowded, congested and polluted. In that regard Patan is undoubtedly one of the nearby cities to getaway from all the dust and noise. You can spend a whole day exploring this medieval city and its heritage architectural sights or just sit back and wath the world go by...

column7: great quality, worthy to check out
column8: We were touring Patan Dubai Square and was led to this little store. The owner did a demonstration, explaining the made, the difference in size, and balancing your chakras using these handmade singing bowl. I supposed they do a sound bowl therapy if u asked.  It may be seems abit pricey, but I feel that at least it gives u some peace of mind you are sold the real deal than other touristy places outside. He was patient to give us some quick crash course on how to use the bowl to its fullest potential! Looking forward to explore the one we picked.

column7: Lovely experience, but remember they are trying to sell you a bowl!
column8: The people here are very nice. They explain how the bowls are made and of course how their's is better than everyone else! The sales pitch is not heavy and I left mum to do all the work. I sat and watched the life going on around the place. But beware, they have jewellery also! Understand, you will end up paying something like $375 for a nice bowl and it is unique, so we went with the flow. Nice place, but you are here to be sold a bowl! Recommend

I had been searching for a singing bowl for a while and as I headed to Nepal I figured there was no better place to buy one. Once I arrived in Thamel I was overwhelmed by the sheer amount of people selling singing bowls in the street all ranging in price and quality. I didn't mind spending a little more money if I could ensure the piece was legitimate, however, I soon became unsure of who to trust while buying one as I wanted one handmade in Nepal. Once I found Om Handicrafts in Patan I had knew I had to look no further. This store is wonderful, prices are fair for what you are getting and the owners are extremely helpful and friendly. They worked with me to find the singing bowl I was looking for and demonstrated various versions until I found the one I loved. If you're looking for a real handmade in Nepal singing bowl, this is your place!

This Handicrafts store is located in an area that was obviously hit hard by the 2015 earthquake. Thankfully this store survived and has been just about fully restored. The store offers for sale an extensive amount of authentic Nepali items such as singing bowls, statues, carvings and prayer wheels.  During my visit, I was given an comprehensive display of the history and use of the singing bowls. These bowls are said to help aid in minimizing minor aches in the body. This is done in part by helping the user to relax and focus. The sizes of the bowls range from smaller to large enough to stand in. I purchased a smaller bowl and was please to be advised that the purchase included a cushion and two mallet; one of the mallets is used to circle the bowl until it rings, the second is used to “hammer” the bowl. I was able to have the items mailed to me in the United States; I received the shipment shortly after my return home in perfect condition. Also included was a set of instructions.  While the items in this showroom are more expensive than the items offered by street vendors, it is easy to tell that these items are authentic pieces and not just for souvenir collection. I found the prices to be fair and left with the knowledge that I was assisting a business in Patan that was hit hard by the earthquake.

This fair trade store has an amazing selection of scarves and jewelry but the real stars are the top quality singing bowls. We've purchased several bowls that are far superior to the ones on the street. The demonstration of the singing bowls is interesting and educational.
Purchased a "Full Moon" bowl after an interesting demonstration. Staff was helpful in choosing the right bowl.

Staying at Om's Apartments (which is just above Om Handicrafts) was an absolute pleasure. It was beautifully appointed, clean, comfortable, warm and safe. Also it is situated in a very beautiful part of Kathmandu. Our family of 4 (2 adults and 2 children age 10 and 6) were most perfectly accommodated in 2 separate apartments. Though we ate out a lot, there is a clean and well equipped kitchen upstairs. The staff are both warm and professional. My children loved going downstairs to Om's Handicrafts to see their exquisite singing bowls and to chat to them and to listen to the magnificent sounds. Manoj, Abhi and Raaz were always available to answer questions and to help us. By the end of our stay I was very sad to leave such special people and a place that housed us so well. My only regret is not buying more singing bowls. They are truly therapeutic and make for wonderful gifts also.

column7: Western Prices and maybe Western product standard
column8: So I had read about this place on Tripadvisor and decided I wanted to stop in and see what it was about. There are a handful of stores that I believe a Westerner would be interested in stopping by: Dukati (prices were really reasonable), Yala (had some luxury bath products and nice jewelry), Om, Sala (I was most enchanted with their blanket wool rugs as these would sell for over $1k in the US – NYC to be specific.) I’ll say, I found Om Handicrafts to be a bit sterile and at Western-like prices. Now did I buy something, yes, yes I did. I had wanted a 100% pure cashmere blanket and I thought in the United States these could range in the $400-800 price range depending on where you purchased. These at Om are part of a fair trade organization (which I prefer to support) and they had a masculine design to them (and I liked the chevron/herringbone/striped patterns in neutrals.) I paid $247 for a double bed size blanket (more for the couch in my particular opinion) and opted for a 4x4 weave. The less expensive weaves can be 1x1 (super thin) or 2x1 (medium to light weight and not as long or wide.) I will also say that the scarves that they offered are the same price as at Kopan monastery and look identical. And now that I have my blanket home, I'm disappointed to say that the edges are starting to show loose/frayed threads that are coming out of the blanket.

Run by very welcoming, friendly and helpful people with also a sense for social responsibility. They are happy to explain more about the process of the production, origin, history, etc. of their handicrafts as well as they also know how to use their Healing Bowls. They give a nice demonstration about how to use the Healing Bowls and are very patient and helpful if you are interested and trying to find your personal bowl. I haven't been to one of the apartments. But after having seen the store, I guess they must be very nice and for sure clean.

The whole Durbar quarter is an absolute must, and although some of the area has been damaged by the earthquake of a few years ago, it's still somewhere well worth visiting. The buildings, carvings, and treasures are superb.

the royal palace in Batan is a big building, which is really beautiful inside and is really worth a visit. We were almost the lonely people inside so we could take some nice pictures of this old palace.

Its a strange experience to visit the palace. it seems like abandoned places, but still with some staff. Its dirty, dusty and the area where the shooting took place, strangely kept. As a backyard with no history.

column7: Just like they left it. Gives you a 1980's feel
column8: If you remember visiting your grandparents home when you were a kids. This will remind you of it. A very large private home/palace that still has the rotary phones and manual TV's. I was surprise that the ground and property are not being well maintained and the area of the killing of the royal family is still closed. Worth seeing for the historic aspect. Worth seeing .
This palace is located in the Patan darbar area. This is an Ancient palace with terracotta artifacts.

Amazing roof top terrasse. Warming welcome in this traditional building. Authentic wooden windows in newari style. Very nice accomadation. Close to Durbar Square. We were a group visiting Patan and we really enjoyed sleeping here. We felt at home thanks also to the host.

Our first time in Nepal, and we stayed at Goathchen. It was such a good experience - the place itself - clean, traditional and cozy, the location right next to Durbar Square, and the hosts - so generous, that we ended up staying there once again when we passed through Katmandu. The low wooden ceilings, the wooden floors, big beautiful windows, the floor seating, and the very cozy low-rise bed, and the economy of the bathroom - very endearing and grounded - hobbit like Breakfast is shared with great generosity, as was the elaborate Newari dinner we were invited to, along with two of our friends who were staying elsewhere. Even more generous was our host Brijender in sharing his stock of the local Nepali Ruksi. We so enjoyed the Ruksi that we carried some back with us. Infact i

Goathchen is a lovely little 300-year old guest house tucked away in a quiet alley literally just around the corner from Patan Durbar square. The rooms are clean and charming with warm running water. Bed was comfortable with spring mattress and synthetic pillows. The owner and his wife are very generous and kind; they looked after us and offered delicious breakfast (local yoghurt, eggs, fresh fruit and coffee/tea) in the lush courtyard. They even took the time and celebrated my birthday with a traditional Newari ceremony with offerings and flowers. So sweet! If you are looking for an authentic home stay experience I would definitely recommend Goathchen.

A 300 year-old perfectly preserved house. Very well located, in the historical center of Patan. Great atmosphere, very nice owners and delicious breakfast. Everything is perfect. Just be careful, the house is hidden in a small alley. Enjoy!

I stayed at Suite Home from late January to mid August 2019. Very good clean and friendly place, with one of the best breakfasts in town on the roof top terrace. On the 7th floor there are good views of the valley, and on (exceptional) clear skies you can see the Himalaya. And, what is a real treat is the green of the British Camp next door. Ann.

Wonderful architecture, like all the temples on the square and this has a rich history. This temple is very popular (dedicated to the god of trade and business) between the local merchant and trader communities. The temple is located on the north of Durbar Square. Bhimsen Temple is dedicated to Bhimsen, one of the five Pandavas of the Mahabarata. The three-storey pagoda has an unusual rectangular plan that sets it apart from other temples in Patan. Non-Hindus may once again be able to climb to the upper level to view the wild-eyed statue of Bhimsen. Wonderfully.

Simply magical and spiritual. The architecture of the kings Malla is simply elegant and unique. People live around these magnificent place vacting to their usual daily life routine. It is a living museum.

Bhimsen popular God among ' Newa' the indigenous people of kathamandu valley . This God is worship by Newa for Balance Business mean making profits without violating the rules and regulations of business. So where ever these Newa people lived there is a huge temple of Bhimsen. One of the beautiful temple located at Durbar square of patan. Three stairs pagoda architecture is beautiful fine work of 12th century AD. Hindus are allowed to visit the temple and a statue of Bhimsen is killing the demons, which actually evils of self . Worth visiting the temple are for travelers.

Located in the Durbar square of Patan, this temple is being renovated because of the earthquake of April 2015. Historic temple. You must hire a local guide to give you a history of this place or of durbar square.

Out of three Durbar square of Nepal, this temple is at Patan Durbar Sqare just 5 km from Kathmandu. The temple is dedicated to Bhimsen, one of five pandavas of Mahabharat Period.Tourist are not allowed inside temple.There are so many temples in Durbar Sqare.

Patan is Nepal's third largest city. Visit Patan is a special experience. Officially called Lalitpur, which translates as the City of Beauty, Patan is known for its rich cultural heritage. Durbar Square ( Main Square ) is interesting, full of magnificent buildings, temples, shops, and always a lot of people. There was a beautiful temple in the square, Char Narayan Temple. But this sixteenth-century temple collapsed completely in the 2015 earthquake. I firmly hope that we will enjoy his beauty again after restoration. We were here a lot of times earlier and we know how beautiful it looked.

column7: Very Good Place to stay in Patan
column8: Very friendly stuff. Nice and clean rooms. Its just a view meters from the historic Durbar Square in Patan. Great view from the rooftop. Would definitely choose this accommodation once again. Only small drawback. Breakfast ist good but not to much.

Visited Patan- Center of the city Lalitpur. This is one of three UNESCO World Heritage Sites, and one of the sites undergoing renovations in the Kathmandu region, post 2015 earthquake. Bring cash to pay entry fee-1000 rupees when I was there. Be sure to look at all the restoration going on and explore the museum.

column7: A true gem of a find
column8: The first time visiting Nepal and with a three week stay in prospect, I was so relieved to arrive at the guest house of Bikram and Preeti. Immediately made to feel so welcome and completely at home, the room was large, airy and the bed completely comfortable. I stowed my clothes in the wardrobe and settled in. The whole stay was a joy. Bikram and Preeti treated us as honored guests and nothing was too much trouble for them. I was very sad to leave at the end of the stay and feel I have made a couple of valued friends into the bargain.

Cora Nepal is a unique place. In Kathmandu you will rarley find a lot of hoses in a safe neighbourhood with such a heartful and light-flooded interior design, lovely decorations, friendly and flexible hosts who make sure that you feel welcome and comfortable throughout your stay, a lovely Didi who takes care of the rooms every single day, a Roof terrace to enjoy the mild evenings, a green garden filled with fresh vegetables and herbs and delicious and fresh breakfast facilities for the perfect start into the day. From the start I felt like home at Cora Nepal and was able to relax from the hustles of the city. The area of Sanepa is known for the delicious restaurants and cafés in walking distance. Great Yoga and Fitness studios are close by. Definitely my favorite place to stay

column7: LOOK NO FURTHER - a retreat from the hustle and bustle!
column8: If you are venturing to Nepal for a short-medium term stent and want a cosy place that is like home away from home then look no further - Cora Nepal has you covered! We can't express our gratitude enough to Shei and Sid! We stayed at Cora for a total of about 6 months and we could have stayed even longer. My husband and I look for a few specifics when choosing a long-term stay location and Cora met all of our needs and more - here are a few highlights: -room: we stayed in the room with a private bath and we loved it! The design of the whole place is of course a reflection of Shei's brilliant architecture background :) The room had a lot of natural light and a desk perfect for working. The bedding was dreamy - there's a down comforter! This is hard to find and a real treat.

column7: The map suggests that this is "I Ba Bahī," south of Mangal Bazaar, there is no stupa at this monastery however
column8: Reviews and photos in this listing are very confusing. Judging from the map, what is meant is I Ba Bahī (identified by the Lonely Planet as I Baha Bahi), a well-restored (with Japanese funding in 1979) Newari Buddhist traditional monastery, also known as Rajashri Mahavihara. There is no stupa, unless people are referring to the small caitya in the courtyard. Elsewhere in Patan there are of course the four Asoka Stupas, an impressive one at Pim Bahal, a smaller one at Dhum Bāhā, a beautiful one at Tago Cibana Bāhā, etc, but the reviews that mention stupas at this bahi are misleading and the photos are not of this place at all.
Please is well maintained and architecture is great. Though not really popular spot with the tourists.
Traditional stupa with a "plus" for birdlovers: a big "screaming party" of House Swifts above the square and... some birds coming down to roost in their nests built in houses!

column7: Great help if your body is in trouble
column8: Went to Sotai's maybe 10 times in the past year or so. They always managed to fix my problems. Be it shoulders, lower back, legs, you name it. Usually, in my experience it took two sessions to really feel a difference. But that's it usually. Money well worth spent.

The staff at Sotai are amazingly powerful healers. I've suffered a frozen shoulder for 7 months now with only 50% movement & lots of pain. Since visiting Sotai my movement is 95% with significantly less pain & improving each visit. Big thank You to Suresh

Visited with family and friends...the food was delicious, the service prompt. In the biting cold of kathmandu evenings, a cosy atmosphere was maintained. Do try the jhol momo, its an absolute delicacy. We ordered a couple of other items also which were tasty.

column7: Pleasant roof top bar and restaurant popular with prosperous younger locals
column8: The bar had a TV showing 'X Factor' and we preferred sitting outside on the roof terrace which looks across the road to the Old Royal Palace. Mushroom chilli and Fish Fingers were good snacks and the equivalent of chicken sizzler was well up to the standard of better local restaurants. We visited twice during our stay in Kathmandu because the location was convenient and food pretty good for the price.

One of my favorite places to go to. The Jhol Momo (Steamed Dumplings in Soup) are one of the best in town. I also tried the Crispy Chicken and Crispy Potato, both of them really crunchy, appetizing, and with satisfactory portions. Please visit this place, everyone, I promise you will not regret. Just keep walking past the fire station n Pulchowk, and Le Trio is on the same side, opposite JJ Machan.  Warning: The place is really small. And service can be slow, so you can call them beforehand and request to keep your Jhol Momo ready. It is run by young people, they are polite for the most part but maybe not as attentive as they could be.

column7: waffle with ice cream bang for the buck
column8: So it was my first time here. I was with my sis. I was just here for the Waffles. So I opened the door to enter , I was just blown away by the aroma of vanilla essence. Place is small but very cute. Here...More

Well, not really, but GG Machaan bills itself as “Feeling Jungle in the City”.  My wife and I have lived in Kathmandu for a little over a year now and when I decided to take off a recent Friday to make a long weekend, I was certain the October weather would be fine. I was wrong. The monsoon, that a few days before seemed to have dissipated, was back. A steady rain settled in making our planned excursion to the Kopan Monastery problematic. When the veil of rain still hadn’t lifted by 11:30 Saturday morning, we scrubbed our plans and headed to lunch.  We visited GG Machaan several months ago and I remembered it as having a pleasant, covered outdoor terrace which made it a good candidate for lunch on a rainy day. We arrived at 12:15 after a short drive and were immediately seated. My memory was correct. The two level outdoor terrace is bamboo covered and sports photos of Nepali royalty hunting for big game in times long past. The menu contains predominantly Nepali snacks but also a mix of western fare and Indian food.  After a brief perusal of the menu, we settled on Perale mushrooms (oyster mushrooms battered w/Benal gram flower, green chili, garlic) and the GG fried Basa fish. The waiter capably took our order and read everything back to make sure he had it correct. While we waited for our order to arrive, I tapped my foot to cover versions of popular tunes played in the background. After a reasonable wait, the mushrooms arrived. What was immediately noticeable to us was that the chef had clearly considered the presentation of this simple dish. In most restaurants around town, food is unceremoniously dumped on the plate. Here, the main dish was carefully plated and garnished with carved vegetables. Nice! The taste was as good as the presentation.  No sooner had we polished off the mushrooms than the fish arrived. The presentation of golden-fried chunks of Basa fish equaled that of the now disappeared mushrooms. The Basa fish soon suffered the same fate. As we lingered on the quiet terrace enjoying a rainy afternoon it was clear to us that we had chosen wisely.  While GG Machaan is no jungle, it is a place for good food, well presented in comfortable surroundings.

New and exciting environment which is designed with a unique style and decorum, accompanied by great live music on Wednesday and Friday. Complimentary starter by the Chef, good portion and great service.

column7: Could improve allot with some small changes...(Yes I'm an old man)
column8: The place is nice and clean, have a good working place and mostly clean bathrooms. The menu is decent and the staff is nice. So far so good. The problem is that every second time we have made an order, half of the things did't come. Since the food often take 25-40 minutes to be made, you get a little frustrated that only 3 of 4 people get their food. This have happened several times! When the restaurant is full and crowded and when there is just a handful of guests.  Another thing that really reduce my willingness to visit Evoke on weekends is that they have live music which is supposed to be nice? At Evoke they have it so loud that it hurts. One time we had to text each other because we could not hear one and another around the table.

column7: One of our favourites - main drawback is all the smokers
column8: Really good food (and large portions) and good choices. Good desserts too (and good quality desserts - e.g. real cheesecake, good moist chocolate cake). Been here a few times - service is good. Mostly outdoor seating - but invariably you end up smoking other tables'...More

This was a real find, the dood was excellent. I had lemon chicken and it was cooked to perfection my wife had the pork steak also cooked perfectly, the owner came and made sure everything was to our liking. The staff was great.

column7: One of the best dining in Kathmandu
column8: The restaurant lives up to its unique feature of "Everything from scratch". The food taste super delicious...you could try all varieties ranging from croquettes, poleko timmur chicken, roasted pork to Gnochii, Saffron Risotto. Unique homely taste with cozy ambience. Perfect place for family dinner, friends...More
friendly bartenders and interesting people to meet there. Good music, simply an entertaining place to be.

I've tried this place a few times, convinced that, given time, it will improve. I get frozen sushi, odd smelling canned tuna rolls, and other unpleasant surprises. Wait staff never seems happy to see business rolling in the door.

Otafuku has so far 2 places serving platters of yumminess. The first original outlet is a small cosy corner tucked away under Bunker Hill. This diner offers you a live experience and you can watch your sushi being prepared while sipping a Asani beer or...More

smiling staff.....awasome and unique test of food ...specially jhaneko momos...&....peach iced lemon ........very good expireance but service was little bit slow...if they keep more staff than easy for guest and staff too....

smiling staff.....awasome and unique test of food ...specially jhaneko momos...&....peach iced lemon ........very good expireance but service was little bit slow...if they keep more staff than easy for guest and staff too....

you can not get much more attached to a restaurant than i am to this one....have been religiously visiting and enjoying this place since it opened a year back. every time i have visited the food has never failed to satisfy my taste buds, our...More

When we visit Manny's we always have great food and great fun. The food is always consistent in quality and delicious. One of our favorites is the patatas bravas! We like the large screen TV outside to watch old Charlie Chaplin movies. Great place for...More

Rupee for rupee you can't be disappointed with the food at Walter's. Some genuine German stuff on the menu as well as local and other international cuisines. Nice atmosphere, family friendly. Phone up and pre-order if you want a Grillhaxe.

column7: Great Place for a quick western meal and cakes and free wifi
column8: Everything was of a high quality and standard not common in Nepal. A foreigners escape definitely. Also available are local arts and crafts on the upper floor's Higher Ground Craft shop.

They served us a frozen thing which they called their "homemade icecream". I am referring to it as frozen thing because it was clearly not icecream to me. It tasted like frozen flavoured water grated and molded into a ball. Also we waited for 25minutes...More

I’ve been here every day for the past week and ordered the spaghetti buff bolognese every time- honestly the best bolognese I have ever had, which is why I keep going back. Sam is a great guy as well, very friendly service and he clearly...More

Nini’s is just down the street from where I’m staying and I’ve walk past a few times and thought it looked pretty well presented. On way back from a walk around one eve me and a friend decided to give it a go for a...More
I drop by to have a beer or a steak at least once a week. If there were more stars to give ... It would be for the steak!!

The place has an incredibly relaxed vibe. The selection of food is unique and you'll always find the perfect beverage to compliment it. It's a miss if you still haven't been here. You'll be raving about the place everywhere! P.S It's always fun to be...More

This is just a change in name of restaurant and its owner -earlier this was the old Celebs lounge in Jhamshikhel which has now been sold to another owner and renamed. Still most of staff and food menu are same. Haven't found much changes compare...More

These people have really amazing tea to serve and pakages to take home. Their service is very impressive. I am their regular customer. Some times I also order espresso which is excellent too. They have parking space and ambience is unique.

column7: Fun place - food is tasty & fast. Close to the Golden Temple, a wonderful old busy temple in Lalitpur Patan
column8: Good spot for breakfast, lunch or a snack. Young friendly Nepalis opened this place recently ~ it’s bright & fun. The Golden Temple is just a couple alleys/squares away - don’t miss the temple & if you want a bite this is a great choice...More

column7: Excellent Korean Food with Little Atmosphere
column8: We have been to this little Korean restaurant and have consistently had tasty and reasonably priced food. Especially the bibimbap is a favorite. Oir two year old loves that dish. The atmosphere and general cleanliness of the restaurant is not the best to be fair,...More
My favourite place, to get the regular dose of Kimchi and Bulgogi and all the good stuff. Food is very good service is nice and quite quick (which alone is something special here.

This Road House still has the old menu so old favourites not available in the other restaurants can still be had. Good food, good service. Great every time. Thanks. Handy to eat here if going to the movies.More

Having been to several places looking to satisfy my milkshake craving, this was by far the best. True, authentic milkshakes as you would find in the UK or the states - cold, refreshing and so many choices for flavours!! Have been back several times, I...More

I recently visited the Keventers milkshake shop in Thamel. It is the only place in Thamel to get a real authentic milkshake. It is a small shop, very clean and inviting. They have good range of different milkshakes. Good place to hangout. Well done

As soon as you step foot into this malt shop in Thamel, you can't believe you're actually in Nepal! A very farmhouse chic decor with delicious milkshakes served in old-fashioned glass milk bottles. So refreshing on a hot, dusty day!

column7: A real firewood oven, right next to Durbar Square!
column8: What an incredible surprise - this place has the best bread (sandwiches, pizzas, baguettes) I have had in Nepal. The sandwiches in particular are incredible, with amazing filling. This place has great vegetarian options. The location is great and the atmosphere inside is great! I...More
Food was all fried and tasted old. Staff was friendly but very slow. Took a long time before we got our food. Quite expensive, given the fact that it was all fried.
There are only a few sports bar in town and this one was a real surprise. It is a complete sports bar. Had Fun

flavors is well situated at the Giant Stupa in Bouda. With all the concerns about what we could/should/can't eat in Nepal, finding this cafe was a real treat. it is very clean and caters to the tourist population while giving an amazing atmosphere = you...More

column7: An Aladdin's cave of Fairtrade crafts
column8: We had read about this shop in our guide book, but nothing could have prepared us for the range of wonderful goods. We are involved in Fairtrade at home, but the range of Fairtrade craft goods here put anywhere in the UK to shame.

I have been going to Chaitanya regularly for the past year and all of my experiences have been very welcoming with exceptional service. They even have Dr. Rakshya. for wellness consultation, where I did my first acupuncture session. I even book sessions for my family time & again.  They also give me some special discounts now and then 😉 . Definitely recommend you to try this wellness center once!

I have been practicing yoga for three years at Gyan Mandala with several highly-skilled teachers; they are the reason why I keep returning. The studio offers a great variety of classes - from active Ashtanga to relaxing yin yoga to traditional Hatha - and there is a good mix of physical and spiritual practice. I always leave the studio in a great mood, with a positive attitude. Gyan Mandala is an inclusive environment - classes are suitable for all levels and teachers are great at offering students a variety of options to suit their particular skill level. I am so grateful to have the opportunity and privilege to practice multiple days a week at Gyan Mandala. I have also participated in several retreats to Neydo Monastery and Hattiban, which have been amazing escapes from the city, and an opportunity to connect with a great community to people.

A lovely, family run and peaceful small coffehouse cum restaurant in a pleasant garden setting with walking distance from the old City of Patan. Highly recommended! Lovely breakfast, lunches and early dinners. A small shop with Fairtrade handicrafts is also on the premises of this...More

I've eaten at this restaurant 3 times in the past 6 months and each time the experience has been great. Twice I've taken my wife and once my nephew, and they both agree. The outside eating space is very nice. There is a small vegetable/herb...More

column7: An unusual garden restaurant - with great food - especially apple crumble
column8: We enjoyed a very good lunch at Cafe Cheeno - everything we tried was of a really good standard. We were the only customers but it was late for lunch and the Cafe is quite new, tucked away where not many people know about it. The garden is a real oasis from the noise and bustle of Patan/Kathmandu. The signature dessert - apple crumble is a must. The only negative was tentative service - the waiter misunderstood our request and instead of asking us brought all dishes at the same time.

I had the opportunity to stay for two weeks in the center. It was a unique expierience. The quality of the treatment was excellent. I can recommend the massages and the yoga lessons. All staff member are genuine friendly. I really look forward to come back.

Danfe Ghar is a great Guest House/ BB in Kathmandu. The area is called Sanepa and it is a peaceful friendly residential area with some NGOs and international organisations. This is actually a good thing because it means that the local coffee shops, cafés, grocery stores and restaurants are good! The owner and staff was always so nice, genuine, friendly and helpful with anything we needed during our stay in Kathmandu. Do not hesitate to ask for tips about what to see and where to go! It was a really nice experience to feel that the owner really wanted us to like Danfe Ghar, the neighbourhood and Nepal. The rooms are always kept super clean and decorated in a nice welcoming vibe. I loved the balcony. I can highly recommend Danfe Ghar. I will book Danfe Ghar again! However, the

column7: Best place for work and nice fresh food
column8: Suburb is a clean, modern Guesthouse with big bedrooms and a very good restaurant. The breakfast is fresh and there are a lot of things to choose from. I used this place to work and the WiFi is very good everywhere, even in the garden - what is my favorite place. Also for lunch and diner Suburb is my favorite. The service is perfect and the guy's can tell you many things about the food and the menu. I think Suburb is a special place to stay because of the location, it's unique, clean and very charming.

I stumbled on this absolute gem as I woke up very early, wanted to walk and headed towards the hotel where I was scheduled for a meeting. The menu looked interesting, it was open early, and I spotted the lovely gardens with tables to eat at. The coffee was excellent and Eggs Benedict absolutely fabulous - perfectly done and delicious. I ended up chatting to the only other customer and it was very convivial. They even charged my phone for me while I ate - excellent service! I will definitely be back!

This old temple sits in the square behind King Yoganareendra Malla's statue and was badly damaged in the 2015 earthquake. It was unusual as it was built of brick in 1565 and is now under renovation and gets lost a little .

Do not go there if you are looking for peace and quiet: it is a very noisy neighbourhood, and there is no way to sleep in the morning, you have to wake up with the community. Lots of works around, hammers and loud noise in the morning... The bed is comfortable though, and the whole style of the building is nice. The staff is warm and helpful. The situation is a plus, since you're close to everything (temples all around). I wouldn't recommend the breakfast too much : juice is "Real" (sugar and colouring) and the jam is "Druk" (the worst jam of Asia). Too bad they don't serve a little quality products, it would definitely raise the bar globally...

column7: Excellent place. It is just around 500 meters to Patan Durbar Square.
column8: Excellent place. Traditional house, clean rooms and bathrooms. Have access to common sitting place and marvelous views of mountains and hills. If you are sitting long term then have few studio apartments with kitchen utensils, refrigerator and micro-oven. Staffs are helpful and informative. Beds are comfortable have sitting area as well. Hot pot in the room with coffee and sugar is best as you can make your own coffee. Highly recommended for family and groups.

This Bungamati home-stay is community based best home stay for traditional and modern culture learner. It is better to stay and visit all around Bungamati old village which is full of traditional culture, wooden art skill and traditional and modern mix knowledge to click beautiful scenes. The capital city Kathmandu of Nepal is near Bungamati about 10 KM. Thank.

column7: Real Sherpa food and much more!
column8: Sherpa specialities like thukpa, shakpa, and rigikur highlight the menu, but they make the best onion rings I have ever had and a creamy shrimp and rice dish to die for. Momos, the Tibetan dumplings that are ubiquitous in Nepal, are argued about regularly, but...More

It was a nice holiday which was organize by Asian Eco Journey. I get chance to visit lots of places near kathmandu . The team peacefully plan my holiday package. The visited places were so much exciting with its own history. As Nepal is a country with warm hearted people with…

column7: The best way to see Kathmandu
column8: I booked with Oneal to see the real Kathmandu and all of the wonderful interesting sites nearby. I went to sites which weren't as touristy and it was amazing. So authentic, even down to the lunch / masala tea stops which were all hidden gems. I was very impressed with Oneal's…

column7: Vistas Himalaya - Excellent Service. Highly Recommended!
column8: This might sound like a paid review, but it is not! Check my profile and you would come to know. After having availed of their services for the 4th time within the past 4-5 years, i can confidently say that Vistas Himalayas are the best Tour Services in Nepal. Shree is just a…

Everything was fantastic! the tour guide Shree is really helpful, knowledgeable and anxious to make your trip to Nepal unique and wonderful. I really wanted to see the rural areas of Nepal and told him that i am interested to see some schools because of my studies, he organized…

WANT SOMETHING UNIQUE!! SEE NEPAL! We had a really nice and relaxing trip to Nepal. Did tour of Kathmandu - Bandibur - Pokhara. Beautiful landscapes with nice people. We enjoyed with our tourguide Mr Shree and his driver ”Mr Money”. Shree had picked us nice hotels and places…

During this autumn I got a chance to trek to Everest Base Camp with Pristine Nepal Treks & Expedition P. Ltd. It was such a wonderful time & dream come true for me. Setting a foot on the highest base camp of the world was absolutely amazing. I want to thank Mr. Chin (owner of…

My first trip in Nepal was an absolute pleasure because of Chin, Ganesh, Tika, and their family. I spent 6 weeks in Nepal, during this time I trekked EBC and did 3 weeks of volunteering in a rural school 8 hours North-West of Katmandu in Mulpani. Before I left home, I was able…

Visiting Nepal was indeed a fantastic experience of my lifetime. Thanks to Pristine Nepal for giving me a tour in Patan (Lalitpur) with full of Nepali cultural information. I have a huge interest in arts, culture and history, and I genuinely appreciate Ganesh who took extra…

After walking through the heritage of Kathmandu Chin offered us to guide us through the markets and help us find souvenirs and equipment. I have to admit it was a great suggestion - no searching, no rip off, and a good feeling of getting all the stuff super fast!
Chin gave us wunderful tour throug Kathmandu, showing us Durbar Square, some very nice temples and gave us insights in the history of all places we visited.

This burger place is located in Labim Mall, in an area with several restaurants. I had an "exotic" beef burger, which was very nice. Also the bun was good. Reasonably priced,especially when you take the "meal" option. There is plenty of sit-down space. Choices include...More

My husband, a colleague and I dined at Summit and had a truly memorable evening. Our server Rajeev was a delightful host who not only advised on menu selections but explained much about the history and culture surrounding various dishes. The menu offered many selections,...More

This is a swayambhu Shivling on hilltop. you have to go up about 365 stairs to reach this place. According to local myth those who are childless may get child by performing puja in the Hindu calender month Magh purnima which falls in the month of January or February. A view of the whole Kathmandu is visible from here.

This is a small guesthouse and cafe with the feel of Brazil - they have a number of rooms, with self cook kitchens on each floor - beautifully set up welcoming. Hot water and western enmities is a plus. A small cafe on the group floor offers REAL Brazilian coffee and Brazilian snacks. Enjoyed their beautiful photographic art. If you need a place away from hustle and bustle, on a budget but want to feel at home - I recommend this place.

Best place for a quick getaway. It gives you a wholesome Nepal experience in 24 hrs. The breathtaking mountain ranges are visible in all their splendour, quick hiking trails to be explored, mountain biking tracks nearby, a great spa with some exotic sound healing sessions, a mod infinity pool with a jacuzzi and sauna, glittery night view of the valley. Adventure, peace, lounging to perfect beats … it’s all there. When you Are short on time but want it all… this is it

The service was really nice, we had family gathering there last two nights ago. It was really family environment but the the parking space was not so big and i park just near to the entry door. The place was really cool and nice to stay for a night. At the night some drunker in the hotel was irritating with loud music sounds that was just some problem which occurs in sometimes i think. But the place to live is very awesome and traditional without that drunker.

Landing in Nepal year ago had me disappointed time and again considering the quality of meat available in the country. At local terms meat is an animal randomly hacked to death, probably even abused before going for the jugular and then just piled the flesh in a heap to cut as per weight, so requesting for a shank or a tenderloin or asking its a veal buff or anything else would be klingon.  Then steps in Grill me, this was a complete set up by the co-owner Anudaan to have me sucked into this place where I was invited for a meeting which discussion feels like a motion blur after gorging on the spread.  The chilly prawns were to die for, subtly spicy with the right amount of flavors and the quality was just perfect considering it was frozen before, the baby back ribs fried were a perfect snack again, never dripped any oil well flavored with chilli soy dip and the highlight was the collection of single malt's which were handpicked by the owners themselves deviating way ahead from the general speyside regulars.  Viola... time for dinner!!...  Apprehensive me only indulged on the commonest of all steaks 'the tenderloin with commonest of all sauces 'the pepper sauce as my previous experiences were like a one night stand in Bangkok were you ask for a doughnut and get served a sausage. lo and behold the meat arrives on the table i get my steaks medium rare with the juices dripping and pink in the centre. It was a sensation where you hear violins in the background as the knife cut through the meat... perfect to the core and so was the sauce... a match made in heaven... served with mashed potatoes and sauted veggies were like the page boy and the flower girl in the tow!!  Finishing the meal and kept me craving for the next visit... inquired about how could they get the meat so right... got to know it came from the Nina-Hager stable which supposedly master the art of meat cuts.  Nevertheless, I would strongly recommend the place to every steak fanatic in the Nepal to give it a peak.

Find it difficult to put my experience into words. Came back yesterday from Nepal where I did the Ghorepani Poon Hill trek with UPEVEREST. First words that come to mind are: amazing, humbling and memorable! Nepal is a gorgeous country with the sweetest people! If you are still…

column7: Everest Base Camp trek was a dream come true
column8: Completing the EBC and Gokyo Lakes trek with UpEverest was literally a dream come true. From first hour to last, I was looked after to ensure there was no hiccups in the trip. Our guide was incredible, from knowing the name of every single peak in the Everest region (and their…

There are many Japanese restaurants in Kathmandu and Patan. They all have to keep up pretty good standards. However, not being my favorite Japanese restaurant it is still pretty good. This one has been one of the longer lasting restaurants on Durbar Marg - I think it has been there more than 20 years. I like the old photos on the walls. They have a good menu and the food is tasty otherwise how could they be there for such a long time. Worth a visit if you crave Japanese food while walking along Durbar Marg.

Koto is well known among the urban Kathamandites. First of all there are two Koto on the same stretch of road, 50 feet apart. If one is closed try the other one. We had the onigiri bento box, tempura bento, tempura udon, salmon nigiri sushi,...More

I cannot remember the first time I visited Koto. It feels like it has been around forever! A true indication of both the quality and value of the fare. I visited after a long period abroad and it was like a time warp. Nothing had changed. The entrance is a narrow, half hidden corridor close close to Hotel Annapurna coffee shop. The same number and set up of tables, with large black and white photos of Kathmandu in bygone pre-car days on the walls. Finally the same menu! I had a vegetarian bento box and gomai-ae washed down with a green tea. Loved it and cannot recommend it enough.

I love the traditional Japanese food and it might come as a surprise that there are several Japanese restaurants in Kathmandu. Koto is clearly my favourite. It is not even very expensive and serve a good selection of sushi amongst many other things. It is also in a good location close to Thamel and the royal palace.  The ambience is nice in a strict way and you can sit overlooking a busy street without being disturbed by the noise.

when you need real rice this is place. if you stayed at hotel yak and yeti, this place is near. they have 2 times of open, they not open everyday. they open 2 times. best rice, best sushi. best food. best service. the location is second floor.

column7: Truly authentic Japanese restaurant in Kathmandu, Nepal.
column8: There are two Koto Restaurants on Durbar Margh (Kings Way) in Kathmandu and on the same block. It is the most authentic restaurant serving truly traditional Japanese food starting from Karashi ae, Goma ae, Sashimi, Sushi, Tonkatsu set, Sukiyaki set, Ten Zaru Soba to Nabeyaki Soba. The restaurnat is absolutely clean, meals are awesome, ambience is true Japanese with a touch of Nepal. Its best to have a prior reservation instead of turning up for a table. The 3 tables next to the window are my favorite spots. For larger groups they also have traditional Japanese style seating (Tatami) and the bar has good selection of drinks including Sake.
Genuine Japanese cuisine in Kathmandu Nepal, Excellent location and excellent meal... Had fun with friends... Teriyaki Chicken was good.

column7: nice place for healthy lunch and shopping nearby
column8: Koto's Restaurant is near the Hotel Annapurnur. If you are on same side of street as the hotel, walk half a block in direction of the old palace and it's upstairs above the shops on street level. There is a sign - just walk with you neck crooked, looking upwards! We have had the avocado sushi, and vegetable sushi, and udon noodles with tofu. All delicious and - as far as I can tell - authentic. Prices are reasonable - about $16-18 for lunch for two with a soft drink and tip. Service good and while the food took a while to arrive, it came very hot and I am sure freshly prepared. Ambience/decor - basic. This is the only reason I downgraded the review from 5 star to 4 star. This is easy walking distance from Thamel with its myriad shopping streets.

column7: Everest Base Camp, Chitwan, Pokhara, Kathmandu and Trekking Guide Team Adventure = perfect adventure of a lifetime. (Ask for gu
column8: We recently returned to the US from the trip of a lifetime in Nepal, organized by Trekking Guide Team Adventure. We started with the Everest Base Camp trek, traveled to Chitwan, then spent a few days in Pokhara. Kabi, the owner and organizer, couldn't have been more professional. He always listened to our wants and needs and always made them happen. He was extremely flexible even when we wanted to change details of our trip on the spot. For example, when going to Chitwan we originally were going to take a tourist bus. We decided we'd rather go by private car(i highly recommend) Kabi arranged us a car and a driver for the entire journey. I can't say enough great things about Kabis professionalism, flexibility, and genuine desire to make our adventure perfect. He succeeded!! Our guide for EBC was Shambu Basnet. This man was one of the main reasons our trip was so enjoyable and successful. He took on several roles on top of being our guide. He arranged for excellent lodging along the trek, made sure our food was wonderful, checked our vitals at high altitude, if we were struggling he was right there to help. He was extremely well knowledgeable and informative regarding the trek, the mountains, the wildlife, and the people and different cultures of Nepal. If you need a guide, you can't do any better than Shambu. I'd trust my life to him any day. He made sure our safety was a number one concern. We were so impressed by Shambu we asked him to join us as our guide after the trek to Chitwan and Pokhara. He graciously accepted and obliged and we are glad he did. Not one part of this trip would have been as enjoyable or educational without Shambu. He too was flexible, if we needed anything...Shambu always went above and beyond to make it happen! We may have started as client and guide but now, thankfully we leave friends forever!!! If you're looking for a trekking or travel agency to help with your trip to Nepal, look no further than Kabi and Trekking Guide Team Adventure. They have a myriad of treks, excursions, and experiences for you to choose from. You won't be disappointed. Kabi, Shambu, and all of the staff at Trekking Guide Team Adventure take customer service to another level. If you're in need of a guide, request Shambu Basnet. Again, you won't be disappointed.

column7: Go Now! Do not wait to experience this!
column8: Wow!! What an experience! We had the time of our lives during this trip. Trekking team adventure took care of all the necessary permits, booking, guide, porter and so much more! Once we landed in Kathmandu we were completely comfortable with the care this teams staff treated us. Their priority was our health, safety and happiness and it was obvious. Everyone is an absolute joy to be around, very friendly good natured people that treated us like family if not better. We managed to complete the full itinerary for our trip without issue as well as tweak some things we wanted to do(such as staying an extra day in a place we really liked) without any issue. We truly fell in love with Nepal and are already planning our next trip and we without a doubt choose Trekking team adventure! Thank you so much for everything!

Australian who went with Trekking Guide Team Adventure in December 2019. Kabi was very professional to deal with when booking and when in Nepal as well.  Hotel was much better than expected and was better than many previous hotels I have stayed in.  Krishna was our guide and he was amazing. If it wasn't for him me and my friend would have never gotten to the base camp. He made us feel like family rather than a client. Our porter was also great too.  Would highly recommend as they were a trustworthy and professional company.

This trip was amazing, highly recommended. I can't speak more highly of our guide Shambu. From the moment we met him at our hotel in Kathmandu, he made sure all our needs were catered for on the trip, adjusting to suit the group requirements.
